title: FreeMarkets Agrees to Buy Auction Unit of Covisint
description: FreeMarkets, which makes Internet-auction software, is buying the auto parts auction business of Covisint, a venture of General Motors, Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Assembly Fails To Meet Court-Mandated Deadline
description: Both houses of the General Assembly recessed until Monday, missing a midnight deadline imposed by the State Supreme Court to enact a strategy for reforming the Arkansas public school system. The court, in 2002, declared the state's schools unconstitutionally inadequate and underfinanced and its formula for distributing aid to local districts inequitable. Unable to reach agreement before the weekend, the Legislature agreed to a last-minute supplemental education appropriation. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Clark Courts Veterans in Swing Through South
description: Winding up several days of campaigning in the South at a V.F.W. post here, Gen. Wesley K. Clark promised on Wednesday to add $2 billion to the budget for health care services for the nation's veterans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PAONE, NICOLA
description: PAONE--Nicola. On December 25, 2003 at age 88. Entertainer and restauranteur. Beloved husband of Dalia. Loving father of the late Joseph P. Paone. Cherished grandfather of Nick J. Paone and Elizabeth D. Fuller and her husband Kevin and greatgrandfather of Emma. Dear brother of Antonia Antonazzo, Nicolina Imperiele and Nina Licata. Friends may call at Frank E. title: The Time We Thought We Knew
description: It was an unlikely place to be at 4:30 a.m., since I'm not much on celebrations and take minimal notice of most every holiday. Yet, a few years back, on a rainy Dec. 31 morning, I stood in Times Square, together with a handful of other early revelers, awaiting images on a giant screen of festivities on Kiribati, the first inhabited place on earth to welcome the new year. I was, as I recognized through the fog of exhaustion and the hazy steam billowing from manhole covers, re-enacting a struggle I'd been engaged in for decades.

description: As the Giants interview prospective head coaches, they find themselves jumping between offensive and defensive specialists. Today alone, they will interview one of each: the New England Patriots' defensive coordinator, Romeo Crennel, and offensive coordinator, Charlie Weis.

title: An Odd Sight in Iran as Aid Team Tents Go Up: The U.S. Flag
description: For the past 24 years, the Stars and Stripes was unfurled publicly in Iran only to be burned, so Iranians were astonished on Wednesday by its sudden unveiling in an official capacity -- not fluttering in the frigid winter wind, exactly, but glued to the peaked roofs of the three tents housing the American earthquake relief team.

title: Art Meets Artichoke
description: JEAN-CLAUDE NEDELEC, an owner of Glorious Food catering, entered in toque and trench coat and marveled at the transformation of the Upper East Side kitchen of Agnes Gund and Daniel Shapiro. Gone were the linoleum counters, the corner stove and the 20-year-old cabinets encrusted with greeting cards and children's drawings. In their place stood a gleaming island of stainless steel with mahogany paneling, a four-burner stove by La Cornue and a sleekly hovering exhaust funnel. ''I've been everywhere, up and down Park Avenue,'' Mr. Nedelec said, ''but this is really something.'' And he set to work filling Parmesan cups with wild mushroom risotto for 100.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about contracts held by Halliburton, the oil giant, for the reconstruction of Iraq's oil industry misstated the rise in one cost estimate. Halliburton's initial estimate for the repair of the Qarmat Ali water treatment plant in southern Iraq was $75.7 million; six weeks later, the Bush administration asked Congress for $125 million for the work, an increase of about 65 percent, not 40 percent.

title: Iranians Appear to Warm to Easing Tensions With U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 — Iranian officials appeared today to warm to the possibility that an easing of American restrictions on aid to Iran, granted after the devastating earthquake in the city of Bam, could bring an improvement to the two countries' long-frigid relationship.

title: So You Want to Be a Star? Help for Your Audition Tape
description: If your sights are set on ''American Idol,'' there may still be hope, even if you're no Kelly Clarkson. With the Official American Idol Audition Kit, you can mix in a little reverb and add some backup vocals to cover those tricky octave jumps. The $30 kit, available at www.auditionkit.com, Target and Best Buy, is made by Fremantle Media. It includes software, a disc with 10 songs (including ''Man! I Feel Like a Woman'' by Shania Twain and ''Rock Your Body'' by Justin Timberlake) and a membership in auditionkit.com.

title: Blocks; Capturing the Spirit of 1776, but With a Different Number
description: ONE day, a glistening skyscraper will rise over the World Trade Center site, commemorating in its very structure, through the unforgettable dimension of its towering height, the milestone year in which the king lost power.

title: Man Behind Sept. 11 Fund Describes Effort as a Success, With Reservations
description: Kenneth R. Feinberg looks more fatigued than he did two years ago, when he agreed to work free as the administrator of the federal program to compensate the eligible relatives of Sept. 11 victims. The job, he now says, was ''by far the most difficult assignment'' of his legal career.

title: CONGOLEUM FILES BANKRUPTCY PLAN WITH ASBESTOS LIABILITY
description: The Congoleum Corporation, a flooring maker facing asbestos-related lawsuits, filed for bankruptcy protection with a plan in place to resolve the disputes, pay creditors and reorganize. Congoleum has reached settlements with a majority of the asbestos claimants suing it, court papers show. With the negotiations completed, Congoleum filed a so-called pre-packaged bankruptcy in Trenton. Congoleum, which is based in Mercerville, N.J., listed $187.1 million in assets and $205.9 million in debts in the filing.

title: For the Ex-Buccaneer, A Pillage-Free Playlist
description: IT was time for the Schwartzes to go legit. No more pirated music for us.

title: BANKRUPTCY JUDGE REJECTS EXIDE'S REORGANIZATION PLAN
description: A bankruptcy judge refused to approve a reorganization plan for Exide Technologies Inc., the world's biggest maker of car batteries, agreeing with creditors that it had undervalued assets. The judge, Kevin Carey of United States District Court in Philadelphia, said in a written ruling on Tuesday that the value should be $1.4 billion to $1.6 billion. The company had valued itself at $950 million to $1.05 billion. Exide's creditors committee had argued that the valuation should be $1.5 billion to $1.7 billion. The ruling delays the company's exit from bankruptcy. During court hearings in the fall, Exide's lawyers said the company needed to exit bankruptcy soon or the value of the company would decline. Exide had sought bankruptcy protection in April 2002 after accumulating more than $2.5 billion in debt, much of it from acquisitions. Exide is based in Princeton, N.J.

title: A Wary Eye On Sites For Music Sharing
description: The last year has seen an explosion of pay music-downloading services. Some have been successes, like Apple's iTunes Music Store, with 1.5 million downloads a week. Others, like BuyMusic, are plagued by complaints from users. But there is another site that has iTunes Music Store and BuyMusic beat: Easy Music Download, which has a greater profit margin than iTunes Music Store and probably a greater percentage of dissatisfied users than BuyMusic.

title: Year's Big Rally Helps Investors Regain Ground
description: Stocks broke their three-year slide with robust gains last year. But the market still has a way to go to return to the heights reached during the bubble that burst in 2000.

title: Washington Memo; Election? Mad Cow? Who Cares? The 'Skins Need a New Coach
description: The ignominious departure of the Redskins' head coach, Steve Spurrier, is the story of the day in Washington, which is not only the capital of the world's sole superpower but also home to one of the storied franchises in pro football.

description: DEIN--Gittie. My sis, loved and remembered always.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: 6 Men Indicted In Cross Burning
description: A federal grand jury has indicted six men from Trenton, Ga., on two civil rights charges each for burning a cross at the home of a white woman who was seeing a biracial man. The men, ages 25 to 41, made a wooden cross, covered it with cloth and transmission fluid and tried to light it, according to the United States attorney's office. Three returned later that day and saw the cross had not caught fire; they were able to light it, the office said. The men are accused of conspiring to injure, oppress, threaten and intimidate the victims. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: A Small Company, a Global Approach
description: Gayle Warwick Fine Linen is a multinational player. Its high-end, handmade bed and table linens are woven in Europe, embroidered in Vietnam and sold in Britain and the United States. Sales are soaring, and its full-time staff recently doubled -- to two: Gayle Warwick and the assistant she hired in March.

title: Corrections

The company raised its profit estimate in September for the fourth quarter of 2003 and lowered its forecast in December for the first quarter of 2004 and the full year. The projections did not apply to the same period.

title: Reimagining the Sofabed, And a Table Bed Is Born
description: It's a conventional-looking coffee table; but then you flip the top and it becomes a spare bed. The Coffee Table bed, which comes in oak, maple, cherry or walnut, is by Julia West, an interior designer in Toronto known for her custom furniture and linens. The coffee table is 42 inches square or a 34-by-41-inch rectangle, and the open bed remains 42 inches, by 72 inches long, larger than a twin but smaller than a full. (Custom sheets are available from the Julia West collection.)

title: Economic Scene; What separates rich nations from poor nations? History can provide some answers.
description: THOSE who do not learn from history are doomed to repeat it. To that old saw, an economist might reply, ''If only it were so easy.'' Then every country could be rich.

description: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist criticized Congress in unusually pointed terms on Wednesday for a recent law that places federal judges under special scrutiny for sentences that fall short of those called for by the federal sentencing guidelines.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Economic Growth Surges
description: India's economy grew at its fastest pace in more than six years in the July to September quarter, helped by tax cuts and above-average rains, putting it on course for growth of more than 7 percent in the current fiscal year. The economy expanded 8.4 percent from a year earlier, accelerating from 5.7 percent growth in the three months to June 30, the government said.

title: FLIGHT SENT BACK ON TERROR FEAR, U.S. OFFICIALS SAY
description: The American authorities in the last week directed a United States-bound flight from Mexico to turn around in midair and imposed extraordinary security measures on at least six other incoming flights because of terrorist concerns, federal officials said Wednesday.

title: ABN AMRO AGREES TO SELL UNIT TO MERRILL LYNCH
description: The Dutch bank ABN Amro Holdings said yesterday that it had reached a preliminary agreement to sell its trade execution and clearing services business in the United States to Merrill Lynch for an undisclosed sum. ABN said the companies hoped to close the deal in the second quarter. The professional brokerage business provides securities trading, clearing and other back-office services for the options and securities markets. A Merrill Lynch spokesman confirmed that a preliminary agreement had been reached.

description: He may not be the most popular man in the land, but when it comes to mathematics, President Leonid D. Kuchma of Ukraine comes out quite well.

title: RAYOVAC TO CLOSE REMINGTON RAZOR SERVICE STORES
description: The Rayovac Corporation, the battery maker, will close the last 65 service stores belonging to its recently acquired Remington Products Company razor business and cut as many as 120 jobs. The closings, expected to be completed by the end of February, were part of Remington's decision three years ago to wind down its chain of about 100 service centers, a Rayovac spokesman, John Daggett, said. Rayovac, which is based in Madison, Wis., decided to speed up the closings and will incur severance costs, he said, without specifying the amount. Rayovac agreed in August to buy Remington for about $322 million to enter the more-profitable razor business amid slowing battery sales.

title: Sun Screen in a Back Alley
description: LORCAN O'HERLIHY, an Irish-born architect living in Los Angeles, is accustomed to designing homes that command glamorous hillsides and ocean views. His first house, on nine acres in Malibu, Calif., was built in 1990 for his parents. (His father is the actor Dan O'Herlihy.) Since then, he has designed a number of oceanfront homes and hilltop eyries and has renovated a 1955 Richard Neutra house for Gary Levinsohn, a producer of ''The Patriot'' and ''Saving Private Ryan.'' In every case, he had incomparable California scenery working in his favor.

title: No 'Auld Lang Syne' for Jailed Russian Oilman

title: Historic Savannah Takes to Herms

title: Empties, Wilted Flowers: The Cleanup Begins

And those ornaments are waiting to be organized and put away. Fortunately there are storage bins and trash cans to fit many spaces. Narrow oval cans slide into tight spots. A handy cart helps when it is time to haul stacks and bags of recyclables to the curb. And there's a special storage box for strings of lights and artificial garlands.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Fatal Fire Was Deliberately Set
description: A fire that killed a mother and her grown daughter on Tuesday night in Unionport was deliberately set, police and fire officials said yesterday. The determination brought the number of homicides for the year up to 595 by 6:30 a.m. yesterday, the police said. (The number was 594 before the arson finding, but one earlier death has been reclassified as an accident, the police said.) On Tuesday, investigators questioned and released a teenage boy in connection with the Bronx fire, and now have no one in custody, the police said. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Jobless Rate Declines
description: Unemployment in France unexpectedly declined for a second month in November, a sign that prospects for faster growth may be encouraging companies to take on additional workers. The number of job seekers fell by 7,000, to 2.62 million, according to International Labor Organization calculations, said Insee, the national statistics office, which is based in Paris. That cut the unemployment rate to 9.6 percent from 9.7 percent, which had been the highest point in more than three years. Insee predicts that the French economy may expand 2 percent next year, its fastest rate since 2001. ''All the indicators are pointing to a recovery,'' including a pickup in investment and spending, said Jean-Franois Cope, a government spokesman, in an interview on radio station Europe 1, which is based in Paris.

title: Between the Years
description: New Year's Day is the pause between the past and the future -- after the grand retrospectives of Hanukkah and Christmas but before the resolutions and predictions kick in. This is one of the few moments in the year when we are almost forced to contemplate the strange propulsion of time that carries us along through life. You can choose your own metaphor. Do the years feel like combers rolling onto the beach, one after the other? Do you feel as if you're swimming downstream with the current of a mighty river? Or does this winter-shift from one year to the next feel like a portage through dark woods between two lakes?

title: COMCAST SEEKS TO SELL STAKE IN CABLE UNIT
description: The Comcast Corporation, the cable television operator, exercised an option that would allow the company to sell its stake in Time Warner Inc.'s cable business in an initial public offering. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TULLY, MARY JEAN
description: TULLY--Mary Jean, 78, a pioneer of the feminist movement, died of a heart attack December 27, 2003. She is survived by her five children: Bruce Tully of Manhattan, Linsey Tully of Manhattan, Laura Tully of Lexington, MA, Scott Tully of Pleasantville, NY and Andrew Tully of San Francisco, CA; six grandchildren: Kelly Anne Tully, Simon Schneider and Tristan, Taylor, Troy and Ashlynn Tully; her former husband, C. Robert Tully; her sister, Carolyn Griffin; and daughters-inlaw, Sandi Tully, Dorothy Tully, and Beth Mooney and sonin-law Rob Schneider. Predeceased by son-in-law Malcolm Birnbaum. Mary Jean became a leader in the women's movement in 1970 and served as president of both NOW Legal Defense and Education Fund and the Fund for Women's Rights, an organization founded with Betty Friedan to work for the Equal Rights Amendment. Mary Jean conceived of and founded the Midlife Institute at Marymount Manhattan College and the Tully Crenshaw Feminist Oral History Project at the Schlesinger Library at Radcliffe College. Mary Jean was a founding member (and co-chair) of the National Committee for Responsive Philanthropy, a founding member of the New York State National Women's Political Caucus and a founding member of the Westchester Chapter of NOW. Mary Jean was a dynamic and inspiring presence within her family and among her many friends. She was deeply loved and will be sorely missed. Services will be private. A celebration of Mary Jean's life will be held in New York City in early 2004. Donations in her name may be made to NOW Legal Defense and Education Fund, Veteran Feminists of America, Alvin Ailey dance company, or any organization dedicated to the defeat of George W. Bush.

El Paso, which is based in Houston, will also get back $45 million in capital from the plant, which produces 117 million gallons of lubricants and automotive performance products annually. El Paso sold its 50 percent interest in a Philippine fuel sales and marketing venture, as well as rights to a terminal and pipeline, for $35 million. The sale will result in the release of a $42 million guarantee. The sales are part of El Paso's plans to reduce debt to about $15 billion from $24 billion.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Boy's Abuse Had Been Reported
description: The state Department of Children and Families said yesterday that it had received an emergency phone line report of neglect about the father of a boy whose body was discovered on Sunday stuffed into a suitcase in Watertown. A hospital employee phoned the agency in May 1998 to report that the father, Allen Lamont James, did not get his then 6-week-old son, Alquan White, proper care before bringing him to the hospital for mild pneumonia, according to an agency statement. On Tuesday, a spokesman for the department said no reports of abuse or neglect were associated with Alquan White at the time when Rhode Island child welfare authorities, investigating a matter related to Alquan's out-of-state siblings, asked their Connecticut counterpart to determine his whereabouts in 2001. A Connecticut social worker never saw the boy and relied on a report from Mr. James's lawyer that the child was fine. The state medical examiner determined this week that Alquan died from blunt trauma. Mr. James, 38, was charged with capital felony murder in his son's death and is being held in $1.25 million bond. The state child welfare agency is being monitored by Federal District Court for failing to adhere to improvements mandated by a 1991 court settlement. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

The judge, Steven Taylor, also denied motions by Mr. Nichols's lawyers to move the trial from McAlester, about 130 miles southeast of Oklahoma City, where it had been moved to avoid publicity problems. Mr. Nichols was convicted in federal court of assisting Timothy J. McVeigh in assembling the bomb, which killed 168 people, and is serving a life sentence. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: 36 Hours | Ottawa
description: ARMS swinging rhythmically, briefcase in tow, a skater glides to work over the frozen surface of the 170-year-old canal that winds nearly five miles through the heart of the city. Parents push bundled-up babies across the ice in sleighs; and French- and English- speaking vendors sell hot chocolate at warming huts and fire pits. This is the winter scene in Ottawa, Canada's capital, an uncommonly civilized city of about 800,000. Frequent blizzards give way to crisp, sunny skies, the neo-Gothic Parliament Buildings rise majestically on a limestone escarpment above the Ottawa River, and the rolling Gatineau Hills crease the northwest skyline. Ottawa has undergone a transformation in recent years, caused in part by an influx of high-tech companies: there are still 39 museums, scarlet-clad Mounties and about 120 foreign embassies, but the city now boasts the highest percentage of Internet-connected households in Canada and enough good restaurants to satisfy the most demanding foodie. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MURRAY, A. BREAN
description: MURRAY--A. Brean, 66, of heart failure on December 25, 2003. Resident of New York City, Cornwall-on-Hudson, NY and Sun Valley, ID. He is survived by his wife of 23 years, Bettina Patterson Murray, sons Christopher and Stephen Murray of Portland, OR, stepdaughter Renee Sands Tobin of New York City and stepgranddaughter Rory Patterson Tobin. Brother of Sean, Noel, Kevin and Grant Cunningham and Lee Cunningham Lisman (who predeceased him). Born in Dublin, Ireland, he emigrated to the United States in 1950 and became a citizen in 1952. He served in the US Army from 1954-1957 as a member of the 82nd Airborne Division and was also assigned to the US Military Academy at West Point. In 1961, he received his BS in Economics from Villanova University, PA. His business career started at IBM and continued with Cogan, Berlind, Weill & Levitt, where he became a partner in 1965. In 1973, he founded Brean Murray & Co., a privately held investment firm. His association with other companies included founding and serving on the board of Shared Medical Systems and as a director of Concept, Inc. At the time of his death he was serving as a director of both Specialty Toner Corp. and Somanetics Corp. He served as an Official of the American Stock Exchange, and in 1985 was elected to the Board of the Tax Council. He was a director of Doral Financial Corp., a firm based in Puerto Rico, for approximately nine years. For the past two years, Brean Murrany & Co. has sponsored the Investment Opportunities in the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico conferences. On October 30, 2003, the conference was held at the New York Stock Exchange and Brean rang the closing bell that day to celebrate the conclusion of the conference. He was a member of the Board of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice Foundation, CUNY. He was instrumental in the establishment of the McCabe Fellowship, a scholarship exchange program between police professionals from John Jay College and the An Garda Siochana, the national police force in Ireland. In 1988, Brean and his wife, Bettina, created a scholarship fund to enable financially underprivileged students to attend Columbia University's Summer Program for High School Students. This program is designed for highly motivated students to experience college-level study, and over the past sixteen years the scholarship fund has supported over 400 students. A private funeral service and burial will be held in Cornwall-on-Hudson. A memorial service will be held in New York on January 12th at 4:30PM at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th St. and 5th Ave, followed by a reception at The Union Club, 109 East 69 St. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made to The John Jay College Foundation, for the Brean Murray Scholarship Fund, President's Office/ P. Maull, 899 10th Ave, New York, NY 10019 or to The Scholarship Fund, Columbia University's Summer Program for High School Students, Attn: Paul McNeil, 303 Lewisohn Hall, Columbia University, New York, NY 10027.

title: Books as Art Objects (Reading Is Optional)
description: ''Ninety From the Nineties: A Decade of Printing'' is an exhibition built around a conundrum that lies at the center of most surveys of the book as object. The tension centers on purpose: books, which we are accustomed to thinking of as containers -- and conveyers -- of information, are placed in a context in which form is valued over content. Language is less important than the type that impresses it on the page. The paper counts for more than the story told on it. The illustrations and the binding might be the story. Words? Who needs 'em?

The new chip will enable home offices and small businesses to connect their computers to networks and the Internet 10 times to 20 times faster, a spokeswoman for Agere said.

description: Legg Mason, the Baltimore-based money management and brokerage firm, said yesterday that it had bought the Singapore business of Rothschild Asset Management. Terms were not announced, though the price was less than $10 million, a spokeswoman said. Legg Mason will merge the unit, which employs 30 people and oversees about $1 billion, into its Asian money management subsidiary. Legg Mason, which has about $237 billion under management worldwide, has been operating in Singapore since 2000 through Western Asset Management and Batterymarch Financial Management. It said the acquisition might help it tap growth in China.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YAHR, DR. MELVIN D.
description: YAHR--Dr. Melvin D. Dr. C. Warren Olanow and the Department of Neurology of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine mourn the passing of our distinguished friend and colleague, Dr. Melvin D. Yahr. Dr. Yahr graduated from the NYU College of Medicine in 1943. After completing a residency in Neurology at Montefiore, he joined The Neurologic Institute at Presbyterian Hospital and Columbia University's College of Physicians & Surgeons. Dr. Yahr became the Chairman of Neurology at Mount Sinai in 1974, a position he held until 1991. Thereafter Dr. Yahr held the title of Chairman Emeritus and was the Aidekman Family Professor of Neurologic Research, remaining active in the Department until the time of his death. Dr. Yahr's major research contributions have been in the area of Parkinson's disease, where he was internationally renowned. He played a pioneering role in the development of L-dopa which still remains the major treatment for Parkinson's disease. Over his career he has received many honors including the Jacobi Medallion presented by the Mount Sinai alumni in 1987. He served as President of the American Neurological Association and the American Board of Psychiatry and Neurology and was Chairman of World Federation of Neurology Research Committee on Extrapyramidal Disorders. In 1995, an annual Melvin D. Yahr Symposium was established as an enduring symbol of appreciation for his many contributions. He was a colleague, teacher and friend, and he will be deeply missed. We extend deepest condolences to his family.

title: MURPHY OIL SAYS IT EXPECTS QUARTERLY PROFIT TO DECLINE
description: Murphy Oil, which produces oil and makes and sells fuels, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit probably fell because of a loss from refining and costs from unsuccessful drilling ventures. Profit excluding items will decline to 55 cents to 60 cents a share from 67 cents a year earlier, said Mindy West, a company spokeswoman. Global refining will have a loss of about $10 million in the quarter after a Meraux, La., plant closed because of a fire, and margins eroded, the company said. Expenses for unsuccessful drilling ventures will be $19 million to $22 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had expected the company, based in Eldorado, Ark., to earn 67 cents a share in the quarter. Murphy's net income in the fourth quarter of 2002 was $57.6 million, or 62 cents a share. The company did not provide an estimate for net income this quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KENNEDY, PATRICIA RAFFERTY
description: KENNEDY--Patricia Rafferty, died peacefully on New Year's Eve after a valiant struggle with cancer. A social fixture in Manhattan, Palm Beach and the Hamptons, Patti was a devoted mother who ran two successful businesses and touched countless people with her warmth, grace and style. Born in New York City, she graduated from Marymount College, Arlington, VA. and later founded ''The Friday Evenings'' at the Stork Club. In 1976 she opened Park Bench I, a boutique for teenagers on Madison Avenue. After moving to Palm Beach in 1987, she created the Palm Beach Tavern. Her many charitable activities ranged from Kips Bay in New York to the American Ireland Fund and Boys and Girls Club in Palm Beach. She was a joy to all who knew her, adored by her family and cherished by her legion of friends. She is survived by her daughters, Michaela Kennedy-Dentzer and Julie O'Neill, their husbands, William Dentzer and Craig O'Neill, three grandchildren, Carlin, Blake and Bailey O'Neill, her brothers, Jack and Larry Rafferty and their wives, Aileen and Barbara, her niece Kathleen and nephews Tommy and Michael Rafferty. A third nephew, John Rafferty, preceded her in death last summer. Patti's family will receive her friends at Quattlebaum's Funeral Home in West Palm Beach on Friday, January 2, from 58PM. A mass of Christian burial will be held on Saturday, January 3, at 9:30AM, at St. Edward's R.C. Church in Palm Beach. Interment will be on Long Island. Contributions in her memory may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, Crippled Children's Society or The March of Dimes.

title: Editorial Observer; The Battle Against Junk Mail and Spyware on the Web
description: Americans are smitten by the idea that new technologies will revolutionize life as we know it and greatly expand human potential. This was true of the inventor Thomas Edison, who predicted in the 1920's that the motion picture camera would transform public schooling and might even replace textbooks. An early broadcasting executive, Margaret Cuthbert, made a similar leap when she envisioned radio as ''a great national headquarters for women,'' which would elevate housewives everywhere through high-minded programming like lectures and university courses. Instead of edifying housewives, however, radio gave them long-running melodramas that were dubbed soap operas because they entertained while selling laundry detergent.

title: As the Race Turns Hot, What About Dean's Collar?

When a local news crew tried to muscle its way into the interview, its cameraman banged into someone in the network crew.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Vodafone Stake Sold

The Spanish builder sold about 285 million Vodafone shares, Acciona said in a regulatory filing. The company, which is based in Madrid, did not give details on how the sale took place. Acciona left telecommunications to expand in areas such as toll-road concessions, maintenance and garbage collection.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Steel Maker's Profit Rises
description: The South Korean steel maker Posco said its fourth-quarter net income rose 4.7 percent to 382 billion won ($319 million) as it increased prices amid surging demand from automakers and construction companies. Sales gained 21 percent to 3.87 trillion won in the three months ended Dec. 31. Fourth-quarter figures were calculated from full-year estimates announced by the chairman, Lee Ku Taek, in a New Year speech to employees in Seoul. Posco and other Korean steel makers raised prices to reflect higher raw material costs and surging demand at home and in China, the world's fastest-growing market for the metal. ''We will strongly push our China business this year for the future of Posco and the development of China's steel industry,'' Mr. Lee said in a statement.

title: ANNALY MORTGAGE SAYS IT IS ACQUIRING INVESTMENT ADVISER
description: Annaly Mortgage Management, a real estate investment trust, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy an investment adviser, Fixed Income Discount Advisory, for about $40.5 million in stock. An additional $49.5 million in shares may be paid based on Fixed Income's revenue and pretax profit margins over the next three years, Annaly said. Investment Income, a fee-based asset-management business that managed or helped manage $13.1 billion as of Sept. 30, will be operated as a wholly owned subsidiary. Annaly, based in New York, said the acquisition would add to earnings per share, though it did not say when.

title: Indonesia's Secret War
description: The guerrilla war in the Indonesian province of Aceh has raged on and off for more than 25 years, but it has now gone underground. In May, the government broke off peace talks, declared martial law and sent in 40,000 troops. Since then, Aceh has been virtually sealed off. Foreign journalists, human rights groups and diplomats cannot enter. For months, the government even barred groups like Unicef and the World Food Program, which provide relief to besieged civilians. Indonesian journalists can travel in Aceh, but intimidation from the military and political pressures have kept them from reporting more than official pronouncements. Local human rights groups, harassed by soldiers, have gone into hiding.

American officials cannot keep pretending that 8 million to 10 million illegal immigrants do not exist.

The health operations are being sold to MultiPlan Inc., a closely held health care network, BCE Emergis said. BCE Emergis will have a fourth-quarter expense of 77 million Canadian dollars ($59.7 million) to reduce the value of the health unit to the sale price. Some of the proceeds may be used to buy back shares or pay a special dividend, BCE Emergis said. MultiPlan runs a health care network in all 50 states. With the purchase of BCE Emergis's health operations, MultiPlan customers will have access to 4,400 hospitals, 400,000 doctors and 70,000 other facilities, the company said.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Inventor of the Wraparound
description: A Parisian court of appeals ruled in 1934 that a woman's hat was a work of art worthy of copyright protection. In the lavishly illustrated SHOCKING! The Art and Fashion of Elsa Schiaparelli (Philadelphia Museum of Art/ Yale University, $65), Dilys E. Blum, the curator of costume and textiles at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, persuasively argues that Schiaparelli was an artist no less than a designer -- and not only because of her collaborations with Dal, Cocteau and Man Ray. Her Spanish rival, Balenciaga, considered Schiaparelli ''the only real artist in the couture.'' From the presentation of her first collection in 1927 to the closing of her salon in 1954, the Italian-born designer ''was quick to adapt to new trends and seemingly fearless when it came to trying new things.'' The perpetually innovative Schiaparelli introduced a multitude of items now taken for granted in fashion. She invented the wraparound dress, designed fashion eyewear, created the first designer boutique and made fashionable the use of synthetic fabrics, like rayon. By 1932, she had 400 employees producing 7,000 to 8,000 garments a year in eight different ateliers. But World War II would prove devastating to her empire: in October 1940, Schiaparelli was compelled to reduce her workforce to 150. Along with Blum's informative chapters, the captions for several hundred illustrations include interesting tidbits of their own; for example, that in lieu of journeying to Paris for her fittings, Mae West sent a plaster cast of her figure. David Kaufman

Christmas and New Year's coming midweek meant you had to party twice as long, eat and drink twice as much, yak yourself hoarse, smile yourself into a rictus. Enough already! title: Plugging Nuclear Leaks
description: Now that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has opened Libya's previously secret nuclear facilities, the world is learning just how much of the machinery for making bomb fuel he had been able to assemble without international detection. Over a period of many years, Libya tapped into an international underground market for specialized steel tubes and uranium enrichment centrifuges that has been scandalously easy to gain entry to and shockingly difficult to close down. Even the newly strengthened provisions of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty cannot guarantee that other countries will not attempt similar end runs. And they may not follow Libya's lead and abruptly come clean before they begin producing nuclear bombs.

The film's greatest asset, however, is Daniel Day-Lewis's incredibly credible performance as Bill the Butcher, a gang leader in a top hat. Leonardo DiCaprio plays a young man out to avenge the death of his father, who was murdered by Bill 16 years ago. Thanks to the Civil War draft riots, the film also throws in enough fires, explosions, gunfire and blood to keep action-movie fans amused -- Saturday at 9 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 3:05 a.m. on Starz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEWITT, DONALD

Born in New York City on February 8, 1928, Don graduated from MIT in 1947. He moved with his family to Beverly Hills in 1954, where he was a distinguished and longtime City commissioner and community leader, a founding member of Stephen S. Wise Temple and of the Skirball Cultural Center. His business, DeWitt Tool & Equipment Co. was a model of integrity and decency to employees and customers. Don's gentle wit and kindness will be dearly missed by his family and legion of friends. title: From Iran to California to 'House of Sand and Fog'

Like Nadi, Ms. Aghdashloo, 51, fled Iran during the revolution and ended up in California. Yet while Nadi is more seen than heard in the movie -- bowing her head in deference to her husband, scuttling out of the room -- Ms. Aghdashloo is an outspoken feminist and political commentator, who for 10 years was host of an opinion show on the Los Angeles-based Iranian television station, Jaam-e-Jam. Although she has a long history in Iranian theater and film, ''House of Sand and Fog'' is her first major American feature. Last month she spoke with Nicole LaPorte, a film reporter for Variety, over coffee in Los Angeles, where Ms. Aghdashloo has lived since 1987.

title: Paralysis on Clean Air
description: Just before Christmas, a federal appeals court blocked a new Bush administration rule that would have weakened existing law governing pollution from power plants and other industrial facilities. Having opposed the rule as little more than a gift to the utilities at the expense of public health, this page had no quarrel with the decision. Even so, it served as a reminder that clean air policy is increasingly being made by administrative fiat and by the courts -- a ruling one day, a reversal the next. This is not productive. The public is deprived of cleaner air; industry is deprived of the regulatory certainty it needs to make wise investment decisions.

title: The City Life; Back of the Tracks
description: I watched ''North by Northwest'' again the other night, as I do at least once a year. One reason, among many, is the scene in which the 20th Century Limited makes its way up the tracks along the Hudson River, through the last rays of sunset, carrying Cary Grant and Eva Marie Saint away into the night. Somehow commuting is never like that. Not that there isn't beauty on the commuter lines running into New York City. On the line I take, the light sometimes turns the landscape into a place I've never seen before, even though I've seen it over and over and over. It's hard to describe just how familiar those fields and rivers and pastures feel to a commuter, except to say that their familiarity is contained in the act of sliding past in a railroad car. If the train stopped and we got out on the tracks between stations, all that familiarity would vanish in an instant.

title: The Joyless Recovery
description: THE stock market is surging and the economy appears to be booming, but Judith Pike is getting out of business. ''I'm finished; I'm out of here,'' said Mrs. Pike, owner of Acme Grinding, whose customers have been vanishing and whose work force has shrunk from 40 to 4. Two days before Christmas, Mrs. Pike sold her business and more than 40 machines used to grind and finish metal parts. ''It will be for pennies on the dollar,'' she said. ''Less than what it cost to buy just one of these machines.''

title: New Jersey Maintains Its Dvorak Obsession

During Zdenek Macal's tenure as music director, from 1993 to 2002, Dvorak was a staple, with results abundantly evident in a four-CD set of his works for chorus and orchestra to be issued this month by Delos International. The box adds a new release of the Te Deum and Psalm 149 (along with the concert overtures Opp. 91 to 93) to reissues of the Requiem, the Stabat Mater and other works.

title: Courtney Love, at Her Furious Best
description: COURTNEY LOVE -- There's a fine line between causing trouble and being in it, and over the last year the most dangerous woman in rock has seemed more like the most endangered. And yet her new single, ''Mono'' (available for download at www.courtneylove.com), is furious and passionate, overstuffed with ambivalent rallying cries and secondhand guitar riffs and incoherent snarls. In short, it's Courtney Love at her best. When she slips into the first-person plural (''We gotta smash it up/ You won't abandon us again''), it's not clear which troops she's commanding, but it's a thrill to hear her once more leading the charge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARRIS, CHAUNCY DENNISON
description: HARRIS--Chauncy Dennison. On December 26, 2003. The American Geographical Society celebrates the extraordinary life of Chauncy Harris and mourns his passing. In addition to his invaluable leadership in the larger comunity of geographical scholarship worldwide, Chauncy served as a Councilor of AGS from 1961-1974, and as Vice President from 1969-1974. He was a longtime member of the editorial board of AGS's ''Geographical Review,'' a key player in the founding of AGS's ''Soviet Geography,'' and co-editor of the latter for many years. In 1985 the Society awarded him The Cullum Geographical Medal for his service in the ''advancement of geographical science'' writ large. His particular loyalty to and support of AGS continued, however, up until his very last days. We will miss his sage advice and unstinting friendship. His was a life well lived, and the American Geographical Society was fortunate to be a significant part of it. John E. Gould, Chair Jerome E. Dobson, President Mary Lynne Bird, Executive Director

description: CHANDOR--E. Haring. 82, died December 22, 2003, in NYC. He was the son of the late Reginald M. and Mary Mulford Chandor. He was a direct descendant of Pieter Haring of Hoorn, North Holland, who arrived in Nieuw Amsterdam in 1638, aboard his family's ship, the Haring, and who built the pre-Revolutionary 200-acre ''Haring Farm'' in Greenwich Village where NYU now stands. He was also a direct descendant of Judge John Mulford of Maidstone, Kent, England, who was one of the nine founders of Maidstone, Long Island (later re-named East Hampton), where the family home has been preserved as ''The Mulford Farm and Museum;'' he was also the great-grandson of Count Laslo Fulop Chandor of Budapest, Hungary. He graduated cum laude from Princeton and became a Lieutenant (Navigator) in the U.S. Air Force. He was formerly a member of the Union Club, River Club, Princeton Club, St. Nicholas Society, Holland Lodge, Shinnecock Golf Club, Meadow Club, and Bathing Corp. of Southampton. He is survived by two daughters: Mrs. Cary Savant of Santa Barbara, CA, and Mrs. Allaire Stallsmith of Baltimore, MD, and six grandchildren. His only son, Peter Haring Chandor, died in 1995. Funeral services, Frank Campbell, Wednesday, January 7, 2 PM. Private burial at Woodlawn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MURRAY, A. BREAN
description: MURRAY--A. Brean, 66, of heart failure on December 25, 2003. Resident of New York City, Cornwall-on-Hudson, NY and Sun Valley, ID. He is survived by his wife of 23 years, Bettina Patterson Murray, sons Christopher and Stephen Murray of Portland, OR, stepdaughter Renee Sands Tobin of New York City and stepgranddaughter Rory Patterson Tobin. Brother of Sean, Noel, Kevin and Grant Cunningham and Lee Cunningham Lisman (who predeceased him). Born in Dublin, Ireland, he emigrated to the United States in 1950 and became a citizen in 1952. He served in the US Army from 1954-1957 as a member of the 82nd Airborne Division and was also assigned to the US Military Academy at West Point. In 1961, he received his BS in Economics from Villanova University, PA. His business career started at IBM and continued with Cogan, Berlind, Weill & Levitt, where he became a partner in 1965. In 1973, he founded Brean Murray & Co., a privately held investment firm. His association with other companies included founding and serving on the board of Shared Medical Systems and as a director of Concept, Inc. At the time of his death he was serving as a director of both Specialty Toner Corp. and Somanetics Corp. He served as an Official of the American Stock Exchange, and in 1985 was elected to the Board of the Tax Council. He was a director of Doral Financial Corp., a firm based in Puerto Rico, for approximately nine years. For the past two years, Brean Murrany & Co. has sponsored the Investment Opportunities in the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico conferences. On October 30, 2003, the conference was held at the New York Stock Exchange and Brean rang the closing bell that day to celebrate the conclusion of the conference. He was a member of the Board of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice Foundation, CUNY. He was instrumental in the establishment of the McCabe Fellowship, a scholarship exchange program between police professionals from John Jay College and the An Garda Siochana, the national police force in Ireland. In 1988, Brean and his wife, Bettina, created a scholarship fund to enable financially underprivileged students to attend Columbia University's Summer Program for High School Students. This program is designed for highly motivated students to experience college-level study, and over the past sixteen years the scholarship fund has supported over 400 students. A private funeral service and burial will be held in Cornwall-on-Hudson. A memorial service will be held in New York on January 12th at 4:30PM at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th St. and 5th Ave, followed by a reception at The Union Club, 109 East 69 St. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made to The John Jay College Foundation, for the Brean Murray Scholarship Fund, President's Office/ P. Maull, 899 10th Ave, New York, NY 10019 or to The Scholarship Fund, Columbia University's Summer Program for High School Students, Attn: Paul McNeil, 303 Lewisohn Hall, Columbia University, New York, NY 10027.

title: Bishop Lee's Choice
description: Throughout his nearly 19 years as the bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Virginia, Peter James Lee has been an unwavering centrist and consensus builder. His diocese, the largest in the Episcopal Church, is diverse, with giant urban churches and tiny rural ones, liberal mainline congregations and conservative evangelical ones, and Lee has managed to hold them all together by astutely finding the midpoint on any controversial issue and luring both sides toward it. At the Episcopal Church's general convention last summer in Minneapolis, Lee oversaw publication of a daily newsletter that offered a middle-of-the-road perspective on the many contentious issues facing the church. It provides rapid ski access 365 days a year.

title: Stolen Moments

She was a single parent with a hefty divorce settlement and so befuddled by her two children that she frequently overreacted with almost-comical extremes of punishment. But there were other moments.

They are trying to walk a fine line between giving ethnic and religious groups the territory, resources and autonomy they demand, and ensuring that such power does not give rise to dangerous nationalisms.

title: Lili Taylor: Another Triumph, and Now the Rent's Due
description: LILI TAYLOR is the type of actress whose fans feel almost proprietary toward her, as if they had discovered her personally. Though she and Julia Roberts both got noticed in the same film (''Mystic Pizza,'' 1988), Ms. Taylor quickly slipped into the lower-profile world of independent film, where her career arc soon became the left-handed image of her co-star's. She played the title dog in ''Dogfight'' and the ''I'' in ''I Shot Andy Warhol''; Abel Ferrara gave her the role of a vampire in ''The Addiction,'' Robert Altman recruited her for ''Short Cuts'' and ''Prt  Porter,'' and most recently the creators of ''Six Feet Under'' cast her as Lisa in their HBO series. Throughout her 15 years in film, however, Ms. Taylor never lost touch with the theater, and she is currently appearing in a revival by the New Group of Wallace Shawn's 1985 play ''Aunt Dan and Lemon'' at the Clurman Theater on Theater Row. Her serene performance as an impressionable -- and ultimately corrupted -- shut-in is winning her the stage notices of her career. On a recent Saturday at the West Bank Cafe near the theater, Ms. Taylor sat down with the writer Jennifer Senior to discuss her latest role, the state of independent film and how impossible it is to find affordable housing in New York.

title: Costa Rican Grandmaster-to-Be Shows True Sophistication at 15

When 15-year-old Alejandro Ramirez of Costa Rica tied for first place in the Santo Domingo International Open, it was his third grandmaster norm, and he simultaneously broke 2500 points in his rating. Together they make up an ironclad grandmaster qualification, and it is expected that his new status will be announced at the next official meeting of the International Chess Federation.

title: When Dad Runs for President
description: In most families, it's the children who dream of what they might someday become, while the parents devote their every hour to making it happen. In a political family, those roles are reversed. The child of a presidential candidate learns to subjugate herself to the machinery of a campaign. She learns to rally a crowd of supporters, to gently push a county official for a much-needed endorsement or, if she's too young for any of that, simply to smile and wave on cue. She learns to accommodate or even adore the coterie of aides who roam the family home and to trust no one outside that circle with the smallest shred of information.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JENKS, RICHARD DIMICK
description: JENKS--Richard Dimick. 66, died on December 30, 2003 at a nursing home in Rye Brook of complications from multiple system atrophy. He is survived by a son, Douglas, and his wife, Patricia, of Hopewell Junction; a son, Daniel, and his wife, Mercedes, of Anaheim, CA; and a daughter, Susan, of Millwood; longtime companion, Barbara Gatje, of Manhattan and Point O'Woods; a brother, Captain Albert Jenks United States Navy, retired, and his wife Barbara of San Diego, CA; and a sister Diane and her husband Lt. Col. Harold Alabaster, United States Army, retired, of Bellevue, WA; and grandchildren Douglas, Valerie, Ryan and Daniel Richard, and a step-granddaughter, Danielle. He received his Ph.D. in mathematics from the University of Illinois in Urbana-Champaign. His first employment after graduation was with the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton. From 1968 to 2002, he worked in the Mathematical Sciences Department of the Thomas J. Watson Research Laboratory of I.B.M. in Yorktown Heights, where he designed computer algebra software. He published numerous articles in his field, was responsible for several patents, and co-authored the book, ''Axiom,'' with mathematician Dr. Robert Sutor, also of I.B.M. With Dr. David V. Chudnovsky, he co-chaired international conferences on Computers & Mathematics, among them, one in 1986 at Stanford University and another in 1989 at M.I.T. He was a voracious reader, especially of history, biography and politics. He traveled widely throughout Europe and North America, as well as to places like Lake Baikal in Siberia; Torajaland in Sulawesi, Indonesia; the Rio Negro in Brazil and the Galapagos in Ecuador. His passion for music was first developed when he was a child in Dixon, IL, where he learned to play the organ and sang in the church choir. Later in life, he became organist and choirmaster of the Church of the Holy Communion in Mahopac. During the 1980's and '90's, he sang in choirs under the direction of Dr. Dennis Keene, conductor, performing at Lincoln Center in Alice Tully Hall. He also sang in the Point O'Woods Church Choir on Fire Island, under Dr. Mary Monroe, choir director, which gave him great joy. The date of a Memorial Service will be announced shortly. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Jenks Computer Algebra Prize to be awarded for outstanding work in software engineering in computer algebra, c/o Professor B.F. Caviness, Dept. of Computer & Information Sciences, 103 Smith Hall, University of Delaware, Newark, DE 19716; or to The Music Fund of the Church at Point O'Woods, Point O'Woods, NY 11706.

title: Kyra Nichols Keeps Balanchine in the Air
description: KYRA NICHOLS is 45. No, it's not exactly young for a ballerina. But for those who didn't experience the prime of George Balanchine and his New York City Ballet, Ms. Nichols -- with her luminous phrasing, regal presence and generous free spirit -- makes everything O.K. Though she is a mother of two, it is difficult to imagine she ever danced better than she does now. A native of Berkeley, Calif., she trained with her mother, Sally Streets, a member of the company in the 50's, before becoming an apprentice with City Ballet in 1974 and a principal in 1979. Now, just as the world is celebrating the centenary of Balanchine's birth, New Yorkers can honor Ms. Nichols, who will be dancing in several principal roles. In a recent conversation with Gia Kourlas at the company's headquarters at the Rose Building in Lincoln Center, she discussed age, dance after childbirth and the years she spent with Mr. B.

title: No Excuses

A few black students were taking accelerated English, but no whites were sitting in the English class that was learning to identify verbs.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: The White Rock: An Exploration of the Inca Heartland, by Hugh Thomson. (Overlook, $16.95.) In recounting his successful quest to discover a lost city deep in the Peruvian Andes, Thomson has much to say about the Incas' creative response to the mountainous landscape in their vast building projects, and about the enduring allure of their vibrant civilization. Last year in the Book Review, Geoffrey Moorhouse found this ''the sort of book that fires the armchair traveler with a desire to follow in its author's footsteps, not just because it is passionate about its subject and immensely well informed about the Inca empire . . . but also because it tells of some quite heroic exploration by Thomson himself, on foot in one of the most intractable parts of the earth.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SASSO, THOMAS EDWARD
description: SASSO--Thomas Edward. We mourn the untimely death of Tommy Sasso, loving best friend to all. Thomas Edward Sasso, 51, of Ridgewood, New Jersey, died on January 1, 2004, in Westchester, New York, of injuries sustained in an automobile accident on the afternoon of Monday, December 29. He is survived by his cherished wife, Kate Quackenbush Sasso and beloved daughter, Allison Quackenbush Sasso; his loving parents, Thomas A. and Felicia Lettieri Sasso of Teaneck, his loving sister, Diane F. Sasso, and devoted brother-in-law, George Karelitsky, of Ridgewood; nieces Elizabeth Sasso-Karelitsky, Susan A. Martin, and Sarah Bruno; nephews Noah and Alexander Sasso-Karelitsky, and Samuel F. Martin; parents-inlaw R. Donald and Audrey Gordon Quackenbush; sisters and brothers-in-law, Susan Q. and John A. Martin and Lynn Q. and Robert Bruno, and more best friends than one can imagine. He was a proud graduate of St. Peter's Preparatory, Class of 1970, and of Boston College, Class of 1974. Even as a youth, Tom was a natural leader and drew people to him with a great passion for life. President of the Real Estate Lenders' Association of New York and a well known professional in commercial real estate, Tom was recognized as both a knowledgeable competitor and valuable partner. He began his career with Chemical Bank, later joining the Chase Manhattan Bank and subsequently GE Capital, where he served as Senior Vice President. Tom was an expert backgammon player, an enthusiastic sailor, and the winner of an award for golfing. Having survived major cancer surgery in 2000, he was downhill skiing within six months and proudly completed the Ridgewood Memorial Day Run within a year. Tommy supported many charitable organizations. He was a populist, a humanist, a gentleman with a passion for justice and peace. He invited divergent views and encouraged debate. He had an uncommon generosity, always lending a hand and encouraging others to give of themselves. Tommy was a treasure to all of us. He will be terribly missed. For visitation information, contact Feeney's Funeral Home, Ridgewood, New Jersey, 201444-7650. A celebration of Tom's life and a special Mass will be held on Wednesday, January 7, 10:45 AM, at Mt. Carmel Church, Ridgewood.

description: When I first saw Marshall Sella's article on Dennis Kucinich, I was over the moon (Dec. 21). My elation faded, however, as I read it. Kucinich is short (a couple inches shorter than Lieberman), he's uncharismatic, he's a vegan, and he's on the left end of the spectrum.

title: The Quest for the North Central Positronics
description: Wolves of the Calla

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Page Two: Dec. 28, 2003-Jan. 3, 2004; AIR TRAVEL, INTERRUPTED
description: A handful of British Airways flights between London and Washington were disrupted for three straight days. Other flights between Mexico and Los Angeles were grounded, with one flight forced to turn around in midair. And F-16 fighter jets shadowed United States-bound flights flown by Air France and other airlines.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Sculptures That Sparkle

title: Executive Life; Business Schools Make a Pitch for Women
description: KRYSTAL WILLIAMS never considered herself a candidate for a business career. After graduating from college in 1996, she entered the Peace Corps, intending to become a math professor one day.

title: Killing the Patient
description: THE DOCTORS' PLAGUE

title: POSTINGS: City Seizes 50 Vehicles; Policing Contractors
description: Unlicensed contractors, beware: inspectors from the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs are on the lookout for you.

title: A Year for Images That Will Linger
description: IT'S still a tossup whether 2003 was a great year for movies. But there's no argument that it was one of the most gratifying years in recent memory for cinematography, and not just the eye-catching, high-contrast color gloss that often passes for great camera work but would be better relegated to press-on nails.

title: All Eyes Will Be On Investigators in 2004
description: The new year in politics brings a reconstituted Legislature, some fresh leaders in the State House, and, inevitably, promises of programs designed to set the stage for the gubernatorial election in 2005.

title: Yankees Buck Tradition By Eschewing Lefties
description: Immediately after the All-Star Game break this season, the San Diego Padres will play a road series against the Houston Astros. One of the games could match the Padres' David Wells against the Astros' Andy Pettitte, with Roger Clemens watching from the stands or, if he resumes pitching and joins his hometown team, from the Astros' dugout.

title: Brazil Gives New Leader Room to Err
description: The ranks of the unemployed have swelled by nearly a million, consumer purchasing power has declined by 20 percent and the economy itself has failed to grow. Yet as Luiz Incio Lula da Silva completes his first year in office as Brazil's first working-class president, his popularity among Brazilians remains at a record high.

title: Spider Hole
description: Contrary to popular belief (a clich heard at ''hastily called press conferences''), I do not ordinarily slip egregious errors into this column to generate paroxysms of outrage from the Gotcha! Gang. Once in awhile I do, just to see if the gimlet-eyed readership is on the ball. (Calm down; when you're using a while as a noun phrase preceded by prepositions like in or for, write it as two words. But when you need it as an adverb to modify a verb, use the one-word awhile. Mnemonic: once in a while, relax awhile.)

title: A Book Made Me Do It; Building the Business of Me
description: ''THE game is never over,'' Jack H. Llewellyn, a sports psychologist, asserts in his new book, which bears the irrefutable title ''Winning Sure Beats Losing.'' If you ''win, if you achieve, if you succeed, then you earn the right to take a breath and move to the next level.''

title: The Nation: Breaking Ranks; Shrink Government, the Right Tells the Right
description: Correction Appended

title: The Week Ahead; ECONOMY
description: Of all measures for gauging the progress of the economy, the one that really counts is employment. What good is a recovery if it does not generate enough jobs? The work force has been expanding since August, but is way short of the 150,000 new jobs a month needed to absorb those who want to work and to really shrink the unemployment rate from its current 5.9 percent. The December report on new jobs comes out Friday and forecasters are hoping for that magic 150,000. Louis Uchitelle

title: Scott Adapts After the Nets Criticized His Methods
description: When the Nets confronted Byron Scott in their locker room last month, he was forced to make one season-altering choice: he could join the shouting or turn a cheek and listen.

title: A Note of Caution
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Note
description: Frank Rich is on vacation.

title: Remedial Work
description: THE PURSUIT

title: Holidays Are Over, But Hunger Is Not
description: Come Christmas, food banks are stocked with goodies. Drives at schools and supermarkets fill the shelves. But the directors of two Connecticut food banks want to remind donors not to forget the hungry now that the holidays are over.

title: Investing; With Fancy Footwork, Barnes & Noble Surprises the Naysayers
description: SHARES of Barnes & Noble rose 82 percent in 2003, a particularly impressive performance considering the hand-wringing early in the year by investors over competition from Amazon.com and discounters like Wal-Mart and Costco.

title: The Optimist
description: I'm something of an optimist myself, so when I read Sella's article, I recalled a quote from Gandhi: ''First they ignore you, then they ridicule you, then they fight you, then you win.'' I'm sure Kucinich is familiar with this quotation, and so your article must be an encouraging sign to him that his campaign for president has progressed far into the ridicule phase. Can victory be far behind?

title: Municipal Madness or 'Creative Localism?'
description: THE two buildings just across the railroad tracks and inside the metal gates have a sort of Hansel-and-Gretel quality. They are prim white with green shutters and trim, with lush, forest-like vegetation all around. The building to the right has a cute A-frame roof and a road beside it, where you can almost imagine a trail of goodies leading into the woods.

title: Land Of the Rising Clich
description: IN the climactic battle of ''Kill Bill Vol. 1,'' Quentin Tarantino's bloody revenge flick, O-Ren Ishii, the kimono-clad yakuza chieftess played by Lucy Liu, turns to Uma Thurman's blonde, blue-eyed Bride, and caustically remarks: ''Silly Caucasian girl likes to play with samurai swords.''

title: Colombian Rebels Capture Was Result of Hunt Aided by U.S.
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 4  Colombian agents, working with American intelligence, tailed a top Colombian guerrilla commander for months before he was arrested Friday on a busy street in Quito, the capital of neighboring Ecuador, Colombian military authorities said today.

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are given at end of Broadway and Off Broadway listings.

title: Corrections
description: A brief essay in the Year in Ideas issue on Dec. 14, about movies that blur the line between real life and fiction, referred incorrectly to ''Elephant,'' a Gus Van Sant film that depicts a shooting spree at a high school similar to Columbine near Littleton, Colo. Most, not all, of the actors playing students had the same names as their characters.

title: Unruly Students Facing Arrest, Not Detention
description: Correction Appended

title: Space Probe Lands on Mars; On Search for Signs of Water
description: An American spacecraft, the robotic roving vehicle called Spirit, landed on Mars late Saturday night and radioed home that it is apparently safe and ready for three months' searching for signs of water in the planet's early history.

title: A New Day for Suffolk County
description: THE type of Long Island that citizens will see in 25 years will be determined by the decisions that we make in this upcoming administration. The future of Suffolk County is not a matter of chance; it is a matter of choice. It is therefore the charge of this administration to implement policy initiatives that place dynamic innovation, long-term planning and maximum efficiency as priorities.

title: From Cereal to Juice, a Year of Innovation
description: Many consumers may look back at 2003 as the year in which the economy and stock market finally started to bounce back. But it was also a year of product innovation.

title: Desperate Islanders Rally Late To Earn Tie
description: The Islanders kept the penalty box warm for the first two periods against the Boston Bruins on Saturday night. Once they stopped paying penance, the Islanders surged back from a two-goal deficit in the third period to squeeze out an improbable point with a 3-3 tie at the Fleet Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GILMAN, BERYL
description: GILMAN--Beryl. On December 30, 2003. Husband of the late Bluma Cohen Gilman. Survived by his loving family; Amy Gilman and Walter Srebnick, Joshua and Amy Sagan Srebnick, Daniel Antonio Srebnick and Sara Bernbach, great-grandson Jake Henry Srebnick, and brothers Harry and Leo Gilman and the rest of the Gilman family. We will miss him greatly. Services Sunday, January 18, 12 Noon at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 21 about the prevalence of standing ovations for Broadway productions misidentified a costume designer in a quotation from the theater historian Ethan Mordden. Mr. Mordden says he referred to Bob Mackintosh, designer for productions including ''Mame'' -- not Bob Mackie -- in a comment about star vehicles for women. Thus the quotation should have read: ''When everyone's attention is focused, the star comes out in her 37th Bob Mackintosh gown of the evening. By that point, you have no choice but get to your feet.''

title: Commercial Property; Becoming a Retail Sector Player With a Single Deal
description: HE'S a ''fixer'' by nature, said David W. Lichtenstein, whose national real estate company, the Lightstone Group, is based in this unlikely small-town venue, in an old Georgian mansion he rescued from dilapidation. He likes fixing buildings, fixing problems and tinkering with companies to enhance their value, Mr. Lichtenstein said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POLSTEIN, JOSEPH NATHAN
description: POLSTEIN--Joseph Nathan. Age 90, of East Rockaway, NY, after a short illness. Preceded into rest by his beloved Dorothy (Barst). Survived by his sister Ruth Sirota of Jerusalem, son Ernest Polstein, daughter Meri Grumbacher, daughter - and son - in - law Kate Sharp and John Grumbacher, treasured grandchildren Laura and Sam Polstein and Stephanie Grumbacher, and numerous nieces and nephews. Funeral will be held Sunday, January 4, 1:45 PM, Boulevard - Riverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Insight column last Sunday, about investing in makers of alcoholic beverages, misidentified the brewer of Corona beer. It is Grupo Modelo of Mexico. (Constellation Brands is the parent of Barton Beers, which distributes Corona in the western United States.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CAREY, JAMES J.
description: CAREY--James J., 62, of Princeton, NJ, died January 1, 2004 at his residence surrounded by his family. Senior Vice President of Citigroup where he worked for 43 years. Survived by his wife Jacqueline, mother Wilma, sister Linda, daughter Heather, step-daughter Christine and husband David, step-sons Patrick and wife Kristin and Lowell. Donations to Healing the Children of Greater Philadelphia Area or Leukemia and Lymphoma Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAUFER, JOHN P.
description: LAUFER--John P. It is with sadness that the Associated Builders and Owners of Greater New York mourn the passing of our great member, John Laufer, ABO's 2000 Associate of the Year. As we start this New Year, we will all feel the void from John's loss. He was truly a gentleman and an all around great guy. Rest in peace John...stay out of mischief. Jerome Belson, President Michael Kerr, Co-Chairman Arnold Sollar, Co-Chairman Nicholas LaPorte, Jr., Executive Director

title: A Designer Lets Loose In the 'Year of the Car'
description: WHEN the Ford Motor Company landed J Mays as design chief in 1997, it was considered something of a coup. Well spoken and well coiffed, Mr. Mays was among the most celebrated and daring young designers in the business. In his previous job, he had presided over the imaginative reinvention of the Volkswagen Beetle into a car that managed to revive the old Bug's spirit while being thoroughly modern at the same time.

title: Lisa Friedenberg, Tyler Anbinder
description: Lisa Joy Friedenberg, a daughter of Arlene and Richard Friedenberg of Chestnut Ridge, N.Y., was married last evening to Tyler Anbinder, the son of Madeline and Stephen Anbinder of New York. Rabbi Daniel Zemel officiated at the Atrium in the Meadowlark Botanical Gardens in Vienna, Va.

title: A Book Made Me Do It; To Tranquillity, Cabbie, And Step on It
description: ONE of these days I plan to relax. I suspect that this will happen when I am dead. Until that unwelcome occurrence, I suppose that the core of my personal stress-reduction program will have to consist of gabbing with friends, running nowhere on a treadmill, creeping around Central Park with my aged hound dog and dosing myself therapeutically with white wine.

title: Panthers End 7 Lean Years With a Rout
description: No matter where the Carolina Panthers turned this week, they could not escape talk of the drought. It had been seven years since fans flocked to Ericsson Stadium for a playoff game, since Charlotte echoed with the sounds of marching bands and giddy fans turning the usually sleepy downtown area into a postseason party.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about Glenn Nordlinger, whose mail was not forwarded after he moved, misstated the intersection for his neighborhood post office, at 55th Street. It is at Third Avenue, not Sutton Place (which in any case, below 57th Street, is called Sutton Place South).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WECHSLER, CECILE, M.D.
description: WECHSLER -- Cecile, M.D. With deep sorrow we announce the passing of Dr. Cecile Wechsler on Wednesday, November 26, 2003. She is sorely missed by her many patients, the children she mothered after WW II, her many friends and relatives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHARMAT, MARY CONSTANCE LEARSON
description: SHARMAT--Mary Constance Learson. 69, daughter of Nora C. Brungot (d.) and James Learson (d.). Survived by children, Lee and James Sharmat, and companion, Frank Vohs, of cardiac arrest on January 1, 2004. Mary's early professional career included roles from the Steve Allen Show and Odd Couple to producing the Follies Bergere. Recently she was a star at the Hampton Playhouse. Best known as Francis the ''Wisk Lady'' in the 1990's, she continued to write plays, perform commercials and voiceover work until her sudden death. As a lifelong activist she led the NYC Anti-Civil Defense Peace Movement in the 1960's. For the past ten years she has been known as the Library Lady for her tireless work on behalf of the Columbus Branch. Viewing Buckley Funeral Home, 445 W. 43 St., Monday, January 5, 2-5 PM, 7-9 PM. Donations to R. Kirk/Manhattan Plaza AIDS Project, 400 W. 43rd St., 10036. ''Just do everything 100% and you will accomplish what you want. It's a long life.''

title: Sharpton Says He Meets Federal Funds Test
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton said that his presidential campaign had raised enough money in enough states to qualify for federal matching funds, which if verified by the Federal Election Commission would funnel more than $100,000 into his campaign with more tax dollars to follow.

title: Yams Under the Frangipani Tree
description: THE anthropologist Bronislaw Malinowski defined the exotic 80 years ago when he wrote about his days in the Trobriand Islands, a place of perfumed trees, untouched villages and free love.

title: As Chaplain's Spy Case Nears, Some Ask Why It Went So Far
description: As the Muslim chaplain at the military base at Guantnamo Bay in Cuba, Capt. James J. Yee often invited some of the Islamic members of the garrison to his quarters for dinner on Friday after he conducted weekly services.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MENDENHALL, MARLENE
description: MENDENHALL -- Marlene. VAIA--Lula. Mom, it's been two years. Thinking of you both in the city and season you loved so much. Lots of love, Christie and your girls, Lucy and Lily

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   STEVENS, HERBERT
description: STEVENS--Herbert. Remembering your strength, courage, integrity & passion for life. Never before and never again will there be someone like you. ....Your family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLAR, HENRY A.
description: KLAR--Henry A., 87, of Tamarac, FL, passed away peacefully on December 29, 2003, with his family at his bedside. A Master Sergeant in WWII, this prominent New York real estate lawyer started a new home brokerage business called Klar Realty in 1947. He became a suburban growth pioneer by initiating contract signings on nights and weekends and ultimately during his career selling more than 40,000 homes in the New York Metropolitan Area. An avid golfer and card player, world traveler and cruise staffer, and commerciallysuccessful sculptor, his good counsel and many contributions touched thousands of lives. He is survived by his loving wife of 63 years, Gloria, his respectful sons Lester and Steven, an attorney and real estate developer, of New York, and Dr. Ronald Klar, of Washington, his daughter-inlaw Deborah and granddaughters Laura and Jennifer, and his brother Edward of Boca Raton, FL. A funeral service will be held on Monday, January 5, 2004, at 12:00 noon at Gutterman's, Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury. Interment will follow at the family plot at Mount Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale.

title: Barbara Garjian, Les Hiscoe Jr.
description: Barbara Joy Garjian and Les Hiscoe Jr. were married yesterday by the Rev. Mardiros Chevian at St. Vartan Armenian Cathedral in New York.

description: Women's Global Health

title: Page Two: Dec. 28, 2003-Jan. 3, 2004; MURDERS DOWN, STATISTICS UP
description: For cities, it is an annual, but grim, statistical necessity: tallying up the year's murders. The final tally for New York City in 2003 was 596 homicides, according to official statistics. (Police officials said the figure could change as current investigations are closed.)

title: Houston
description: It's fitting that the clash of the professional football titans, the Super Bowl, will take place in Houston, a city where sports has played a significant role in what many citizens call its rebirth. After the oil bust of the early 1980's, the world's energy capital set about diversifying, and sports is part of the plan.

title: Mad Cow, Chicken, Pig
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Here's Something to Celebrate: High Fund Fees
description: MUTUAL fund fees have been a sore subject. So when Alliance Capital Management recently settled government complaints of improper trades in its funds by agreeing, among other things, to cut its fees, many investors probably cheered.

title: The Nation; Yes, Howard Dean Can Be Toppled and How
description: HE played down the capture of Saddam Hussein. He called Osama bin Laden innocent until proven guilty. And Howard Dean is still leading in the polls?

title: Clinton Enjoys Role as Adviser in Chief
description: He left office nearly three years ago, but Bill Clinton, the youngest ex-president in modern times, is still the go-to guy in Democratic politics.
