title: Test Confirms Infected Cow Was Born on Canada Farm
description: Federal officials said on Tuesday that genetic tests had confirmed that the cow in Washington State found to have had mad cow disease was born on a dairy farm in Alberta, Canada.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: US AIRWAYS, Arlington, Va., said its passenger load factor, a percentage of seats filled in planes by paying passengers, rose in December. Its load factor was 72.9 percent, a 0.5 percentage point increase from December 2002.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAMOS, ELIZABETH
description: RAMOS--Elizabeth. The Partners, Associates and Staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the death on January 3, 2004 of Elizabeth Ramos, beloved mother of our friend and partner Carey R. Ramos. We express our deepest sympathies to Carey and to all other members of the family.

title: Trade Curbs Affect More Than Ranchers
description: The discovery of two cases of mad cow disease on North American farms in the last nine months has sent ripples through more than Canada's beef industry, creating a surplus of milk because dairy cows can no longer be exported to the United States and a shortage of pet food because American animal parts are banned in Canada.

title: Molitor and Eckersley Gain Hall of Fame
description: Paul Molitor has always been a savvy baseball player. So when he faced Dennis Eckersley with runners on second and third, two outs and the score tied in the ninth inning on Aug. 22, 1998, Molitor noticed the third baseman was playing too deep. Molitor pushed a bunt in that direction for the softest of game-winning singles.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: BP To Sell Stakes In Gas Business
description: The British oil giant BP plans to sell stakes in its Malaysian and Singapore retail gasoline business as part of a corporate realignment. BP will sell its 70 percent stake in its Malaysian retail unit, which runs 240 gasoline stations, said Rosli Hussin, BP's Malaysian director for corporate affairs. In addition, BP will sell 30 gasoline stations that it runs in Singapore. It is selling assets in some countries to focus on regions with potential for higher growth, like Russia. It made a $6.35 billion investment in Russia last year. The company is also planning to sell its liquefied petroleum gas business in Malaysia and Singapore. The remaining 30 percent in its Malaysian unit is held by Lembaga Tabung Angkatan Tentera, an armed forces trust fund. BP said it would keep its other Malaysian units including the manufacturing of chemicals and lubricants.

description: The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose for the sixth trading day in seven yesterday, reaching a level not seen in more than 20 months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BETTRIDGE, WILLIAM B.
description: BETTRIDGE--William B., on January 5, 2004. Beloved husband of Susan Thomases, father to Shannon and Thomas, son to Mary Helen and son-to-law to Florence Thomases. Cherished brother to James, Thomas, Alicia, David, Gerald, Jack and Mary Bettridge and Robert, Matthew and Jeffrey Thomases. Devoted godfather to Phoebe Thomases and Aubrey and Jack Bettridge. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Viewing Wednesday, 6pm-9pm. Service Thursday, 3:30pm.

title: Schumer Letter Prods Bush Aide Over Leak
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York asked the White House on Tuesday to require staff members to disclose any confidential conversations with reporters that might help determine whether an administration official improperly divulged the name of a C.I.A. undercover officer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDSTEIN, HELEN
description: GOLDSTEIN -- Helen. Our condolences to Helen's beloved Leonard and her adoring family. Her friendship, wit, style and commitment to Judaism will be sorely missed. Dawn and Arnold Pohl

title: Baltimore Sun Editor Is Abruptly Ousted
description: The Baltimore Sun said yesterday that the publisher had replaced its editor, William K. Marimow, an unexpected decision that surprised even those at the higher echelons of the newsroom, who received little explanation.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Court Upholds Handgun Law
description: A new law authorizing licensed civilians to carry concealed handguns does not violate the state's Constitution, the state Supreme Court ruled, rejecting a challenge by a doctor and a children's advocacy group. The decision will allow the Department of Public Safety to begin issuing permits this month. The law requires that those seeking to carry a handgun be at least 25 years old, pass a criminal background check and complete firearms training. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: John Toland, 91, Author Of Best-Selling History Books
description: John Toland, a best-selling historian whose book ''The Rising Sun: The Decline and Fall of the Japanese Empire, 1936-1945'' won the 1971 Pulitzer Prize for nonfiction, died on Sunday at Danbury Hospital in Connecticut. He was 91 and lived in Danbury.

title: A Collector Following the Thread of the Chinese Imperial Court
description: Tucked away in her atelier along antique row on Wyndham Street here, Teresa Coleman nurtures a collection of ornate imperial robes from the courts of China that give new meaning to the term vintage clothing.

title: UConn Eludes Upset In Big East Opener
description: Rutgers may not play a more inspired 40 minutes of basketball this season. One of the nation's elite teams was in town Tuesday night and the Scarlet Knights responded to the electricity shooting through the packed Louis Brown Athletic Center. They hustled, made some clutch shots and gave the more talented team fits through every dramatic minute.

title: I.M.F. Report Says U.S. Deficits Threaten World Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7  With its rising budget deficit and ballooning trade imbalance, the United States is running up a foreign debt of such record-breaking proportions that it threatens the financial stability of the global economy, according to a report made public today bythe International Monetary Fund.

title: Off the Menu
description: FENG SHUI , a Chinese cafe and takeout counter, has opened in the lower level dining concourse of Grand Central Terminal, replacing Nem. It is owned by SUSHIL MALHOTRA , who also owns the Cafe Spice Indian restaurants. The chef, BEN LEE , who was previously at the Mandarin Oriental hotel in Shanghai, is preparing popular dishes like General Tso's chicken, shrimp with lobster sauce and vegetable lo mein. Mr. Malhotra has also opened another branch of CAFE SPICE at 54 West 55th Street.

title: Look Up There
description: More than curiosity or altruism or even profit, what drives discovery is the spirit of competition. Whether it's unlocking a genetic code, developing a drug to cure disease or finding the key to longevity, the prospect of personal glory or national prestige propels us to risk reputation, capital and even our lives to get there first.

title: PROCESSOR OF STUDENT LOANS EXPANDS IN HEALTH CARE
description: Affiliated Computer Services, the world's largest processor of student loan payments, has acquired Patient Accounting Services Center, which handles billing and accounts for health care providers, for $94 million in cash. If Patient Accounting Services ''hits certain revenue and profit targets in the next few years, they will receive additional monies as part of the purchase price,'' said Mark King, president of Affiliated Computer, based in Dallas. Patient Accounting, based in Kent, Wash., processes more than a million patient accounts monthly for 240 health care groups. Patient Accounting has more than 1,000 employees and operates service centers in Kent and Houston; the company is expected to have revenue of about $68 million in 2003. Shares of Affiliated Computer rose 64 cents, to $57.46.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Arris Narrows Loss
description: Shares of the Arris Group, which makes cable modems and broadband networking gear, rose 13 percent yesterday after the company said it had a fourth-quarter net loss of 11 cents to 16 cents a share, less than it had forecast. Arris shares rose 99 cents, to $8.58. The loss was narrower than the 12 cents to 20 cents a share Arris had forecast, because of better-than-expected sales, the company said yesterday. Excluding certain costs, Arris said it had a profit of 1 cent to 6 cents a share. On that basis, analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial had forecast a loss of 3 cents a share. Arris said it would release final fourth-quarter results on Feb. 3. Arris lost $94.1 million, or $1.14 a share, in the fourth quarter of 2002.

title: Piaf Would Recognize This Place. Almost.
description: BACK in the days when a seat in the second balcony of a Broadway play was $1.80, the theater district was filled with little French bistros in which a three-course dinner was $4.95. My first time around in New York, I sat in many second balconies and went to lots of those restaurants, where, at the time, canned peas were the green vegetable. A few, like Tout Va Bien and Pierre au Tunnel, are still with us.

title: China Announces New Bailout of Big Banks
description: China announced a complex transfer on Tuesday of $45 billion from its soaring foreign exchange reserves to two of the four big government-owned banks, the third large bailout in the banking system in less than six years.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about automakers' plans for more hybrid vehicles misidentified one model that Honda will start selling this year. It is an Accord, not an Acura. Because of an editing error, the article also referred incorrectly to a forecast from the Toyota Motor Company. The figure of two million sold by the end of the decade was for Toyota models only, not those of all automakers.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: EUROPEAN OFFICIALS MEET ON AGENDA Meeting in Dublin as the presidency of the European Union rotated to Ireland and to Prime Minister Bertie Ahern, Mr. Ahern, at right, and Romano Prodi of Italy, left, president of the other main branch of the union's government, the European Commission, addressed their clashing views about future negotiations for a new constitution. "We cannot wait forever," Mr. Prodi said at a news conference, sitting next to Mr. Ahern. "Europe cannot always go at the speed of the very, very slowest wagon." Mr. Prodi said that failure to agree on a constitution quickly would result in a "two-speed" Europe. Mr. Ahern said new talks must include all members, including 10 new nations set to join in May. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: In S.I., Laying Down the Law Seems Different
description: IN New York City, a district attorney's passing the baton is as rare as a rent-stabilized apartment's changing hands. The granddaddy of the city's five, Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan, has served since 1975. And until this New Year's Day, the most junior was Richard A. Brown of Queens, who took office 12 years ago.

title: 3 Teams Picked to Plan Airliner Defense Systems

Under his pseudonym he is the author of 19 novels, many of them international best sellers and nearly all of them about the plots and counterplots of international espionage.

About 500 cases were filed against the Archdiocese of Los Angeles, while an additional 175 were spread among the dioceses of Orange, San Diego and San Bernardino, said Ray Boucher, a lawyer whose office is handling filings for 320 plaintiffs in Southern California. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: New Ruble Bank Notes Planned
description: Russia's central bank plans to introduce new ruble bank notes in the second half of the year to combat counterfeiting. The central bank also plans to issue a 5,000 ruble note next year, in addition to existing 10, 50, 100, 500 and 1,000 ruble notes. ''The new notes will circulate in addition to existing ones, there won't be any swap,'' Arnold Voilukov, the first deputy chairman at the bank, said. ''The old notes will be accepted any time and will be in circulation until worn out.'' Roughly 1.2 trillion rubles, or $41 billion, are in circulation in Russia, and the central bank estimates that about 100 million of the rubles in circulation are forged. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: More Than a Food Guide, A Portable Conscience
description: ''The Vegan Guide to New York City,'' by Rynn Berry and Chris Abreu-Suzuki (Ethical Living $9.95), is not only for vegans, who eat no animal products. Borough by borough, the book lists restaurants that are vegetarian, those that are macrobiotic and might serve fish, and others that are merely ''vegetarian friendly,'' meaning that diners who don't eat meat will find something appealing on the menu. Lists of places that serve raw food, health food stores, mail-order sources, bookstores, Web sites and even shops that sell ''cruelty free shoes'' are packed into the guide's 70 pages, which also contain advertising.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Marconi Shares Rise On Sale Of U.S. Unit
description: Shares in the Marconi Corporation, a maker of phone equipment that ceded control to creditors in May, rose as much as 8.9 percent after it sold a North American unit to Advanced Fibre Communications for $240 million. Marconi, based in London, will use the proceeds to repay notes, the chief executive, Mike Parton, left, said. The business had been for sale for a year. ''We said we would sell at the right conditions and we believe those conditions have been achieved,'' he said. Marconi, whose products once spanned weapons to washing machines, is selling units to cut debt and focus on equipment that sends data and voice through phone networks. The company handed control over to creditors in exchange for 4.82 billion ($8.7 billion) that it owed them.

title: A QUARTER-CHICKEN IN EVERY POT

''When will the Bush administration devise a how-to plan to put people back to work, a how-to plan to create jobs, or a how-to plan to save manufacturing jobs?'' he said in a statement. In Ames, Iowa, he added: ''They're putting out a guideline to employers for the ways in which those employers can actually avoid their responsibility to workers, even as they're prepared to give people earning more than $200,000 a year yet another tax cut. He was predeceased by his wife, Sally Barber Johnson. Born in Amarillo, Texas, he attended Harvard College on a full scholarship, interrupted Harvard Law School to serve in the US Marine Corps(4th Corps) in WWII, was wounded at Iwo Jima, and received a Bronze Star and a Purple Heart. A longtime resident of Bedford and Mt Kisco, NY, he worked his entire career at the Shearman & Sterling law firm in NYC where he was a partner and a leading legal adviser to Citicorp. He also served on the Board of Directors of major companies, including Fuji Bank. Favorite pastimes included skiing, tennis, hiking, canoeing and carpentry and other work on the family farmhouse in Weston, VT. description: Boeing, the world's largest airplane maker, yesterday named its controller, James A. Bell, chief financial officer as it seeks to restore confidence in the company's ethics after the departure of its top two executives. Mr. Bell, 55, had been acting chief financial officer since Michael M. Sears was fired in November for misconduct. Mr. Bell most recently was responsible for Boeing's accounting and external reporting, and was the primary contact with the board's audit committee, said the company, which is based in Chicago. The chief executive, Philip M. Condit, resigned shortly after Mr. Sears was fired.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: One Execution Held; One Is Stayed
description: Charles L. Singleton, a schizophrenic whose case tested the nation's standard for executing the mentally ill, was put to death by lethal injection even as another death row inmate won a stay. Mr. Singleton, 44, drew national attention because his sanity depended on antipsychotic drugs. Convicted of the murder of a grocer in a robbery in 1979, Mr. Singleton deteriorated steadily in prison until officials began to medicate him, often against his will. A federal appeals court panel reduced his sentence to life. The death sentence was reinstated by the full court when the state appealed; and the Supreme Court declined to review the case last month. The execution of Karl D. Roberts, 35, convicted of murdering his 12-year-old niece in 1999, was stayed. Mr. Roberts had expressed a desire to be executed until yesterday, and a federal district judge granted a stay to allow his lawyers time to study a possible appeal. When the state appealed, the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit upheld the stay. Justice Clarence Thomas of the Supreme Court, who oversees the circuit, also upheld it. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey

The detective, Norman Price, 45, of Bedminster, is charged with official misconduct and other offenses. Prosecutors said he was part of a scheme that began shortly after he was assigned in 2001 to help choose vendors to upgrade the Police Department's communications and computer equipment. Prosecutors said that Mr. Price's wife, Natasha McRae, 35, and a family friend, Vaughn Miller, 41, of North Plainfield, bought items like office furniture and computer software from legitimate businesses and resold them to the department through fake corporations at inflated prices. Ms. McRae and Mr. Miller were also charged in the indictment.    Richard Lezin Jones

description: The Xinyuan market reeks of animal waste and death. Trucks arrive daily with animals jammed into cages -- cats, dogs, pigeons, boars, ostriches, even rats. The people who work in the market live in cages, too. They sleep above their shops, in tiny lofts with bars for walls.

title: Sports of The Times; The Best Man for the Job to Lead the Giants
description: WHEN Tom Coughlin was named the Jacksonville Jaguars' coach as well as their director of football operations in 1994, he described his hiring as a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to construct an expansion franchise.

title: In Hussein's Shadow, New Iraqi Army Strives to Be Both New and Iraqi
description: If moments in the new Iraq strain credulity for those who knew the country under Saddam Hussein, few have done so more than the scene on Tuesday at this old Iraqi barracks: recruits of the new Iraqi Army marched across the parade square, past rows of saluting American officers, to the strains of ''Colonel Bogey March,'' the theme for the movie ''The Bridge on the River Kwai.''

title: New Jersey Tells of Progress In Developing a 'Smart Gun'
description: State researchers on Tuesday unveiled their work so far on developing a childproof ''smart gun,'' while members of the state's Congressional delegation said they would seek federal research grants to help advance the technology, which is intended to revolutionize gun safety.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: EarthLink Cutting Jobs
description: EarthLink, one of the country's largest Internet access providers, said yesterday that it would close call centers in California and Pennsylvania and cut its work force in Atlanta to lower expenses. About 1,300 jobs will be cut. The company said it would close offices in Pasadena, Roseville and San Jose, Calif., and in Harrisburg, Pa. Customer support will be handled by EarthLink's remaining employees in Atlanta and by companies that contract with EarthLink. EarthLink said it would have about $36 million in costs for closing offices in the first quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EHRENBERG, SHIRLEY

title: A New Year's Antidote For the Holiday Heavies
description: ABOUT a hundred years ago, when I had a brief affair with low-fat food, I started to sneer at real cooking. Anyone, I thought, could make food taste good without any dietary concerns getting in the way at the stove. The real challenge was to produce food that you actually wanted to eat when you were painting, as it were, with a restricted palette.

title: Writers Best Bet For Rose
description: Pete Rose played his last major league game in 1986, and three years later he was barred from baseball. Still, Rose was scheduled to be on the Hall of Fame ballot in 1991. Banishment from baseball was not then linked to exclusion from the Hall of Fame.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: FORMER BLACK PANTHERS UP FOR PAROLE The president of the police officers' union and the widow of a slain police officer began a letter-writing campaign yesterday to oppose parole for two former Black Panthers convicted of killing two police officers in 1971. One former Panther, Herman Bell, 55, comes up for parole for the first time in February, and the second, Anthony Bottom, 52, will be considered for the second time in July. The two men each have several disciplinary infractions since the late 1980's, but the parole board noted that Mr. Bottom had earned a degree and certificates for "good works" while serving time. The union president, Patrick J. Lynch, and Diane Piagentini, the widow of Joseph Piagentini, said they had collected 5,000 signatures to present to the parole board. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly, above, also released a letter opposing parole for the two men, while City Councilman Charles Barron said the decision should be based on their behavior in prison, not on the nature of their crime.    Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: In Defense of Local Control
description: Near the end of their legislative session in mid-December, Pennsylvania lawmakers voted in favor of a bill about crime and the motor vehicle code. But that bill also carried an unexpected provision: a law that would have prevented municipalities from having any control over local factory farms and their manure disposal. On New Year's Eve, Pennsylvania got a gift. Gov. Edward Rendell vetoed the bill, arguing that the state needed to address the question of manure disposal -- euphemistically called ''nutrient management'' -- in a more coherent manner than in a last-minute vote on a last-minute insertion into an unrelated bill.

title: Brooklyn Jurors Weigh Punitive Damages in Smoking Case
description: Alawyer for the widow of a longtime smoker urged Brooklyn jurors today to "send a message" to a tobacco company by imposing a large punitive-damage award in retribution for decades of hooking people on cigarettes that could kill them.

title: 7 at Chinese Paper Held After Articles on New SARS Case
description: BEIJING, Jan. 7  The police stormed the offices of one of China's feistiest newspapers and detained the top editor and six other officials in what many journalists regard as retribution for aggressive reporting on a recent SARS case, employees said today.

title: World Briefing | Europe: European Officials Meet On Agenda
description: Meeting in Dublin as the presidency of the European Union rotated to Ireland and to Prime Minister Bertie Ahern, Mr. Ahern, at right, and Romano Prodi of Italy, left, president of the other main branch of the union's government, the European Commission, addressed their clashing views about future negotiations for a new constitution. ''We cannot wait forever,'' Mr. Prodi said at a news conference, sitting next to Mr. Ahern. ''Europe cannot always go at the speed of the very, very slowest wagon.'' Mr. Prodi said that failure to agree on a constitution quickly would result in a ''two-speed'' Europe. Mr. Ahern said new talks must include all members, including 10 new nations set to join in May. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Harassment Charge To Be Investigated
description: City Council Speaker Gifford Miller has hired a private firm to investigate accusations of sexual harassment made against Councilman Allan W. Jennings Jr., of Queens, by two of his former aides. The firm, ADR Associates/JAMS will interview those involved in the case, and recommend how to address sexual harassment and discrimination complaints. Mr. Jennings has denied the accusations. The Council's Standards and Ethics Committee has also asked the city's Department of Investigations to review the matter. Council officials have said the speaker was told of rumors of a sexual harassment complaint in June, but did not learn that it concerned Mr. Jennings until the councilman's aides filed a complaint with the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission in December. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ETHRIDGE, JAMES MURDOCK III.
description: ETHRIDGE--James Murdock III. Age 83. Died peacefully at home after a lengthly illness on January 5, 2004. He is survived by his beloved wife Ann, his children James M. Ethridge IV, Judy Goodale, Brooke Cort and step-daughter Sybil Hajek, six grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. He graduated from Andover in 1938 and Yale University in 1942 and served proudly as a captain in the U.S. Army during World War II. He was the President of Howe Furniture Corporation in New York City. He grew up in Greenwich, Ct., where he was a longtime member of the Greenwich Field Club. He was the national doubles squash racquets champion in 1956 and 1957. Upon retirement, he moved to Hobe Sound, Fla. where he was currently a member of the Loblolly Club. His love for children lead him to become a mentor for many years at local elementary schools, where he enjoyed spending and giving his time. He will be greatly missed by all of those who knew him and loved this gentle man. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, January 10 at 11:30AM at Christ Memorial Chapel on Jupiter Island. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in his name to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, Box 4777, Grand Central Station, New York, N.Y. 10163.

description: A woman was fatally hit by a truck as she crossed the Avenue of the Americas yesterday morning, the police said. The accident occurred at 6:45 a.m., the police said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

description: A 120,000-square-foot office and retail building being completed in Jamaica Estates, Queens, illustrates how an aging structure with high vacancies and little curb appeal can be transformed into a profitable complex that has drawn national tenants, among them a Barnes & Noble bookstore scheduled to open in May. The building, known as Utopia Center, is at 176-60 Union Turnpike at the corner of Utopia Parkway.

description: Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron, has tentatively agreed to plead guilty to fraud charges and has provided evidence against another former high-ranking executive who is expected to face criminal charges as soon as this week, people involved in the case said yesterday.

title: U.S. Officials Plan to Release Iraqis Who Pose Just 'Some Risk'
description: The American-led government is expected to announce on Wednesday that it will release 506 detainees in Iraq who still pose ''some risk'' but who have not engaged in violence against occupation forces, senior military and government officials said Tuesday.

title: Army Official Backs Halliburton on Fuel Price
description: An Army Corps of Engineers official overseeing Halliburton's imports of fuel into Iraq from Kuwait has found that the company has ''continued to negotiate the best price possible'' for the fuel and has also provided information indicating that the prices paid are ''fair and reasonable.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Teacher Charged With Felony
description: A New York City schoolteacher was arrested in Westchester County after he had sexually explicit conversations on the Internet with a detective posing as a teenage girl, the Westchester County district attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro, said yesterday. The teacher, Joseph Bovino, 54, of Baldwin Place, N.Y., had taught social studies at a special high school for students in their late teens and early 20's and has been on leave since November 2002 because of an injury, a school spokeswoman said. Mr. Bovino was charged with attempting to disseminate indecent material to a minor, a felony that carries a jail term of up to four years. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Power Failure
description: Residents of Springfield Gardens lost power for nearly three hours last night because of an electrical failure that Con Edison said was caused by a fallen power line. The power failure affected about 1,300 customers, according to Martha Liipfert, a Con Edison spokeswoman. The electricity went out around 8 p.m. in an area bounded by 131st and 147th Avenues and 181st and 225th Streets. It was restored at 10:45 p.m., Ms. Liipfert said. Norma Bracken, a resident of the area who emigrated from Venezuela 14 years ago, said power outages were common in her home country. ''Sometimes, these kind of things happen,'' she said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: The Hunt Through Dr. Dean's Past
description: It's a safe bet in American politics that any time a governor stands out in a run for the presidency, his or her statehouse record will be vetted furiously in a search for cronyism, hypocrisy and a fresh cast of colorful characters who promise the real truth about the candidate's past. Bill Clinton and George W. Bush went through this process and lived to inhabit the White House.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7  President Bush offered a plan today that he said would help millions of illegal immigrants working in the United States while also making the country more secure and prosperous and living up to its finest ideals.

title: Scientists in 'Awe' of Color Photos of Mars
description: The first color photography of the Spirit mission, made public on Tuesday, showed that the robotic rover was resting on a broad, ruddy plain of Mars among gray rocks of all sizes and shapes, streaks of windblown dust tracks, a patch of cohesive soil that looks like mud but cannot be and hills set against a pink sky on the distant horizon.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: East Orange: Policeman Charged With Misconduct
description: An East Orange police detective was indicted yesterday on charges that he overcharged the city more than $100,000 for computer supplies bought from fake corporations created by his family and friends. The detective, Norman Price, 45, of Bedminster, is charged with official misconduct and other offenses. Prosecutors said he was part of a scheme that began shortly after he was assigned in 2001 to help choose vendors to upgrade the Police Department's communications and computer equipment. Prosecutors said that Mr. Price's wife, Natasha McRae, 35, and a family friend, Vaughn Miller, 41, of North Plainfield, bought items like office furniture and computer software from legitimate businesses and resold them to the department through fake corporations at inflated prices. Ms. McRae and Mr. Miller were also charged in the indictment. Richard Lezin Jones

title: ENRON RECOVERY PLAN ALLOWED TO PROCEED
description: Enron, which owed more than $67 billion after collapsing into bankruptcy protection, can seek creditors' support for a recovery plan that gives them most of the energy company's assets, a federal judge ruled yesterday. The judge, Arthur Gonzalez, at a hearing in United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, approved Enron's description of its strategy for exiting Chapter 11, which would give creditors stock in companies holding Enron's overseas assets and North American natural gas pipelines, more than $7 billion in cash and proceeds from lawsuits. Enron can now send the proposal to creditors for a vote. With sufficient creditor support, Enron, which is based in Houston, can seek court authorization to leave bankruptcy.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Elizabeth: Voting Rights Of Ex-Convicts
description: The American Civil Liberties Union and several minority rights advocates filed suit yesterday, seeking to overturn a New Jersey law that prohibits convicted felons from voting after they have left prison and are serving terms of parole or probation. ''The purpose of the lawsuit is to expand democracy and expand voting rights,'' said Prof. Frank Askin, director of the Rutgers Constitutional Litigation Clinic and one of the lawyers who prepared the suit. ''Public policy favors reintegrating ex-offenders into society, including making them full participants in civic life. We don't believe the state has any justification in denying these people the right to vote.'' The suit contends that denial of voting rights to those on probation or parole violates the New Jersey Constitution's provisions guaranteeing equal protection under the law.

title: The Battle for Iran's Future
description: Looking back on three decades of international news coverage of Iran gives me a squeamish feeling. For a host of reasons -- historical-civilizational significance, geostrategic position, pre-eminence in the Persian Gulf and, not least, the still unfolding dynamism of the 1979 revolution -- Iran has consistently been at the center of international attention. So much so, in fact, that a decade ago the American scholar Graham Fuller called his book on Iran ''The Center of Universe.''

title: ESTE LAUDER GRANDSON NAMED CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: The Este Lauder Companies, the maker of Clinique and Bobbi Brown cosmetics, said yesterday that William Lauder, the grandson of the founder, Este Lauder, would become chief executive on July 1, succeeding Fred Langhammer. Mr. Lauder, 43, joined the cosmetics maker in 1986 and became chief operating officer last year. Mr. Langhammer, 59, had led the company since 2000 and will take on a new position, chairman for global affairs, the company said. title: For U.S. Aid, City Switches Reading Plan In 49 Schools

title: Blushing Beauty From Brittany Steps Ashore
description: Roscoff, on the coast of Brittany in western France, has just the right kind of soil and climate for growing onions. The specialty is a pinkish onion called Ros de Roscoff, and it deserves to be the center of attention. It is a mild onion with a mellow pungency. The French like these onions raw on open-face sandwiches. Chopped, they can top a salad or a canap. They are also good to marinate in an escabeche, to use in onion soup or to saut gently and fold into an omelet. The onions hold up well and do not sprout readily in a warm apartment. A 2.2-pound mesh bag is $4.89 at Fairway markets, where the onions are also sold loose for $2.99 a pound. A box of three onions weighing just under a pound is $2.99 at Agata & Valentina and $5 at Dean & DeLuca stores.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Rhodia Shares And Bonds Plunge
description: Shares of Rhodia S.A., a French chemical maker that has lost almost two-thirds of its value in the last year, dropped as much as 13 percent after Moody's Investor's Service cut the company's credit rating on concern that it might have to repay $290 million in bonds early. Shares fell 9.1 percent, to 3.18 euros in Paris ($4.02), after trading as low as 3.06 euros. Rhodia's bonds also plunged. The company, whose losses tripled in the third quarter as demand for chemicals slumped, is selling assets, planning to issue new shares and negotiating with bondholders as it seeks to avoid default. Moody's cut Rhodia's ratings on concern that the company may be forced into early repayment of the $290 million in bonds sold to hedge funds.

title: Carrying On A Conductor's Quixotic Tradition
description: When the iconoclastic conductor Jens Nygaard founded the Jupiter Symphony in 1979, he established an ideal programming recipe. Standard repertory works performed by young musicians, often with a name soloist, would be the immediate draw. But the programs would also include 19th- and early 20th-century rarities heard virtually nowhere else. The oddities quickly became the main reason to attend the orchestra's performances, as Nygaard no doubt hoped they would. The ensemble was so thoroughly steeped in Nygaard's personality that when he died in September 2001, it seemed unlikely the group would survive.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint PCS Adds Customers
description: The Sprint Corporation's PCS Group, a leading cellphone company, added 390,000 subscribers in the fourth quarter, defying some analysts' expectations that a new federal rule would hurt it. The monthly rate of customer defections was 2.7 percent, Sprint said, the same as in the third quarter, when PCS added 184,000 customers. Beginning Nov. 24, the Federal Communications Commission required cellphone companies to let customers keep their phone numbers when switching companies. The chief executive of the BellSouth Corporation, F. Duane Ackerman, said yesterday that Cingular Wireless, a joint venture of BellSouth and SBC Communications, also experienced less switching than forecast. Sprint plans to report full results on Feb. 3.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: F.C.C. Approves Fax Fine
description: The Federal Communications Commission approved a record $5.4 million fine against a California company for illegally faxing unsolicited advertisements. The commission said the Orange County-based company, Fax.com, violated federal rules for such advertisements 489 times, incurring a fine of $11,000 for each violation. The chairman of the commission, Michael K. Powell, said it was seeking to send a message to the senders of unsolicited faxes: ''Violate our rules and you will pay the consequences.'' Fax.com has said the restrictions violate its First Amendment rights. Officials did not return phone calls. John Files (NYT)

title: Campaign Briefing | The Democrats: Hands Off Wallets

''The lobbyists and insiders have built a brick wall around Washington,'' Mr. Edwards said in remarks at a community center. Mr. Edwards, who does not accept campaign contributions from registered lobbyists and political action committees, called on his rivals to follow suit. He said that on his first day in office he would sign executive orders or propose legislation to carry out his changes, which include stricter limits on the lobbying activities of former government officials and more open and frequent reporting of contacts between lobbyists and government officials. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

Mr. Nuzzo, who has 19 years in the Correction Department, is an assistant deputy warden. His lawyer, Joe Tacopina, said he planned to contest the judge's recommendation and, if necessary, appeal a decision to fire Mr. Nuzzo in State Supreme Court. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REHMAR, MICHAEL ISADORE, M.D., COL., USAF RETIRED
description: REHMAR--Michael Isadore, M.D., Col., USAF Retired, died at home on January 6th. Dr. Rehmar was born in Cleveland, Ohio, May 21, 1925. He graduated Glenville High School with honors and was selected for the V-12 Naval Officer-Training Program at Williams College during WW II, graduating Phi Beta Kappa. He attended the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, graduated in 1949, and did his post-graduate work in Internal Medicine at Cleveland's Mount Sinai Hospital. He greatly enjoyed a distinguished 28-year career in the Air Force, most as Hospital Commander. He was awarded the Legion of Merit Medal in 1973. As a flight surgeon, he established new medical facilities and communication sites around the world before retiring with the rank of Colonel in 1974. Dr. Rehmar joined General Electric in 1974 as New York area and International Medical Director, and first Corporate EAP Director, initiating a strong alcohol and substance abuse program for employees and training for managers. From 1975 to 1995, Dr. Rehmar worked at The New York Hospital and Cornell Medical College as Clinical Assistant Professor of Medicine teaching Physical Diagnosis to medical students and volunteering in the general medical clinic. In 1988, he received his certification in Addiction Medicine. He was a board member of the Alcoholism Council of New York and was instrumental in developing a training program for counselors. In 1991, he was appointed Medical Director of the Methadone Maintenance Clinic of Long Island Jewish Hospital and instituted changes for patients that continue today. He always believed that there was hope in recovery from addiction. Dr. Rehmar believed strongly in his work as an old fashioned physician, one who truly cared for his patients and their families. In 1993, Dr. Rehmar joined Frontier Insurance Company as Medical Director of Medical Malpractice Claims. He was active in the NY County Society of Internal Medicine and President for 2 years. He served on the Board of Directors of the NY County Medical Society from 1992-2001 and as Chair of the Committees on Public Health and By-Laws. His ability to listen, his intelligence and his sense of humor were his hallmarks. Michael's passion for music began in childhood with the family's wind-up Victrola and the Metropolitan Opera radio broadcasts. He had a natural ly beautiful voice and loved to sing. He had a strong Jewish identity and was a staunch supporter of Israel. Michael was devoted to the causes of peace and justice and single payer health care. He had a lifelong love of animals, especially of his Boxers, Bowden and Lady, and his cat, Program. Michael was a magnificent human being who taught and selflessly helped many. He is predeceased by his parents, Mamie and Solomon, and his twin sister, Anita Talbert. He is survived by his wife and best friend, Miriam Pollack; his children Ellen, Marc and Alan (Tamara); grandsons, Adam, Aaron, Alexander and Nolan; sister, Judith Millenson; nieces, Debra and Leslie Millenson; nephews, Jeffrey and Ellis Talbert, and families; cousins, Judith and David Botwin. Services will be at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 East 70th St on Friday, January 9, at 1 PM. Burial at Arlington National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the charity of your choice. Cleveland Plain Dealer, please copy

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Dam To Be Completed

Some analysts had predicted Mr. Abdullah, who took over from Mahathir Mohamad in October, would shelve the dam after he scrapped a $3.8 billion rail project, citing budget constraints. But Mr. Abdullah said the dam was too far along not to complete. Originally planned as a much larger project, the dam was shelved in 1997 with the outbreak of the Asian financial crisis, but not before displacing local tribes. Mr. Mahathir revived a scaled-down version in 2001. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Killed In Fire
description: An elderly man died in a fire in his apartment last night, a Fire Department spokesman said. The man, Craven Polk, 76, lived in a second-floor apartment in the rear of the building at 461 West 153rd Street. The fire started just after 6 p.m., when Mr. Polk was cooking dinner, neighbors said. Some neighbors said that the fire -- which burned for less than half an hour -- began after Mr. Polk sent his home attendant to the grocery store. The police said the fire did not appear suspicious. Mr. Polk, who worked for the Ford Motor Company, had lived in the building for more than 10 years, a tenant said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: One Diana Rumor Down

The coroner, Dr. John Burton, who was present at the post-mortem of the princess, told The Evening Standard that he had spoken out in an effort to set the record straight because of the ''absurd'' conspiracy theories swirling around. title: From Portugal With Flair
description: At a dinner party a decade ago, the Portuguese architect lvaro Siza, right, impressed Max Protetch, the Manhattan art dealer, with a sketch. ''It must have been on a tablecloth or napkin, because I didn't manage to grab it,'' Mr. Protetch said. Mr. Siza won the Pritzker Prize in 1992, but despite masterpieces like the Borges & Irmo Bank, in Vila do Conde, Portugal, below, he remains relatively unknown in the United States. But Mr. Siza is working alongside Frank Gehry on an expansion of the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena, Calif. title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: GARDEN CITY: CONVICTION DISMISSAL SOUGHT Citing disclosures in an award-winning documentary on the Long Island father and son convicted of molesting students, a lawyer filed a motion in Nassau County Court here on Wednesday to vacate the conviction of Jesse Friedman, left. His father, Arnold, who pleaded guilty to molesting computer students in Great Neck, died in prison. To avoid a longer sentence, the son also confessed, and was paroled after 13 years, said his lawyer, Earl H. Nemser. The film, "Capturing the Friedmans," claims that most of the students had denied being molested but that some changed their stories after being badgered by investigators. Had Jesse Friedman had that information, he would have contested the charges, Mr. Nemser said.   Bruce Lambert (NYT)

description: ETHRIDGE--James Murdock III. Age 83. Died peacefully at home after a lengthly illness on January 5, 2004. He is survived by his beloved wife Ann, his children James M. Ethridge IV, Judy Goodale, Brooke Cort and step-daughter Sybil Hajek, six grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. He graduated from Andover in 1938 and Yale University in 1942 and served proudly as a captain in the U.S. Army during World War II. He was the President of Howe Furniture Corporation in New York City. He grew up in Greenwich, Ct., where he was a longtime member of the Greenwich Field Club. He was the national doubles squash racquets champion in 1956 and 1957. Upon retirement, he moved to Hobe Sound, Fla. where he was currently a member of the Loblolly Club. His love for children lead him to become a mentor for many years at local elementary schools, where he enjoyed spending and giving his time. He will be greatly missed by all of those who knew him and loved this gentle man. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, January 10 at 11:30AM at Christ Memorial Chapel on Jupiter Island. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in his name to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, Box 4777, Grand Central Station, New York, N.Y. 10163.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIEBERMAN, ELWYN
description: LIEBERMAN -- Elwyn. The Officers and Members of Old Oaks Country Club mourn the passing of their dear friend and fellow Member Elwyn Lieberman. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his wife, to his children and other members of his family. Paul J. Konigsberg President

title: To Endorse or Not to Endorse? Harkin, an Iowa Power Broker, Is a Politician Torn
description: The most sought-after Democratic caucus-goer in Iowa is agonizing in this hamlet of 150, torn over whether to make what could be the most important endorsement in the state's still shifting presidential contest.

title: Sari, Right Number
description: Almost any room can benefit from a pick-me-up. And there is hardly a quicker way than to add sari-cloth curtains or a bedcover made from a vintage Indian wedding shawl. Bright stacks of fabric, originally cut for clothing, are neatly packed into Hello Sari, a small shop on the Lower East Side. The textiles, 80 inches long by 40 inches wide to 216 inches long by 42 inches wide ($45 to $175) are as suitable for window treatments as for tablecloths. The owner, Kris Jensen, a fashion stylist, and her husband, Akram Mughal, buy the textiles near Lahore, Pakistan. At 261 Broome Street (Orchard Street), (212) 274-0791. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Danny Whelan, Knicks Trainer, Is Dead at 84
description: Danny Whelan, the trainer for the Knicks' two National Basketball Association championship teams and for the Pittsburgh Pirates' 1960 World Series champions, died last Friday at the Mary Manning Walsh Home in Manhattan, a day before his 85th birthday.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Recall For Igniting Candles
description: A company in Wisconsin has recalled 92,000 novelty candles because some resin casings have ignited, federal officials said. The manufacturer, Lang Candles of Delafield, announced the recall along with the Consumer Product Safety Commission. Lang Candles said it had received information about nine incidents, including six that resulted in property damage. The company said that refunds were available at (888) 526-4011. John Files (NYT)

title: Nurse Seeks Deal in Serial Deaths: Naming Victims in Return for Life
description: Charles Cullen, the nurse who has claimed that he killed 30 to 40 patients in New Jersey and Pennsylvania during the past decade, has made a tantalizing offer to the teams of investigators trying to retrace his sprawling trail of victims.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRIGGIN, BARBARA
description: BRIGGIN--Barbara, 71, died January 6, of leukemia in New York City. She graduated from Sarah Lawrence College. Her commitment to education included years as a creative first grade teacher and tutor at the Ethical Culture School. At NYU Medical School, she taught reading and writing to disadvantaged high school students. She is survived by her brothers, Herb of Belvedere, CA and Clifford of Chestnut Hill, MA, a niece, two nephews and their families. A memorial will be held at Ethical Culture School, 33 Central Park West on January 14, at 4:30. An education fund was established by Barbara for her tutoree, Amanda Mayfield. Donations can be made to The Amanda Mayfield Fund and sent to Herb Briggin, 7 Cove Road Place, Belvedere, CA 94920.

title: Bush Calls On 2 States Crucial to Re-election
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  President Bush traveled today to Tennessee and Florida, probably the two most pivotal states in his 2000 victory, where he promoted his education program and raised more millions for his re-election campaign.

title: How to Grow Without a Lot of Capital
description: David Hartstein wanted to make his KaBloom chain of florists the Starbucks of flowers. But how? KaBloom, based in Woburn, Mass., owned 30 shops, mainly in New England, but building more seemed too risky. It had always been difficult for him to motivate store managers to put in long hours, and in a vivid display of the perils of expansion, a competitor with the same national aspirations as his, Gerald Stevens in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., went bankrupt by acquiring too many flower stores too fast.

title: US Airways Said To Be Pursuing Big Asset Sales
description: Less than a year after it emerged from bankruptcy protection, and facing stiff competition from low-fare competitors, US Airways is seeking buyers for a number of its assets, including its East Coast shuttle and possibly one of its three hubs, people who have been briefed on the airline's plans said last night.

title: In an Oil-Rich Land, Power Shortages Defy Solution
description: Nine months after the American-led invasion toppled Saddam Hussein, frequent breakdowns in supplies of fuel and electricity, especially in Baghdad, are defying attempts by both Iraqis and foreign occupiers to stitch together something resembling normalcy here.

title: Patrick Miller, 51, Avant-Garde Leader Of 'Antimusic' Band
description: Patrick Miller, a musician who led the experimental 1980's rock group Minimal Man, died on Dec. 14 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 51.

title: Israel and Libya Discussed Ties at Meeting
description: Israeli and Libyan officials held a secret meeting in December and discussed the possibility of ties between the longstanding enemies, Israeli officials said Wednesday.

title: Group Works to Promote Diversity on the Slopes
description: If Schone Malliet had his way, in dozens of American cities every Friday afternoon there would be a long line of buses waiting to take city dwellers to the snow-covered mountains.

title: Forgot Your Key? Say 'Open Sesame' With Your Fingertip
description: Ask anyone who has just been locked out of the house if the traditional door lock might be ripe for improvement, and be prepared for some attitude. But frustration over forgotten keys is just one incentive people may have to investigate the new Shepherd 210 Fingerprint Identification Doorlock, according to ArrowVision, the California biometrics company that makes it.

The Greater New York Bridge Association awards points for placing well in major competitions and adds them up to determine the champion.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: U.S. Invitation
description: President Bush telephoned the newly elected president, Mikhail Saakashvili, and invited him to visit Washington. Mr. Saakashvili studied law in the United States. The United States has a keen interest in the former Soviet republic, in large part because a crucial pipeline that crosses it is to open next year carrying Caspian oil from Azerbaijan to Turkey. Seth Mydans (NYT)

description: As the City Council started its new term yesterday, Speaker Gifford Miller turned a welcoming message to his members into a political attack on the man that he is likely to challenge in 2005, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

description: During his first six months in office, President Nstor Kirchner's relations with Argentina's business community were about as frosty as the icebergs of his native Patagonia.

description: Insurgents fired six mortar rounds late Wednesday at a United States military camp about 50 miles northwest of Baghdad, wounding 35 soldiers in an area used for living quarters, the military announced at midnight. It said the soldiers had been given first aid and evacuated for medical treatment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARTY, THOMAS F.
description: CARTY--Thomas F. on January 6, 2004 at the age of 85. Dear son of the late Thomas and Elizabeth (nee Finnegan). Brother of Joseph and the late Margaret C. Brock. Also survived by his cousins, nieces and nephews. A veteran of W.W. II, and past commander of the American Legion. President and owner of Carty Heating Corp, NYC, founded 1915 by his father. Thomas was an attorney, real estate investor, contractor and apartment house owner in Manhattan, Bronx, and Queens. He served as a former City Councilman of Yonkers, and Chairman of the Democratic Party of Westchester County. He had been a National President of the Mechanical Contractors Association of America, President of the Mechanical Contractors Association of NYC and President of Queens Daughters Day Care Center in Yonkers, New York. Reposing Thursday and Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Riverdaleon-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 9:45 at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment in Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: A Swirl of Calligraphy, A Bit of Art, a Bit of Magic
description: Yoshiaki Yuki, right, is a Tokyo artist who paints bold calligraphic-inspired designs on tables, screens, plates and bowls. He will open Gallery Gen, a shop and gallery in TriBeCa, tomorrow, stocked with antique pots as well as his own pieces. Above, from left: a three-panel screen with abstract Chinese characters painted on rice paper with charcoal ink ($22,000); red and white two-panel screens ($6,000 each); and a wooden rack ($864). Above right: Painted porcelain plates, 11 inches in diameter ($200 each), descend to a blue screen ($9,000) and a 19th-century pot ($8,182). Far right, an oval ceramic bowl, 14 inches by 19 inches, is $205.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SWEDEN: MAN ADMITS KILLING FOREIGN MINISTER A man being held by the police in the fatal stabbing of Foreign Minister Anna Lindh in September has admitted the crime, the chief prosecutor said. The lawyer for the suspect, Mijailo Mijailovic, a 25-year-old Swede of Yugoslavian origin, said that there was no political motivation behind Ms. Lindh's stabbing and that the crime was random. Prosecutors said that Mr. Mijailovic would be charged with murder on Monday and that a trial could follow within days. (AP)

title: India and Pakistan Agree to Talk
description: ''History has been made,'' Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the president of Pakistan, declared this week after signing an agreement to hold peace talks with top officials of India, its neighbor and adversary. The invocation of history may be premature, because the agreement to talk only returns these populous nuclear powers to where they were in 1999. But both the Indian and Pakistani leadership deserve credit for moving their countries a bit further back from the edge of war.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Dec. 31 about efforts by big companies to address shortfalls in their pension funds included one company erroneously among those that are expected to owe large contributions in the next two years. Ford says it contributed $1 billion in late 2003 and will not be required to make more contributions any time soon.

description: When a proposal called Reflecting Absence was submitted last year to the World Trade Center memorial site competition, there was one name on it: that of Michael Arad, a young architect for the New York City Housing Authority.

title: In Shift, Dean Starts Watching His Words
description: With a wary eye on Gen. Wesley K. Clark's rise in national and New Hampshire polls, Howard Dean's campaign has begun to limit his availability to the press, and the candidate himself is watching his words after several recent statements unleashed a storm of criticism from opponents.

title: U.S. Presses Iraqi Kurds to Compromise on Issue of Autonomy
description: The Bush administration, increasingly fearful of Iraq's breaking up along ethnic lines after the American occupation ends, is urging Kurdish leaders to compromise in their demand for a fully autonomous state in the north, administration officials said Wednesday.

title: Steuben Sells Some Classics
description: Two hundred pieces of vintage Steuben glass are for sale at the Steuben store, 667 Madison Avenue (61st Street). Before 1933, Steuben produced only colored glass designed by Frederick Carder, the company president. In 1933, a design staff started producing clear modern pieces to compete with Scandinavian designs. The vintage pieces are all out of production. Most are colored glass from the 1920's and 30's; the most recent clear piece is from 1950. A clear cigarette urn is $250; eight amethyst-colored dinner plates are $3,200; a blue perfume bottle similar to the one at right is $1,500. The exhibition ''Glass and Glamour: Steuben's Modern Moment'' is at the Museum of the City of New York (Fifth Avenue and 103rd Street) until April 24. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Subway To Remove Scrap Rails
description: Transit officials have decided to remove all scrap rail pieces throughout the subway system after a preliminary investigation into why a discarded 20-foot section of rail pierced the bottom of a subway car on Monday. No one was hurt. Rail pieces extracted during replacement work are often nailed down in the trough between tracks so they can be removed later. About a thousand rail pieces were inspected during the investigation, said Charles F. Seaton, a New York City Transit spokesman. Michael Luo (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DONOHUE, FRANCES RICH
description: DONOHUE--Frances Rich, 90, January 6, 2004, of Guilford, CT and formerly of Guilderland, NY and NYC. Wife of the late Charles D. Donohue. Beloved Mother of Charles D. Jr. (Beverly) of NYC and Helen Donohue Higgins (Edmund) of Guilford. Also survived by four grandchildren, Wendy and Andrew Higgins, and Michael and Philip Donohue. Private services and burial in Woodlawn Cemetery, NY. For information, contact Guilford Funeral Homes, Guilford, CT.

title: Powell, Back After Surgery, Defends His Call for Iraq War
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell today offered a vigorous defense of his United Nations presentation last year on the need to wage war against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, even as new criticism emerged and some American weapons inspectors have left Iraq empty-handed.

title: In a Sign of Progress, the Red Storm Keeps It Close
description: The incremental progress St. John's had made under the interim coach Kevin Clark was there again Wednesday night. The Red Storm was not embarrassed by Syracuse, the defending national champion and the 17th-ranked team in the country. That means something, but the reality remains that St. John's is not nearly talented enough to beat a team like Syracuse.

title: City Settles Suit and Will Take Back Students
description: The New York City Department of Education has settled a federal lawsuit charging that it illegally forced hundreds of struggling students out of Franklin K. Lane High School in recent years.

title: Businessman Found Guilty of U.S. Tax Charges
description: Jurors found a Texas businessman who has not withheld taxes from his workers' paychecks since 2000 guilty on Wednesday on 29 federal charges.

title: MONSANTO SAYS LOSS WIDENED BUT LESS THAN EXPECTED
description: The Monsanto Company, the world's biggest developer of genetically engineered crops, said its fiscal-first-quarter loss was not as wide as the company had expected, as orders from the United States and Brazil increased seed sales. It said its net loss widened to $97 million, or 37 cents a share, in the period that ended on Nov. 30, compared with a loss of $18 million, or 7 cents, a year earlier. Excluding costs to shed units and to lay off workers, Monsanto said it had a profit of 4 cents a share, compared with the average estimate of a penny from analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. The company said its revenue rose 22 percent, to $1.03 billion, in the quarter as rising commodity prices prompted farmers to buy more seeds and pesticides.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: Shareholders Challenge Retailer
description: The food retailer Royal Ahold said it had received a summons to appear before a Dutch court in connection with demands by the shareholders association VEB that it revise its results over a five-year period. VEB is asking the company to nullify annual reports from 1998 through 2002, saying Ahold failed to disclose critical information to shareholders. VEB is asking a judge to, among other things, force Ahold to reveal more information about bonuses paid to executives at its American Foodservice subsidiary, which played a major role in the $1.2 billion accounting scandal. Ahold called VEB's claims unfounded. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDSTEIN, HELEN
description: GOLDSTEIN -- Helen. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of a deeply cherished Jewish communal leader, the wife of Rabbi Leonard Goldstein, and the proud mother of two sons from whose endeavors she derived much satisfaction. Heartfelt condolences are extended to Rabbi Goldstein, and Michael Fried and Arthur Fried, Chairman of the Board of the Avi Chai Foundation which has supported the Graduate Program for Women in Advanced Talmudic Studies at Stern College for Women, and the training of principals at the Azrieli Graduate School of Jewish Education and Administration. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman Board of Trustees

description: POLONER--Eleanor ''Elkie'' (nee Berkowitz), on January 7, 2004. Loving, devoted wife of the late Fred ''Poppy''. Loved and adored by children, grandchildren, great grandchildren, nieces, nephews, relatives and friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVIA, JUDITH HIDLER
description: SILVIA--Judith Hidler, 63, died December 28 at home in Newport, RI. She was the wife of James M. Silvia, a teacher at St. Bernard's School, NYC. Her first marriage to Jack Richardson, author and playwright, ended in divorce. She was most recently executive director of The Ann Norton Sculpture Gardens at West Palm Beach, FL. She had a long career in the arts in NYC, being associated with the Sonnabend Gallery, Pace Gallery, and Sidney Janis Gallery. In 1975 she became the first executive director of the Newport Art Association and Museum and held that position until 1977 when she and her husband moved to Yokohama, Japan where she became consultant to Green Collections. Over the years, she advised and set up over 500 one man and group exhibits in this country, Europe, and Japan. She is listed in Who's Who of American Women and Who's Who in American Art. Mrs. Silvia was the last of the line of Hidlers who colonized Pennsylvania in the 17th century. Donations may be made to The Redwood Library and Athenaeum, 50 Bellevue Ave, Newport, RI, 02840.

title: BOISE CASCADE PLANS TO CLOSE ABOUT 40 STORES
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation said yesterday that it expects to close 40 to 45 retail stores this year and open 12 stores, including OfficeMax Express stores. The company, which is based in Boise, Idaho, said in a planned investor presentation attached to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it also plans to relocate 10 retail stores and to remodel 250 stores this year. Boise Cascade, which completed its acquisition of OfficeMax Inc. last month, did not say in the filing whether the store closings, relocations and remodelings would occur at OfficeMax or other retail stores.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Agreement To Share The Wealth
description: The government struck a deal with a rebel group to evenly divide oil revenues once their civil conflict -- Africa's longest -- ends. But the parties continue to tackle two remaining issues: how to share political power and the status of three contested areas. Washington is pushing hard for a conclusion to the talks. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Mid-Atlantic
description: PENNSYLVANIA: DEADLY CRASH ON INTERSTATE 80 About 50 vehicles crashed together on Interstate 80 late Tuesday, and six people were killed. The chain-reaction crash, about 65 miles northwest of Harrisburg, happened when a snowstorm caused a blinding whiteout. About 30 tractor trailers and 20 passenger vehicles were involved. The police said they could not reach all the vehicles involved until yesterday because of fires and spills of hazardous materials. Workers opened eastbound lanes of Interstate 80, but the authorities said westbound lanes would remain closed until further notice. (AP)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Greenmarket Director Fired
description: Nina Planck, the director of Greenmarket, New York's system of farmers markets, was dismissed on Tuesday after 5 1/2 months on the job, said Lys McLaughlin, the executive director of the Council on the Environment of New York City, the organization that oversees Greenmarket. Ms. McLaughlin and Ms. Planck did not comment on the reason for the dismissal. Tom Strumolo, the former deputy director, has been named the new director. Amanda Hesser (NYT)

description: The Food and Drug Administration has notified a maker of silicone breast implants that it is not ready to approve the devices and has revised its guidelines for breast implant makers, asking for more and different data to address implant safety.

title: Corrections
description: A grouping of thumbnail sketches on Dec. 31 with a front-page article about the economic proposals of the Democrats seeking the presidential nomination referred incorrectly to Gen. Wesley K. Clark's plans for spending on large health care programs. He has indeed offered specifics: $695 billion over 10 years, partly to guarantee coverage to all uninsured Americans under 22 and to subsidize insurance for those who have trouble paying for it. The sketches also misstated the positions of John Edwards and Howard Dean on Nafta. They say they will indeed renegotiate it and other trade agreements.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: GUATEMALA: PACT WITH U.N. Guatemala and the United Nations signed a agreement that would allow a United Nations-appointed commission to prosecute organized crime and rights abuse cases. The pact, still to be approved by the Guatemalan Parliament, was signed by Edgar Gutierrez, the foreign minister, and Kieran Prendergast, the United Nations undersecretary general for political affairs. (Reuters)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YAHR, DR. MELVIN
description: YAHR--Dr. Melvin. On 1st January, 2004. He founded the World Federation of Neurology Research Group dedicated to Parkinsonism and Related Disorders. The first meeting was in 1959. Dr. Yahr chaired the Research Group until its 14th International Congress in 2001. The congresses grew from 50 neurologists and scientists to 2,300. Dr. Yahr helped plan each congress and he attended every one of them. Dr. Yahr's impact can be judged from letters just received. For example, Dr. Mizuno, (Japan) wrote: ''Melvin was a real pioneer clinician and scientist in the field of Parkinson's disease.'' Dr. Melamed, (Israel) wrote: ''His death represents the loss of a great teacher, and, for me personally, the loss of a father-figure. His memory will be cherished.'' Dr. Stoicchi (Italy) wrote: ''Melvin Yahr will remain in the memory of all those who were lucky enough to meet him, and all those concerned with the history of Parkinson's disease''. Dr. Manyam, (USA) wrote: ''Mel was a source of inspiration for us.'' Dr. Kishore (India) wrote: ''I gratefully remember his enthusiastic and encouraging letters in reply to applications for travel grants for young scientists, and the look of great satisfaction when I met him personally.'' Donald Calne, Chair World Federation of Neurology Research Group on Parkinsonism and Related Disorders

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VALSAMIS, MARIUS P.

title: Punitive Award Sought for Smoker's Widow
description: A Brooklyn jury should ''send a message'' to a tobacco company and punish it for decades of hooking people on deadly cigarettes by granting a large damage award to the widow of a longtime smoker, the woman's lawyer argued yesterday.

title: Rockets Seek to Uncover Yao's 7-Foot-6 Mean Streak
description: When Carroll Dawson, the general manager of the Houston Rockets, met Yao Ming two years ago, one of the first questions he asked him was, ''Why don't you dunk the ball?''

title: U.S. Rescinds Ban on Bids By WorldCom
description: The federal government said yesterday that it had lifted a ban that prevented WorldCom from bidding on new government contracts but that it would continue to scrutinize the company's ethics and accounting practices.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Glaxo Estimates Tax
description: The drug maker GlaxoSmithKline said that a decade-long tax dispute with the United States might cost it more than $5 billion and that the company intended to contest the government's claims in court. The Internal Revenue Service is demanding $2.7 billion in taxes on profits the company earned from 1989 to 1996, before the merger that formed the company. Glaxo said it would be responsible for another $2.5 billion in interest if the I.R.S. is successful, raising the tax liability to more than two-thirds of last year's profit. The dispute concerns the way Glaxo priced its Zantac ulcer medicine and other drugs for sale through its American unit.

title: National Briefing: South
description: GEORGIA: TEN COMMANDMENTS IN NEW COURTHOUSE DISPUTE Barrow County, which is fighting a suit by the American Civil Liberties Union over a poster of the Ten Commandments in the county courthouse, has removed a display with Hindu, Muslim and other writings that a resident installed last week. Officials left the poster. The head of the Barrow County Commission, Eddie Elder, said the new freestanding display boards about other religions could blow over and hinder pedestrians. Saying no one had the right "to change the facts of the pending lawsuit," Mr. Elder also placed a moratorium on further religious displays until the A.C.L.U. case is resolved. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Corrections

title: Sports of The Times; Gibbs Makes Redskins A Relevant Team Again
description: BACK when Washington had a major league baseball team, the usually woebegone Senators, the sports joke there was that the nation's capital was ''first in war, first in peace and last in the American League.'' title: Technology Briefing | Software: JDA Shares Plunge
description: Shares of the JDA Software Group, whose retail-management programs are used by clients including the Kroger Company, fell about 16 percent yesterday after fourth-quarter profit missed analysts' forecasts. JDA shares dropped $2.97, to $15. They gained 71 percent last year. Some deals failed to be completed, and sales fell in Europe and Asia, JDA said. Its software helps retailers manage inventory, receipts and returns, according to Hoover's Inc. Excluding some costs, profit was 4 cents or 5 cents a share on sales of about $55 million, JDA said. Analysts expected 11 cents, excluding some costs, on sales of $59.3 million, the average estimates in Thomson Financial surveys. Net income was break-even or a penny a share. A year earlier, net income was 3 cents a share on revenue of $53.3 million.

title: New Jersey Senate to Weigh Measure on Same-Sex Unions
description: A measure that would establish legal recognition and expand benefits for same-sex couples is expected to undergo intense debate on Thursday in the New Jersey State Senate. Both Democrats and Republicans say the legislation will win approval, and Gov. James E. McGreevey wants to sign it before the Legislature convenes on Tuesday, a spokesman said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bronx Man Fatally Stabbed
description: A Bronx man was fatally stabbed by a homeless man in a subway station yesterday, the police said. The two men were quarreling inside the 14th Street station of the Sixth Avenue subway line about 4:50 a.m., when the homeless man, Lloyd Koulen, stabbed the other man four times in the chin, the police said. The victim, John A. Wilson, 41, died in the station. Mr. Koulen, 28, was arrested and charged with second-degree murder, the police said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Music Deal For Roxio And Target
description: Roxio, owner of the Napster music-sharing service, and two other companies said yesterday that the Target Corporation would begin selling packages of software and computer disks that let people buy, download and record music over the Internet. Roxio, Imation and Case Logic will begin selling the combined product on Feb. 15 at Target's stores and Web site, Roxio said. Imation will provide the recordable disks; Case Logic, the CD cases; and Roxio and Napster will package recording software and access to downloadable music. The agreement will help Roxio, whose Napster service competes with bigger companies including Apple Computer, to sell downloadable music to a wider range of consumers. Apple, the maker of iPod digital music players, said Tuesday that it had sold more than 30 million songs at its iTunes online store. Roxio began selling music through Napster on Oct. 29, and by Nov. 7, the company said that it had sold 300,000 songs and that the unit would have revenue of $5 million in the quarter that ended in December.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZALAZNICK, EDWARD PHILLIP
description: ZALAZNICK--Edward Phillip. Perished in a plane crash on January 2 along with his beloved wife Isabelle Fouchard and three adored sons, David (12), Paul (9), Thomas (TT) (6). In addition, six members of the Fouchard family also died. Ed was a graduate of Scarsdale, NY High School, Tufts University (Summa Cum Laude and Phi Beta Kappa), and NYU Law School. In New York, he was an Associate at Shulte, Roth and Zabel. The family moved to Paris in 1994 and Ed joined Elf Aquitaine (now TotalFina) as a specialist in Mergers/ Acquisitions and the SEC. He was recently named Chief of the Division. The tragedy occurred at the end of a family vacation at Sharm-El-Sheik. In a New Year's call to his mother Gilda Gellin Zalaznick, he described the awe of all 11 family members watching the sunrise on Mt. Sinai after climbing the mountain together. Ed was a renaissance man. He could have been a writer, a painter, a teacher, a chef he was all of these things. But mainly, he was a principled man, who believed in the goodness of his fellow humans and who tried to live every day to the fullest. He was a wonderful husband, father, son, sibling and especially a friend. His survivors include his mother, his sister Dana Grossman (Lee), his brother Brian (Bobby), two nephews Steven Gorel and Benjamin Zalaznick, his brother-in-law David Fouchard (who had been unable to make the trip with the family) and hundreds of friends. His life was a blessing, one we will never forget. Dana Zalaznick Grossman will host a gathering Thursday between 6 and 9 P.M., 34 Sherwood Road, Greenwich. A Memorial service will be held in the future. Contributions in Ed's memory can be made to The Gellin Foundation, Inc., of which Ed was a Trustee, 29 Beechcroft Road, Greenwich, CT 06830, or to a charity of your choice.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Conviction Dismissal Sought
description: Citing disclosures in an award-winning documentary on the Long Island father and son convicted of molesting students, a lawyer filed a motion in Nassau County Court here on Wednesday to vacate the conviction of Jesse Friedman, left. His father, Arnold, who pleaded guilty to molesting computer students in Great Neck, died in prison. To avoid a longer sentence, the son also confessed, and was paroled after 13 years, said his lawyer, Earl H. Nemser. The film, ''Capturing the Friedmans,'' claims that most of the students had denied being molested but that some changed their stories after being badgered by investigators. Had Jesse Friedman had that information, he would have contested the charges, Mr. Nemser said. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Mars Photos Tempt Scientists With Vast Areas for Exploration
description: Geologists examining the latest pictures from the Spirit rover on Mars said on Wednesday that they were finding tempting targets for close-up exploration in each new view of the russet landscape and were becoming increasingly puzzled over how to read the rocks as an archive of the planet's more dynamic and warmer history.

title: A Vital Immigration Debate
description: President Bush has now waded into one of the most turbulent and emotional issues of our day: immigration reform. He had barely thrown out the first hints of a new guest worker program yesterday when it came under a noisy assault from both conservatives and advocates for immigrants. For simply reopening what has always been a torturous debate in this country, the president deserves applause. He has recognized that the nation's immigration system is, as he put it, ''broken.''

title: Campaign Briefing | The Democrats: Embracing Themes
description: Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts, beginning a two-day swing through New Hampshire to talk to workers about his economic plans, said he would create a White House ''director of family economic security'' to guard workers' pensions and savings, protect them from identify theft and ensure fair lending and housing. In Bedford, he unveiled a workers' bill of rights, a new umbrella for his proposals on taxes, health care, trade and workplace issues. Its 10 items are less a set of legislative measures than ''a group of efforts and initiatives and ethics that we embrace,'' Mr. Kerry said. The New Hampshire trip is Mr. Kerry's last until the Jan. 19 caucuses in Iowa, where he is concentrating his efforts in hopes of an unexpectedly strong showing.
