title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel Shares Surge On Verizon Venture
description: Shares of the Nortel Networks Corporation, North America's largest maker of telephone equipment, rose 19 percent yesterday after Verizon Communications selected Nortel to provide equipment for Internet-based phone calls. The companies agreed to initial terms of a contract and expect to sign a five-year agreement on converting Verizon's network with new packet switches and other Web-calling gear in the next few months, they said. A Verizon spokesman, Mark Marchand, would not say how much the contract was worth. Nortel expects to report a profit for 2003 after net losses of more than $35 billion in the preceding five years. Nortel is winning orders as carriers upgrade networks with packet-switching technology, which compresses voice and data traffic so it can be sent together over high-speed lines. Shares of Nortel, based in Brampton, Ontario, rose 92 cents, to $5.68. The shares are down from a high of $89 in July 2000. Verizon shares rose 8 cents, to $36.56.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: AOL Introduces Low-Priced Access Service
description: The America Online unit of Time Warner is selling a dial-up service for $9.95 a month, less than its flagship AOL product, to compete with cheaper Internet providers. The new service carries the Netscape name to distinguish it from AOL, which offers more features and costs $23.90 a month, executives said. The company introduced the Netscape product yesterday at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. America Online, based in Dulles, Va., lost two million customers last year as people migrated to cheaper or faster Internet connections. By entering the growing discount market, America Online is attempting to fend off rivals like United Online, which are luring cost-conscious consumers. America Online has made forays into discount Internet access. It offers unlimited access for $19.95 a month under its CompuServe brand, and has a partnership with Wal-Mart Stores to provide access under the Wal-Mart name for $9.94 a month.

New York City Transit has until 2020 to make 100 stations accessible for wheelchairs, the report said. It included a July letter from the president, Lawrence G. Reuter, which said that New York City Transit was considering some of the report's suggestions. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: In Subatomic Tracking, Clues to the Unseen Universe
description: An experiment that tracks subtle motions of subatomic particles called muons has found tantalizing evidence for a vast shadow universe of normally unseen matter existing side by side with ours, scientists at the Brookhaven National Laboratory said yesterday.

description: Bingham Ray, an independent film stalwart who took over United Artists less than three years ago in the hope of turning it into a leading art house boutique, resigned late Thursday.

title: Kurdish Autonomy in Iraq
description: By promising to hand over political authority in Iraq to Iraqis on June 30, the United States sent a useful message about its desire to lower its profile there and forced Iraqis to get to work on a constitutional structure and an electoral system. Unfortunately, the door is now open to radical forces, which in volatile situations and in the face of short timetables tend to be the best organized, with the clearest agendas. Washington needs to do all it can to block the radicals' path -- and postpone the handover if certain conditions are not met.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: PETERSON TRIAL WILL BE MOVED A judge ruled that Scott Peterson, who is accused of murdering his pregnant wife and their unborn son, should be tried in a city other than Modesto because jurors in Modesto, Mr. Peterson's hometown, might be prejudiced against him. The case, in which Mr. Peterson, left, is accused of killing his wife, Laci, around Christmas Eve 2002 and dumping her body into San Francisco Bay, has generated national publicity and turned him into a controversial figure in Modesto. The judge, Al Girolami, did not name an alternative city in his decision but said a judicial panel would pick one. The trial was originally scheduled to begin on Jan. 26.   (Reuters)

title: Talent On Display, Buyers In Town

title: 'Embarrassed,' Rose Says About Betting on Baseball
description: Pete Rose has always loved to talk. About baseball. About himself. About everything. The walking, talking, infamous legend has grudgingly added a humiliating subject to his conversations after admitting in a new book that he bet on baseball games. For 14 years, Rose had publicly denied that he gambled on baseball while managing the Cincinnati Reds.

Services will be held Friday, January 9, at 11:15AM, at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Simkanin, 59, was found guilty late Wednesday on 29 federal charges stemming from his refusal to withhold taxes from the paychecks of the 49 employees of his company, Arrow Custom Plastics, the filing of fraudulent tax refund claims, and refusal to file personal returns.

description: As Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled his proposal yesterday to send $400 property tax rebate checks to city homeowners, taxpayers exulted but some fiscal experts questioned whether the move was good policy.

Beloved mother of Laura Labaton, adoring grandmother of Mark and Stephen Labaton, doting great-grandmother of Max and Ellie. She was fiercly courageous and independent, unboundedly devoted to her family, and optimistic and uplifting even in the worst of times. title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GREECE: FOREIGN MINISTER SEEKS LEADER'S POST Foreign Minister George Papandreou formally declared himself a candidate to replace Prime Minister Costas Simitis as leader of the governing party, the Pan-Hellenic Socialist Movement, better known as Pasik. The move was widely expected. The party is counting on Mr. Papandreou to turn the tide against the conservative New Democracy Party, which has a 7 percent opinion poll lead ahead of the general election on March 7. (Reuters)

title: Plan May Lure More to Enter U.S. Illegally, Experts Say
description: When President Ronald Reagan signed into law the last great shake-up in immigration policy, his goal was to stop the flow of illegal immigrants. The flow increased instead, and that may be the response to President Bush's guest worker plan, if Congress enacts it, various experts say.

title: Mother and Girl, 2, Die in New Haven Fire
description: A woman and her 2-year-old daughter died in a fire last night in New Haven a spokesman for the New Haven Police Department said.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Mother Of Heroin Seller Charged
description: An 11-year-old girl who was observed selling heroin should not be prosecuted, South Miami police recommended, though they asked prosecutors to add child endangerment to the drug charges lodged against the girl's mother. The state's attorney's office said it was inclined to agree. The mother, Alison L. Davis, 36, was arrested last week on drug trafficking charges after the police watched her daughter deliver heroin to buyers while she was dressed in her school uniform or nightgown. The girl and her 7-year-old sister have been placed in foster care by social services officials. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Supreme Court Expands Review of Enemy Combatant Cases
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  The Supreme Court stepped squarely into a momentous debate over national security and personal liberty today by agreeing to consider the case of a man who has been held without charges by the United States military since he was captured in the fighting in Afghanistan.

title: Suspect in Four Family Deaths Is Found Shot
description: A Georgia man who the police say killed four people and fled with three girls was found shot yesterday after a police chase near the Georgia-Tennessee line, the authorities said. The girls appeared to be unharmed.

title: Balanchine With Views Both Austere And Imperial
description: ''Balanchine 100: The Centennial Celebration'' continued at the New York State Theater on Wednesday night, when the New York City Ballet presented three works by George Balanchine that offered his personal interpretations of dance history and style.

title: Enron And the System
description: Two years after Enron, then one of America's most admired companies, was revealed as a fraud, prosecutors finally seem to be getting somewhere. Andrew Fastow, the company's former chief financial officer, and his wife, Lea, are reported to be engaged in plea-bargaining. Mr. Fastow's testimony will probably lead to charges against other former Enron executives.

title: Brian Gibson, 59, a Director Of Movies and TV Shows
description: Brian Gibson, the British film and television director known for his inspiring early collaborations with the writer Dennis Potter and for an eclectic array of projects ranging from Hollywood studio films to television documentaries, died on Sunday in London, said Ann Louise Bardach, a family friend. He was 59 and lived in London and Los Angeles.

title: Putting the Sex Trade on Notice
description: Around the world, about one million women and children are seduced into leaving their homelands every year and forced into prostitution or menial work in other countries. Most are duped with promises of good jobs in more prosperous nations. These cases are not confined to remote parts of the world. Of the 15 nations the State Department listed last year as having done little or nothing to stop this growing human rights abuse, five of the worst offenders were in the Western Hemisphere: Belize, Cuba, the Dominican Republic, Haiti and Suriname.

title: Turn-Ons: Classical Concerts. Turnoffs: Sticker-Shock Tickets.
description: There is much fretting in the land of high culture about aging audiences. At classical-music concerts and operas, or so the worry goes, you see nothing but bent old people. Where is the surging vitality of youth? Where are the audiences of tomorrow, in a nation with crippled arts education? Where (and here the real fears lie, you suspect) are the donors of tomorrow?

description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil's Happy Dance Party, In Session on Avenue C
description: After the predominating samba, forr is the 20th-century popular music from Brazil that won't subside. You hear it all over the country, and despite its age and earthiness, that's not embarrassing; it remains genuinely popular. It may have taken 60 years, but now it's cool in the East Village, too.

title: Sports Authority Hires Cliff Freeman
description: The Sports Authority in Englewood, Colo., yesterday named Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York as agency of record on its account, which had been handled since 2000 by the Tampa, Fla., office of West Wayne. Billings were estimated at $80 million.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS

title: Tide of Second Thoughts Rises Among Democrats
description: Only a few weeks ago, Jenny Briggs, an Iowa State University graduate, was all set to enthusiastically support Howard Dean in the caucuses. But now, with the vote 11 days away, Ms. Briggs said she is having second thoughts as she watches Dr. Dean stumble through his difficult days of the presidential contest.

title: The Bishops Seek Recovery
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops have taken a praiseworthy but sadly belated first step toward putting in place safeguards against the scourge of rogue priests, whose sexual abuse of children was hushed up for decades. In releasing an audit claiming improvements in most of the 191 dioceses studied, the bishops underlined how far they still had to go to repair the deep damage to the church's reputation. The audit makes clear that outreach programs for victims remain lacking in many dioceses, as are programs for ensuring safer parishes and adequately tracking abusers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MYERS, HENRY F.
description: MYERS--Henry F. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Henry F. Myers, associated with The Times from 1953 until retiring in 1989.

title: Real Life Behind 'Monster': A Serial Killer's Last Days
description: Any documentary that focuses on the final days of a prisoner locked on death row is inescapably tinged with voyeurism, no matter how high-minded its intentions. Nick Broomfield's ''Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer,'' which chronicles the courtroom shenanigans that led up to the Florida execution of Aileen Wuornos on Oct. 9, 2002, is an absorbing film, partly because its subject exudes a scary charisma. But even though its portrait of Wuornos is sympathetic, the movie still carries a ghoulish taint, especially when the camera zooms in for extreme close-ups of her stricken face.

title: Bids for Strong Capital Expected to Be About $900 Million
description: About a dozen suitors have signaled their intention to bid as much as $900 million for the assets of Strong Capital Management, one of the mutual fund companies caught up in an investigation into improper trading, according to executives close to the auction.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Denmark: Big Loss For Lego
description: Lego, the European maker of the popular building blocks, posted a record pretax loss of 1.4 billion kroner ($239 million) for 2003 and fired its deputy chief executive, Poul Plougmann, after losing market share. Lego said it would cut its management team to nine people from 14 and is seeking to eliminate more jobs, Jorgen Vig Knudstorp, head of corporate affairs, said in a telephone interview. Disappointing sales of items inspired by the popular Harry Potter books were among the main reasons for last year's loss, Mr. Knudstorp said. Revenue fell 25 percent, to 8.5 billion kroner, and Kjeld Kirk Kristiansen, owner of the privately held company, said Lego lost market share.

title: Financial Firms Are Bush's Biggest Donors, Study Reports
description: A new study released Thursday shows that employees and political action committees of brokerages, banks and credit companies make up 6 of President Bush's top 10 career contributors, a clear indicator of his increasing support from the financial sector.

title: Credit Rating Downgraded At Westchester Hospital
description: The troubled Westchester Medical Center lost more than twice as much money last year as it had anticipated, according to financial analysts studying the company. The finding has led a credit rating agency to downgrade the rating on a large portion of the center's $278 million in long-term debt to one step above junk.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about a proposal by President Bush to overhaul immigration laws misstated the number of green cards issued per year. It is 675,000 (140,000 is the number of employment-based visas). An article yesterday about the proposal also included an incorrect total from the Immigration Service. The article on Wednesday also referred imprecisely in some copies to the amount of time Mr. Bush proposes that undocumented workers could participate in a guest worker program. While the White House indeed did not specify the time, it did offer workers the option of three years, plus a chance to renew for three years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIDES, PATRICIA A.
description: SIDES--Patricia A. Died in her sleep January 1, 2004, after a long illness. Born in Cyprus, she was raised in California in Riverside and San Mateo, and educated at Pomona College, Stanford University and Universita' di Firenze. An adventurous spirit, she combined her love of travel with writing and foreign language to create a career in television from the 1960s on. Over the next 30 years, residing in NYC, she won national and international awards as a producer/director/writer of documentary films. Her most recent work was as senior producer for the New York office of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and for arts news on MacNeil-Lehrer Newshour. Earlier for WNET/ 13, she produced two Emmy award-winning series: ''The New Immigrants'' and ''Skyline with Beverly Sills.'' For PBS, she produced a series hosted by Abba Eban on ''Heritage: Civilization and the Jews,'' a series by Bill Moyers on international issues and a series called ''Woman Alive!'' Documentaries for ABC included ''Directions'' and ''Make A Wish.'' She worked in collaboration with Downtown Community Television Center on films about people of other cultures from Cuba to Vietnam. Her independent production, ''Washington Square Wrap'' on the sculptor Francis Hines, has been rebroadcast many times since 1982. For the last several years, she devoted herself to volunteer work for New England Border Collie Rescue. Pat will be much missed by her beloved border collie, Katie, and her fellow rescuer and companion, Viv Ramos, as well as her many friends. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, January 13, 11 AM at the Church of the Resurrection, 119 E. 74 St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to New England Border Collie Rescue, c/o Jalyn White, 136 Edgemere Rd, Coventry, CT 06238.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZUNZ, SYLVIA M.
description: ZUNZ--Sylvia M., 81, of Fort Lee, NJ and Stockbridge, MA died Wednesday, January 7, 2004. Beloved and treasured wife of Lyonel E. Zunz for 58 years. Devoted and loving mother of Dr. Sharyn J. Zunz of Durham, NH and Gail C. Zunz of Arlington, MA. Dear sister of Marlene Facher of Nutley, NJ. She was cherished by her many other relatives and friends. She was a member of the Teaneck Jewish Center and a supporter of innumerable charitable and civic organizations. To know her was to love her. Services will be held at GuttermanMusicant Funeral Home, 402 Park St. Hackensack, NJ on Sunday at 12:30 PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to: The Community School, 11 Forest Ave. West, Teaneck, NJ 07666, or New York Presbyterian Hospital, Lenox Society, Church Street Station, Box 6412, NY, NY 10277-1172.

title: Ice Age Ancestry May Keep Body Warmer and Healthier
description: A team of California geneticists has found that many of the world's peoples are genetically adapted to the cold because their ancestors lived in northern climates during the Ice Age. The genetic change affects basic body metabolism and may influence susceptibility to disease and to the risks of the calorie-laden modern diet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHOMER, HELENE
description: SHOMER--Helene, 88, on January 4, 2004 (11 years to the day after her beloved husband Eddy's passing). Before retiring, she was a lifelong musician, playing violin for both the New York City Opera and the New York City Ballet orchestras for 47 years. Prior to that, during the bigband era, she worked with such well-known bands of the time as Jan Savitt, Skitch Henderson and Frank Sinatra. Before that, among her numerous other musical accomplishments, she was also a member of the prestigious All American Youth Orchestra conducted by the great Leopold Stokowski. She is survived by a son, Durer, his wife, Sally, and a sister, Ruth. A small gathering for family and close friends will be held at Beth El Cemetery in Paramus, New Jersey, on Sunday, January 11th, at 12:30 P.M. She touched many lives and will be deeply missed.

title: A First Daughter Longing for Normalcy
description: A high-born daughter who has an incognito fling with a working stiff who is aware of her disguise. This motif of romantic comedies like ''It Happened One Night'' and ''Roman Holiday'' is the theme of the pallid ''Chasing Liberty,'' which stumbles as it tries to stay in the footfalls of those earlier films.

title: Walking Tall on Hallway Beat; Growing Stature for Officers Who Patrol City Schools
description: A lot of police officers are not used to being touched. They are trained to keep suspects out of reach, far from their gun belts, their personal space, their bodies.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Setback For LG Card
description: The troubled credit card company LG Card was forced to halt cash advance services at most banks in the country as a liquidity shortage worsened. LG Card, strapped with about $17 billion in debt, temporarily halted all of its cash advance services in late November, until its creditors offered $2 billion in emergency loans to avert a bankruptcy. An LG Card spokesman said the liquidity crunch might worsen unless creditors offered more emergency loans. About 14 million South Koreans are LG Card holders, with many of them using cash advances obtained from credit cards to repay other loans. LG Card's 16 creditors have been unable to reach a decision on a costly rescue plan because of disagreements on how much each lender should provide and over who should manage the company. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Jobless Rate Falls
description: German unemployment fell for a fourth month in December, helped by government programs to increase self-employment and temporary work, as Europe's largest economy returned to growth in the second half of 2003. The number of jobless people fell a seasonally adjusted 21,000 from November to 4.34 million, the Federal Labor Agency said. The unemployment rate declined to 10.4 percent, the lowest in almost a year, from 10.5 percent.

title: World Briefing: South Pacific
description: NIUE: RELIEF SUPPLIES ARRIVE A New Zealand Air Force Hercules aircraft and two air ambulances touched down in Niue, carrying doctors and relief supplies to the tiny island nation after a cyclone destroyed homes, crops and the only hospital. One woman died when her house collapsed around her. Her seriously injured baby was found in the wreckage. (AP)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Woman Dies In Fire
description: A woman died and a firefighter suffered minor injuries in a fire in Washington Heights yesterday, a Fire Department spokesman said. The woman, Bertha Ortiz, 77, was found in her bedroom after the blaze tore through the fourth floor of her apartment building at 701 West 175th Street. She died from her injuries soon after, the spokesman said. The fire began about 4 p.m., said Melanie Gonzalez, 19, a tenant on the third floor. Neighbors ''started screaming and banging on the doors, telling everybody to get out,'' Ms. Gonzalez said. The landlord, Joshua Siegel, said the fire was probably caused by a lit cigarette. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

Mr. Kett fled, but was later arrested and charged with second-degree murder.

title: INSTINET SAYS IT WILL LAY OFF 185 WORKERS IN A REVAMPING
description: Instinet Group, the electronic stock brokerage firm, said yesterday that it would lay off 185 employees, or 15 percent of its work force, and reduce office space because of its decision to split the company's operations. Instinet said that the move would cost $60 million, and that it expected its cost cuts to eliminate $30 million in expenses in 2004. The company said most of the job reductions and office space consolidation would be completed by July. Last year, it said it would split its electronic trading business from its agency brokerage business, which seeks stock orders from mutual funds.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Buffalo: Doctor's Killer Said To Be Harassed
description: The lawyer for a man convicted of killing an obstetrician who performed abortions said in federal court yesterday that inmates were harassing his client. John Humann, a public defender representing James C. Kopp, left, on a charge of denying access to a clinic, told Judge Hugh B. Scott in federal court that inmates at a federal holding center in Batavia were threatening his client. Mr. Kopp was sentenced in May to 25 years to life after his conviction on state murder charges in the 1998 shooting death of Dr. Barnett A. Slepian. Mr. Kopp is in federal custody on the clinic charge. David Staba (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Former Swim Coach Arrested
description: The former coach of a girls' school swim team was arrested yesterday and accused of arranging to meet a 13-year-old girl for sex. The man, Ronny Seigle, 48, of Brooklyn -- who coached 12- and 13-year-old girls at the Good Shepherd School -- did not know that the ''girl'' he had communicated with on the Internet since August was a police detective, the authorities said. Mr. Seigle has been charged with attempted-sex offenses, endangering the welfare of a child and attempted dissemination of indecent material, the district attorney's office said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: NEW RULES FOR CONTRACTORS Attorney General Richard Blumenthal said yesterday that he would not approve any more state contracts unless contractors signed affidavits detailing their gifts to state employees. Without those documents, and without similar affidavits from state employees who oversee contract approval, no deal of more than $100,000 will go through, he said. Mr. Blumenthal is requiring notification of all gifts given in the past 10 years valued at $50 or more. (AP)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Tuition Raises Proposed
description: The government unveiled a bill that would let universities nearly triple their annual tuition fees, charging as much as $5,500 a year. In concessions to Labor Party critics in Parliament who have threatened to vote against the bill, the bill's sponsors said it would provide almost complete financial aid for students whose families earn less than $27,500 a year. Under the plan, students would not have to pay their tuition fees until after they had begun earning $27,500 a year, and outstanding loans would be written off after 25 years. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Splitting. Screens. For Minds. Divided.

Although it has become de rigueur to hate the crawl -- even Jim Walton, the president of CNN, has said publicly that he dislikes it -- CNN's research has shown that 70 percent of its viewers favor it. And why not? At times it's your only hope of getting real news.

title: National Briefing: South
description: SOUTH CAROLINA: REWARD FOR LEADS ON POISON The F.B.I. offered a reward of up to $100,000 for information leading to an arrest of anyone responsible for leaving a package containing the deadly poison ricin at a post office serving Greenville-Spartanburg International Airport on Oct. 15. A letter inside the package said the author could make much more ricin and would "start dumping" large quantities of it if new federal trucking rules went in effect. The rules, which require more rest hours for truck drivers, took effect on Sunday. No one has been arrested in connection with the poison package and no illnesses have been reported since the package was found. The F.B.I. and other federal agencies set up a toll-free number, (866) 839-6241, for information about the incident.   (AP)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Painkiller Traces In Ferry Case
description: Tests conducted for the National Transportation Safety Board found traces of a prescription painkiller in the blood of the man at the helm of a Staten Island ferry that crashed last year, officials said yesterday. Assistant Capt. Richard J. Smith told investigators after the Oct. 15 crash -- which killed 11 people and injured dozens -- that he had taken blood pressure medicine and probably passed out at the helm. But two witnesses said he was upright at the controls, officials have said. The N.T.S.B. tests, first reported yesterday in Newsday, found the painkiller Tramadol, officials said. The drug had not been found in tests performed for the Staten Island district attorney's office by a laboratory in Pennsylvania. A lawyer for Captain Smith declined to comment. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Finance Investigation
description: The Stock Exchange of Thailand said that it had begun setting up a task force with regulators in response to a request by Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra. On Tuesday, Mr. Thaksin called for the formation of a committee to monitor possible stock-price manipulation. Then on Wednesday, he ordered the finance ministry and the exchange to set up a task force to scrutinize the financial reports of listed companies to prevent money laundering. An exchange spokeswoman would not elaborate on whether the new task force would combine the two roles. Thailand's benchmark stock index more than doubled last year and Mr. Thaksin, while saying stocks are likely to rise further this year, has condemned short-term speculation by investors. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Recovery Strengthens
description: Retail sales rose 5.2 percent in November from levels a year earlier, as a flood of tourists joined residents in stores. The biggest increase, 32.9 percent by volume, came in electrical goods and photographic equipment, which are sold in large quantities to visitors. The increase in retail sales in October, announced last month as having been 3.8 percent, was revised up to 4.0 percent. An outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome last spring produced a steep drop in retail sales, and despite the recent improvement, sales for the first 11 months of last year were still down 3.1 percent compared with the first 11 months of 2002. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

Chapman owns 1.43 million Footstar shares, or about 7.1 percent of the company, it said in the filing. Footstar, based in West Nyack, N.Y., operates Footaction and Just For Feet stores. It is restating earnings for 1997 through June 2002 after finding possible understatements of liabilities. Chapman also said that it wanted Footstar to replace its chief executive, Neele E. Stearns Jr. A spokeswoman for Footstar said the company declined to comment.

title: World Briefing: Asia

Mr. Ky, 74, who lives in Southern California, is to arrive in Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, on Wednesday to visit relatives and friends for Tet, the Lunar New Year. He is also scheduled to visit Hanoi and Son Tay, his hometown, in Ha Tay Province, 25 miles northwest of Hanoi. The official did not elaborate on any other aspects of the visit. (AP)

title: Technology Briefing | Services: Verso To Post 4th-Quarter Loss

Shares of Verso fell $1.39, to $1.93. Verso's fourth-quarter revenue was about $15 million, the company said. Verso, based in Atlanta, had revenue of $10.7 million a year earlier. It will report fourth-quarter results at the end of February. Verso previously forecast quarterly revenue of $19 million to $20 million. Verso is expected to post a loss of a penny a share, the average estimate of four analysts polled by Thomson Financial. Verso attributed the drop in revenue to a lack of spending on sales and marketing.

title: 36 Hours | Aspen, Colo.
description: ASPEN is a small town where you can see incredible things -- bear prints the size of snowshoes in the snow, Jack Nicholson on a chairlift, ski instructors coming down the mountain with torches at Winterskl (Jan. 15 to 18) looking like a lava flow. The architecture in town is a mix, from the colorful Victorians in the West End neighborhood to the monster movie-star mansions on Red Mountain to new houses with rusty-looking tin roofs and industrial details -- references to Aspen's silver-mining past. The Aspen crowd is also a mix: celebrities, artists, motorcyclists, bankers, 40-year-olds who live to snowboard, yogis, snow bunnies, Australians. The four ski mountains in the area -- Aspen, Highlands, Buttermilk and Snowmass -- have every kind of terrain, from smooth as cream cheese to bumpy, steep and scary. If you're just skiing Aspen Mountain, no need to rent a car. The gondola, hotels and the best bookstore in town (Explore Booksellers, 221 East Main Street, 970-925-5336) are all within walking distance. And there's no need to pack fancy clothes. ''In Aspen, everyone is always very casual,'' said Greg Poschman, a local filmmaker who grew up here. ''In the old days, if you saw someone wearing a suit, they were either D.E.A. -- drug enforcement -- I.R.S. or a Jehovah's Witness. Since then, Aspen has become chic and trendy but the casualness remains.'' LOIS SMITH BRADY

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Suit Opposes Taking Logs

The lawsuit, filed by Santa Fe Forest Watch and Forest Guardians, contends that much of the acreage, in the Jemez Mountains, is protected habitat for the endangered Mexican spotted owl. The Forest Service declined to comment. Steve Barnes (NYT)

The man, Adrian Lamo, 22, told Judge Naomi Reice Buchwald of Federal District Court in Manhattan that he was ''genuinely remorseful'' before entering his plea to one count of computer damage. He faces a maximum of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine when he is sentenced on April 8. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: F.D.A. SEEKS MORE TESTING FOR BIOPURE BLOOD SUBSTITUTE

The findings will be the basis for more human trials. Hemopure would be the first human blood substitute available in the United States and Biopure's first product on the market.

title: Diane Arbus, a Hunter Wielding a Lens
description: IN the photograph, the 11-year-old girl stands stiffly before a plain wall in her sleeveless, white crocheted dress, arms leaden, mouth shut. Her grave face is tightly framed by long hair and bangs, which almost conceal her eyes. She stares back at us from the shadow cast by the bangs, with a look that I might register as fear, although who is to say for sure? The heavy formality of the transaction between photographer and subject announces itself. The girl is clearly responding to the person making this portrait, whose presence we sense. By its nature the picture tells us who this photographer is. She makes sure that we know.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NORTON, WILLIAM F., JR.
description: NORTON--William F., Jr., died on January 6th at the Schervier Nursing Care Center in Riverdale, NY. He was 90. A former FBI agent, Mr. Norton was in charge of the investigation that culminated in the execution of atom bomb spies Julius and Ethel Rosenberg. He resigned from the FBI in 1953 to enter private practice in the admiralty field. Mr. Norton graduated from St. Francis Xavier High School, Fordham College and, in 1938, Fordham University School of Law. In 1941 he entered the FBI Academy at Quantico, VA. His work as a special agent included assignments in Latin America and, during World War II, counterespionage, counter sabotage and national defense investigations in New York. He was cited twice by FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover and also commended by the U.S. Attorney's office for his work in the Rosenberg case and the Soviet spy cases involving Harry Gold and his associates. Mr. Norton survived his wife of 56 years, Rita Elaine who died in 2001 and his sons William and Thomas. He is survived by his loving children Mary Elaine Morris, Margaret Clare, Jeanne Anne, Gerard, Michael and Joan Marie, his son-in-laws David M. Morris, Kenneth D. McGuinness and daughter-inlaws Jennifer Norton and Nancy Belley; adoring grandchildren Jennifer and Alexis Morris, Alexander, Kelly Anne, Patrick and Michel Kelly Neville Norton, as well as his former daughter-in-laws Carolyn Butler and Marie Khatami. Visitation on Monday, January 12, at the John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Ave. (70th St.), NYC, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, January 13, 10 AM, at Schervier Nursing Care Center, 2975 Independence Ave. and 231st St., Riverdale, NY. Interment at Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. Donations in his memory preferred to Schervier Nursing Care Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAME, DR. ENID SUE JACOBS
description: DAME--Dr. Enid Sue Jacobs. It is with the deepest regret that we mourn the passing on December 25, 2003 of a poet, editor, teacher, essayist and Jewish feminist whose life and work was a paradigm of character, courage and compassion. She received her baccalaureate from Towson State College, Maryland, her Master's from City College of New York, and her Ph.D from Rutgers University. As a teacher she was revered by her students for her concern and sensitivity. As a poet her work was widely published and anthologized, and her readings well-received and attended. She was considered by several national critics to be one of the ten best Jewish poets in America and was a runner-up for Poet Laureate of Brooklyn. Her last national featured reading was in Ann Arbor, Michigan; her last tristate reading was at Poets and Teachers in Union Square, Manhattan. Her work combined nostalgia and humor with poignancy and purpose. Her early work featured characters such as Lilith, Superwoman and Vilda Chaya, a wild woman who sought counsel from cats and plants even as she climbed down the economic ladder. Enid Dame inherited her political activism and a desire for justice and truth from her parents, the late Morton and Bernice Jacobs. She is survived by her husband, Donald Lev, with whom she founded Home Planet News, which recently celebrated its 25th year of publication. All who knew Enid loved her for her grace, charm, humor and intelligence. She was always glad to meet friends and always went out of her way to support them. She is also survived by her brother, Philip Jacobs, his wife, Lisa and their two daughters Diana and Emily. Adieu mon amie, ma soeur, ma belle. Namaste. Careufel de Lamiere

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PRYSTOWSKY, ROSE, MD.
description: PRYSTOWSKY--Rose, MD. The President and Board of Trustees of Montefiore Medical Center are deeply saddened by the death of Rose Prystowsky, MD, beloved mother of Michael Prystowsky, MD, university chair, Department of Pathology, Albert Einstein College of Medicine and pathologist-in-chief, Montefiore Medical Center. Dr. Prystowsky, a child psychiatrist, died in a house fire early Wednesday that critically injured her pediatrician husband, Milton, and also killed her live-in nurse. Dr. Prystowsky was the only woman graduate in her medical class and she received her training in psychiatry at Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York City. She also held a Master's degree in public health from Johns Hopkins University. She and her husband raised five boys, all of whom became doctors. The medical community, the thousands of patients she cared for, and the entire Montefiore family grieve this tremendous loss. Our condolences go out to her husband, Milton, and her sons, Dr. Stephen of New York City, Dr. Eric of Indiana, Dr. Barry of Nutley, NJ, Dr. Richard of California, and Dr. Michael of New York City, and her 14 grandchildren. Spencer Foreman, MD, President Jay B. Langner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

title: Studying Literature By the Numbers
description: If Franco Moretti had his way, literature scholars would stop reading books and start counting, graphing and mapping them instead. For an English professor, this is an ambition verging on apostasy. But Mr. Moretti, a professor of English and comparative literature at Stanford and director of the university's center for the study of the novel, insists that such a move could bring new luster to a tired field, one that in some respects, he says, is among ''the most backwards disciplines in the academy.''

title: National Briefing: South
description: TENNESSEE: MIXED RULING IN GAY FATHER'S CASE The State Court of Appeals ruled that a lower court order barring a gay man in a custody dispute "from taking the child around or otherwise exposing the child to his gay lover(s) and/or his gay lifestyle" was not overly broad and was properly issued. But it reversed the contempt citation that put the man, Joseph R. Hogue Jr., in jail for two days for telling his son he is gay, saying the statement did not violate the order.

title: When Safety Costs Too Much
description: In defending against disasters, society plays a complicated game against nature that has unclear rules and high stakes. Still, we improve our odds of surviving earthquakes, floods and hurricanes by carefully choosing how and where we build. For example, last month's earthquake in Iran -- where lax construction standards mean that buildings collapse even without natural disasters -- killed more than 30,000 people. But earthquakes of similar strength in California, which has strict rules, cause far fewer deaths (last month's earthquake there killed two people, and even the slightly stronger 1994 Northridge earthquake, in a densely settled area of Los Angeles, killed only 61 people).

title: STRIKES MAY LOWER PACIFICARE'S EARNINGS
description: PacifiCare Health Systems Inc., a leading operator of Medicare health plans, said strikes at California supermarkets might lower its earnings this year. Work stoppages over health benefits at Albertson's Inc., the Ralphs Grocery chain of the Kroger Company and the Vons stores of Safeway Inc. may cause PacifiCare to miss goals for increasing membership and trim as much as 19 cents a share from 2004 earnings on a presplit basis, the company said. PacifiCare, which is based in Cypress, Calif., insured about 48,000 United Food and Commercial Workers members who have been striking against the supermarkets since October and provided prescription-drug services to another 200,000. Some employees lost eligibility for coverage because of the strikes, the company said.

title: Cohen in Position to End Kwan's Lengthy Reign

title: Fraydele Oysher, 90, Actress Who Starred in Yiddish Theater
description: Fraydele Oysher, a star of the Yiddish theater and a member of a musical dynasty, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan, said her daughter, the singer and comedian Marilyn Michaels. She was 90.

title: I.B.M. AND REALNETWORKS TO INTEGRATE SOFTWARE
description: International Business Machines and RealNetworks Inc. said yesterday that they would make their software work together for selling Internet-based audio and video services. The resulting products, due for availability in the first half, will let users deliver media like Internet-based television and digital music for automobiles, RealNetworks said in a statement on its Web site. The collaboration will integrate RealNetworks' software for disseminating audio and video over the Internet and setting up pay subscription services with I.B.M.'s Internet, database and content-management software, RealNetworks said. The companies will market the programs together. RealNetworks is based in Seattle and I.B.M. is based in Armonk, N.Y.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Low Interest On Savings
description: Interest rates on savings deposits are approaching zero as the Hong Kong Monetary Authority pumps money into banks in an effort to prevent the Hong Kong dollar from appreciating against the American dollar. HSBC, the Chinese territory's dominant bank, said that it was lowering the interest rate it would pay on savings deposits of at least $1,300 to one-thousandth of 1 percent from the previous rate of one-hundredth of 1 percent. The bank left its main lending rate at 5 percent.

title: RITE AID REASSIGNS EXECUTIVE BECAUSE OF S.E.C. TALKS
description: Rite Aid, the drugstore chain, said yesterday that it had reassigned its chief financial officer, Chris Hall, because he is in settlement talks with the Securities and Exchange Commission over an accounting investigation at a former employer. Mr. Hall, who was named senior vice president for real estate and planning, was replaced by John T. Standley, Rite Aid said. The investigation involves Mr. Hall's work at Ralphs Grocery, which was acquired by the Kroger Company. Mr. Hall has proposed a settlement to the S.E.C. in which he does not admit or deny wrongdoing. In March 2001, Kroger restated earnings for three years because of financial manipulation by former managers at Ralphs.

description: GUSSEN--Ruth, M.D. Beloved mother of James Gussen, sister of Dr. Raymond Marcus and long-time companion, Professor Philip Levine, passed away December 31, 2003 in Los Angeles, after a long bout with cancer. She was a full professor of pathology at the UCLA Medical School and a nationally recognized authority on ear pathology, whose discoveries and insights broke important new ground in her field. After retirement, she joined the Plato Society at UCLA, where she became a beloved teacher on operatic subjects, and went on to serve as its president. She died at home surrounded by friends and family. She had a natural inner light that shone on all who came in contact with her, and she will be sorely missed by the many people who loved her. Memorial services will be held at 2PM Saturday, January 10th at 10790 Wilshire Blvd, Los Angeles, CA. Donations may be made to the Plato Society, 1083 Gayley Ave, Los Angeles, CA. 90024. title: INDEPENDENT BANK CORP. AGREES TO BUY FALMOUTH BANCORP
description: The Independent Bank Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Falmouth Bancorp for about $36.9 million in stock and cash. Under the agreement, half of Falmouth's outstanding shares will each be converted into 1.28 shares of Independent Bank and the remaining shares will be purchased for $38 in cash, Independent Bank said. The stock portion of the transaction is based on Independent's closing price Thursday of $29 a share. Independent Bank, which is based in Rockland, Mass., is the parent of the Rockland Trust Company, which has $2.4 billion in assets and 52 retail branches in Massachusetts. Falmouth is based in Falmouth, Mass., and has assets of $166.1 million and four branches, all in southern Massachusetts.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Harbor Reprieve
description: In a rare victory for a citizens group in Asia, Hong Kong's highest court ruled that the government had failed to meet legal criteria for filling in part of the territory's famed Victoria Harbor and must show an ''overriding public need'' for the project. The ruling by the Court of Final Appeal blocked the government -- at least temporarily -- from further land reclamation work to fill in a swath of the harbor for a covered highway. The government said it would review its plans and believed it could yet meet requirements imposed by the court. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

He was among about 1,800 N.Y.U. students who received the same e-mail notification from the university. In some cases, students' phone numbers were posted, too.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Vote For A New Parliament
description: The government announced that parliamentary elections would be held March 28, replacing the Parliament whose flawed election in November touched off the protests that ousted Eduard A. Shevardnadze from the presidency. The new president, Mikhail Saakashvilli, elected Sunday, will be inaugurated Jan. 25. In the meantime, the current Parliament continues to meet, but often without a quorum and with questionable legitimacy to enact any laws proposed by Mr. Saakashvili. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Profit In Software Service
description: India's second-largest exporter of software services, Infosys Technologies, said it earned 3.28 billion rupees ($72 million) in the quarter that ended Dec. 31, an increase of 28 percent over the year-earlier period. Infosys, a bellwether for software services companies in the country, has gained from outsourcing by companies in the United States and Europe that are trying to reduce expenses. More than 70 percent of the company's revenue comes from corporations based in the United States. The company added 30 clients and hired 3,666 people during the quarter. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHLOSS, PATTI NEE O'KEEFE
description: SCHLOSS--Patti nee O'keefe of New York. Beloved wife of Michael Schloss, devoted daughter to Florence and the late Harold Adler, adored and cherished by her many friends. Died January 8, 2004. Patti was an Alumnus of Bellevue Nursing School. Devoted to her profession, she became the Head Nurse of Bellevue's Emergency Room and later opened the first Bellevue ICU. With the opening of one of the first cardiac rehabilitation centers in the country, Patti became a pioneer in Cardiac Rehabilition Nursing. She later became the founder and director of Pace Scan a follow-up cardiac pacemaker program. Besides being a beloved caregiver to her many patients and friends, she was a political activist for local neighborhood improvement. Following Michael's passion for flying, she was a volunteer and organizer for the Warbirds of America. She was a passionate, quintessential shopper with style, taste and a zest for life. There was never any question about where she stood on any issue ''not always right but never in doubt''. She brightened and changed the lives of all she touched and will be deeply missed. A funeral service is planned for Monday, January 12, 3:30 PM at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations should be sent to NYU LIPID Center, Cardiology Division, 560 First Avenue, NY, NY 10016.

title: WESTPOINT STEVENS WILL CLOSE 4 FACTORIES
description: WestPoint Stevens Inc., the bankrupt maker of Ralph Lauren Home, Martha Stewart and Disney Home sheets and towels, said it would close four factories and lay off about 975 workers. WestPoint will shut two plants in LaGrange, Ga.; a towel factory in Valley, Ala.; and a bedding production operation in Coushatta, La. Another factory in Valley will be converted to towel manufacturing, the company said. The job cuts will begin in mid-March and come after WestPoint said in November that it planned to close an Alabama factory and eliminate 300 jobs. The company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in June after more than $103 million in losses since 2001. WestPoint is based in West Point, Ga.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Exports Surge
description: China's exports grew 51 percent from a year earlier in December, the fastest pace in more than eight years, as factories accelerated shipments to the United States, Europe and Japan before tax rebates were cut at the start of this month. Overseas sales rose to a record $48 billion after climbing 34 percent in November, the commerce ministry said. The trade surplus for the month was $5.73 billion, close to October's record of $5.74 billion.

description: ZUNZ--Sylvia. We mourn the passing of Sylvia Zunz, beloved wife of 58 years of Lyonel Zunz, esteemed and distinguished Chairman of the Board of Trustees of The Community School, who has offered unmatched and dedicated leadership to New Jersey's and New York's learning disabled children for nearly four decades. Standing beside Lyonel for the past 35 years, Sylvia helped nurture the growth of The Community School, positively shaping the lives of thousands of children. title: National Briefing | Washington: No Federal Help For Legal Bills
description: A federal appeals court panel denied a request from Susan H. McDougal to have the government pay her legal bills related to a special counsel investigation of President Bill Clinton. The panel, three judges from the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, said the government did not have to pay the more than $300,000 in fees. Mrs. McDougal was acquitted of obstructing justice after she refused to testify before a grand jury about the Arkansas financial dealings of Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton. That person is the illegal immigrant. Let's call him Sam. This whole immigration debate is about him, the choices he faces and the way he responds.

title: Michigan's Online Ballot Spurs New Strategies for Democrats
description: The virtual ballot box has arrived in Michigan. Democrats in this state are the only voters in the country who have the option of voting online in the presidential primaries this year.

title: A Song of Queens, a Dream in Brooklyn
description: To the Editor:

title: A Song of Queens, a Dream in Brooklyn (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire Lieutenant Reassigned From S.I. Was Suspended After 1986 Fight
description: A fire lieutenant who was transferred after a fight on New Year's Eve at a Staten Island firehouse was suspended for drinking and fighting on the job in 1986.

title: Suspicious Fire in Brooklyn Injures 10
description: Afire early yesterday morning in Bushwick, Brooklyn, injured 10 people and cost three families their homes, and the authorities said it appeared to have been set.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Dec. 25 about hardships endured by service members and their families at Fort Hood misstated the post's size ranking. Fort Hood is not the nation's largest military installation, although it is the only one to support two full divisions. Fort Bliss is the largest geographically, and Fort Bragg has a slightly larger population.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEINBERG, NORMAN
description: STEINBERG--Norman, 78, of Long Island on January 8, 2004. Beloved husband of Madeline for 54 years. Father of Mitchell (Randy), Arlene Fisher (Shelly), and Gary (Debbie). Grandfather of Allison, Jason, Josh and Matt. WW II Veteran, graduate Baruch, founder of Crosstex International. Funeral at Gutterman's, Woodbury, Sunday January 11 at 1PM. We will all miss you dearly.

title: National Briefing: Rockies
description: MONTANA: SENATOR HAS EMERGENCY SURGERY Senator Max Baucus underwent emergency surgery to relieve pressure on his brain, apparently caused by a fall while running in a race in November. Dr. Mark Sanz, Mr. Baucus's personal physician, said the senator, a 62-year-old Democrat, underwent surgery at the Mayo Clinic in Scottsdale, Ariz., and was expected to recover fully.

title: Terror Threat Is Lowered To 'Elevated,' Ridge Says
description: The Bush administration lowered the terrorist threat status on Friday to ''elevated'' after nearly three weeks at high alert. Officials said they would continue heightened security for industries like aviation, banking and energy that are regarded at risk of attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORAN, JOHN PATRICK
description: MORAN--John Patrick. 76, died Wednesday January 7 at a local hospital in Charleston, SC. He was a member of the US Navy serving during WWII. He was a graduate of Long Island University and served honorably, loyally and efficiently as a member of the New York Police Department for 38 years rising from Patrolman to Assistant Chief. Survived by his wife of 52 years, Sally Connolly Moran; one son, Gerard; two daughters, Celia and Mary; one brother, James Moran; and two grandchildren, Matthew Sean and Kristin Mary Blumm. Contributions may be made to Charleston Catholic School Scholarship Fund, 888 King St., Charleston, SC 29403. Condolences may be sent to the family at www.mcalister-smith.com

title: U.S. Seeking Backing Of U.N. Chief For Iraq Plan
description: The United States moved Friday to secure backing from Secretary General Kofi Annan for the American plan to transfer authority to Iraqis this summer, and to persuade him to send United Nations staff members back to Baghdad promptly.

title: $8 Million Award to Widow Punishes Tobacco Company
description: For the first time in New York State, a jury in Brooklyn yesterday said that a tobacco company should pay punitive damages for the lung cancer death of an individual smoker.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: University To End Legacy Program
description: Texas A&M University will immediately end its legacy program, under which the children of alumni got preference in admissions. The university president, Robert M. Gates, who said he had consulted the A&M trustees, declared the program inconsistent with the university's policy of merit-based enrollment. Black and Hispanic political organizations had threatened to sue unless A&M ended the program. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Big Three Hope Rising Economy Will Lift All Vehicles
description: The Big Three are putting a bullish face on 2004, predicting that a wave of new products, aided by an improving economy, will increase earnings and might even cool off their price war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BACHENHEIMER, HAROLD H.
description: BACHENHEIMER--Harold H. Passed peacefully in his sleep on January 8, 2004. Survived by his wife Anne, son Steven (Elaine), brother and sister, Micha (Miriam) and Lee (Alfred). Grandchildren Staci (David) and Jill (Ken) and great grandchildren Daniel, Casey, Matthew and Connor. Throughout his 92 years, Harold was devoted to his family, his business and the Jewish community. Born in Germany, as a first generation American he worked tirelessly to bring his parents and sister to the U.S., and to build a warm and supportive home for his beloved first wife, Andree and son Steven. Harold's 68 years of extraordinary commitment as a food broker to the New York wholesale grocery trade is legendary. He served his principals and his customers with a deep sense of responsibility and always made a difference. We will all miss you. You were truly ''one of a kind''. Services will be held Sunday, January 11 at 11:15 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W 76 St, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KARGER, JOHN S.
description: KARGER--John S., 95, passed away peacefully on January 8 at RiverMead in Peterborough, NH, formerly of New York City, White Plains and Greenwich, CT. Beloved husband of Mimi for 23 years, and of the late Ellie for 45 years. Devoted father of the late Ann and of Tom and his wife Mary Jane, and proud grandfather of Michael and Dave; and loving stepfather of Jane and her husband Andy, and adoring grandfather of Jocie, Nan and Hilary. Predeceased by brother Robert. Also survived by sisters-inlaw Margery Engel and Mary Goldsmith and by many nieces and nephews. A graduate of Harvard University, John was a longtime member of the New York Stock Exchange and a principal partner with Rothschild Securities Corp. A generous man, he was committed to many social causes. A memorial service will be held at Congregation Kol Ami in the Chapel in the Woods, 252 Soundview Ave, White Plains, NY on Thursday, January 15 at 10AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Hamilton-Madison House, 50 Madison St, NY, NY 10038 or to your favorite charity.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: JUDGE RULES ON UNABOMBER ITEMS The writings and personal photographs of Theodore J. Kaczynski, the Unabomber, should be sold, with the earnings given to his victims, or the items should be donated to a university, a federal magistrate ruled. The judge, Gregory G. Hollows of Federal District Court, said it appeared prosecutors could be trying to hinder distribution of the manuscripts and journals. "That some may find an idea offensive does not shield the idea from First Amendment protection," he wrote. (AP)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Retailer's Sales Fall
description: Germany's largest department store operator, KarstadtQuelle, said that sales for the fourth quarter of 2003 fell 6.8 percent, to 4.5 billion euros ($5.75 billion), because of weak holiday season sales and the general reluctance of German consumers to spend. According to provisional figures for the 2003 financial year, the group had sales of 15.3 billion euros ($19.5 billion), a decline of 3.5 percent from the previous year. Still, the company reported continued growth in its online business and said that it was able to expand its market position in Germany. Online revenue increased 28 percent, to 1.59 billion euros ($2.03 billion).

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Stock Index Surges
description: Indonesia's benchmark stock index rose 3.13 percent yesterday to a record amid growing optimism about the country's economic outlook this year. Analysts said the absence of new terrorist attacks over the year-end holidays, higher oil prices, low inflation and falling interest rates had buoyed hopes that Indonesia's economic growth would accelerate this year. Fears that parliamentary and presidential elections this year might lead to fresh instability have abated, and foreign investors were net buyers of about $50 million in Indonesian stocks in the first week, according to statistics compiled by Nomura International in Hong Kong. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Music Piracy Alert
description: The United States government put South Korea on its priority watch list, saying it had failed to stanch the growth of online piracy of music and motion pictures, according to the office of the United States trade representative. Officials said sanctions would be imposed if South Korea did not provide better protection of intellectual property rights. The United States industry estimates that it lost $572 million in 2002 as a result of piracy in South Korea. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: Got Milked?
description: Many Europeans felt a bit vindicated by the Enron and WorldCom scandals. They saw such complex, huge cases of accounting fraud as a sign of how self-destructive America's swashbuckling hypercapitalism can get.

title: Beijing Leaders' Populist Touch Is Not Felt by Most Rural Poor
description: Correction Appended

title: Campaign Briefing: THE DEMOCRATS; CLARK ON TERRORISM
description: Gen. Wesley K. Clark asserted that the federal government had not done all it could to thwart either the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks or future such attacks, and that terrorism in this country was not inevitable. ''I think that it's clear that more could have been done to prevent 9/11 than was done,'' General Clark said Friday, speaking to reporters in Lebanon, N.H. He was quoted in Friday's Concord Monitor as saying that ''the two greatest lies'' of the last two years were that the Sept. 11 attacks could not have been prevented and that more attacks were inevitable. He said the fact that the nation's terrorist threat status had been put at ''high'' over the Christmas holidays indicated that President Bush had erred in invading Iraq before Osama bin Laden was captured and his terror network dismantled. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

title: Boyz N a New Hood (Fatherhood, That Is)
description: ''My Baby's Daddy,'' a new comedy that opened nationwide yesterday, has a not-bad (though not-too-original) premise and a sweet attitude. The movie, directed by Cheryl Dunye from a committee-written script, follows three bachelor buddies on a journey toward maturity initiated by the simultaneous pregnancy of their girlfriends.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Art in Review column of Weekend yesterday about ''The Art of Aging,'' at the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion Museum in Greenwich Village, misstated the closing date. The exhibition continues through June 25, not Jan. 25.

title: Irvington Schools Chief, Charged With Stalking, Remains in Job
description: Schools Superintendent Vincent T. Beni was back on the job Friday after arraignment on misdemeanor charges of stalking and harassing a former girlfriend, school officials said.

title: Strike by Operations Staff Looms at Indian Pt. Nuclear Plant
description: Maintenance and operations workers at the Indian Point nuclear power plant were making preparations for a possible strike in the event that negotiations between their union and Entergy Nuclear Northeast, the plant's owner, do not yield a new contract within eight days.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 489 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: What's in a $400 Rebate? One iPod, or Two Manolos
description: Inside the Family Corner Restaurant on 31st Street in Astoria, Queens, the question yesterday was what to do with the $400 that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg wants to give homeowners as a rebate on the 18.5 percent property tax increase from 2002.

title: Crouching Leopard, Somersaulting Dragon
description: Long before martial-arts acrobatics became a staple of action movies, they were part of Chinese opera, and the composer and baritone saxphonist Fred Ho has decided they can be at the center of an American opera as well. His ''Voice of the Dragon 2: Shaolin Secret Stories'' is an opera without songs. But it has plenty of jazzy music from Mr. Ho's sextet, the Afro Asian Music Ensemble, and a nearly nonstop display of leaping, punching, somersaulting, pole-twirling, sword-wielding combat, choreographed for a dozen martial artists by Jose Figueroa.

title: Struggling to Design the Future for Gucci
description: As a teenager in Paris in the 1960's, Serge Weinberg had no intention of becoming a garment maker like his father. ''I was leftist -- May 1968,'' he said. ''I wasn't interested in the apparel business, or any kind of business.''

title: Destroying the Museum to Save It
description: Does the Barnes Foundation, with its trove of Renoirs, Czannes, Matisses and other Impressionist and modern masterpieces, really need to leave the small town for the big city in order to survive?

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Takashi Ishihara, the former president of the Nissan Motor Company, misstated the date of his death. It was Dec. 31, not Dec. 28.

title: Editorial Observer; Coming to Terms With the Problem of Global Meat
description: The DNA proves that the Washington State Holstein found to have bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease, in December definitely came from a Canadian herd. You can almost hear the relieved sighs of the American cattle industry, joined by the sighs of grain farmers and exporters and meatpackers and the U.S.D.A. itself. In the world of bureaucratic borders, this fact of origin makes a vital difference. It will probably allow the United States to retain its status as a non-B.S.E. nation, and that in turn will allow us to pry open the borders that slammed shut, stranding shiploads of frozen meat and causing cattle prices to drop sharply, almost as soon as that one case was discovered.

title: Shell Cuts 20% Off Estimates Of Oil and Gas In Its Reserves
description: Royal Dutch/Shell said yesterday that it was reducing its proven oil and gas reserves by 20 percent, a surprising announcement that raised questions about the company and about the tabulation of oil and gas reserves throughout the industry.

title: Man Pleads Not Guilty in Plot To Sell Missiles for Terror Use
description: A British citizen who was arrested last August in a sting operation pleaded not guilty Friday to federal charges that he plotted to sell shoulder-fired missiles that he knew were to be used against commercial airliners in the United States, as well as a so-called dirty bomb, to people he believed to be terrorists.

title: Ethnic Friction Over Signs That Lack Translations
description: Should stores in ethnic neighborhoods be allowed to have signs with no English on them?

title: Iowa Senator Endorses Dean as 'Best Shot'
description: Howard Dean won a prized endorsement on Friday for the fast-approaching Iowa caucuses as Senator Tom Harkin, the state's most influential Democratic lawmaker, called Dr. Dean ''our best shot'' to oust President Bush.

title: For One Earthquake Survivor, Joy Is Tempered by Sorrow
description: Adele Freedman sat in a wheelchair at a hospital in Queens yesterday and recalled the horror of last month's earthquake in Bam, Iran. Shortly after the quake, she and her fianc, Tobb Dell'Oro, lay trapped by the wreckage of their guest house, choking on dust and bleeding.
