title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEIDEN, HAROLD (HAL)
description: SEIDEN--Harold (Hal) of New Hyde Park was born on August 1, 1920 in New York. He passed away in his sleep on January 11, 2003, having just achieved his 60th wedding anniversary to his devoted and beloved wife, Jessica Greenberg Seiden. A graduate of Brooklyn College, Hal was a well-known and highly regarded motion picture cameraman, and long-time member of I.A.T.S.E. Local 644. His father Joseph was a motion picture pioneer, and a producer and director of Yiddish films. Hal was fortunate to have turned a life-long passion and hobby into a career--photographing presidents, numerous sports events including the summer and winter Olympics, ABC Wide World of Sports, Major League Baseball, and golf, and working on award-winning documentaries and commercials. He is succeeded by his wife and soul-mate Jessica; his sister, Marilyn Bloom; his three sons, Michael, Richard, and Matthew; and four beloved grandchildren, Marc, Miles, Carolyn, and Laura. Services at Dalton Funeral Home, 412 Willis Avenue, Williston Park, New York, at 10 am, January 13. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, contributions be made in Hal's memory to the Long Island Alzheimer's Foundation, 5 Channel Drive, Port Washington, New York, 11050.

A World War II Army veteran and clothing industry executive, Mr. Olin was elected to the board of North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset in 1971 and actively supported a range of initiatives, including the hospital's emergency department expansion, and cardiology and pediatric hematology programs. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family, including his wife Susanne Cohen, his son Daniel and his daughter Laura. Roy J. Zuckerberg, Chairman Michael Dowling President & CEO North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System

The winner, chosen from 1,500 entries and to be broadcast next week, criticizes Mr. Bush on the federal deficit and argues that future generations will pay for it by showing children washing dishes, mopping a floor, checking groceries and slinging trash bags. The man, Mijailo Mijailovic, admitted the crime last week, prosecutors said. The Swedish police said Mr. Mijailovic denied acting for political reasons and told investigators he had stabbed the minister on the orders of an inner voice belonging to Jesus Christ. His trial begins tomorrow. Alan Cowell (NYT)

Siemens, based in Munich, said it had agreed to sell 150 million shares as part of its plan to divest itself of all its Infineon stake. title: 3M TO BUY SWEDISH COMPANY FOR $100 MILLION
description: The 3M Company agreed to buy Hornell International, a maker of protective equipment for welders, for about $100 million to expand its line of safety products. Hornell, based in Gagnef, Sweden, has 215 employees and annual sales of about $49 million, 3M said. Its products include Speedglas helmets that filter light and protect welders' eyes, and Adflo respirators. Welders' demand for new safety technology is growing globally, 3M said. The Hornell purchase will complement existing 3M safety products that include hearing protection and reflective materials for clothing. The purchase price includes the assumption of debt and technology, 3M said.

title: COUNTRYWIDE FINANCIAL LOWERS EARNINGS ESTIMATE
description: The Countrywide Financial Corporation, a mortgage lender, said yesterday that its earnings for last year would be less than expected. The company, based in Calabasas, Calif., said earnings were probably $12.30 to $12.45 a share, compared with a previously forecast range of $12 to $13.50. ''As anticipated, refinance activity declined during the quarter due to higher mortgage rates,'' Stanford L. Kurland, the president, said in a statement. Countrywide forecast that 2004 earnings would be $9 to $12 a share, the same as an earlier prediction. Analysts expected the company to earn $13.05 in 2003 and $10.25 in 2004, according to a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: 10 Dead In Human Cases Of Bird Flu
description: Nine children and an adult have died in Hanoi since October from a rare strain of avian influenza that usually spreads from birds to people, the World Health Organization said. Three other children have survived infection from the strain, known as Influenza A(H5N1). Because some of the cases occurred in the same family, health officials are monitoring a possible person-to-person spread of the virus. Epidemiologists are seeking a possible link between the cases and chickens. Last year, the strain killed one person and sickened another in Hong Kong. In 1997, the same strain infected 18 people in Hong Kong, killing 6, and officials ordered the slaughter of all of the territory's 1.4 million chickens out of concern for an epidemic. ''We're always concerned when we see this kind of influenza appear,'' said Dick Thompson, a spokesman for the W.H.O. Lawrence K. Altman (NYT)

title: EVENFLO SAYS IT MAY PUT ITSELF UP FOR SALE
description: The Evenflo Company, a baby-products maker controlled by the buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, said yesterday that it might put itself up for sale after it closed factories and laid off workers last year to cut costs. The investment bank Lazard will help evaluate strategic alternatives for the company, which makes baby bottles, pacifiers and infant car seats, Evenflo said. The company, which also makes products under the Snugli brand, is based in Vandalia, Ohio, and sells its products in 61 countries. Kohlberg Kravis, the world's largest buyout firm by assets, has been the controlling shareholder in Evenflo since 1996, when it bought Evenflo and Spalding Holdings. It separated Evenflo from the holding company in 1998, a year after merging Evenflo with the Gerry Baby Products Company.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: 2 GET LIFE IN APARTMENT BOMBINGS A court convicted two men on charges that they took part in the bombing of three apartment buildings that killed 243 people in September 1999. The court then sentenced them to life in prison. The verdict came after a two-month trial that was closed to the public and that did little to answer lingering questions surrounding the attacks, which some have blamed on the Russian secret services. The bombings of the buildings — two in Moscow and one in the southern city of Volgodansk — were part of a wave of violence that led to the second war in Chechnya. One defendant, Yusuf I. Krymshamkhalov, made his first comments on the case against him. "It's all based on lies," he said in televised remarks after the verdict was announced.    Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Partnership Rights for Gays
description: New Jersey struck an important blow for equal rights yesterday, when Gov. James McGreevey signed a gay domestic partnership law. The new law gives gay couples significant new rights, including financial benefits and hospital visiting privileges. New Jersey's action, which produced surprisingly little controversy, should encourage other states and municipalities to redress discrimination against gay and lesbian couples.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Novell Makes Offer To Linux Customers
description: Novell plans to announce today that it will offer to pay the legal fees of any Linux customer that is sued. Novell's move is the latest by computer companies supporting the Linux operating system to shield customers from the threat of litigation from the SCO Group. A consortium, led by I.B.M. and Intel, said yesterday that it was setting up a $10 million fund for any companies that are sued by SCO. SCO, which owns the license rights to the Unix operating system, contends that Linux, a variant of Unix that is distributed free, violates its license and copyright. Last year SCO sued I.B.M., a leading corporate supporter of Linux, and it has threatened to begin suing corporate users. Novell sold the Unix license to SCO in 1995. That contract, said Jack L. Messman, Novell's chief executive, means Novell has ''the right to authorize our customers to use Unix that is in Linux.'' Steve Lohr (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PRESTIN, FRIEDA
description: PRESTIN--Frieda. Age 92, of Tampa, FL, died Saturday. Mrs. Prestin was preceeded in death by her husband Henry and a daughter Rena Yannopoulos. Survived by her daughter, Lorna Michaelson, Tampa; five grandchildren, including Maia Michaelson, Manhattan, NY, and Jay Michaelson, Brooklyn, NY; great-grandson Henry Michaelson. title: Dealing With Depression and the Perils of Pregnancy
description: When Jennifer Klein, a 32-year-old social worker in Los Angeles, discovered that she was pregnant, she immediately stopped taking her antidepressant to avoid exposing her baby to it. She had made the same choice with her first child and experienced only the normal ups and downs of pregnancy.

title: Canada Can Bid on Next Round of Iraq Contracts, Bush Says
description: President Bush, moving for a second day to repair relations with a North American neighbor, said today that Canada would be allowed to bid on a future round of Iraq reconstruction projects.

title: Iraqis Get a Taste of Democracy At a Lively Town Hall Meeting
description: If many Iraqis complain that the foreigners who run their country have given them little so far, they at least can now grab, shout out, dissect, swear by and see in action a word that had meant nothing before: demokratiya, or democracy.

title: Dean Under Pressure As First Voting Nears
description: A week before the first votes are to be cast, Howard Dean finds himself facing challenges in Iowa and New Hampshire. Dr. Dean's supporters expressed distress at what many described as a faltering performance in a televised debate in Des Moines Sunday. And several of his competitors, including John Edwards and John Kerry in Iowa and Wesley K. Clark in New Hampshire, have made aggressive late-campaign pushes for support from undecided voters. Dr. Dean responded, ''When people attack me, that rejuvenates me.''

Before, the ''sandbox,'' as they call it, was a field of dreams. Now, a duplicate rover is rehearsing the first actual maneuvers of the most capable robot ever to traverse the surface of another world.

description: '' 'Twas the night before Christmas and all through the house, not a creature was stirring . . . '' Brendan Miller, 7, paused as he read the words of the holiday poem from a photocopied page. He looked up, stealing a glance at his audience. Then he continued: ''. . . Not even a mouse.''

title: From the Crucible of a Battle, a Jewel of a Park Emerges
description: From atop a small rise at the eastern end of the Ahmanson Ranch, a vision of two Californias spreads as far as the eye can see. To the west lies a stunning, uninterrupted vista of Ventura County's oak- and chaparral-covered mountains. To the east, the developments of the San Fernando Valley spread across hundreds of square miles.

title: FORMER PROCTER & GAMBLE EXECUTIVE TO HEAD CHIQUITA
description: Chiquita Brands International Inc. said it had named a former executive from the Procter & Gamble Company, Fernando Aguirre, to be its chief executive, succeeding Cyrus F. Freidheim Jr. Mr. Aguirre, 46, was also named president and elected to the company's board, Chiquita said. Mr. Freidheim, 68, will continue as chairman. Chiquita, which is based in Cincinnati, named Mr. Freidheim chief executive in March 2002 after it emerged from a Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization. Mr. Aguirre joined Procter & Gamble in 1980 and held various positions, including overseeing operations in Brazil and Mexico. He also served as president of global feminine care.

title: Canada Can Bid on Next Round of Iraq Contracts, Bush Says
description: MONTERREY, Mexico, Jan. 13  President Bush reversed United States policy on Tuesday and said Canada would be allowed to bid on some of the $18.6 billion in American-financed Iraqi reconstruction projects, bringing to an end a bitter dispute with a major ally.

Smith, a Republican trial lawyer from Manhattan and a financial donor to various Republican campaigns, to the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court. The Senate's action to confirm Mr. Smith, who was nominated by Gov. George E. Pataki, means that the court will retain a 4-to-3 Republican majority, said Gary Spencer, the spokesman for the Court of Appeals. Mr. Smith, 59, is a graduate of Stanford University and Columbia University Law School. He will take his seat on the bench today. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Dress for Hoped-For Success
description: Was Howard Dean ever really regarded as the Birkenstock candidate? That seems a fuzzy memory now, six days before the Iowa caucuses, as the Democratic front-runner has disported himself day in and day out on the campaign trail in a manner that has failed to conjure up images of Buffalo Springfield albums or the graphics on a pint of Ben & Jerry's. So committed has Dr. Dean been to his let's-do-business look of rolled shirt sleeves and a meticulously knotted tie that he stuck to it even while handing out pancakes from behind a griddle to voters in Iowa over the weekend. No T-shirts for him. Instead, he protected his oxford cloth with a green apron.

title: Marino Joins Dolphins' Front Office
description: In a surprise move Monday, the Miami Dolphins named Dan Marino, their former star quarterback, as the team's senior vice president for football operations.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Cable Venture Bailout
description: Southeast Asia's biggest phone company, Singapore Telecommunications, will bail out its unprofitable C2C undersea cable venture, lending $225 million as part of a plan to restructure $592 million of the unit's debt. C2C, which runs a $2 billion phone network linking countries from Singapore to Japan, will repay about a third of its debt at 55 cents to the dollar and have as long as 12 years to pay the remainder. Singapore Telecommunications, which owns about 60 percent of C2C, wrote off the entire value of its investment last fiscal year, incurring costs of 812 million Singapore dollars ($480 million).

There were no reports of injuries, and damage to property was limited, an Air Force spokesman said. The bomb was recovered. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Inquiry On Movie Contracts
description: The European Commission is ready to investigate accusations against Hollywood-based movie studios over a clause in contracts they signed with European pay television operators. Contracts between the studios and pay TV companies like British Sky Broadcasting and Canal Plus in France include a clause forcing the pay TV companies to offer the best price and conditions it agrees to with one studio to all the others. The commission has said it suspects that this provision is anticompetitive and inflates the price of movies on European television. A decision to open an antitrust case against the studios is expected later this month or in February, according to people close to the competition regulator. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Trade Sanctions Sought
description: The European Commission will seek permission from the World Trade Organization today to impose sanctions on the United States, because the nation has not scrapped a law that awards fines levied against companies exporting to the United States to their American rivals. The commission contends that the law punishes exporters twice because first they are fined and then the money is passed on to competitors. The trade organization ruled that the law, known as the Byrd Amendment, was illegal after it received complaints from several countries including Australia, Canada, Mexico and Japan as well as from the European Union. Robert Zoellick, the United States trade representative, sent letters yesterday to more than 140 other members of the World Trade Organization to express his hope that 2004 not be a ''lost year'' and set forth some ideas for breaking the impasse reached by trade negotiators at a meeting in Cancn, Mexico, last September.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Questions Harassment Inquiry
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg questioned yesterday the City Council's expenditure of $15,000 to investigate accusations of sexual harassment against Councilman Allan W. Jennings of Queens. ''I don't know why they're spending money on an outside investigatory agency,'' the mayor said, noting that the city has its own Department of Investigation to look into suspected misconduct. The Council said it hired the firm ADR Associates/JAMS to provide an impartial investigation. Mr. Jennings has denied any wrongdoing. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: VeriSign To Operate Product ID Directory
description: VeriSign is expected to announce today that it has been selected to provide a worldwide directory of the electronic identification tags that major retailers are being required to put on pallets and cartons they send to Wal-Mart Stores, the Defense Department and other big customers. The technology, called radio-frequency identification or RFID, allows tagged items to be identified by a radio scanner rather than by lasers sweeping across a bar code, and can handle more information. The service will be similar to one VeriSign provides for the Internet. Terms were not disclosed. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Supreme Court Rejects W  WorldCom Appeal
description: The United States Supreme Court rejected an appeal yesterday by WorldCom in a dispute with SBC Communications over rules for letting competitors connect into local-phone markets. WorldCom and Wisconsin regulators had sought to reinstate the state's rule for reaching network-connection agreements. A federal appeals court threw out the state rule, saying federal law pre-empted it. The 1996 Telecommunications Act requires the former Bell regional phone companies to open their markets to competition by leasing network components to new competitors. Under the law, leasing plans are reached by negotiation or arbitration and then must be approved by state regulators, with a possible federal court appeal. WorldCom said Wisconsin's procedure would let competitors enter the market sooner.

title: Distressed or washed-out, jeans are a must for every man
description: PARIS  Take a look at the first dozen men you see on the street in Tokyo, London, Los Angeles or New York. How many of them are wearing jeans? The five-pocket, in destroyed denim, waxed canvas, washed-out corduroy or leather, is the pant of choice for men of all ages, shapes and tastes. For them, jeans are comfortable, young, sexy, natural and iconic.

Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, said Monday that elderly people were forming negative impressions of the new Medicare law, and he blamed Democratic presidential candidates, who he said were spreading misinformation about the measure, championed by President Bush.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Stamford: Janitors' Union Ratifies Contract
description: A union representing 2,000 janitors at Fairfield County commercial buildings said yesterday that the workers had overwhelmingly ratified a new one-year contract. The contract will raise hourly pay for full-time workers to $10 an hour on Dec. 31, 2004, up from $9 under the previous contract, which expired on Dec. 31, 2003. The contract was signed by several cleaning contractors and Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union. To increase its negotiating leverage, the union asked for a contract that lasted just one year, so it will expire on Dec. 31 of this year, the same date that the union's other agreements with commercial buildings in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are to expire. Under the agreement, employers will increase their contributions for health coverage by $40 per month per employee. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Industrial Use Rises
description: India's industrial output rose 7.4 percent in November, compared with 5.4 percent in October and 4.1 percent in the month a year earlier. According to figures released by the government's Central Statistical Organization, industrial output rose 6.2 percent from April to November 2003. Industry accounts for only a quarter of the country's gross domestic product but contributes a substantial part of the government's revenues. Manufacturing grew 8.1 percent in November compared with 4.3 percent a year earlier. With farm incomes increasing after a season of ample rainfall, the demand for consumer durables like televisions and refrigerators increased 14.1 percent in November compared with 1.4 percent a year earlier. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Garbage Hauler Sentenced To Jail
description: A man described by the authorities as an organized-crime figure was sentenced to jail yesterday on charges including extortion and bribery in garbage hauling contracts. The district attorney's office said the man, Anthony Piccolo, 58, of Massapequa, N.Y., was given a jail sentence of two and three-quarter years to eight and one-quarter years. He was also directed to pay more than $500,000 in cash and assets in forfeiture. The court sentenced Mr. Piccolo's daughter, Toni-Lynn Piccolo, 32, of Islip last week to six months in jail and five years' probation, but Mr. Piccolo had headed the multimillion-dollar waste fraud scheme, the district attorney's office said. The two pleaded guilty in September. Stacy Albin (NYT)

The money will be used to create an endowment that can finance children's programs, conferences and other educational outreach efforts. Glenn Collins (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DANNENBAUM, ALEXANDER W. JR.
description: DANNENBAUM -- Alexander W. Jr., passed on January 10, 2004, former Sr. Vice President of Westinghouse Broadcasting, was a pioneer in the early days of radio and TV. Beginning in 1956 he began his career with Philco Corp in Philadelphia and then joined Westinghouse Broadcasting Corp in New York City where he had a prestigious career for 17 years and retired in 1973. Mr. Dannenbaum, fondly remembered as Bink, was born July 11, 1910. He graduated from Princeton in 1933, was an avid polo player and a Major in the US Army Signal Corps during WWII. After his retirement he moved to Florida where he became a sailing enthusiast. He spent his time between his home in Florida and Camden, Maine. He is survived by his wife Sally; son Alexander W. Dannenbaum III; brother Paul O. Dannenbaum; beloved by his step-children Brian, Ricky and David Stahl, and his six grandchildren. He will be remembered fondly by his family and friends for his sense of humor, warmth and love.

title: Press Release From J. P. Morgan Chase & Company
description: NEW YORK & CHICAGO (BUSINESS WIRE) Jan. 14, 2004 -- J. P. Morgan Chase & Co. (NYSE: JPM - News) and Bank One Corporation (NYSE: ONE - News) today announced that they have agreed to merge in a strategic business combination establishing the second largest banking franchise in the United States, based on core deposits. The combined company will have assets of $1.1 trillion, a strong capital base, 2,300 branches in seventeen states and top-tier positions in retail banking and lending, credit cards, investment banking, asset management, private banking, treasury and securities services, middle-market, and private equity. With balanced earnings contributions from retail and wholesale banking, the combined company will be well-positioned to achieve strong and stable financial performance and increase shareholder value through its balanced business mix, greater scale, and enhanced efficiencies and competitiveness.

title: From the Tap, Free Hot Chocolate Conquers the Freeze

Try the lobby of the Regency Hotel, 61st Street and Park Avenue, where the hot chocolate is free to anyone, from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m., on days when the temperature dips below freezing. Back near the elevators, the hotel has set up a stand for self-service hot chocolate, a steaming winter warmer that the chef, John Iachetti, makes just rich enough by melting his chocolate in half-and-half. Minimarshmallows, chocolate swizzles and peppermint sticks are available as garnishes. In summer, when it's above 80 degrees, there will be fresh lemonade for all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ENGELMAN, FRED L.
description: ENGELMAN--Fred L. 77, of Manhattan, died peacefully in his home on January 11, 2004 after a long illness. Born in the Bronx, NY to Tyler Henryta Weisel and Frederick William Engelman, he grew up in Chatham, NJ and graduated from Chatham High School (1944), Springfield College (1950) and Harvard University (1951). He served from 1944 to 1946 as a turret mechanic gunner in the Army 306th Bombardment Group. He taught history at the Hackley School, Tarrytown, NY for four years before leaving to pursue historical research and writing begun under the tutelage of Samuel Eliot Morison at Harvard. His work culminated in 1962 with the publication of ''The Peace of Christmas Eve,'' a narrative history of the peace agreement that ended the War of 1812. His writing also appeared in American Heritage and in 1964 he received the prestigious Guggenheim Grant. He then began a successful business career in the field of marketing and print media research where he developed new methods for measuring audience and compiling demographic information. e hen began a successful busi He held executive positions at Young and Rubicam, Lever Bros., New York Magazine, Monroe Mendelsohn Research and formed his own company F.L. Engelman & Associates before retiring in the early 1990's. He leaves a son, Peter C. Engelman, his daughter - in - law Kendell Clark, granddaughters Waverley and Grace Engelman of Conway, MA, and daughter-in-law Ann Hogan of Hampton Bays, NY, a niece and two nephews. He was predeceased by his son Bruce F. Engelman in 2001. A service will be held on Thursday, January 15, at 11 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the New York Public Library, Fifth Ave. and 42 St., NY, NY, 10018, Attn: Denise Szabo.

title: RAYOVAC ANNOUNCES LAYOFFS AND A MOVE TO ATLANTA
description: The Rayovac Corporation, the battery maker, said that it would consolidate the operations of Remington Products, the razor business it acquired in September, lay off 217 workers and move its own headquarters to Atlanta from Madison, Wis. Remington's offices and a plant in Bridgeport, Conn., will be shut and combined with Rayovac in Wisconsin beginning in March, Rayovac said. Rayovac is also shutting 65 remaining Remington service centers by next month. Rayovac will have costs of at least $8 million this year to integrate Remington; the company expects eventual annual savings of as much as $35 million. About 25 positions, including Rayovac's executive management, will move to Atlanta, which was chosen because it is closer to important global customers, the company said.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Embargo On Import Of Civet Cats Linked To SARS In China
description: The federal government imposed an immediate embargo on the import of civet cats, a relative of the mongoose, because of concerns that they have spread the SARS virus to humans in China. ''This embargo will help us protect the American public and prevent introduction of SARS in the United States,'' said Tommy G. Thompson, secretary of health and human services. This month, officials in Guangdong Province in southeastern China ordered the killing of every civet cat in captivity in the province after researchers found that a Guangdong man had fallen ill with a new strain of SARS virus that is genetically similar to a strain found in civet cats. The civet is considered a delicacy in parts of China. John Files (NYT)

title: Cultures Collide, and a Heart Is Broken
description: When Aeschylus' ''Eumenides'' had its premiere in Athens in 458 B.C., women reportedly screamed, and some even had miscarriages. When Bobby Simone, Jimmy Smits's character on the television series ''N.Y.P.D. Blue,'' died in an episode in 1998, thousands of viewers were said to have wept before their televisions. Today the catharsis of tragedy, noted since the days of the ancients, can lurch perilously close to soap opera. And Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly,'' which returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Monday night, lies squarely at the intersection of the two.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIS, CHARLES ELLIOTT
description: LEWIS--Charles Elliott. Age 71. Of Boca Raton, FL., formerly, a long-time resident of Bronxville, N.Y., passed away peacefully after a long illness on Sunday, January 4, 2004. Adored and beloved husband, soulmate and friend of Christine B. Lewis. Devoted and loving father of Charles E. Lewis, Jr. and Dr. Catherine F. Lewis. Loving brother of Maryann Wolter. Admiring father-in-law of Dean Hamilton. Adoring grandfather of Colin Lewis Hamilton. Born in Youngstown, OH. Charles served in the Air Force and held an MBA from Case Western University and an LLB from Yale Law School where he was on the Law Review. He retired in 1998, having spent his legal career as an attorney at Wilkie Farr, Gulf & Western, and F.D.I.C. Charles was one of a kind, an extraordinary man of great character, inner strength and spirit. His learned advice, legal and business knowledge, worldly views and witty personality will sorely be missed by his family and all who knew him. May he rest in peace. A memorial service will be held Saturday, January 17, 2004, 1PM, Christ Church, Bronxville, N.Y. Memorial donations may be made to Yale Law School, POB 208341, New Haven, CT. 06520-8341.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BRONX: SHOPKEEPERS THWART ROBBERY Two shopkeepers — a husband and wife — with the help of a neighboring vendor, fought off two armed attackers who were trying to rob them on Monday night, the police said yesterday. The two, Young Sang, 61, and her husband, Don Sang, 65, were slashed on the face and neck by one of the men, who used a box cutter, the police said. The attempted robbery began at 6:30 p.m. at Sang's Gift and Beauty on East 167th Street. After the two attackers — the second armed with an air pistol — tried to take cash from the register, the police said, the Sangs began struggling with them. Down the street, Soo Shin, 41, of Young Discount Shop, noticed a commotion and ran over, the police said, helping to restrain one suspect, identified as Julius Pena, 19, of the Bronx. The police arrested the other man, Alpha Reid, 22, who lives in the same building as Mr. Pena, later last night. Mr. Shin and the Sangs were treated at Lincoln Hospital and released.   Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINER, IRVING H.
description: WEINER--Irving H. June 7, 1910-January 11, 2004. Dearly beloved soulmate and friend, husband, father, uncle, grandfather, great grandfather, ''Gramps''. Both his laughter and ethics will echo in our ears and his love for us and our love for him will be eternal. A self made accomplished NYU graduate; his accounting ethics are unmatched. No deduction in love or money taken for granted. Donations in his honor may be sent to B'nai B'rith or NYU Stern School of Business.

title: Bush Plans $1.5 Billion Drive For Promotion of Marriage
description: Administration officials say they are planning an extensive election-year initiative to promote marriage, especially among low-income couples, and they are weighing whether President Bush should promote the plan next week in his State of the Union address.

title: Army Copter Downed West of Baghdad in Hotbed of Anti-U.S. Sentiment
description: A month after Saddam Hussein was pulled from his spider hole, and with the transfer of sovereignty looming, Iraq staggered through another disturbing day of violence and instability.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Caterer Asks For Inquiry
description: The French catering company Sodexho Alliance asked the French financial market regulator to investigate a 3.5 percent decline in its share price on Monday after a report issued by Citigroup's Smith Barney questioned a filing it made with the Securities and Exchange Commission in the United States. The filing disclosed that a Sodexho subsidiary in Britain had packaged 82 million euros in loans ($104 million) and sold them as securities. The Smith Barney report said the securitization had not been previously disclosed and might have been the reason Sodexho's results were better than expected last year. Sodexho's chief financial officer, Sian Herbert-Jones, said the accounting had been previously disclosed and did not account for the company's better-than-expected cash flow. The company said it would wait until the French regulator investigates to decide on further legal action. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: Killer of Swedens Foreign Minister Tells of Hearing Voices
description: STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 14  On the first day of his trial, the confessed killer of Anna Lindh, Sweden's foreign minister, denied today that he had intended to kill her but said he could not ignore voices in his head telling him to attack.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Five Beaten In Racial Fight
description: Five men were beaten, one almost fatally, in a racially charged fight in Bushwick early yesterday, the police said. The men, all of Russian extraction, were leaving a bodega around 1 a.m. when a group of at least six Hispanic men approached, the police said. The Hispanic men made anti-Russian slurs, an ensuing argument quickly escalated to a fistfight, and the Hispanic men began brandishing weapons, a police official said. Wilfredo Ramos, 32, was charged with assault and criminal possession of a weapon, and the police were seeking his companions. Valery Charnavus, 43, who was beaten with what the police think was a baseball bat, was taken to Elmhurst Hospital Center in Queens, where he was listed in very critical condition. Two of his companions were stabbed and two others beaten. Michael Brick (NYT)

title: Choir Founder Admits He Erred in Allowing Counselor to Keep Working With Students
description: Walter J. Turnbull, the embattled founder and director of the Boys Choir of Harlem, acknowledged yesterday that he had made a mistake in allowing a counselor to remain in contact with students after the man had been banned from the school for molesting a 14-year-old student.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Polio Spread From Nigeria, W.H.O. Confirms
description: Laboratory tests have confirmed that Nigeria was the source of the polio virus that led to two new cases of the crippling disease in Benin and Cameroon in West Africa, the World Health Organization said. On Thursday, the W.H.O. is holding an emergency meeting of health ministers from countries where polio cases are occurring to assure the agency's efforts to eradicate the disease by 2005. A grave concern is opposition to polio vaccination by some Muslim leaders in the north of Nigeria who have forced suspension of the immunization program there. Nigeria has exported polio cases to at least six West African countries in recent months. Lawrence K. Altman (NYT)

title: Kelsey Grammer May Join 'Producers'
description: The television star Kelsey Grammer, who won fame in ''Frasier'' and ''Cheers,'' is in negotiations to take over the role of Max Bialystock, the rakish producer at the heart of the musical ''The Producers'' after Nathan Lane completes his current run in the role, the show's producers said yesterday.

title: Gephardt Defends His Vote on Force in Iraq
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt offered a vigorous defense yesterday of his vote in favor of the use of force in Iraq and marched squarely into a debate that has roiled this presidential campaign.

title: A Splash of Americana for Your Cocktail?
description: Vintage cocktail shakers, like these unusual glass ones, above, decorated with whimsical animals, including red elephants, not pink, are among the items that will be offered on Saturday and Sunday at Antiques at the Piers. This show and sale is devoted to American antiques and collectibles. Other barware, kitchenware and gadgets from the 1920's to the 60's will also be on sale. The silk-screened cocktail shakers, from Michael Smith of Depression Modern, are $85 each, at booth 1100 on Pier 88. The show is from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. at the passenger ship piers, 88, 90 and 92, at 12th Avenue and 55th Street. Admission is $12.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORROW, LAURA EHRLICH, M.D.
description: MORROW -- Laura Ehrlich, M.D. retired psychiatrist. on Tuesday, January 13, 2004. Wife of the late J. Lloyd Morrow, M.D. and mother of Charlie, Mary Ellen, Kenneth, and Robert. Grandmother of nine. Services 12noon Wednesday, January 14 at the Jewish Memorial Chapel, 841 Allwood Rd, Clifton, NJ

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about gjetost, a kind of Scandinavian cheese made in part from goat's milk, misstated the part of its name that means goat in Norwegian. It is gjet, not gje. (Ost is Norwegian for cheese.)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Teacher Charged With Assault
description: A Brooklyn teacher was arrested yesterday after he punched an unruly student, the police said. The teacher, identified as Douglas David, 63, of Middle School 136, was charged with third-degree assault. The student, a 12-year-old boy in the sixth grade, was treated at Lutheran Medical Center for a cut over one eye. A police official said that when Mr. David plugged in an overhead projector for a lesson, the student unplugged it twice. Mr. David reprimanded him, the student ''came toward'' Mr. David, and Mr. David punched him, the official said. A spokeswoman for the Department of Education said that Mr. David, who has taught in city schools since 2001, had been transferred to an office job pending investigation. A teachers' union spokesman said the matter was being looked into. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Hurray! A Constitution! (Tell It to the Warlords)
description: For Ahmad Shah Mirdad, head of monitoring at the Afghan Independent Human Rights Commission, the adoption of a new Constitution by the loya jirga this month was something of a nonevent.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: Aristide Promises Elections
description: President Jean-Bertrand Aristide announced at the Summit of the Americas in Monterrey, Mexico, that he would hold legislative elections within six months, a move intended to quell growing opposition in Haiti to his leadership. Mr. Aristide did not set a date. Haiti's legislature essentially ground to a halt on Monday night as the terms of most of its elected representatives expired. Protests against Mr. Aristide have been growing, and his opponents, who accuse him of corruption and mismanagement, want him to step down now, two years before his term is scheduled to end in 2006. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about President Bush's involvement in his re-election efforts referred incorrectly to the current assignment of the political operative Ralph Reed. (The error also appeared in an article on Dec. 20 about grass-roots voting efforts by the Republican Party and in one on Sept. 29 about preparations by the Bush campaign to focus on the eventual Democratic nominee.) Mr. Reed is the Southeast regional chairman for the Bush-Cheney '04 campaign. He resigned as head of the Georgia Republican Party in May 2003 to join the Bush campaign, and was succeeded by Alec Poitevint.

title: Dean Wins First Primary, a Nonbinding Vote in Washington
description: Howard Dean won the District of Columbia's nonbinding presidential primary here on Tuesday, with the Rev. Al Sharpton running a stronger second place than had been expected.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: UZBEKISTAN: 36 BELIEVED KILLED IN PLANE CRASH; U.N. OFFICIAL DEAD A domestic airliner crashed in heavy fog on its approach to the airport in Tashkent, the capital, the Interior Ministry said. At least 36 people, including the senior United Nations official for Uzbekistan, were aboard and no survivors were reported. The Soviet-era Yak-40 passenger plane was en route from the southern town of Termez. In London, the Foreign Office confirmed early today that the envoy, Richard Conroy, had been killed. There was no immediate indication of what caused the crash.

title: Water Pump Case Tests Federal Law
description: For nearly half a century, a pumping station in South Florida has been pouring millions of gallons of storm runoff annually into the Everglades, keeping the farms and backyards of western Broward Country dry but filling the wetlands with water often tainted by pollutants, mainly from phosphorus-rich fertilizers.

title: New York College Enjoys Caribbean Success
description: Monroe College, a for-profit school founded in 1933, faced a sticky problem in the early 1980's. Its Bronx neighborhood was going downhill, and the administration felt it had to act. In search of a hedge, the college opened a second campus in New Rochelle, an urban pocket in affluent Westchester County.

title: With the Same Road Map, Koppel Returns to Iraq
description: The last time Ted Koppel traveled across the Iraqi desert, it was at the start of the United States-led invasion in March, accompanying the tanks of the Third Infantry Division.

title: Cathedral Statues Smashed
description: Seven religious statues, most a century old, were smashed yesterday in the San Fernando Cathedral in San Antonio by a man who proclaimed himself God and shouted that he wanted to save worshipers by destroying idols, the police said.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Wyoming: Agency Rejects Plan For Protecting Wolves
description: Wyoming's plan for managing its gray wolf population was rejected by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, which said the state must include greater monitoring and protection. The wildlife service plans to eliminate federal protection for wolves, which recovered in number in the 1990's, but will not begin the process until Idaho, Montana and Wyoming have plans in place for managing and maintaining the packs. Plans by Idaho and Montana have already been accepted. Kirk Johnson (NYT)

title: Shockey Favorite Is Retained
description: When Giants Coach Tom Coughlin announced the hiring of four assistant coaches yesterday, he made at least one of his players very happy.

title: Kerry Turning Some Iowans Into Believers in His Cause
description: He is no firebrand preacher, but more and more Senator John Kerry is seeing audiences that sound like revival meetings.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of American military deaths in Iraq on Jan. 7 misstated the age of Capt. Eric T. Paliwoda. He was 28, not 23.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NESSER, LOUIS M.
description: NESSER--Louis M. Died on January 12. Beloved husband of Thelma. Loving father of Mitchell, Ivan and Robin. Grandfather of eight. Greatgrandfather of five.

title: Suicide Bombing in Gaza Kills at Least 4 Israelis
description: EREZ, Gaza, Jan. 14  A young Palestinian mother, feigning a limp and requesting medical help, blew herself up today at the entrance to a security inspection center for Palestinian workers, killing four Israeli security personnel and wounding seven people.

title: Jury Selection Begins in Trial Of Ex-Nets Star In Gun Death
description: Jury selection in the aggravated manslaughter trial of Jayson Williams started Tuesday with about 320 prospective jurors gathered in an ornate former church that is being used as a jury-assembly room.

title: CANADIAN COMPANY BUYS MAKER OF SCHWINN BIKES
description: Dorel Industries, a manufacturer of furniture and car seats, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Pacific Cycle, the maker of Schwinn bikes, for $310 million. Dorel, based in Montreal, said it bought Pacific Cycle from Wind Point Partners, a closely held investment firm based in Chicago. Schwinn bikes are sold by some of the same retailers that sell Dorel goods. Schwinn, established in 1895 in Chicago, filed for bankruptcy protection in 1993. Pacific Cycle purchased the bicycle assets in 2001. Dorel had 2002 sales of $992 million. Pacific Cycle, based in Madison, Wis., also makes Mongoose and GT bikes.

title: The Kurdish Question
description: On Monday, Kofi Annan will have a chance to play ''a vital role'' in Iraq that the U.S. has promised. Iraqi, U.S. and British representatives will troop into his New York office with a request: inform the Shiite leader, Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, that the world body supports a reasonable timetable for Iraqi elections, not a premature election that would amount to a coup by Iraq's Shiite majority.

title: Suffolk's New Leader Hits the County Running
description: SURROUNDED by an indoor wilderness of potted plants received as office-warming gifts, most still dressed in cellophane and ribbon and some as tall as him, Steve Levy, the new Suffolk County executive, ducks out of his penthouse headquarters atop the county's H. Lee Dennison Building to, as he blithely puts it, blow his ''schnozz'' before sitting still, sort of, for a casual interrogation.

title: New Cadillac STS Is Coming to New York
description: The Cadillac division of General Motors, which will officially unveil its STS sport sedan at the New York auto show in April, released the first images of the car today.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Norway: Court Rejects Mullah's Release
description: Mullah Krekar, an Iraqi Kurd and the founder of the Islamic extremist group Ansar al-Islam, will remain in custody until Feb. 2, according to a judge's order. He was arrested in Oslo on Jan. 2 on charges of helping to plan murders in Northern Iraq two years ago. The police and prosecutors asked for the extended detention while they investigated. Ansar al-Islam has been blamed for attacks against American-led occupation forces in Iraq. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Kennedy Denounces Bush on Planning for Iraq War
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14  Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts issued a scathing denunciation today of the Bush administration's planning for the Iraq war, saying the decision to remove Saddam Hussein was misrepresented, was in part political, and could represent "one of the worst blunders in more than two centuries" of American foreign policy.

title: Police Tracing Clues in Spalding Gray Case
description: The theatrical monologist Spalding Gray was reported missing after he failed to arrive at a friend's home on Saturday evening and then failed to board a flight at La Guardia Airport the next morning, the police said yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: Lawsuit Costs Hold Steady

title: Study Disputes View Of Costly Surge In Class-Action Suits
description: A new study has concluded that both the average price of settling class-action lawsuits and the average fee paid to lawyers who bring them have held steady for a decade, even though companies have said the suits are driving up the cost of doing business, hurting the economy and lining lawyers' pockets.

title: Orange Crunch
description: The terror alert level has just been lowered to elevated (yellow) from high (orange), and America's cities, their budgets strained from paying police overtime, can breathe a sigh of relief for now. Federal announcements of a terrorism alert seem to be as regular as clockwork -- but there's been no talk of federal help to cities. Local governments now open their wallets with little help from Washington, but eventually cities may decide they can't afford to increase security during terrorism alerts, leaving the country more vulnerable to attack.

title: Latest Green Fashions Come in Many Styles
description: AS a lesson in the twists of globalization, nothing beats the story of the United States lime business. Spurred by immigrants from tropical countries and the taste for their cooking, lime consumption per capita quintupled to 1.9 pounds a year in the last quarter century. At first mostly American growers fed the demand, but in the last decade, as low-priced imports from Mexico surged, domestic production collapsed.

title: Clemens's Decision Doesn't Annoy Jeter
description: Derek Jeter sensed that Roger Clemens was close to abandoning his brief retirement when they spoke at Michael Jordan's golf tournament in the Bahamas last week. Clemens told Jeter about his fruitful discussions with the Houston Astros and how he was waiting for his family to give approval for him to pitch one more season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLFMAN, MATHILDA (BILLIE SCHWARTZ)
description: WOLFMAN--Mathilda (Billie Schwartz). Passed away peacefully on January 11, 2004 in her 96th year. A beloved mother of Judy and Al, Stephen and Sandra, grandmother to Larry, Madeline, Randi, Jeffrey, Marcie, Lauren, Leslie and Bobby, great grandmother to Joe, Greg, Alexa, Nathan, Isaac and Miles. Special Grandma Billie to the Molls and Getraer families. She was Aunt Billie and Grandma Billie to all her nieces, nephews and dear friends who appreciated her uniqueness. Billie Wolfman was one of a kind and the last of her line. She will be sorely missed. Contributions in her memory may be sent to the Hebrew Home, Fairfield Division, Riverdale, N.Y. or the ML4 Foundation. Schwartz, Linksman, Sobel Families

title: JUDGE ALLOWS HALLIBURTON UNITS TO BORROW FROM PARENT
description: The DII Industries and Kellogg Brown & Root units of the Halliburton Company won permission from a federal judge to borrow as much as $350 million from the parent company to help them reorganize, pay creditors and exit bankruptcy. Judge Judith K. Fitzgerald of the United States Bankruptcy Court in Pittsburgh approved the loan yesterday, to be paid back before almost all other creditors are compensated. The units sought Chapter 11 protection last month to gain court approval of a $4.2 billion settlement with more than 400,000 people who say they were harmed by asbestos or silica exposure.

title: Hussein Warned Iraqis to Beware Outside Fighters, Document Says
description: Saddam Hussein warned his Iraqi supporters to be wary of joining forces with foreign Arab fighters entering Iraq to battle American troops, according to a document found with the former Iraqi leader when he was captured, Bush administration officials said Tuesday.

title: Governor Rowland Should Resign
description: John Rowland appears determined to gamble that he can survive as governor of Connecticut even if state lawmakers move to impeach him, a process that could begin soon with the selection of an investigative committee. Governor Rowland maintains, over and over, that he broke no laws when he took gifts from people on state payrolls -- employees and contractors -- and lied to cover up his actions. But it is already clear that the governor has failed the state and is no longer capable of leading. It is time for Mr. Rowland to stop trying to save himself at public expense and step down.

title: She's a Doctor, Not a Candidate
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Taboo' to Close Next Month, At a Loss for Rosie O'Donnell
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FELDMAN, DR. ROBERT HOWARD
description: FELDMAN--Dr. Robert Howard. Beloved husband of Nobuko. Devoted father of Naumi and Mori. Son of Dr. Emanuel Feldman and brother of Amy Feldman Juhas and brother-in-law of Mark Juhas. Uncle of Rachel and Amanda Juhas. Services today, 11:15, ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Exprsswy, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: China to Give Up $41 Billion Stake in 2 Big Banks
description: Just a week after bailing out two of the country's biggest banks, China's Ministry of Finance is preparing to help them again, this time by writing off its $41 billion stake in them in a bid to help cleanse their balance sheets of nonperforming loans and prepare them to issue stock, Chinese bankers said on Tuesday.

title: FOOD IRRADIATION COMPANY TO FILE FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: The SureBeam Corporation, a maker of food irradiation systems, plans to file for Chapter 7 bankruptcy and cease operations on Friday after failing to reach a restructuring agreement with its senior secured lender or raise the funds needed to keep doing business. The lender has indicated that it plans to accelerate the maturity and to demand payment of SureBeam's debt, the company, which is based in San Diego, said Monday. The Titan Corporation, a military contractor that spun off SureBeam in 2001, said yesterday that SureBeam owed it $25 million in senior secured notes. Titan, also based in San Diego, said that it expected to take a one-time charge of up to $10 million.

title: A Musical Clue to an Enigma
description: To the Editor:

title: Couple Set To Plead Guilty In Enron Case
description: The former chief financial officer of Enron and his wife have agreed to plead guilty to crimes after all.

title: Profits Rise 38% at Lukoil, Mainly From Overseas Sales
description: Lukoil, Russia's second-biggest oil company, rode higher crude oil prices to a 38 percent increase in quarterly earnings, and said Tuesday that it planned to sell even more crude oil outside Russia and less at home to cash in on high global oil prices.

title: Inviting All Democrats
description: I'd like to invite Richard Gephardt and the other Democratic candidates to come here to Cambodia and discuss trade policy with scavengers like Nhep Chanda, who spends her days rooting through filth in the city dump.

title: Lure of Dermatology
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts yesterday about lobbying for the Golden Globe film awards, voted by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, referred incorrectly to Stern, a publication represented in the association. It is a German magazine, not a newspaper.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Will It Impurify Our Precious Bodily Fluids?

title: Enron Pleas Expected
description: Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron, and his wife, Lea, have agreed to plead guilty to crimes today in Houston, people involved in the case said.

title: Times Names Susan Chira Foreign Editor
description: Susan Chira, editorial director of book development at The New York Times, has been appointed foreign editor.

title: European Call To Reactivate Trade Talks
description: Europe's top trade minister added his voice to the call for reinvigorating global trade talks one day after the United States began its campaign to breathe new life into the stalled negotiations.

title: Sharon Again Hints at Gaza Pullout
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon raised the possibility on Tuesday that the Israeli military could one day withdraw from the Gaza Strip, where large numbers of troops guard Jewish settlers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SPOTO, ROGER M.
description: SPOTO--Roger M. One year in heaven today, my darling. Love you forever. Mo

title: Former Finance Chief of Enron Pleads Guilty to Conspiracy
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 14  Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron , pleaded guilty today to two felonies, becoming the highest-ranking officer at the company to admit to participating in crimes that contributed to its collapse into bankruptcy more than two years ago.

title: Giddy Times for Champagne Makers
description: ECONOMISTS and others who should know are saying that the economy's upturn in recent months has bypassed the working class and particularly benefited the country's elite.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CASALINI, FRIEDA MAY
description: CASALINI--Frieda May. Also known as Fritzi, age 93, died January 12, 2004, in the comfort of her home in New York City. She is survived by her husband of 45 years, Angelo F. Casalini, daughter, Valerie F. Petersen, granddaughter Gille K. Petersen and sister Mitzi Zarr. She attended The Cooper Union College. She worked for Block, Hesse and Shalat Architectural firm for 34 years before retiring in 1965. She was a avid reader, sportswoman and bridge player. She loved to travel and adored the opera. She won many speedskating competitions in the 1940s and 1950s at Grossingers in the Catskills. A private funeral service and burial is being held on January 14, 2004 at the New Mount Carmel Cemetery in Brooklyn. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, January 17th at 1PM at 141 East 56 St., Apartment 8K, New York City. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made in Fritzi Casalini's name to Hospice, 1250 Broadway, 7th Flr, New York, N.Y. 10001.

title: Democrats See A New Urgency In Health Care
description: Ten years after the political collapse of President Bill Clinton's health plan, the Democratic Party's presidential candidates are proposing, once again, major new programs for guaranteed, affordable health insurance, setting the stage for one of the starker contrasts with President Bush in the general election campaign.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett-Packard Invests Overseas
description: Hewlett-Packard said yesterday that it would invest $1 billion over the next five years to expand its manufacturing operations in Singapore, where it will shift some production from the United States. The company said the move would permit it to more quickly meet rising demand from China and South Korea for its high-end servers and printers. While many manufacturers have been moving jobs out of Singapore, Hewlett-Packard has nine factories there. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SUTTER, JEROME
description: SUTTER--Jerome, of Paris and New York, passed away in his sleep at his country home in France on November 12, with his family and close friend at his bedside.

title: The Zen of Braising
description: NOTHING beats a wood fire to bring out a cook's best instincts. At Fore Street, the restaurant in the Old Port district of Portland, Me., where Sam Hayward is an owner and executive chef, the focus of the kitchen is a long wood-fired grill and a wood-burning oven on a 35-square-foot hearth. The kitchen itself is open, warm, and bustling -- in effect, a kind of stage for an audience of diner-spectators.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   QUATTROCCHI, HENRY
description: QUATTROCCHI--Henry. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Henry Quattrocchi, associated with The Times from September 1967 until retiring in February 1990.

title: The Movie's Over. Well, Maybe Not Quite . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Bruno Says Billions More for Schools May Not Be Necessary to Meet Court Mandate
description: The Republican leader of the State Senate said on Tuesday that next year's state budget need not include billions of dollars more for schools to satisfy a court mandate to offer children a ''sound basic education.''

title: Hill, Holliday Acquires Erwin-Penland Agency
description: Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopolus in Boston is expanding for the first time in four years by acquiring Erwin-Penland in Greenville, S.C. Terms of the deal, to be announced today, are not being disclosed.

title: As the Democrats Take Over, McGreevey Turns Humble
description: James E. McGreevey's first two years as New Jersey governor have been nothing if not enigmatic, so it should come as little surprise that Tuesday, at the moment of what is arguably his greatest triumph, he gave his most unassuming major address.

title: Justices Uphold Roadblocks As a Way to Find Witnesses
description: The Supreme Court on Tuesday endorsed the use of police roadblocks as an investigational tool for finding witnesses to recent crimes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBERG, MORRIS
description: GOLDBERG--Morris. Age 81, died on January 11, 2004. Beloved husband and best friend of Frieda for 57 years. Loving father to Kenneth, Vicky and Jay; devoted father-in-law to Ivy, Michael and Rosanne. Adored grandfather to Ross, Stefanie, Daniel, Jonathan, Alexandra, Max and Kyle. A man of integrity and honor whose loss leaves a hole in the hearts of his family. Funeral Wednesday at 12 noon at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 800-938-6372

title: Mets Did Not Review Guerrero's Medical Data
description: Mets General Manager Jim Duquette said yesterday that he might have overstated the amount of medical information the team had about Vladimir Guerrero's back.

title: Fed Chief Offers an Optimistic View
description: The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said yesterday that the United States was able to finance its near-record current account deficit with few consequences to the global financial system and that the dollar's decline had not caused inflation.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When I would walk on the street, people would say to me, 'You've got teeth!'''

title: S.E.C. Proposes New Rules for Mutual Fund Industry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 — A deeply divided Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today that most of the nation's mutual funds remove the chairmen of their boards because they are also management insiders and replace them with independent chairmen.

title: Senators Don't Miss Stevens
description: Devils defenseman Scott Stevens had the flu and stayed home Tuesday night. The Devils might as well have played without skates.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Rogue Trades Cause Loss
description: National Australia Bank, the country's largest lender, said unauthorized trading in foreign-exchange options set off a loss of as much as 180 million Australian dollars ($140 million). The bank's shares fell 1.5 percent. Three employees in Melbourne and one in Britain were suspended because of the trading, which started last October and involved the Australian and New Zealand currencies, a bank spokesman, Robert Hadler, said. Mr. Hadler said action had been taken to close the transactions and no customers were affected. The loss was before tax, he said.

title: A Precaucus Pilgrimage To Plains, Ga., For Dean
description: Correction Appended

title: Grabbing the Limelight by Turns And Finding Comfy Grooves
description: Vida Blue

title: Straightforward Fare and License to Linger
description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections
description: A picture in the Business Digest column yesterday with an entry about a push by Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, for global trade talks was published in error. It showed Jim Peterson, the trade minister of Canada.

title: WB Ratings Slide: Reality vs. Reality Shows
description: The WB television network has had a loser of a season so far. That much its executives acknowledge, with a forthrightness unusual in the industry.

title: A Palestinian Asks, Who Made My Son a Suicide Bomber?
description: Bilal al-Masri lost his 15-year-old son, Amjad, to Israeli Army gunfire on Jan. 3. During the funeral hours later, his teenage nephew was shot and killed by Israeli troops. And on Sunday, Mr. Masri's 16-year-old son, Iyad, set out seeking revenge as a suicide bomber, but killed only himself.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Accusation Of Gay Bias Against Golf Club
description: The Human Relations Commission of Atlanta has decided that the Druid Hills Golf Club is violating a city ordinance by refusing spousal privileges to two gay members' domestic partners. The commission has the power only to advise Mayor Shirley Franklin, who has 30 days to make a decision. If she decides against the club and it does not change its practice, it could lose its business and liquor licenses. The complaint is the second legal challenge to a country club for discrimination against same-sex couples, said Jon Davidson, senior counsel for Lambda Legal, which is scheduled to argue the first such challenge, against the Bernardo Heights Country Club of San Diego, in the California Court of Appeal next month. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: The Movie's Over. Well, Maybe Not Quite . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: A Miami Makeover for an Aspiring SoHo of the South
description: Once a drab stucco structure with a heavy cornice, the Newton Building has a new skin. Now the 1970's building on Northeast Second Avenue, just west of Biscayne Bay, sports a shimmering aluminum cylinder with a turret emerging from the roof. By day, the metal has a moir pattern. Illuminated at night, it seems almost diaphanous.

title: Spareribs, Unflamed
description: IN this country, ribs tend to be summer food: we grill 'em. But in much of the rest of the world, they have been braised more often than not. When braising, of course, you sacrifice the crisp crust that is such a big part of the appeal of grilled meat.

title: Germany to Overhaul Military And Reduce Defense Spending
description: Germany announced deep cuts in defense spending yesterday and a sweeping overhaul of its armed forces, part of a continuing effort to modernize its outdated military.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MATERA, ARTHUR R.
description: MATERA--Arthur R. Died peacefully at his home on Saturday, January 10, 2004, after a long illness. He was preceded in death by his wife Barbara. Together they founded Barbara Matera Ltd., a theatrical costume company recognized internationally for its excellence. He lived his life fully; inhabiting the world of Broadway, dance and especially the opera which was his lifelong passion. Honoring Mr Matera's wishes, there will be no funeral or memorial service. Donations in his memory may be made to NYU Hospitals Center, Department of Cardiology, NYU Medical Center, Office of Development. 1 Park Ave, NY, NY 10016, attn Aron Bukspan or Broadway Cares Equity Fights AIDS, 165 W. 46th St., Suite 1300, NY, NY 10036.

Worsnop and the late Elaine Jones; grandmother of Julie, Michael & Kenneth; great grandmother of Lillian & Camellia Ford and Victoria and Catherine Jones. Memorial Mass will be offered Monday, January 19, 10 a.m. St. Matthew's Cathedral, 1725 Rhode Island Ave., NW, Washington, DC. For information DeVol Funeral Home.

title: U.N. Will Send Team to Iraq To Prepare for Possible Return
description: The United Nations said Tuesday that it had decided to send security advisers to Baghdad to study safety provisions in preparation for a possible early return of staff members to Iraq.

title: Roddick's Commitment Praised
description: Patrick McEnroe, the United States Davis Cup team captain, said Andy Roddick's commitment to playing in Cup matches went beyond the first-round match Feb. 6-8 against Austria in Uncasville, Conn.

title: The N.F.L.'s Passer Rating, Arcane and Misunderstood
description: It is the numerical ideal for National Football League quarterbacks. Yet it is an odd figure that lacks the clarity of a .400 batting average, or 2,000 rushing yards in football, or a 300 score in bowling.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Teacher Shot And Killed; Student Held
description: A high school student in The Hague fatally shot a biology teacher in the school's crowded cafeteria. The teacher had suspended the teenager just days earlier. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

description: Correction Appended

description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retailer Raises Funds
description: The British su-permarket chain, Tesco raised 773 million ($1.4 billion) through a share sale to add clothes and toiletries in existing stores and to open more outlets. Tesco also wants cash to buy as many as 23 Safeway stores that William Morrison Supermarkets must sell after it acquires Safeway amid an industry consolidation, the chief executive, Terry Leahy, said in a telephone interview. Tesco may raise more money this year through a property transaction like a sale and leaseback. The company, based in Cheshunt, England, sold 315 million shares at 5 pence each and granted an overallotment of 45 million shares to Cazenove & Company, which managed the sale with Deutsche Bank. The amount of money raised by the company is after expenses. Tesco also said that sales at stores open at least a year climbed 7.5 percent during the holidays as shoppers bought more DVD's and compact discs.

title: Evolution of Gene Related to Brain's Growth Is Detailed
description: A gene that helps determine the size of the human brain has been under intense Darwinian pressure in the last few million years, changing its structure 15 times since humans and chimps separated from their common ancestor, biologists have found.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Insignia In Venture With I.B.M.
description: Shares of Insignia Solutions rose 154 percent on Tuesday after the company said it had joined with I.B.M. to sell a system for remotely managing and updating cellphones. Financial terms were not disclosed. Shares of Insignia rose $1.52, to close at $2.51 on Nasdaq. Under the pact, Insignia, based in Fremont, Calif., will adapt its software to work with I.B.M.'s WebSphere business package and with device management software from I.B.M., which is based in Armonk, N.Y. The two companies will sell the product together to cellphone operators and phone manufacturers worldwide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GAMBLING, JOHN
description: GAMBLING--John. John was always a great friend to us. His good humor and voice will be missed greatly. Our deepest sympathy to Sally and the family. We are sure that John and Bill are playing paddle tennis as we speak. Annette and Noah Osnos, and June Bremer

title: Knicks Fire Chaney as Coach and Hire Wilkens
description: With another swift blow in his 24th day as team president, Isiah Thomas continued his dramatic reconstruction of the New York Knicks by severing the team's ties to head coach Don Chaney, who had failed to produce a winning record in two-plus seasons, and installing the Hall of Fame coach with the most victories and defeats, Lenny Wilkens.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Kashmir Separatists Asked To Talks
description: For the first time since separatists began an insurgency in the Indian-controlled portion of Kashmir 15 years ago, the Indian government has formally invited separatist leaders to New Delhi for talks, officials said. Deputy Prime Minister Lal Krishna Advani will meet with leaders from the All Parties Hurriyat Conference, a coalition of nonviolent separatist groups, on Jan. 22. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: Inhabitants of an Empty House Built With Grief and Longing
description: We often equate loss with chaos. Loss has its own logic, though, its ''architecture'' to use the playwright Julia Cho's word. The materials of loss include grief, rage, repression and longing. A family is the subject of ''The Architecture of Loss,'' Ms. Cho's touching new play at New York Theater Workshop's Fourth Street Theater. The play opens on a dry hot summer day just outside Tucson. We see bare white walls. Sand at the front of the stage represents the desert; a bare floor, a white table and a few chairs are all we get of home. (This effective design is by Riccardo Hernandez.)

title: Editorial Observer; Paul O'Neill, Unplugged, or What Would Alexander Hamilton Have Done?
description: Read Robert Rubin's recently released memoir and ''The Price of Loyalty,'' Ron Suskind's new book on Paul O'Neill's time in the Bush administration, and a few things become apparent. The first is that Mr. O'Neill would have really liked having Mr. Rubin's job.

title: Keeping Detentions Secret
description: The Supreme Court made it easier this week for the government to drape a cloak of secrecy over the imprisonment of people accused of crimes when it rejected an appeal seeking the identity of hundreds of men rounded up after the Sept. 11 attacks. The freedom of all Americans is diminished.

title: National Briefing: Rockies
description: WYOMING: AGENCY REJECTS PLAN FOR PROTECTING WOLVES Wyoming's plan for managing its gray wolf population was rejected by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, which said the state must include greater monitoring and protection. The wildlife service plans to eliminate federal protection for wolves, which recovered in number in the 1990's, but will not begin the process until Idaho, Montana and Wyoming have plans in place for managing and maintaining the packs. Plans by Idaho and Montana have already been accepted. Kirk Johnson (NYT)

title: Rowland Says He Would Welcome an Impeachment Inquiry
description: A day before the Legislature was expected to announce the formation of a committee to study his impeachment, Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut said on Tuesday that he welcomed the inquiry.

title: Heard of City Mouse? Try Bigger, and Uglier
description: What was that furry creature parked yesterday on a ledge at 135 East 35th Street? A big rat? A cat? A small bear? For nearly eight hours, a quiet corner in Murray Hill was transformed into a kind of temporary zoo, as passers-by stopped to gawk and guess the identity of the long-snouted cat-size animal that paced along a narrow stone ledge about nine feet over a brownstone garden, sniffing, shaking and yawning.

title: About New York; At 99 Cents, Mystery Sells Cheap
description: ANOTHER customer, perusing the odd items of yet another 99-cent store in this city, selects a synthetic black belt from a rack and wonders aloud whether it is long enough to complete the loop around his formidable girth.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: President Abdicates Peace Role
description: President Chandrika Kumaratunga said she would not take over the stalled peace effort with the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam. Last week, Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe said he wanted to withdraw from the peace effort with the Tigers because the president had stripped him of control of the military. The president and prime minister have been in a political standoff since November, when the president fired three ministers and took over the military and state media. ''The prime minister cannot walk away from the cease-fire agreement, because he brokered it, and I won't take responsibility,'' President Kumaratunga said in a statement read by her spokesman, according to Bloomberg News. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Gephardt Says Dean Flip-Flopped on Crucial Issues
description: Richard A. Gephardt, battling Howard Dean for primacy among Democratic presidential hopefuls in the Iowa caucus vote on Monday, launched a fierce attack on Dr. Dean today by accusing him of flip-flopping on crucial issues out of political convenience.

title: In Olympian Dreams, Designs for the City; An Architectural Exhibition Showcases New York's Bid for the 2012 Games
description: ''NYC2012: Olympic Opportunities,'' now at the Center for Architecture in Greenwich Village, is a small show, but it presages huge architectural ambitions for New York City. The bid to make the city the home of the Olympics in 2012 may seem like a pipe dream, but detailed plans are well under way for some 25 sites spanning all five buroughs, New Jersey and Nassau County.

title: The New Europe:Slovakia : Bratislava vies to turn itself into strategic hub
description: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia  For decades during Communist rule, this small city at the southern edge of what was then Czechoslovakia was a dusty industrial town, best known for a massive oil refinery and a vast wilderness of decaying concrete apartment blocks on the north.

description: To the Editor:

title: One Thing or Another Gets in Mosley's Way
description: Shane Mosley could only smile Tuesday when it was suggested that his sweetest victory had tasted like bitter fruit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NAGLER, SIMON H., M.D.
description: NAGLER--Simon H., M.D. died on January 7, in New York. Dr. Joseph English, Professor and Chairman of the Department of Psychiatry, New York Medical College and the Psychoanalytic Faculty of the Psychoanalytic Institute of New York Medical College mourn the passing of their esteemed colleague, Professor Emeritus of the Department of Psychiatry and former Director of their Psychoanalytic Institute. He was a loved teacher, an inspiring mentor, an outstanding clinician and a caring friend. We express our heartfelt condolences and sincerest sympathy to his wife of 64 years, Thelma, his children and grandchildren.

title: A Smoke-Filled Room Without the Politics
description: Taking pity on desperate smokers, Joseph Franco, the owner of Caff on the Green, 201-10 Cross Island Parkway in Bayside, Queens, has set up a tent, the Butt Hut, outside his restaurant and catering hall, once the home of Rudolph Valentino. It has heat, lights and seats. ''But I never go in there,'' Mr. Franco said. ''I'm not a smoker.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAVITS, IRVING A.
description: SAVITS--Irving A. Beloved husband of Ruth, father of Cheri, Carol, Steve and Robert; grandfather of Mark, Danny, Jenny, Andrea and Toby. A gentle and kind man passed away Sunday, January 11, 2004. He loved his wife, family, heritage and country. We should all know the love Irving and Ruth shared. Contributions graciously accepted at UJA-Federation, 130 East 59 St., Room 402A, New York, New York 10022.

title: J.P. Morgan Chase to Acquire Bank One in $58 Billion Deal
description: J.P. Morgan Chase has agreed to acquire Bank One in a deal valued at about $58 billion that would realign the competitive landscape among the world's global banking giants, the two companies announced this evening.

title: Chaney Feels Heat But Won't Step Down
description: Don Chaney sounded as if he were a man backed against a wall Tuesday. He is trying not to see the handwriting behind him, but is dismayed by what lies ahead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCCAIN, BLANCHE TOBIN
description: McCAIN--Blanche Tobin, of Lenox, Massachusetts, formerly of New York, died on January 11th, 2004, after a long illness. Devoted wife of the late John Harlan McCain, beloved mother of John, Thomas and William. Loving grandmother of five and great-grandmother of nine. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Church of the Epiphany, 1393 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021.
