description: Edited by Martha Angle and Arwen Bicknell

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAMINSKY, LEONARD
description: KAMINSKY -- Leonard. On January 11, 2004 at age 76. Beloved husband of Eve. Father of Lauren, Richard, James and Lisa. Grandfather of Rachel, Hannah, John, Julia and Emma. Services Thursday morning, 10:30am, Temple Israel, Westport, CT,

title: CANADIANS TO BID ON IRAQ PROJECTS
description: President Bush reversed United States policy on Tuesday and said Canada would be allowed to bid on some of the $18.6 billion in American-financed Iraqi reconstruction projects, bringing to an end a bitter dispute with a major ally.

title: MEN'S FASHION : Knits and leather:Bringing into focus Italy's twin icons
description: Sweater boys in showy knits and cool dudes in sleek leather are icons of Italian style. In the movies or the streets and especially on the fashion runways, knits and leather are fixtures. But two houses showed on Tuesday how to take the look forward for the 2004 autumn/winter menswear season.

title: Gas Leak Is Blamed in Death of 2 in Family
description: Two members of a Bronx family, including a 9-year-old girl, died last night of what fire officials said was carbon monoxide poisoning caused by a leak in a gas boiler ventilation pipe.

title: The Neediest Cases; Mother and Daughter Flee To New Home, and Safety
description: It was close to midnight, April 1, 1999, and Rebecca Glucksman, 54, had two shopping bags packed with personal belongings. One was for her, the other for her daughter, Chaya Heitler, now 14.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANS, BARBARA E.
description: LANS--Barbara E., died Monday, January 12, 2004 on a beautiful snowy morning she would have greeted with a child's joy, of complications resulting from a fall, which is to say from her fierce independence. She was the Director of the BEL Gallery in Westport which mounted more than 200 exhibits. Postcards and greeting cards with her photographs of local scenes were distributed by CR Gibson and others, and her work also appeared in calendars and magazines. Her poetry was published in poetry magazines and regional newspapers. She was a past Board Member of the Silvermine Guild Arts Center and the Westport Arts Center; an artist member of those two organizations and the Rowayton Arts Center; and a founding member of the Y's Women of Westport/Weston, among her many community activities. She leaves behind her devoted children, Debbie, Stephen, Alan Amos and Maria, and her brother, Mark, and many wonderful friends. Donations in her memory can be made to Silvermine, 1037 Silvermine Road, New Canaan, CT. 06840. There will be a memorial celebration in February.

title: Brisket Was His Madeleine
description: ''I HAVE always said that holidays are very dangerous,'' said Edward Serotta. Old Jewish women are always looking to stuff a nice Jewish bachelor like him. Still, Mr. Serotta, 54, takes his chances because holiday meals are essential to his work, documenting what remains of Jewish life in Central and Eastern Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALLARMAN, ALFRED, DR.
description: HALLARMAN -- Alfred, Dr. We are devastated by the loss of our very dear friend. Our hearts are broken for his wife Paula and their daughters Denise, Randi and Lynn. We will miss him and he will be forever in our hearts. Lucy and Martin

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Investment Limits Loosened
description: India will allow local companies and partnership firms to invest up to 100 percent of their net worth in ventures overseas. The country's central reserve bank said companies looking to invest more than $100 million had previously needed approval from the bank. But the new rule abolished the monetary ceiling on such investments. The move was intended to allow Indian companies to take advantage of opportunities abroad and to acquire skills to adopt at home, the bank said. India's foreign exchange reserves are at a record high of more than $100 billion. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: The Other Down Under
description: Correction Appended

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Shopkeepers Thwart Robbery
description: Two shopkeepers -- a husband and wife -- with the help of a neighboring vendor, fought off two armed attackers who were trying to rob them on Monday night, the police said yesterday. The two, Young Sang, 61, and her husband, Don Sang, 65, were slashed on the face and neck by one of the men, who used a box cutter, the police said. The attempted robbery began at 6:30 p.m. at Sang's Gift and Beauty on East 167th Street. After the two attackers -- the second armed with an air pistol -- tried to take cash from the register, the police said, the Sangs began struggling with them. Down the street, Soo Shin, 41, of Young Discount Shop, noticed a commotion and ran over, the police said, helping to restrain one suspect, identified as Julius Pena, 19, of the Bronx. The police arrested the other man, Alpha Reid, 22, who lives in the same building as Mr. Pena, later last night. Mr. Shin and the Sangs were treated at Lincoln Hospital and released. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Sunday about cancer prevention at medical centers misidentified the health agency that is requiring prevention components at designated centers and spending $500 million, or 12 percent of its budget, toward prevention. It is the National Cancer Institute, not its parent agency, the National Institutes of Health. The article also misstated the affiliation of a cancer expert, Dr. Barnett Kramer. He is director of the office of disease prevention at the National Institutes of Health, not the Cancer Institute.

title: After Practicing With Wie, Els Says Seeing Is Believing
description: Ernie Els had heard about Michelle Wie's talent, but watching her display it impressed him even more.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Redwood: Temporary Water Solution
description: Residents of this upstate hamlet, who have put up with discolored well water that smells like oil for more than 20 years, will have spring water delivered to them free until a seven-mile pipeline can be built to bring in fresh water from the St. Lawrence River. The New York State Environmental Protection and Spill Compensation Fund announced yesterday that it would pay for the bottled water and contribute up to $1.8 million toward the $7.3 million cost of the pipeline, expected to be completed by 2006. State officials said that for decades, gasoline and oil from leaking commercial and residential tanks spilled into the groundwater, eventually contaminating the wells of about half the 200 homes in Redwood, 23 miles north of Watertown. Starting in 1983, those homes were fitted with charcoal filters, paid for by the oil spill fund. Jeffrey Gordon, a spokesman for Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, above, whose office administers the fund, said the recent discovery of lead in the Redwood wells made financing the pipeline even more urgent. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: The State of the Art column in Circuits on Thursday, about watches that download text information from the Web, misstated the fee structure for the data service, MSN Direct from Microsoft. It has an annual or monthly charge only; there is no activation fee.

title: McGreevey Sets Limited Goals As New Jersey Faces Strains
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey, facing a third year of fiscal strain, used his annual address to the Legislature on Tuesday to set out modest plans to build on recent economic gains and environmental protections.

title: Pfizer Moves to Try to Stop Drugs From Canada
description: Pfizer is stepping up its efforts to stop exports of low-price prescription drugs from Canada to the United States by imposing new restrictions on sales to Canadian drug wholesalers.

title: Berlusconi Can Be Prosecuted, Court Rules
description: Dealing a potentially severe blow to Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, Italy's highest court on Tuesday overturned a recently enacted law that had shielded him from criminal prosecution while in office.

title: High Jinks in Parliament Are Without Peer, Milord
description: If it weren't the last company of its kind in New York, a theatergoer might be tempted to take the New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players for granted. Its repertory is only a handful of works, shuffled slightly from year to year, and its productions are offered in short bursts, rather than steadily through the year. Still, when Albert Bergeret started this company in 1974, it was one of a handful of ensembles that specialized either in Gilbert and Sullivan or in the broader operetta repertory, of which these satirical works are the pinnacle.

title: String Quartets as a Magician's Bookends
description: Bernard Rands's new string quartet, played for the first time at Symphony Space on Friday, is further evidence that the madness that fell upon a good part of 20th-century music has lifted. In an odd evening that featured the Ying Quartet, a performance of Debussy's G-minor Quartet and a magician named Torkova, Mr. Rands's piece looked at first to be facing the wrong way: turning its back on heady exploration and retreating toward Debussy.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: SARS False Alarm
description: Officials said a person in Shenzhen infected with what the Hong Kong media said was SARS actually had a bacterial infection. China is still listing one case of confirmed SARS and two others as suspected, and Hong Kong television said China was close to labeling one of the two suspected cases as confirmed. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Chief Executive Quits At BBDO in New York
description: Bill Katz is stepping down after three years as president and chief executive at the flagship New York office of BBDO Worldwide, the agency said yesterday. The timing of his departure has not been determined.

title: A Jolt of Democracy in Georgia
description: The country of Georgia has a fierce political history and remains torn by separatist guerrillas. Bombs explode regularly in the capital, Tbilisi, and large parts of the government, the security forces and the business sectors are controlled by mafias. All of that makes Georgia an unlikely site for what have been relatively hopeful events in the last several weeks.

title: Dispute Heard on States' Duties Under Disabilities Act
description: In 1990, when Congress passed the Americans With Disabilities Act and placed new obligations on state governments to remove barriers to accessibility, the Supreme Court's revival of interest in states' rights still lay a few years in the future. Few people would have predicted the coming collision between the new law and the new federalism.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: SAP Revenue Falls
description: The software maker SAP warned yesterday that its revenue declined 3 percent in the fourth quarter compared with the period a year earlier, but that it was slightly better than analysts had expected. On a preliminary basis, revenue fell to 930 million euros ($1.2 billion) as a result of weak corporate demand and currency effects, the company said. SAP, which is based in Germany, said it had expected its operating margin to exceed the previously forecast 25 percent for 2003. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Revised Ground Zero Memorial Will Include an Artifact Center
description: The finished design for the World Trade Center memorial site will build on the original concept of twin voids marking the location and outlines of the twin towers, but will add lusher landscaping, create an underground center to house artifacts from the attack and establish a cultural center at the recreated intersection of Fulton and Greenwich Streets.

title: Brazil Seeks To Bypass Fingerprinting
description: Brazil on Tuesday ratcheted up its campaign to be exempted from a new American program that requires those foreign visitors who need visas to be fingerprinted and photographed on arrival in the United States. The effort followed a meeting late Monday night in which President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva personally appealed to President Bush to suspend the measure.

title: Dunham Continues To Own Isles
description: Yesterday morning, Mike Dunham insisted that his mastery over the Islanders was ''just coincidence.'' And he did not change his tune last night despite matching the longest unbeaten streak by a goaltender in the 31-year-old rivalry between the Islanders and the Rangers at eight games.

title: On to the Moon, And to Mars, Via von Braun
description: Once again, it is back to the future for NASA.

title: First 10,000 Units Are Coming In Housing Plan, Mayor Says
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that 10,000 units of new or refurbished housing -- the first of 65,000 units he has promised will be built or rehabilitated over the next five years -- were now under development, and that his administration would offer a loan program in cooperation with four commercial banks to develop thousands more abandoned or decaying properties in the city over the next few years.

Beloved Husband of the late Jean Mason, cherished Father of Howard, Molly and the late Eli, devoted Grandfather of Andrew and Evan and Great-Grandfather of Amelia, Jack, Lily and Rachel, Uncle of Alan, Elliot, Goldie, Leo, Marsha, Phyllis, Phyllis, Ray, Renee, Solly and Yuri. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, FR. ARNOLD, O.F.M.
description: BROWN--Fr. Arnold, O.F.M., beloved Chaplain of the Franciscan Family Circle Pilgrimages for 47 years. Died unexpectedly December 29 at St. Anthony Friary, St. Petersburg, FL. Funeral Mass celebrated on what would have been his 81st birthday, Friday January 2, 2004. Interment in Calvary Cemetery, Clearwater, FL. Special Memorial Mass for friends in metropolitan area, 2 P.M., Sunday, January 18, 2004 in Upper Church of St. Francis of Assisi, 135 West 31st St., New York City.

title: USA Today's Investigation Of Writer Raises Concerns
description: USA Today, which announced yesterday morning that it had concluded a seven-month inquiry into the accuracy of several articles by a former foreign correspondent without resolving whether he had falsified information, said last night that it had ''serious concerns'' about another of his dispatches.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: POLIO SPREAD FROM NIGERIA, W.H.O. CONFIRMS Laboratory tests have confirmed that Nigeria was the source of the polio virus that led to two new cases of the crippling disease in Benin and Cameroon in West Africa, the World Health Organization said. On Thursday, the W.H.O. is holding an emergency meeting of health ministers from countries where polio cases are occurring to assure the agency's efforts to eradicate the disease by 2005. A grave concern is opposition to polio vaccination by some Muslim leaders in the north of Nigeria who have forced suspension of the immunization program there. Nigeria has exported polio cases to at least six West African countries in recent months.    Lawrence K. Altman (NYT)

title: Tests Suggest Scientists Have Found Big Bang Goo
description: At least three advanced diagnostic tests suggest that an experiment at the Brookhaven National Laboratory has cracked open protons and neutrons like subatomic eggs to create a primordial form of matter that last existed when the universe was roughly one-millionth of a second old, scientists said here on Tuesday.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Uzbekistan: 36 Believed Killed In Plane Crash; U.N. Official Dead
description: A domestic airliner crashed in heavy fog on its approach to the airport in Tashkent, the capital, the Interior Ministry said. At least 36 people, including the senior United Nations official for Uzbekistan, were aboard and no survivors were reported. The Soviet-era Yak-40 passenger plane was en route from the southern town of Termez. In London, the Foreign Office confirmed early today that the envoy, Richard Conroy, had been killed. There was no immediate indication of what caused the crash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KUPFERMAN, LEONARD
description: KUPFERMAN -- Leonard. 1926-2004. He was the beloved husband of Edith, devoted father of Ellis (Maura) and Seth (Cindy), proud grandfather of Max, Jacob, Jennifer and Rachel. Leonard was a man of great character, known for his warmth and kindness. A dedicated father; he will be sorely missed by his family and friends. The Kupferman Family

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Record Glacier Melt
description: Swiss glaciers retreated last year at a pace not seen since systematic record keeping began in 1880, and the melting was a result of prolonged recent climate warming, not Europe's scorching summer heat wave, the Swiss Academy of Natural Sciences said. Some glaciers retreated nearly 500 feet, the academy said. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: 'Jimmy Kimmel Live' In a Deal With Coors
description: The Coors Brewing division of the Adolph Coors Company in Golden, Colo., has signed the first major sponsorship deal for ''Jimmy Kimmel Live,'' the late-night comedy-variety show by the ABC television division of the Walt Disney Company. Terms of the deal, to be announced today, were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARTIN, FRANCIS JR.
description: MARTIN--Francis Jr. Who helped take New York City broadcasting representative, John Blair & Co., public in the 1960s, died surrounded by his family on December 23, 2003 in Reno, NV, after a long battle with cancer. He was 83. Son of a distinguished Bronx County judge, Martin was a sales representative for the Dumont Co. before joining John Blair in the 1950s. In 1965, he was promoted to President and Chief Executive Officer. He retired after 15 years with the company. He was born in New York City on June 8, 1920 to Edith and Judge Francis Martin. Judge Martin was a presiding justice of the Appellate Division and the first District Attorney of Bronx County, NY, where a regional branch of The New York Public Library stands named in his honor. Martin attended Columbia University and Cornell Law School. He was a member of St. Anthony Hall fraternity, and the Union Club in Manhattan, and a former member of Maidstone Club in East Hampton and the Apawamis Club in Rye, NY. He was a lifetime social member of the La Quinta Country Club in La Quinta, CA, where he served for several years on the board of directors. He then moved to Merrakesh where he spent three wonderful months a year. He also served on the Board of Desert Hospital in Palm Springs for eight years. After retiring, he enjoyed playing golf, backgammon, bridge, fly fishing and traveling. He is survived by his wife of 40 years, Mimi Martin, his two children, Anne Rossman of Menlo Park, CA and Francis III of Portland, OR, his stepson, Scott Marshutz of Laguna Niguel, CA and two granddaughters, Eleanor and Grace of Portland, OR. He is missed by all. Friends are invited to attend a Celebration of Life service on Saturday, January 24, 2004 from 4-6 P.M. at the Hidden Valley Country Club, 3575 Hidden Valley Drive, Reno, NV 89502. In lieu of flowers, donation may be made to the American Cancer Society.

Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY, at 11:30 AM, Thursday, January 15. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Asthma Hospitalization Rates Drop
description: New York City children were less likely to be hospitalized for asthma in 2002 than at any time since the city started keeping track in 1984, the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene reported yesterday. The rate declined 44 percent from 1993, yet there were still 9,821 hospitalizations in 2002, and asthma remains a leading childhood health threat. There is no sign that asthma has become less prevalent. Rather, officials say, it is better controlled, after years of public education campaigns urging doctor visits, regular use of medication and avoidance of situations that trigger attacks. Out of every 1,000 children in the city under age 14, 6 were hospitalized for asthma in 2002. The Bronx had the highest rate, 9.7 per 1,000, followed by Manhattan, 5.8; Brooklyn, 5.5; Queens, 4.6; and Staten Island, 2.8. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

Brightly colored garments sold well in the quarter, particularly a pink trench coat that had been modeled by Kate Moss, above, Mr. Metcalf said. ''It's been a color story,'' he said. title: The New Europe:Slovakia : How will Slovakia define itself in EU?
description: LONDON  As Slovakia moves toward European Union membership on May 1, its leaders face a dilemma familiar to any prospective member state: what role should their country seek to play in the Union? With a population of just 5.4 million, Slovakia cannot aspire to join big countries like France and Germany in trying to shape the Union in its own image. As a relatively poor country, it hopes to gain funds from its EU partners rather than exerting influence through being a paymaster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STODDART, NORMA AGNES
description: STODDART--Norma Agnes. Born in Edinburgh, Scotland on May 12, 1944, Norma died at her home in Santa Monica, CA. on January 12, 2004 surrounded by family and friends, after a heroic 12-year struggle with breast cancer. She graduated from Edinburgh University in 1969 with a Ph.D. in biochemistry. In 1968, she married Fraser Stoddart, currently professor of chemistry and Director of the California NanoSystems Institute at UCLA. Following post doctoral research in endocrinology at Queen's University in Canada and at Sheffield University in England, she devoted the next ten years to raising their two daughters. She then returned to academic life in support of the research efforts of her husband in chemistry at the Universities of Sheffield, Birmingham, and California, Los Angeles. Norma will be remembered for her down-toearth common sense, dry wit, and generosity of spirit. Donations may be send to the Norma Stoddart Prize for Academic Excellence and Outstanding Citizenship open to research students and fellows in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at UCLA. Contact the Chair's Office, Telephone: 310 825-3958; email: chair@chem.ucla.edu. Flowers to The Little Chapel of The Dawn, 1925 Arizona Ave, Santa Monica, CA. 90404. The service in celebration of her life and works will be private. Norma is survived by her husband and their two daughters, both chemists, Fiona McCubbin of Belmont, MA. and Alison Stoddart of Cambridge, England.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEVERIN, AUGUSTA
description: SEVERIN--Augusta, age 89 of Bronxville, NY. Wife of the late Harry M. Severin and mother of the late Gregory M. Severin. title: From Vermont, All-American Buffalo Mozzarella
description: Water buffaloes have always been considered the source of the finest mozzarella. But the only way to get it was to import it from Italy. Last spring, at his Star Hill Dairy in Woodstock, Vt., David Muller began milking a small herd of water buffaloes to make yogurt. That turned out to be a delicious tease, because now he is also producing the only buffalo mozzarella made in the United States. Star Hill Dairy's is certainly fresher than any Italian import. A small snowy globe, a mere four ounces, is satiny and just firm enough on the outside to hold its sumptuously creamy heart. Without the ripe summer tomatoes and basil it deserves, consider serving it with a drizzle of fruity olive oil and some lightly sauted mushrooms or slices of roasted beets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIS, CHARLES ELLIOTT
description: LEWIS--Charles Elliott. Age 71. Of Boca Raton, FL., formerly, a long-time resident of Bronxville, N.Y., passed away peacefully after a long illness on Sunday, January 4, 2004. Adored and beloved husband, soulmate and friend of Christine B. Lewis. Devoted and loving father of Charles E. Lewis, Jr. and Dr. Catherine F. Lewis. Loving brother of Maryann Wolter. Admiring father-in-law of Dean Hamilton. Adoring grandfather of Colin Lewis Hamilton. Born in Youngstown, OH. Charles served in the Air Force and held an MBA from Case Western University and an LLB from Yale Law School where he was on the Law Review. He retired in 1998, having spent his legal career as an attorney at Wilkie Farr, Gulf & Western, and F.D.I.C. Charles was one of a kind, an extraordinary man of great character, inner strength and spirit. His learned advice, legal and business knowledge, worldly views and witty personality will sorely be missed by his family and all who knew him. May he rest in peace. A memorial service will be held Saturday, January 17, 2004, 1PM, Christ Church, Bronxville, N.Y. Memorial donations may be made to Yale Law School, POB 208341, New Haven, CT. 06520-8341.

In every case, Apple's goal was obvious: to create products so simple and creative that people would say, ''iWant, iLove, iBuy.''

Hall, the late David Henry Tishman and the late Virginia (Nina) Alexander. Adored grandfather of Adam and Laurie Bramwell, Margaret and David Doyle and David Alexander and Lauren Alexander and father-in-law of Richard Alexander. Mr. Tishman was the former Chairman of the Dartmouth College Real Estate Committee, Vice-President of the Jewish Child Care Association and one of the original developers of the Association for a Better New York. Family and friends are invited to the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 1076 Madison Avenue on Thursday, January 15, 2004, between 4:00 and 7:00. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERINGER, STUART MARSHALL
description: BERINGER--Stuart Marshall. 80, passed away on January 13, 2004. Born January 27, 1923 in New York City, he grew up in Larchmont and lived most of his married life of 54 years in Rye. He graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy, received a BS degree in Chemistry from Harvard University and an MBA from Columbia University. Beringer was a founding partner and, at the time of his death, Chairman of TM Capital Corp., NYC; Chairman of Servo-Tek Products, Co., Inc., Hawthorne, NJ; Chairman of Thakar Aluminum Corp., Sandusky, OH and Vice President Advest, Inc., Rye, NY. A seasoned and well respected member of the investment community, during his career he served on the Board of Directors of approximately 30 public companies including Essex Chemical Corp. and Lynch Communications Systems, Inc. His survivors include his wife, Alice, his sons Stuart Stratton Beringer and Peter Marshall Beringer; two daughters' inlaw; four grandchildren; two sisters' in-law; three nephews and three nieces. A memorial service is planned for January 31st at 2:00 P.M. at Rye Presbyterian Church. The family requests in lieu of flowers that remembrances be sent to Rye Presbyterian Church, Boston Post Road, Rye, New York 10580.

title: A Few Leftovers
description: This column is, after all, called "From the Desk of David Pogue." So by my calculations, that ought to mean that anything on my desk is fair game - including Post-Its. Herewith, a few scraps I've been saving up, none worth a whole e-column, but worthy items as a group.

title: Iraqi Team Disables Bombs With a Snip and a Prayer
description: The four police officers were squeezed into a small pickup truck, screaming down the highway from Baghdad at 90 miles an hour toward a bomb sighting, and they were happy.

title: JEFFERSON-PILOT TO PURCHASE CANADA LIFE
description: The Jefferson-Pilot Corporation, a life insurer, said it had agreed to buy the group life, disability and dental insurance businesses of the Canada Life Assurance Company unit of Great-West Lifeco. Jefferson-Pilot said it would commit about $200 million to the businesses. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. The purchase will increase Jefferson-Pilot's annual premiums in the three businesses by 56 percent, to about $1 billion. Jefferson-Pilot is based in Greensboro, N.C.

title: AOL hopes to score a touchdown for its struggling dial-up operations on Super Bowl Sunday.
description: THE AOL division of Time Warner will bet an estimated $10 million in a gamble on Super Bowl Sunday that it can start to turn around its struggling dial-up operations by helping customers who feel the need for speed.

description: The guide for the 2004 Sundance Film Festival, starting today in Park City, Utah, has its own special effect: it looks like an old library book, right. Images of a faded leather binding and marbleized paper were digitally distressed by AdamsMorioka of Los Angeles (www.adamsmorioka.com), the graphic designer for the festival. title: 'Did the Knicks Win?' A Clock Radio Races to Reply
description: Clock radios offer plenty of early morning news, weather and traffic reports, but they dole them out on their own schedules and interrupt them with commercials. The Web, of course, supplies an abundance of information on demand. Most people do not have bedside computers, however, or the inclination to use them when they first wake up.

title: Where There's Smoke There's Serenity

Just fill it with a garden hose or a pail, put firewood in the bin, light it up, wait a while and enjoy a 100-degree soak with natural eddies.

title: Tropical Brush Strokes for Next Year's Garden

The geraniums in my window are putting out new leaves, and we gardeners are quickening too. We are hearing the siren call of the catalogs and poring over them long into the night. It is almost as if, by morning, we expect cascading river birches, orange coneflowers and blue bamboo to be flourishing in the garden. A midwinter night's dream.

title: Bush's Space Vision Thing
description: Critics will no doubt accuse President Bush of fiscal folly for proposing a grandiose plan for space exploration at a time when the nation faces onerous deficits and insufficient money to meet costly obligations on planet Earth. The critics would be right that money is short and there are many more important things to do than put astronauts on the Moon or Mars. But Mr. Bush is a canny enough politician to avoid committing much money to his new space vision. He calls for only $1 billion in new financing for NASA over five years and a reallocation of the current five-year budget of $86 billion. The cost will of course explode later on, when NASA tries to actually carry out the program. What Mr. Bush has really done is promise the moon (literally) while leaving future presidents and Congresses to figure out how to pay the potentially large future bills while they cope with the severe revenue losses caused by Mr. Bush's reckless tax cuts.

title: Reflecting Absence

That name describes a design by Michael Arad and the landscape architect Peter Walker, a plan chosen by a jury, elaborated with their help and presented to the public in detail for the first time yesterday. But when construction is finished, when visitors wander through what Mr. Walker called ''the forest grove'' and come upon the voids marking the footprints of the twin towers, ''Reflecting Absence'' will have become, simply, the 9/11 Memorial. The anonymity of that name -- the way it takes for granted the design's expressive power -- will be the highest compliment the public can pay the designers and the jury that selected them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DIWAN, ROMESH KUMAR
description: DIWAN -- Romesh Kumar. Age 70, died January 12, 2004 in Troy, NY. He was loved & esteemed by his wife Joyce Johnson Diwan, parents Leela Devi and Fateh Chand Diwan, brother and sister Denesh Diwan and Lata Kaushal, and many other relatives, friends, and students. Distinguished economist, teacher & scholar, his M.S. degree was from Delhi School of Economics and Ph.D. degree from University of Birmingham, England. He was Professor Emeritus at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, where for several years he chaired the Economics Department. He held positions also at Panjab Univ., Univ. of Glasgow, UNCTAD, Washington Univ., & London School of Economics. Thesis advisor to 40 Ph.D. students, he published five books & 200+ articles in fields including Gandhian economics, international development, productivity and technical change, and information technology. Born in India, he was a long-time resident of Troy and Brunswick, NY. In lieu of flowers, you may donate in his memory to the Hindu Temple Cultural Center, 450 Albany Shaker Rd., Albany, NY 12211. Wake at 2-4 & 7-9 PM Friday and funeral services at 10 AM Saturday, at Morris-StebbinsMiner & Sanvidge Funeral Home, 312 Hoosick Street, Troy, NY 12180.

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Genentech Posts 37% Profit Increase
description: Genentech said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit rose 37 percent, increased by sales of its cancer medicines. Net income climbed to $126.7 million, or 24 cents a share, from $92.8 million, or 18 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue jumped 26 percent to $933.9 million, the South San Francisco, Calif.-based company said. Sales of Rituxan, which treats blood cancer, climbed 28 percent last year. The drug is Genentech's biggest and will increase profit even after federal regulators approve Avastin, a colon-cancer treatment that analysts say will top $2 billion a year in revenue. Shares of Genentech, which is majority owned by Roche Holding A.G., rose 42 cents to $90.67.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Yukos Challenges Tax
description: Russia's largest oil company, Yukos, said it was contesting a claim for back taxes and fines of 98 billion rubles, or $3.4 billion, made last month by the Russian government. Yukos said that the tax bill, the equivalent of 98 billion rubles, was unconstitutional, and that the company had formally demanded Russia's Tax Ministry withdraw its claim. Yukos called the tax bill ''blackmail on the part of tax authorities trying to create a false threat of bankruptcy around the company and to openly pressure its shareholders, creditors, employees and partners.'' The Tax Ministry said last month that Yukos owed more than 98 billion rubles in taxes and fines, contending that the oil producer unlawfully avoided the taxes by setting up illegal tax shelters. description: The number of uninvestigated fires last year was more than seven times higher than the number the year before, and is so large that the union that represents fire marshals says it cannot determine the city's true arson rate. Ed Burke, the fire marshal representative for the Uniformed Firefighters Association, said on Tuesday that because of budget cuts last year, 1,861 fires were not investigated. In 2002, only 253 fires were not investigated, Mr. Burke said. While the Fire Department last year stopped routinely investigating fires under three alarms, David Billig, a department spokesman, said suspicious fires and those that cause injury or death were still being investigated. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANS, BARBARA E.
description: LANS--Barbara E., died Monday, January 12, 2004 on a beautiful snowy morning she would have greeted with a child's joy, of complications resulting from a fall, which is to say from her fierce independence. She was the Director of the BEL Gallery in Westport which mounted more than 200 exhibits. Postcards and greeting cards with her photographs of local scenes were distributed by CR Gibson and others, and her work also appeared in calendars and magazines. Her poetry was published in poetry magazines and regional newspapers. She was a past Board Member of the Silvermine Guild Arts Center and the Westport Arts Center; an artist member of those two organizations and the Rowayton Arts Center; and a founding member of the Y's Women of Westport/Weston, among her many community activities. She leaves behind her devoted children, Debbie, Stephen, Alan Amos and Maria, and her brother, Mark, and many wonderful friends. Donations in her memory can be made to Silvermine, 1037 Silvermine Road, New Canaan, CT. 06840. There will be a memorial celebration in February.

description: A Long Island contractor was sentenced to 3 to 10 years in prison yesterday for second-degree manslaughter in connection with the deaths of five construction workers who were killed when a scaffold collapsed in Gramercy Park in October 2001. In pleading guilty on Sept. 30, the contractor, Philip V. Minucci, 32, of Commack, admitted that he had designed the 130-foot-high, 90,000-pound scaffold without following city building codes. In her sentencing remarks, Justice Rena K. Uviller of State Supreme Court in Manhattan called Mr. Minucci's crime ''the very definition of manslaughter.'' Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHEIN, ETHEL PAULINE
description: SHEIN--Ethel Pauline. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the immeasurable and untimely loss of Ethel Shein, a beloved member of the Museum's staff for 38 years. Ethel began her career at the Museum in 1965 as Promotions Manager in its Department of Publications. Between 1972 and 1995, she served superbly as Executive Assistant to the Museum's Director, Richard E. Oldenburg. In 1996, Ethel was named Director of Special Programming and Events. She is fondly remembered for her great loyalty and dedication to the Museum; her expertise in matters of diplomacy and protocol; her sincere solicitude for friends, colleagues and Trustees; and her love for art. Her life was enlivened by an insatiable appetite for Bakelite jewelry; a passion for Vienna, Tuscany, and St. Petersburg; and a deep love for music, which was reflected in her close involvement in the planning of the Museum's Annual SummerGarden concerts. Somehow in the midst of all she did, Ethel found time to edit a rare gem of a book, ''The American Sunrise.'' She will be deeply missed when we open our new building, but there are countless ways she will live on in it. We extend our profound sympathies to her brother, Paul Shein; to her nieces, Mary Santamarina, Abby Alford, Jennifer Anapolski, Alison Quill, and Katie Behr; and to her nephew, David Shein. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. Menschel, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: KB TOYS FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: KB Toys, the nation's fourth-largest toy retailer, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection yesterday, citing holiday-season price wars for its continuing losses. The company, which is privately held and is based in Pittsfield, Mass., said it had secured $350 million worth of financing from the Fleet Retail Group for its Chapter 11 reorganization. KB Toys has more than 1,200 retail stores nationwide. It plans to close roughly 400 to 500 stores. The company said it would continue to pay its 13,000 employees salaries and benefits and its vendors and suppliers while it reorganizes. According to a filing made in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Delaware, the toy maker Hasbro was listed as KB Toys' biggest unsecured creditor. KB Toys said that it hoped to emerge from bankruptcy protection before the holiday season at the end of this year. Barry Meier (NYT)

title: BANK OF NEW YORK TO OVERSEE CITY PENSION FUNDS
description: The City of New York has hired the Bank of New York Company as the custodian of its five pension funds, which hold $78 billion in assets. The retirement systems involved cover city employees, the schools, the Board of Education and the Police and Fire Departments. The Bank of New York will be responsible for accounting for and reporting of all their assets, starting on April 1, according to the city comptroller, William C. Thompson. The bank will also provide services to the pension funds' growing private equity and real estate programs.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: AFGHANISTAN: JUDGES PROTEST FEMALE SINGERS The Supreme Court protested the lifting of a ban on female singers on state television. "This is totally against the decisions of the Supreme Court and it has to be stopped," the deputy chief justice, Fazl Ahmad Manawi, said. He said the court had complained to the culture minister, Sayed Makhdoom Raheen, the main figure behind the ending of the ban, which had been in force for nearly 12 years. A broadcast by Kabul Television on Monday featured old images of Parasto, a popular singer who now lives in the West, performing without a head scarf. The deputy culture minister, Abdul Hamid Mubaiz, said the move was in line with the new Constitution. "There should be no discrimination between man and woman," he said. (Reuters)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Arrests In Insurance Fraud
description: After a two-year investigation resulting in 33 indictments, the police have arrested 20 people over a scheme to defraud no-fault auto insurance companies, law enforcement officials said yesterday. They said the operation used several businesses, including two medical centers, a law firm and an ambulette transportation company, to stage accidents, file false claims, provide unneeded medical treatment and obtain fake police reports in Queens and Brooklyn to support the claims. Two lawyers, Alan Blumen and George Vishnevetsky, are among those charged. The group is accused of filing false claims to procure more than $236,000 from companies including Allstate and Geico. Michael Brick (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Interest Rate Falls
description: Indonesia's benchmark interest rate fell to a record low amid slowing inflation and rising demand for the country's currency and stocks. The rate on the central bank's debt certificates that mature in one month fell to 8.06 percent in the weekly auction, down from 8.24 percent a week ago. Falling interest rates are buoying optimism about the economic prospects of Indonesia this year, despite the potential for unrest around parliamentary elections in April and the presidential elections that are scheduled for July. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Spain Sentences Imam for Book Offering Advice on Wife-Beating

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Accused Drug Lord Sent To U.S.
description: The Panamanian authorities extradited one of Colombia's most-wanted suspected cocaine lords to the United States, where he is accused of smuggling large amounts of cocaine in recent years. The suspect, Arcangel de Jesus Henao, who was arrested last week in a joint Panamanian-American operation in a remote and lawless region of Panama, was flown to New York, where he was to be arraigned. The authorities said that Mr. Henao was a leader of the Norte del Valle cocaine cartel and that he had contracted right-wing paramilitary gunmen to protect drug routes through which cocaine was transported to the United States. Juan Forero (NYT)

This happens when you properly cross funk, with all its nubby phrases and rhythmic accents, with the traditionally more flowing feel of jazz since the swing era, and that basic tension can draw in an audience. Henry Threadgill used that tension; in recent years Greg Osby and Dave Holland have built great bands with it.

Acquisitions and currency gains accounted for 11 percentage points of the sales increase. Danaher, which is based in Washington, is expected to report full results on Jan. 29.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Red Brigades Guerrillas Seized In Egypt
description: After more than 20 years on the run, Rita Algranati, 46, convicted in absentia in Italy for taking part in the 1978 kidnapping and murder of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro by the Red Brigades guerrilla group, is under arrest in Rome, the police said. The Italian and Egyptian police seized Ms. Algranati and a fellow fugitive, Maurizio Falessi, at Cairo Airport on Tuesday. An Italian court sentenced Ms. Algranati to life imprisonment in 1993. Mr. Falessi, 50, was convicted in absentia in 1989 and sentenced to 11 years for the attempted murder of a politician. The far-left Brigades terrorized Italy in the 1970's and early 80's. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Company Recalls Baby Toy

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Rises

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Playstation 2 Sales Surpass 70 Million
description: Sony announced yesterday that worldwide sales of its PlayStation 2 game console had surpassed 70 million, despite a year-to-year drop in holiday sales. The company sold 7.83 million units worldwide in November and December, according to a Sony statement, below the 8.5 million sold during the same period last year. The drop was most pronounced in North America, where holiday sales totaled three million, down from four million a year ago. The results still put the company ahead of estimates from analysts, who have predicted a steep sales decline for the PlayStation 2 and other game consoles as consumers wait for new models. Analysts at WR Hambrecht, UBS Investment Research and others increased their ratings on a number of game-related stocks yesterday, based on presumptions of better-than-expected holiday sales reports. The 70 million total further widens PlayStation 2's lead over Nintendo's GameCube and Microsoft's Xbox, both of which are edging past the 10 million mark. Nevertheless, Nintendo reported strong holiday sales for the GameCube, on which it recently offered a discount. Nintendo plans to reveal specific sales figures when it reports earnings at the end of the month, but a spokesman said that holiday sales were up 70 percent from a year ago and that it was on track to meet internal targets.

The Italian and Egyptian police seized Ms. Algranati and a fellow fugitive, Maurizio Falessi, at Cairo Airport on Tuesday. An Italian court sentenced Ms. Algranati to life imprisonment in 1993. Mr. Falessi, 50, was convicted in absentia in 1989 and sentenced to 11 years for the attempted murder of a politician. The far-left Brigades terrorized Italy in the 1970's and early 80's. title: 36 Hours | St. Paul
description: IF St. Paul were a play, it would have closed the January 1885 morning that a visiting New York newspaperman reviewed the city as ''another Siberia, unfit for human habitation.'' Town fathers of Minnesota's capital city didn't even bother to write a nasty note to the editor. Instead, to prove that the know-it-alls ''Out East'' were just wimps, they planned an outlandish outdoor festival in the dead of winter. The annual St. Paul Winter Carnival began in 1886. This year's edition will be Jan. 22 to Feb. 8., and as always, will be a battle between Vulcanus Rex, the king of spring, and winter's King Boreas, for the future of a town where the wind chills often hit 40 below zero. A highlight this year will be the National Hockey League's All Star Game, to be held the last day of the carnival. Among the other attractions: a palace made of 27,000 bathtub-size blocks of ice (shown above being cut out of Lake Phalen); an ice carving competition, which begins Tuesday; ice skating; a giant snow slide (helmets provided); and opening day and closing night parades with elaborately outfitted floats. There is even an occasional famous visitor. In 1986, Prince crossed the river and played unannounced to a crowd that danced away in long underwear and fur caps. Standing in the sub-zero wind chill, the Purple One ecstatically declared to the audience, ''Los Angeles ain't got this!'' NEAL KARLEN

An inquiry by education officials revealed that Sharpstown, which reported no dropouts during the 2000-1 school year, in fact had 30. It also found that the entire Houston district understated by more than half the number of its dropouts. Mr. Kimball said he would appeal the decision. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STODDART, NORMA AGNES
description: STODDART--Norma Agnes. Born in Edinburgh, Scotland on May 12, 1944, Norma died at her home in Santa Monica, CA. on January 12, 2004 surrounded by family and friends, after a heroic 12-year struggle with breast cancer. She graduated from Edinburgh University in 1969 with a Ph.D. in biochemistry. In 1968, she married Fraser Stoddart, currently professor of chemistry and Director of the California NanoSystems Institute at UCLA. Following post doctoral research in endocrinology at Queen's University in Canada and at Sheffield University in England, she devoted the next ten years to raising their two daughters. She then returned to academic life in support of the research efforts of her husband in chemistry at the Universities of Sheffield, Birmingham, and California, Los Angeles. Norma will be remembered for her down-toearth common sense, dry wit, and generosity of spirit. Donations may be send to the Norma Stoddart Prize for Academic Excellence and Outstanding Citizenship open to research students and fellows in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at UCLA. Contact the Chair's Office, Telephone: 310 825-3958; email: chair@chem.ucla.edu. Flowers to The Little Chapel of The Dawn, 1925 Arizona Ave, Santa Monica, CA. 90404. The service in celebration of her life and works will be private. Norma is survived by her husband and their two daughters, both chemists, Fiona McCubbin of Belmont, MA. and Alison Stoddart of Cambridge, England.

In preparation for Monday's meeting in New York among Secretary General Kofi Annan, the chief American administrator, Paul Bremer III, and leaders of the Iraqi Governing Council, high-level American and U.N. officials have begun promising discussions on related issues. Both sides are speaking of each other in far more constructive tones than those used in the past year. This welcome breakthrough needs to be sustained and built on. Iraq's future depends on strong coordination between the United States and the United Nations.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Bank Assistance

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Beatle Settlement Sought
description: Lawyers for the estate of George Harrison and for the oncologist they sued last week negotiated for four hours yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn in an effort to resolve the case and put an end to the publicity surrounding it. The suit sought damages for what the Harrison family claimed was Dr. Gilbert Lederman's violation of Mr. Harrison's confidentiality by giving many interviews in the former Beatle's final days and after his death. A major goal of the suit appeared to be to force the doctor to turn over a guitar that he had his 12-year-old son play for a failing Mr. Harrison and that he reportedly coerced the dying musician to autograph. Judge Nicholas G. Garaufis said, ''The reputation, the dignity of all concerned is best preserved by trying to reach some early settlement of the matter.'' William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Editorial Notebook; Fantasy and Reality in Iowa

''I have listened to everyone stand up every four years and promise me the world,'' she declared rather wearily to Senator John Kerry, who happened to be the candidate making his pitch at the moment. Then Ms. Noren dared to pose the ultimate caucus question: how on earth could the candidate -- a good man, she conceded -- get all those promises enacted into reality?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHEIN, ETHEL PAULINE
description: SHEIN--Ethel Pauline. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the immeasurable and untimely loss of Ethel Shein, a beloved member of the Museum's staff for 38 years. Ethel began her career at the Museum in 1965 as Promotions Manager in its Department of Publications. Between 1972 and 1995, she served superbly as Executive Assistant to the Museum's Director, Richard E. Oldenburg. In 1996, Ethel was named Director of Special Programming and Events. She is fondly remembered for her great loyalty and dedication to the Museum; her expertise in matters of diplomacy and protocol; her sincere solicitude for friends, colleagues and Trustees; and her love for art. Her life was enlivened by an insatiable appetite for Bakelite jewelry; a passion for Vienna, Tuscany, and St. Petersburg; and a deep love for music, which was reflected in her close involvement in the planning of the Museum's Annual SummerGarden concerts. Somehow in the midst of all she did, Ethel found time to edit a rare gem of a book, ''The American Sunrise.'' She will be deeply missed when we open our new building, but there are countless ways she will live on in it. We extend our profound sympathies to her brother, Paul Shein; to her nieces, Mary Santamarina, Abby Alford, Jennifer Anapolski, Alison Quill, and Katie Behr; and to her nephew, David Shein. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. Menschel, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Foreign Minister Out
description: Foreign Minister Yoon Young Kwan resigned, accepting responsibility for a rift between pro-American officials in his ministry and members of President Roh Moo Hyun's staff who favor an independent approach in relations with the United States. Mr. Roh's office said that Mr. Yoon, above, had failed to direct and supervise the president's foreign policy while ''dissent and confusion'' could be seen in the country's diplomatic efforts. Mr. Roh was elected with the support of many South Koreans who view Seoul's ties with Washington as a hindrance to reconciliation with North Korea. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: Three Down-and-Outs Rescue a Foundling From the Trash. Anyone Have a Pacifier?
description: It is curious that animation, in many ways the freest form of filmmaking, should also be among the most convention-bound. In the United States, feature-length animation is synonymous with children's entertainment, and even in Japan, where anime occupies a much broader cultural niche, much of it is confined to the science fiction and fantasy genres. Satoshi Kon, a 39-year-old Japanese director whose third film, ''Tokyo Godfathers,'' opens today, is happily oblivious to such constraints. His previous movie,''Millennium Actress,'' which had a brief commercial release in the United States last year, was beyond category -- a meticulously drawn surrealist pseudo-documentary that was also a pen-and-ink primer in classical Japanese live-action cinema.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Airbus Deliveries
description: Airbus became the world's largest maker of commercial aircraft by delivering 305 planes last year. It topped the Boeing Company, which had 281 deliveries, but it remained near the level of 2002, when it delivered 303 planes. Last year, Airbus won gross new orders for 284 jets, compared with 240 for Boeing. Airbus, which is based in Toulouse, France, has a backlog of orders for 1,454 aircraft, which represents about five years of production at current rates, compared with 1,110, about four years of production, for Boeing. The Airbus chief executive, Nol Forgeard, said that ''for 2004, we expect the market to remain soft, with deliveries close to 300.'' In 2003, Airbus delivered its first A318 double-decker aircraft to Frontier Airlines and Air France. Hlne Fouquet (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: The headline and the opening paragraph of an article yesterday about a government study of the effectiveness of this year's influenza vaccine misstated a finding. The research, by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, suggested that the vaccine was largely ineffective against influenza and other ailments that resemble it. But because of the limits of the study, the researchers were unable to conclude specifically that it was ineffective against any influenza strain, including the Fujian strain that has caused a majority of cases this year.

title: WCI STEEL TO CUT JOBS AND REDUCE 401(k) CONTRIBUTIONS
description: WCI Steel, a steel maker that sought bankruptcy protection in September, said yesterday that it would cut 10 percent of its salaried work force and reduce contributions to salaried workers' 401(k) savings plans. The cuts affect 37 of WCI's 370 salaried employees. The company, based in Warren, Ohio, said it would offer the workers incentives to retire early. The company, which is owned by the closely held Renco Group, expects the move to save about $3 million annually and help it become more competitive. WCI makes steel for electrical equipment, construction and automotive customers.

title: GILLETTE LOSES RULING AS IT TRIES TO BAR A SCHICK RAZOR
description: Gillette lost a court ruling yesterday in which it sought to force the new Schick Quattro razors off market shelves and eliminate a competitor to its best-selling Mach3 product line. Judge Patti B. Saris of United States District Court in Boston said Schick, a unit of Energizer Holdings, could sell the Quattro until a patent-infringement lawsuit filed by Gillette is decided. The judge said Gillette, based in Boston, was not likely to succeed in its claim that the four-blade Quattro copied patented technology. Gillette said yesterday that it was introducing a battery-powered version of its Mach3 razor. The new version, which sends pulses to stimulate hair away from the skin, will cost about $15.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: First Sentencing In Gang Rape
description: One of the five homeless men who have admitted robbing, beating and raping a woman near Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in 2002 was sentenced in State Supreme Court yesterday to 21 years in jail. The man, Victor Cruz, 23, and his four co-defendants pleaded guilty last month to sexually assaulting a 42-year-old woman they had taken to a homeless encampment near the park on Dec. 19, 2002. Officials have said the men also beat and robbed the woman's male companion. Three of the homeless men are scheduled to be sentenced next week and the fifth will be sentenced next month, said the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown. Mr. Brown said that Mr. Cruz ''has been justly sentenced to a lengthy prison term for taking part in one of the most shocking and brutal crimes in Queens County history.'' Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VERRILL, JEAN
description: VERRILL--Jean, 80, of Atlanta. Educator, student and mother, passed away peacefully on Jan. 14, 2004 at Hospice Atlanta after a long illness. She was born in New York City on January 27, 1923, but called Atlanta her home, and hometown, since 1965. She was the wife of F. Glenn Verrill. They were married in NYC 57 years ago. Her degrees included a Bachelor of Arts from Hunter College, NY, as well as her J.D. from John Marshall Law School and Master of Law from the Georgia State University School of Law. A lifelong educator and student, Jean was constantly seeking new knowledge & was very active in the arts throughout her life. She started her career in education at New York University, serving as Assistant to the Dean of the NYU School of Dentistry, and went on to serve as Assistant to the Bursar at Columbia University, and as Associate Director of Veterans Affairs at The Juilliard School. Jean was also a professionally trained singer and was a member of The Collegiate Chorale, the first ensemble formed by Robert Shaw when he was Director of the Fred Waring Glee Club of New York City. Upon her arrival in Atlanta, her love for the arts led her to join The High Museum's Docent Guild in 1965, where she was an active and inspiring teacher and contributor for the last 38 years. She was also a member of the Michael C. Carlos Museum's Weekend Committee and Docent Guild, and the American Art Committee of The High Museum of Art. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, and sister, Jean is survived by her husband Glenn; her daughter Joan; her son Gary; her two grandchildren, Kristofer and Sergei and her brothers, Ralph and Tony. Funeral service and interment will be private. Visiting hours will be Friday, January 16 from 5-7pm at H.M. Patterson & Son Funeral Directors at Spring Hill, 1020 Spring Street N.W., Atlanta, GA. Family and friends are invited to attend the Memorial Service to be held on Saturday, January 17, 2004 at 2pm at St. Anne's Episcopal Church, at the intersection of Northside Parkway and Moores Mill Rd, with reception to immediately follow. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Anne's Episcopal Church, The High Museum of Art, and The Michael C. Carlos Museum, all of Atlanta, GA. For information, call H.M. Patterson & Son 404-876-1022.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Temp Worker's Tax Fraud
description: After 45 minutes of deliberation yesterday, a Federal District Court jury convicted Benjamin Harris, a temporary office worker from Crown Heights, of seven counts of tax fraud and filing a false return. His tax return for 2001 claimed that he had earned $9 million as a lawyer for the Temporary Time Capital Corporation and was entitled to a refund of $1.5 million, even though he had reported an income of only $1,061 for 2000. A refund check was direct-deposited into his bank account, but he was unable to withdraw the money and was later charged. In his defense at the two-day trial, his lawyer said the tax return had been signed by someone impersonating him. Mr. Harris faces a prison term of more than three years. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: New American Beachhead in France: Starbucks
description: Starbucks will open its first shop in France on Friday, hoping to spread ''to go'' coffee culture among Parisians long used to waiting for their drinks and lingering for hours in one of the city's 2,000 traditional cafes.

title: 15 Arrested in New Jersey In Child Pornography Inquiry
description: The operators of a global Internet child pornography service that stretched from Eastern Europe to Mount Laurel, N.J., were indicted on Thursday, and federal and state authorities arrested 15 people in New Jersey who subscribed to the service.

description: 'Jerry Springer,' Including Victims

title: A Ballad About Hunting a Fugitive and Finding Evil
description: A stark moral fable told in the language of the sort of western Hollywood has stopped making, the Australian director Rolf de Heer's film ''The Tracker'' is constructed around a suite of 10 interlocking story-songs that simmer with political outrage. Composed by Graham Tardif, with lyrics by Mr. de Heer, and performed by Archie Roach, a husky-voiced Aboriginal singer, together they suggest an extended folk ballad in the mode of Curtis Mayfield's ''Superfly.'' The lyrics describe the oppression of Australian Aboriginals with the same mixture of sorrow and resistance that fueled the songs of Bob Marley.

title: Low-Key Adams Makes High Impact on Patriots
description: When Bill Belichick attended Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., he sat around the dormitory with his offensive linemate Ernie Adams, drawing up plays on scratch paper.

title: India Eases Investment Caps On Foreigners as Vote Nears
description: Continuing a string of economic changes before elections, India's government on Thursday raised the ceilings on foreign investment in private banks, and did away with the limit on foreign investment in private oil exploration and marketing companies.

title: Corrections
description: A map in Business Day yesterday with an article about the merger of J. P. Morgan Chase and Bank One, showing states where the companies have bank branches, misplaced four Bank One branches. The branches are indeed in Wisconsin, not in Minnesota, which was highlighted in error.

description: Health ministers from the six countries where polio is now spreading said yesterday that they would intensify efforts to immunize 250 million children against the crippling disease by the end of this year.

description: Margie Gillis commanded the stage on Tuesday night with her stately presence and beautiful long red hair in a program of solos that was part of the Altogether Different festival at the Joyce Theater. But her choreography to taped accompaniments was uneven. Four New York premieres exemplified the presentation's strengths and weaknesses.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  Four days before he is to give his State of the Union address, President Bush came under scathing criticism today from top Congressional Democrats in anticipation of the speech.

description: The Spirit has moved.

description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 16  Israel's deputy defense minister has proclaimed the spiritual leader and founder of Hamas to be "marked for death," signaling that Israel will step up its campaign to kill the leadership of the militant group.

title: The Jets Sign Edwards for Two More Years
description: Jets Coach Herman Edwards received a two-year contract extension yesterday, assuring that he will be under contract with the team through 2007.

title: Residential Real Estate; Park Slope Walk-Up Revival May Signal New Rental Era
description: The four-story walk-up is a form of housing not often produced in New York City any longer. But two new side-by-side walk-ups in Park Slope, Brooklyn, may lead the way to resurrecting it for rental housing designed for moderate-income tenants throughout the city.

description: To the Editor:

title: Reflections On an Absence Of Eloquence
description: NOW that the World Trade Center memorial has assumed clear form, subject to change though it still may be, perhaps it is not out of order to reflect on absence of another kind. This is the prolonged absence of memorable words from our leaders articulating where we are as a city and as a people more than two years after the evil.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Profit In Semiconductors
description: Europe's largest maker of machinery for the semiconductor industry, ASML Holding, posted its first profit in six quarters after eliminating jobs. The company also said its chief executive, Doug Dunn, planned to retire this year. Net income reached 16 million euros ($20.3 million), or 3 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, in contrast to a loss of 50 million euros, or 10 cents a share, a year earlier, Mr. Dunn said at a news conference. Sales declined from the quarter a year earlier but were up 41 percent from the previous quarter, and Mr. Dunn said the company, which is based in Veldhoven, the Netherlands, would be profitable each quarter this year.

title: EU envoys press Manila to end death penalty
description: MANILA:  The ambassadors of European Union states visited the Philippines' death row on Thursday, an unprecedented move that opponents of capital punishment viewed as a rebuke to the government on its death penalty policy.

title: Bitter Cold Keeps Snow Powdery and People Bundled
description: First came the snow and bitter cold that closed down schools throughout most of the region and made a mess of the morning commute. Then came a bright sun that made the afternoon tolerable for those who didn't have to work outdoors. Then came the wind and hyper-chill that sent nighttime temperatures plunging toward record lows.

title: Woman, 81, Dies in Fire at Brooklyn Home
description: An 81-year-old Brooklyn woman died yesterday afternoon in a fire that tore through her Ocean Parkway home, Fire Department officials said.

title: Playing St. Andrews, a Continent Away
description: KEVIN CONNORS, a scratch golfer from Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., pulled his 3 wood from his bag and gazed up the bunker-strewn 17th fairway, the immemorial Road Hole at the Royal and Ancient Golf Club at St. Andrews. Here he was at the game's spiritual Scottish home, and as he stepped up to the ball, from somewhere far away the skirl of bagpipes drifted over the moor. He swung, and the ball took flight in a long, beautiful arc -- and landed squarely in the sandy abyss of a pot bunker.

description: ROSEN--Steven Mark, of Irvington, New York, died on Monday, January 12th. He was 61 years old. Steve had a distinguished 37-year career at NBC television. He was Associate Director for NBC Sports and NBC News and directed many NBC programs, including Grandstand, Today, Sunrise, Weekend Nightly News and many News Specials. A Memorial Service will be held at NBC on Wednesday, February 4, at 11am, in Studio 8-H. Steve is survived by his wife, Penelope Fleming; children: Scott, Craig, Abigail and Emma; parents: Charles and Ruth; and three grandchildren. He was deeply loved and will be greatly missed by his family and friends.

description: FEDER--Theodore D., age 89, died January 15th. Beloved husband of Marika. Devoted father of Gene, Ann and Joan. Caring grandfather of Ellie, Ben, Josh, Jojo, Elizabeth, Jacob and Sam. Loving uncle of Beverly, June, Alan and Lami. Ted devoted his long professional life to the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, his second family. Services Sunday, 10 AM, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91 St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Ted Feder Fund, Joint Distribution Committee, 711 Third Ave., NY NY 10017.

title: Technology Briefing | People: Texas Instruments Names New Chief Executive
description: Texas Instruments will promote Richard K. Templeton, left, its chief operating officer, to president and chief executive. He will succeed Thomas J. Engibous. Mr. Templeton, 45, was named to the board in July and has been with Texas Instruments since 1980. Mr. Engibous, 50, will continue as chairman, the company said yesterday. The stock has more than doubled in the last 12 months as consumers bought new cellphones with cameras and MP3 players that use the company's chips. Mr. Engibous and Mr. Templeton both have headed the semiconductor division, which accounted for 84 percent of the company's sales in its most-recent quarter. Shares of Texas Instruments rose $1.17, to $33.65.

I'd just finished an interview with Al Gore and it was hard to shake the melancholy feeling that the man who should be president was spending a stormy night in Midtown Manhattan while the momentous world events he should be shaping were careering in all sorts of dangerous directions.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: ATX Files For Bankruptcy Protection
description: ATX Communications, a telecommunications-services provider, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday as part of a plan to transfer ownership of the reorganized company to the Leucadia National Corporation. ATX listed assets of $160.2 million and debt of $329.9 million in papers filed with the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. Leucadia purchased $156 million of ATX senior secured debt and, as part of the reorganization, will convert the debt into equity, a spokesman, Grant Evans, said.

title: DELHAIZE TO CUT 1,500 JOBS AT KASH N' KARRY STORES
description: The Delhaize Group, a Belgian retailer that is the fifth-largest supermarket operator in the United States, said yesterday that it would eliminate 1,500 jobs at its Kash n' Karry chain and close or sell 34 stores. Delhaize will take a charge of $88 million in the first quarter for the reorganization, which will also involve renaming the chain, a spokesman, Guy Elewaut, said. The Kash n' Karry job cuts amount to about 1 percent of Delhaize's total staff. The stores that Delhaize is removing -- about a quarter of the chain -- are in central and eastern Florida and most will be closed rather than sold, Mr. Elewaut said. Delhaize aims to focus Kash n' Karry on Florida's Gulf Coast, where it will open or remodel 20 stores this year.

title: For 50 Years, a Red-Letter Winter Show for Charity
description: It's funny to think that there was ever a time when it seemed daring to produce a first-class antiques show in New York. But in 1954 it was. Back then the cavernous drill shed of the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue at 67th Street had never been used for selling art and antiques. (Now it is booked years in advance, with back-to-back shows from September through June.)

title: A Second Chance for 'Double Check'
description: On Sept. 11, 2001, with everything in ruins, one figure remained in Liberty Park across the street from the World Trade Center. He was sitting hunched over, staring in his briefcase, a businessman who seemed to be in shock and despair. Rescue workers, it was reported, approached him in the chaos to offer assistance, only to discover that he was not a man at all, but a sculpture.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fraud Ring Broken
description: Eight people have been arrested in connection with a New York-area crime ring that obtained driver's licenses and other forms of identification from the State Department of Motor Vehicles through the sale of fraudulent documents, the authorities said yesterday. Those arrested in the seven-month investigation include five current or former motor vehicle bureau employees and a civilian Police Department employee. They are charged with illegally obtaining fraudulent documents. In the scheme, brokers would sell fraudulent documents like birth certificates to clients who used them to obtain authentic identification, like driver's licenses, from motor vehicle employees in two Manhattan offices and one in Westchester, the police said. Andrea Elliott (NYT)

title: When the Mountain Is Too Cold
description: WITH two more months of winter left, indoor rock climbing is one way to fool the calendar, but some special skills are needed. Rock-climbing gyms require that you demonstrate competence in climbing and safety techniques. If you don't have your own gear (typically, you will need a harness, shoes and comfortable clothing that allows full movement), rentals are available at most gyms for $5 to $10; daily or weekly instruction are also offered, usually at extra cost. Here are some top rock-climbing gyms nationwide.

title: Robert Schumann: A Tuneful Miniaturist With a Ton of Soul
description: Here are some favorite Schumann recordings of the classical-music critics of The New York Times. Availability is hard to determine in the current state of the market. Most of the recordings here can be found on Amazon.com or in major record stores. CD's range in price from $12.99 for one CD to $21.99 for a two-CD set and $40.99 for four CD's. (An introduction appears on Page 1 of Weekend.)

title: YUM BRANDS SAYS IT WILL OPEN KFC RESTAURANT IN TIBET
description: Yum Brands said yesterday that it planned to open its first KFC restaurant in Tibet, the only Chinese region where the company has yet to establish a presence. The company has received government approval and has an ''active plan'' to enter Tibet, said Samuel Su, president of China operations at Yum Restaurants, a unit of Yum. He declined to give details. KFC has 1,000 outlets in 230 Chinese cities after opening 230 new restaurants last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FISHER, ELIZABETH KENOWSKY
description: FISHER--Elizabeth Kenowsky. The Boy Scouts of America, Greater New York Councils acknowledges the passing of E.K. Fisher and extends its sincere sympathy to her family and many friends. Mrs. Fisher and her late husband, Zachary, were strong supporters of scouting and other charitable programs throughout New York City. The Intrepid Foundation, founded by the Fishers, continues to do fine work, most notably through its ''Fallen Heros Fund'' and the refurbishing of the Intrepid as a floating museum. Mrs. Fisher will be greatly missed. John F. McGillicuddy, President Daniel R. Gasparo, CEO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARUSONA, AGNES ''PAT''
description: CARUSONA--Agnes ''Pat'', 83, died January 13, 2004. Former resident of Harrison, NY, for over 20 years. Devoted wife and homemaker. Married to the late Fred J. Carusona, Esq., who predeceased her in 1991. They were regulars at the Stork Club, Bill's Gay 90's, etc., and a member of the NYAC. Survived by children, Fred and Thomas of New York; Christopher of New Mexico, Richard and Margaret of Vermont, Peter of Illinois, and Eileen Altland of Connecticut; sister, Ann Brennan of Florida, 11 grandchildren, Christopher Jr., Thomas Jr., Dylan, Peter Jr., Nicole, Matthew, Michelle, Andrea, Zachary, Lauren and Sarah; great-grandchildren, Tilson, Andrew and Ra'quel (Washakie) Carusona of Wyoming. Visitation today, Friday, 79PM, at Coxe and Graziano Funeral Home in Mamaroneck, 914-698-5968. Funeral Mass Saturday, 10AM, at St. Gregory's Church in Harrison.

title: Judge Closes Doors on Selection of Stewart Jury
description: Citing a possible ''chilling effect'' on the criminal trial of Martha Stewart and her former stockbroker, a federal judge issued an unusual order yesterday barring reporters, courtroom artists and others from attending sessions at which prospective jurors would be questioned by lawyers for both sides.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Journalist Killed
description: Unidentified men murdered a prominent Bangladeshi journalist in the country's turbulent southwest, Reuters reported. The reporter, Manik Shaha, 48, worked for the daily newspaper New Age and the BBC. Witnesses said several men stopped the rickshaw Mr. Shaha was riding in and hurled a bomb. Colleagues said he had been aggressively reporting on armed Maoist groups and criminal gangs operating in the area. David Rohde (NYT)

title: Top Runner Challenging Drug Appeals Process
description: Regina Jacobs, the nation's top female middle-distance runner, who has tested positive for the designer steroid THG, is challenging the appeals process established for Olympic sports in the United States, saying it is biased against accused athletes.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Executive Leaves Clothing Retailer
description: The clothing retailer Austin Reed Group said its chief executive, Roger Jennings, had quit after a 22-week period when sales at stores open at least a year fell more than 11 percent. Total sales for the 22 weeks ended Jan. 10 declined 5.2 percent. Austin Reed, which is based in Thirsk, England, reiterated that it expected that full-year pretax profits before one-time charges would be lower than analyst's forecasts.
