description: MARCELLUS What, has this thing appear'd again to-night?

title: A Governor's Hard Sell: Higher Taxes in Virginia
description: Gov. Mark Warner, jacket off and microphone on, was pacing the front of the conference room, preaching his gospel of tax reform, again.

title: Using a Recorder to Create Illusion
description: Through astute programming and interpretive ingenuity, Marion Verbruggen made 90 minutes of unaccompanied recorder playing seem varied and even dramatic. Her recital on Jan. 11, part of the Music Before 1800 series at Corpus Christi Church, began with a lively 14th-century Italian dance, the anonymous "Chominciamento di Gioia," and then moved steadily toward the German Baroque by way of Dutch settings of English melodies, and to a French exploration of "Folies d'Espagne." By the time she closed the concert with two Bach works - the Partita for Flute (BWV 1013) and the Suite No. 5 (BWV 1011), originally for unaccompanied cello - a listener had full confidence in Ms. Verbruggen's power of illusion.

title: Next Target in the French Headgear Debate: The Bandanna
description: PARIS, Jan. 20 — And now for the bandanna ban.

title: Carolina Fans Show Support at Any Hour
description: The stadium lights were on at 2 o'clock in the morning Monday. It was a strange, bright beacon in the sky in a usually quiet uptown that often goes dark much earlier in the night.

title: The Blackboard Jungle: Tamer Than You Think
description: Next month, as part of what New York City officials are calling a crackdown on school violence, 150 additional police officers will be deployed to help their colleagues patrol the city's most dangerous schools. Plans are also under way to impose tougher disciplinary measures, including the swifter suspension of problem students.

title: When Meals Are Carted With Care
description: For a few years I delivered Meals on Wheels twice a month to homebound adults. They were ill, blind or unable to shop and cook for themselves. I brought my toddlers with me because I wanted them to get a sense of living in a community, and because I knew that the elderly people we visited loved seeing them.

title: Back Pain Takes a Vacation
description: A Dutch study released yesterday found that workers suffering from back pain returned to their jobs sooner if their rehabilitation included measures to help them overcome their fears of reinjury.

title: Finding J.F.K. Is Easy: First, Find the AirTrain
description: Logistically, things were not going well yesterday for Natalie and Atis Lode, whose attempt to get from Manhattan to Kennedy International Airport started with a ride in the wrong direction on the E train.

title: Abandon the Space Station? Not So Fast, Visionaries Say (What a Movie Set!)
description: In the gray buyer's-remorse dawn after the celebration of President Bush's announced plans to return to the Moon and even send humans to Mars, the changes and sacrifices necessary to fulfill the dream are coming into focus.

title: G.I.'s Headed for Iraq Train For Peace as Well as War
description: When Lt. Gen. Thomas F. Metz arrives in Iraq in the coming days to take command of day-to-day military operations there, he will be battling insurgents as much as ill will, and his troops will be engaged in everything from firefights to fixing sewers.

title: The Passions Over the Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBERG, LESTER M.
description: ROSENBERG -- Lester M., age 80, of Elmhurst, NY, on December 25, 2003. Son of Anna and Solomon Rosenberg (deceased); brother of Alfred (Mildred) Rosenberg (deceased); cherished uncle of Arthur (Cheryl) Rosenberg and Sue (Arthur) Biagianti; cherished great-uncle of Megan Rosenberg and Anna (Marc) Solomon and Adam Biagianti. Beloved former Scoutmaster of Troop 195, Queens. Respected local businessman. Memorial service was held at Parkside Memorial Chapel. Donations to Boy Scouts of America or charity of your choice.

title: City Backs Off Overhaul Effort On Assessments
description: The Bloomberg administration, after a two-year review of the city's property tax laws, has delayed a broad legislative push to overhaul New York City's tax assessment system after concluding such changes would be politically impossible in Albany now.

title: Pitt's Perfect Opening Ends As Connecticut Holds On
description: Streaking Pittsburgh was due to lose, and Connecticut well, the Huskies were expected to win, especially playing at home Monday night after losing that big one out of conference on the road over the weekend.

title: In Upper Manhattan, Talmudic Scholars Look Up and Find Cardinals Among the Rabbis
description: In a study hall filled with the hubbub of Talmudic debate, the men wearing scarlet sashes and large crosses made their way between tables, sometimes sitting to chat with the young scholars, sometimes marveling at the intensity of study.

title: The Passions Over the Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: Martha Stewart, Near Trial, Arranges Her Image
description: Long before Martha Stewart steps into a courtroom today to watch the selection of a jury for her federal trial, she and her legal team will have carefully tested the government's case -- and her own reputation -- before a sampling of the kind of people who will be deciding her fate.

title: An Assault on Housing Vouchers
description: The Bush administration, which created a record budget deficit partly through tax cuts for the rich, is threatening to make up some of the difference by cutting desperately needed programs aimed at the poor. One candidate for the chopping block is Section 8, the federal rent-subsidy program whose main purpose is preventing low-income families from becoming homeless.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HYMAN, HENRY
description: HYMAN--Henry, 86, of Brooklyn, died on January 18, 2004. Loving husband of the late Rachel, devoted brother of Sy and the late Noel, adored uncle and dear friend. A rare human being loved by many, he will be missed by all. Funeral services Yablokoff Chapel, January 20, 1978 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, at 11:00AM.

title: Pope Has Not Endorsed Gibson Film, Report Says
description: Pope John Paul II's secretary has denied widespread news reports that the pope offered a personal endorsement of Mel Gibson's unreleased movie ''The Passion of the Christ,'' the Catholic News Service said in an article on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARRECA, ROBERT F.
description: BARRECA--Robert F. On January 16, 2004, at age 80. Beloved husband of Betty. Loving father of Pamela, Robert Jr., Greg and Rocco. Grandfather and great grandfather. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St, Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass at St. John the Evangelist Church, First Ave and 55th St, Wednesday, 10 am. Entombment Cemetery of the Gate of Heaven.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: NORWAY: 2 DEAD, 16 MISSING AS FREIGHTER CAPSIZES At least 2 seamen were killed and 16 were missing after a freighter with a mainly Filipino crew capsized near the western port of Bergen, officials said. Boats and helicopters picked up nine survivors in the North Sea, and three more were pulled out of a hole cut in the side of the hull seven hours after the ship capsized. It was carrying heavy rocks from Norway to Germany.    (Reuters)

title: Conflict Issue Won't Force Judge Off Pricing Case
description: A federal judge presiding over a price-fixing case involving the Monsanto Company said last week that he would not disqualify himself from the case even though some lawyers in the case had said there was the appearance of a conflict of interest.

title: As Martha Stewart Trial Begins, the Action Is Mostly Outside
description: Martha Stewart entered the old federal courthouse at Foley Square in Lower Manhattan today surrounded by a horde of reporters and cameramen who shouted, "Martha! Martha!" and a supporter who cried, "You go, girl!"

title: Navigating Berlin's Past and Its Future
description: ''It's by the big balloon, not more than 500 yards from the Ritz-Carlton, but there's really nothing to see,'' Richard Campbell said with a discernible lack of enthusiasm.

title: The Iowa Surprise
description: A great many people were caught off guard by the Iowa caucus results, including, of course, supporters of Howard Dean and Richard Gephardt. But high up on the list of bad guessers were all the political theorists who believed that the Democrats who are angry at George Bush wanted the presidential candidate who best channeled their outrage. Yesterday, at least, being angry at Mr. Bush meant wanting to find a candidate who could beat him.

title: Going For Broke
description: According to advance reports, George Bush will use tonight's State of the Union speech to portray himself as a visionary leader who stands above the political fray. But that act is losing its effectiveness. Mr. Bush's relentless partisanship has depleted much of the immense good will he enjoyed after 9/11. He is still adored by his base, but he is deeply distrusted by much of the nation.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Arrest In Plane Hoax
description: The police arrested a 19-year-old German man on suspicion of carrying out a bomb scare that forced a Delta Airlines flight from Frankfurt to Atlanta to make an emergency landing at Shannon Airport on Sunday. The suspect was among the 147 passengers. A note saying ''bomb on board'' was found in a bathroom on the plane, which was declared safe after a search and continued on to Atlanta. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: For Up-and-Down Campaign, Iowans Offer a Big 'Up'
description: Exulting in victory, pumping his fists, embracing his wife and saluting his fellow Vietnam veterans, Senator John Kerry, for a moment, sounded almost penitent.

title: Dr. Howard A. Eder, 86, Leader in Heart Research, Dies
description: Dr. Howard A. Eder, a New York doctor and scientist whose studies of cholesterol led to breakthroughs in the understanding of heart disease, died on Jan. 15 in Raleigh, N.C. He was 86.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Blind Rats' Compass

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HECHT, LILLIAN
description: HECHT--Lillian. On behalf of the Congregation Shaare Zion and the Executive Committee, we express our deepest condolences to Emeritus Rabbi Abraham Hecht and his family for the loss of Lillian Hecht A''H. On Thursday, January 15, 2004, Mrs. Hecht tragically lost her life in a fire which erupted in her home. Lillian Hecht, 82, remains a beloved wife, mother, grandmother and great grandmother. Isaac M. Franco President

title: Primary Battle Moves to New Hampshire After Kerry Win
description: PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Jan. 20  Fresh off his disappointing third-place finish in the Iowa caucuses, Howard Dean landed here before dawn today, promising to fight for eight straight days to win the Jan. 27 primary in New Hampshire, where the commanding position he once held has diminished considerably if not disappeared altogether.

title: From Vision to Catwalk, Backstage at Dior
description: ''Slick'' is not a word anyone would use to describe the great house of Dior, but slick is exactly what the Dior shows have become under John Galliano. They are the most spectacular of shows and, at the same time, the most predictable. You know before the first model hits the glossy runway that the clothes will be wild, the Dior logo vivid against the backdrop, and even the most hapless photographer will get a good, clean shot.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about last-minute campaigning before the Iowa caucuses misattributed an observation about the exuberance of Senator John Edwards's backers at a rally in Cedar Rapids. It was Senator Edwards, not his New York campaign chairman, Bill De Blasio, who said, ''Can you believe what is going on?''

title: Praying for a Few Properly Spelled Words
description: In a commentary with ''Spellbound,'' Jeff Blitz's documentary about eight participants in the 1999 National Spelling Bee, the producer Sean Welch says that Mr. Blitz has a stutter that is made worse by microphones. Mr. Blitz takes part anyway (stutter free), and we learn that a father of one of the contestants, also a stutterer, prayed not only for his son's victory but also that the boy wouldn't falter during ''kookaburra'' or some such. He doesn't, in a film with ''enough drama, humor and unfiltered nail-biting suspense to put all the thrill-mongering screenwriters in Hollywood to shame,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. 2003. Columbia TriStar. $26.96. 97 minutes. G.

title: Plea to Policy Makers: Let's Take Another Giant Step
description: I asked my daughter, Mira, this morning if she wanted to go to Mars. She cocked her head in a frown, raised her hands in a tiny shrug and went off in search of her mother. She's only 20 months old and doesn't really know Mars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRAMER, HARRY
description: KRAMER--Harry, 82, of Delray Beach, formerly of Great Neck, NY and Boca Raton, FL on January 18. Beloved husband and best friend of Sylvia (nee Blitzer) for 55 years. Devoted father of Dr. Jeffrey Kramer, dear fatherin-law of Donna (nee Laub). Adored grandfather of Rachel and Joshua Kramer. Brother of the late Louis, Morris, and Helen. Graveside service on Tuesday, January 20, Mt. Hebron Cemetery, 130-04 Horace Harding Expressway, Flushing, NY 11367 at 1PM. Shiva at the home of Dr. Jeffrey and Donna Kramer, 1 Robin Hill Road, Great Neck, New York 11024.

title: Surprised? Don't Be, Fox Says
description: John Fox acknowledged that a Super Bowl berth in his second season was not exactly the time frame he expected when he took over as head coach of the Carolina Panthers in January 2002.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cases Of Infant Death To Be Reopened
description: Hundreds of parents convicted of killing their infant children will have their cases reviewed after the Court of Appeal said it would halt prosecution of cases in which sudden infant death syndrome might be a possible cause of death. During the past decade, 258 adults in Britain have been convicted of killing a child under the age of 2, and more than 50 are still in prison. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Officers Foil Bridge Jumper
description: Off-duty police officers pulled a woman from a narrow ledge on a ramp at the Manhattan entrance of the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday morning, the police said. The woman, in her 20's, had just climbed onto the ledge, 30 feet above the ground, when Officer Rafael Martinez, driving to work, stopped and approached her. She told him she wanted to jump because of problems in her love life and music career, Officer Martinez said. ''I told her being a star takes a lot of work,'' he recalled. Two other off-duty officers soon arrived, and the three men grabbed the woman and pulled her to safety, said Officer Michael Bazerman. Michael Brick (NYT)

title: Jets to Interview Eagles' Rivera
description: The Jets are expected to interview Philadelphia's linebackers coach, Ron Rivera, for their opening at defensive coordinator in the next few days. Rivera is available now that the Eagles are out of the playoffs.

title: Media Baron Goes to Court For Approval Of Stake Sale
description: Escalating an increasingly bitter fight, Conrad M. Black asked a Canadian court yesterday to issue an injunction that would prevent the board of Hollinger International from trying to block his sale of control of the company.

title: Bank's Ex-Chief Arrested in Parmalat Case
description: Italian police officials arrested a former president of a regional bank on Monday as the investigation into the collapse of Parmalat continued.

title: Hey Cabby, The Fare Rise Is in the Mail
description: AMONG the many great lies that keep the world spinning -- ''The check is in the mail,'' ''This won't hurt a bit,'' ''Sure, I'll respect you in the morning'' -- is the one about New Yorkers' being able to put up with anything.

title: The Passions Over the Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Serious About a Kidney Transplant
description: On Jan. 8, Vanya Keenan turned 28. That day, while having surgery to replace a synthetic tube in her arm so that she could receive dialysis, she had a pulmonary embolism, when a floating blood clot in her veins blocked an artery to her lungs.

title: Little Familiar With Setbacks, Dean Stumbles
description: He burst into the ballroom, fists thrust in the air, and slapped a string of high-fives with the dozens of labor union members standing onstage. He grabbed hold of Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa and yanked his hand up, too. He whipped off his suit coat and rolled his sleeves up as far as they would go.

title: Canada Is Expected to Lower Interest Rate Today
description: The Bank of Canada is widely expected to lower its main interest rate on Tuesday, seeking to ease the pain of the strong Canadian dollar on exporters and link its economy to the recovery in the United States.

title: Drug Eases Heroin Withdrawal
description: Last year, the federal government gave doctors who work with heroin addicts a new tool when it approved a drug that blocks withdrawal symptoms. Now a small new study has found that a single shot of the drug, which has few of methadone's drawbacks, can be effective for as long as six weeks, opening the prospect of making heroin treatment far more flexible.

title: National Book Critics Circle Makes Its Nominations
description: Monica Ali's ''Brick Lane'' (Scribner) will vie for National Book Critics Circle honors this year against fiction by Edward P. Jones (''The Known World,'' Amistad/HarperCollins), Caryl Phillips (''A Distant Shore,'' Alfred A. Knopf), Richard Powers (''The Time of Our Singing,'' Farrar, Straus & Giroux) and Tobias Wolff (''Old School,'' Knopf).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAAL, JESSICA
description: SAAL--Jessica. Our thoughts and prayers are with Carol and Harry Saal upon the untimely loss of their beloved daughter, Jessica. May the beauty of the love they shared with Jessica remain forever in their hearts and minds. May her memory always be a blessing. Our deepest sympathies to Carol, Harry, Nate and the entire family. Lord Weidenfeld, Chairman, Board of Governors, BGU Prof. Avishay Braverman, President, BGU Zvi Alon, Chairman, AABGU Lis Gaines, Pres, AABGU Vivien Marion EVP, AABGU

title: TRIUMPH SAYS EARNINGS WILL NOT MEET EXPECTATIONS
description: Triumph Group said yesterday that it expected fiscal third-quarter earnings to fall short of analysts' expectations as a result of a decline in the market for industrial gas turbines. Triumph said industrial gas turbine sales to its largest customer, which totaled $35 million in the fiscal year ended March 2003, dropped in the third quarter to an annualized rate of less than $5 million, with no expectation of a significant increase soon. The company said it had begun a review of its industrial gas turbine business as a result of declines in revenue and margins. Separately, Triumph, which also makes aerospace parts, said it had acquired Rolls-Royce Gear Systems Inc. of Park City, Utah, from the Rolls-Royce Group of Britain for $36 million in cash.

title: Annan Signals He'll Agree To Send U.N. Experts to Iraq
description: Correction Appended

title: A Day for Oratory and Action, Recalling a Master of Both
description: Trying to preserve Martin Luther King's Birthday as something more than a three-day ski weekend or another day of department store sales, people around the region gathered yesterday to mark the day by feeding the hungry, protesting the war in Iraq, and discussing the unfinished work of seeking racial justice in America.

title: Reid Hears the Squawking of Crushed Eagles Fans
description: With the vicious, vocal fan base in full roar over the talk-radio airwaves Monday morning, Eagles Coach Andy Reid inserted himself squarely into the debate over culprits for his team's third straight loss in a conference championship game.

title: Massachusetts Senator Gets Lift for the Race in New Hampshire
description: DES MOINES, Jan. 19  Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts won the Iowa caucuses here Monday, brushing aside the insurgent anti-war candidacy of Howard Dean by presenting himself as the strongest Democrat his party had to send up against President Bush next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KATZ, SHELDON C.
description: KATZ--Sheldon C. Beloved husband of Deana. Loving father of Lennard and Amy Katz and Sari and Olen Earl and Nanci Katz. Cherished grandfather of Danielle, Matthew, Aaron and Ava. Dear uncle of David and Nancy Katz, Ronald and Cynthia Katz and Susan and Lee Schulman. Services Wednesday 10 AM at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave. (Ave. J). Contributions may be made to MDA for ALS Research, U.S.C. Neuromuscular Center, Good Samaritan Hospital, 637 South Lucas Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90017.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Education Life section on Sunday about dormitories for upperclassmen misstated the affiliation of Robert Stickney, a consultant who has held focus groups with students. He works for KPMG L.L.P., not KPMG Consulting.

title: Visa applications rise as 'dirty politics' drains idealism : Despair drives Philippine exodus
description: MANILA:  A few weeks ago, Lloyd Mendoza applied for a visa at the U.S. Embassy, and he has been eagerly waiting for his application's approval. "I can hardly wait to leave," he said.

title: G.M.s Net Income Slips, but Automaker Raises Forecasts
description: DETROIT, Jan. 20 — General Motors reported today that its fourth-quarter net income fell slightly as strength in its financial operations was offset by an continuing price war in North America that has failed to increase its market share.

title: Pricewaterhouse Moving to Madison Ave. Tower
description: PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting company, announced yesterday that it had completed its long-anticipated deal to move to a new home at Madison Avenue and 42nd Street in one of the largest leasing deals in three years.

title: In New Hampshire, Lieberman Turns His Attention to Bush
description: NASHUA, N.H., Jan. 19  With most of his rivals focused on Iowa, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman took to the air on Monday for a seven-city tour of New Hampshire, making what he called his "closing arguments" that he was the candidate best positioned to defeat President Bush .

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Plant Sale Offered
description: Foreign stakeholders in the Enron Corporation's stalled $2.9 billion power project, Dabhol Power, have offered to sell their 85 percent for less than half their original investment. Enron, which owns a 65 percent stake, and the General Electric Company and the Bechtel Group, which own 10 percent each, have offered to sell their combined stake for $380 million. The 2,184-megawatt power project came to a standstill two years ago when the sole buyer of the power it generated, the utility of the western state of Maharashtra, defaulted on payments. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''And now I have a special message for the special interests that have a home in the Bush White House: We're coming. You're going.''

title: Standing Up to Bullies
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping The Faith
description: At the Iowa caucus I attended, one of John Edwards's people went over to the Kucinich supporters and said if they came over and joined Edwards, they wouldn't have to be vegans anymore. Everybody laughed, and the debate continued. The Dean people played up the war issue; the Kerry people, electability. But eventually, most of the Kucinich folks went over to Edwards, and a great cheer rose up from that side of the room.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BALLIN, EDWARD H
description: BALLIN--Edward H, age 79, died January 18, 2004. Beloved husband of the late Renee Sacks. Devoted father of Sharon Ballin of Stanford, David Ballin and wife Zucelly of White Plains, Caasi Waters of Bradenford, FL. Loving brother to Stewart Ballin of New Rochelle and Richard Ballin of Boca Raton, FL. Five cherished grandchildren Faith, Elizabeth, Samantha Ballin, Rachel and Bryan Waters. Funeral service will be held Wednesday, 1 PM at McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Ave, White Plains 914949-7777. Interment to follow. Donations to the United Jewish Appeal or Doctors Without Borders.

title: Using the Right Bait to Catch a Comet
description: On Jan. 2, NASA's Stardust spacecraft flew through a 14,000-mile-an-hour hail of debris from the Wild 2 comet. Under this withering barrage, the ship's objective was not only to survive, but to use a collector made of a bizarre substance to gather an unaltered sample of five-billion-year-old dust and gas ejected by the comet.

title: With Doping Case Lingering, Rusedski Loses
description: Despite the suspicion enveloping him, Greg Rusedski wanted to play in this Australian Open, but he did not play for long. After making the long trip here and taking the short walk to the windswept show court No. 2 on Tuesday morning, Rusedski, the British veteran, did not win a set in his first-round match against Albert Costa, the former French Open champion from Spain.

title: Spread of Bird Flu in Asia Worries Officials
description: For a small number of bird watchers, the question is not how many species they can spot but what viruses infect the birds. In recent weeks, these bird-watching virologists have become worried about what they and the World Health Organization say is the ''unprecedented'' simultaneous appearance of an avian influenza virus in a number of countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAUSEN, ROD
description: HAUSEN--Rod, 52, accomplished and beloved pianist, composer, arranger, musical director, and teacher died on January 18, from cancer. He is survived by his parents Roy and Ruth Hausen and his loving spouse, Susan. A wake will be held from 3 PM to 9 PM on Wednesday, January 21st, at Flynn and Son Funeral Home, 23 Ford Ave., Fords, NJ. (732) 826-0358. A Mass will be held January 22nd, 11 AM at Trinity Church, 33 Mercer Street, Princeton, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIRULNICK, MARCY
description: SIRULNICK--Marcy. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the passing of Marcy Sirulnick, a cherished friend and beloved leader who was greatly admired for her extraordinary generosity and compassionate concern. Mrs. Sirulnick and her husband Joseph, earned enormous respect in the Jewish community for their deep commitment to helping those in need. Mrs. Sirulnick's philanthropic spirit and generosity will continue to touch the lives of many for years to come. We mourn the loss of a dear friend and extend our deepest sympathies to Joseph; to Mrs. Sirulnick's children, Phyllis, Sandy and Carole; her grandchildren and great-grandchildren; and the entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Executive V.P. & CEO

description: For the future of human space exploration, NASA may turn to retro spacecraft designs.

title: Man Is Fatally Shot on Subway
description: A man died from two gunshots to his head that he received on a subway train in Greenwich Village early yesterday, the police said.

title: Controlling the Gain, Moderately
description: For a group of sedentary, overweight people, three hours of moderate exercise a week was enough to halt their weight increase and even to begin to reverse it, without any change in diet, a new study has found.

title: Award Named for Saplin
description: The National Track and Field Hall of Fame announced yesterday that it would honor the memory of Stan Saplin, the track historian, with a permanent educational exhibit. Part of the exhibit will be Saplin's voluminous scrapbooks that cover the sport's history for three-quarters of a century. He died in 2002 at age 88.

title: Letters
description: Alaska's Ailing Tundra

title: 8-Hour Strike by Alitalia Workers Cancels 350 Flights
description: Workers at Alitalia staged an eight-hour strike on Monday that forced the cancellation of more than 350 flights and affected thousands of domestic and international passengers, in the latest example of labor unrest and transportation chaos in Italy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, GERALDINE
description: MILLER--Geraldine of Boynton Beach, FL, wife of the late Alvin M. Miller, died peacefully at age 82 on January 17. She is survived by two sons, Jeffrey and Peter, and their spouses Angela and Deborah, grandchild Eric and wife Amy, and grandchild Paul. She will be missed by her family and especially her oldest and dearest friends, Mike and Florence Benay. A memorial service in Florida is planned for February.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LALLY, VERONICA M. (NEE MCCARTHY)
description: LALLY--Veronica M. (nee McCarthy) entered peacefully into eternal life on January 18, at the age of 83, after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Martin J. Lally, NYPD. Loving mother of Veronica M. Kehoe, the late Martin J. Lally III and Maureen B. Lally. Cherished grandmother of Allise McAuley Dickson, Martin J. IV and Stacy Ann Lally. Friends may visit at the John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Ave (70th St) Tuesday and Wednesday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Thursday, January 22 at 10 AM at Our Lady of Good Counsel Church, 230 East 90th Street, Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Her life and memory are a blessing to all who knew her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DRESSELHUYS, RICHARD
description: DRESSELHUYS--Richard, on December 29, at age 86. Memorial, 2 PM, January 24, UN Chapel, 777 UN Plaza (1st Ave & 44th). Contributions may be sent to the Friends Shelter, C/O Sylvia Friedman, 210 E. 15th Street, NY, NY 10003.

title: The Passions Over the Memorial (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Romanian Gypsy Ensemble Gives New Meaning to Vivace
description: Oompah went haywire in the music of Taraf de Haidouks, the Romanian Gypsy band that played a sold-out show at Zankel Hall on Friday night. The group, from the town of Clejani near Bucharest, hurtled through tunes at speeds that would make bluegrass bands blink and then, when it felt like it, even accelerated from there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEE, ANN ROSENTHAL
description: LEE--Ann Rosenthal, on January 18, 2004, at home, aged 78. Beloved wife of Dr. Stanley L. Lee. Dear mother of Nancy (Gordon Johnson), Ted (Deborah), and Kenneth (Milly) Lee. Dear sister of Robert L. Rosenthal. Devoted grandmother of Seth and Toby Johnson; Matt, Anna, Jamie, and Nina Lee; Sam and Noah Lee. Memorial at a later date. Contributions may be made to Greenwich House Pottery, 16 Jones Street, New York, New York 10014.

title: Results Show Conventional Wisdom Short on the 'Wisdom'
description: For weeks, reporters practicing the tricky art of political prognostication here declared the Iowa Democratic caucuses to be a two-man race, with former Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont riding to front-runner status on a jet stream of antiwar sentiment and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri close behind.

title: On Baseball; Mets Seem to Pay Price No Matter Their Choice
description: OTHER owners, those in Oakland and Pittsburgh, for example, do not feel sorry for Fred Wilpon, but they do not envy him either. Trying to keep up with George Steinbrenner cannot be fun for anyone.

title: Frequent Flier; On Travel and Matchmaking From a Woman in a Ball Cap
description: As far as I know, I am the only vice president for romance in the entire world. You wouldn't believe how readily business travelers on the plane put aside their laptops and BlackBerries to tell me intimate details of their love life or lack thereof. My favorite conversations start when someone makes a disclaimer to me about dating such as, ''I'm too busy to date, I'm running a company.''

title: Primary Battle Moves to New Hampshire After Kerry Win
description: The 2004 presidential race shifted to New Hampshire today as most of the Democratic candidates put Iowa behind them and, before the sun had even risen, began the final week of campaigning in New Hampshire for the state's primary election on Jan. 27.

title: BCE TO BUY EQUIPMENT FOR INTERNET CALLING FROM CISCO
description: BCE Inc., Canada's biggest telephone company, said yesterday that it would spend 200 million Canadian dollars ($154 million) on equipment from Cisco Systems Inc. to upgrade its network for Internet-based calling. BCE's Bell Canada unit will buy the equipment over the next three years, Isabelle Courville, president of Bell Canada's enterprise group, said on a conference call. Cisco, which is based in San Jose, Calif., is the world's largest maker of computer-networking equipment. Bell Canada, based in Montreal, has said it plans to offer Internet-based phone service to 90 percent of its customers by 2006, starting with corporate clients this year.

But are they ready to see a film in which Ottoman Turkish soldiers shoot defenseless civilians and burn women alive? That question has set off a bitter debate here.

title: What's That Odor? Better Ask a Monkey
description: If you see the world with only two color-detecting pigments in your eye, as many monkeys do, your sense of smell is very important. But in higher primates, which see with three pigments, the sense of smell is less critical, evolutionary biologists have found -- to the extent that people have lost the use of more than half their odor-detecting genes.

Meanwhile, the man in charge of the city's vaunted Police Department, Commissioner Howard Safir, was slipping badly in opinion polls.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Economic Assessment Raised
description: Japan's government raised its assessment of the country's economy and said the economy was recovering steadily. The government cited improving exports, consumer spending and capital investment. Policymakers expect Japan's recovery to continue on the back of strong demand overseas. The government warned, however, that the yen's rise against the dollar posed a risk to the recovery. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: An Actress of a Certain Age Eyes the Beauty Cult

title: WAL-MART SALES MEET FORECAST; TARGET FALLS SHORT
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said yesterday that sales so far this month had met its forecast for a gain of as much as 5 percent at stores open at least a year, while the Target Corporation said sales were slightly below its forecast. About two-thirds of last week's sales increase came from more shoppers visiting Wal-Mart stores, the company said. Wal-Mart is based in Bentonville, Ark. Target, which is based in Minneapolis, said sales for the month to date were slightly below forecast after sales last week did not meet its plan for a 4 percent to 6 percent gain.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Still Missing In Lake
description: Two searches of Prospect Lake Park by police divers yesterday morning failed to locate the body of a man who fell through the ice on Sunday, the police said. The divers suspended their search because their air tanks were freezing. They plan to resume today, said Lt. Brian Burke, a police spokesman. The man, who appeared to be in his 20's, was walking on the ice on the western part of the 60-acre lake when witnesses saw him fall in. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DURGIN, DON
description: DURGIN--Don. Died December 26, 2003, at Lenox Hill Hospital, at age 79, from an aneurism. Beloved husband of Catherine Meacham Durgin. Father of William Ryerson Durgin II of Manhattan, and Hillary Durgin Harmon of Houston, TX. Grandfather of Murphey, Cornelius Kelley, Samuel and Therese Harmon. Don's first wife, Therese Keresey, died in 1981. Don graduated from the Hotchkiss School 1941, Princeton University, A.B., summa cum laude in 1945, and LLB, NYU 1954. During WW II, First Lieutenant U.S. Army Air Corps, flying combat missions as a B-17 bombardier, 8th Air Force (96th Bomb Group) 1943-45 from England. Don retired in 2001 as Vice Chairman of Newsweek magazine, which he joined in 1989. He spent most of his career at NBC Television Network 1949-'75, leaving briefly in 1951 to join ABC Television Network, becoming at age 32, Vice President ABC Radio Network. Returned to NBC in 1957 as Vice President National Sales NBC Television Network and then President of the NBC Television Network from 1965-'73. Executive Vice President NBC 1973-'75. Don began his career at Foote, Cone & Belding in 1947, becoming Assitant Account Executive. Following his years at NBC, he became President McAffrey & McCall advertising agency, 1975-'76. Director, American Savings Bank. Executive Vice President, Dun & Bradstreet 1977-'82 in charge of broadcast and publishing operations. Vice President marketing 1982-'88. Society of the Cincinnati. Memorial service Saint James' Church, January 23, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Don Durgin Scholarship at Princeton University, P.O. Box 5357, Princeton, NJ 08543; or to The Princeton Triangle Club, c/o McCarter Theatre, Princeton, NJ 08543.

The suspect, Mijailo Mijailovic, 25, has said he heard inner voices ordering him to stab Ms. Lindh. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Gaming Overtime
description: Some ominous fine print has turned up in the Bush administration's promise to help long-suffering low-wage workers get the overtime pay they have long been denied. As initially presented, the White House estimated that its new rules governing nonunion workers would mean $895 million in guaranteed time-and-a-half pay for 1.3 million of the nation's poorest-paid workers. That inviting proposal was coupled with a far more controversial plan to allow employers greater leeway to close out overtime pay for a midrange of white-collar professionals by designating them as managers.

title: Taurasi and the Huskies Have Fun Again

title: Editorial Observer; The Whole Cow and Nothing but the Whole Cow
description: In the mid-1990's, British officials had been trying for almost a decade to respond to the appearance of bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease, in a herd near Ashford, England. At first, they simply dismissed public concern or proclaimed their faith in British beef. Even when humans began dying of variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease -- the human equivalent of B.S.E. -- government officials found it hard to act coherently. They had the one excuse that we lack: they didn't know what they were confronting. In time, the British government put in place a set of prohibitions against the use of meat and bone meal as food for cattle and against the sale of certain kinds of offal for human consumption. Those steps have seriously reduced the incidence of mad cow disease.

title: LYDALL TO CLOSE OHIO PLANT AND LAY OFF 139 WORKERS
description: Lydall Inc., which makes industrial air filters, said yesterday that it would close its plant in Columbus, Ohio, by the end of this year and cut 139 jobs. Lydall plans to move the automotive manufacturing operations at the Ohio plant to other plants, the chief operating officer, Christopher R. Skomorowski, said in a statement. About 100 to 120 new jobs will be created at the other plants as a result of the shift, the company said. The consolidation is expected to cost about $3 million to $3.5 million, with a portion of the expense recorded in the fourth quarter, Lydall said. Lydall is based in Manchester, Conn.

title: GAP NAMES JEFF JONES HEAD OF MARKETING FOR GAP STORES

Mr. Jones will join the company as an executive vice president on April 1 after he leaves his position as president of LB Works, a unit of Publicis Groupe's Leo Burnett USA. The review will also involve Northern Irish political parties and is expected to conclude by Easter. Brian Lavery (NYT)

description: NEUWELT--Gerald, 82, died Janaury 19th. He is survived by wife Bettye; four sons: Lewis (Diane), Stuart (Myrna), Ronald, and Richard, two daughters: Mona, and Bonnie, and 11 grandchildren. For information contact Danzansky Goldberg Funeral Chapel, Maryland, 301-340-1400.

title: Discovery Shows Sacred Status of Egyptian Lion
description: Scientists excavating a tomb in the Nile Valley have stumbled upon the remains of a mummified lion, strengthening the long-held belief that ancient Egyptians worshiped it as a sacred beast.

title: A Puppet Fantasy Evokes the True Aftermath of Hiroshima
description: These days ambitious theater works are often accompanied by extensive program notes. At their best they are small, valuable essays that prepare the mind and stir the senses. At their worst they are pompous little lectures that let us know we need educating to grasp the full complexity of what we are about to see.

title: Brooklyn Councilman to Run for Mayor in '05
description: With more than 100 supporters filling the steps of City Hall and chanting ''Charles in charge,'' Charles Barron, the Democratic city councilman from Brooklyn and a former Black Panther, announced his plan to run for mayor in 2005.

title: Boston to New York: Four Ways to Make the Trip
description: The 200-mile distance between Boston and New York is one of the busiest corporate travel stretches in the United States. According to NYC & Company, a tourism marketing organization, 316,000 Bostonians travel to New York for business each year. The Greater Boston Convention and Visitors Bureau estimates that almost a million New Yorkers return the favor. Now, there is a new way to connect the cities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CZEISLER, RUTH (NEE RUBIN)
description: CZEISLER--Ruth (nee Rubin) Loving wife of Gene for 55 years, devoted mother of Barbara and Ed, adoring grandmother of Alyssa, Justin and Gabriel and of Heather of blessed memory, beloved sister of Herbert and Justice Rose Rubin. Always in pursuit of excellence, fittingly she leaves this earth as a caring and skilled teacher of Hebraic studies. She will be sorely missed. Funeral services at I. J. Morris Funeral Home, Dix Hills, January 20 at 10:15 am. Eugene Czeisler, Drs. Barbara and Edward Buro, Alyssa, Justin, Gabriel, Herbert and Judge Rose L. Rubin

title: The Taliban Creep Back
description: Afghanistan has a fine new constitution, but for most of its people, security remains the foremost concern. Debates about the intricacies of civil versus Islamic law or the division of powers between the central and provincial governments seem secondary when people are afraid to sow their fields or transport their crops to market. Setting the stage for something like normal life in Afghanistan will require sustained military help and training from American and NATO military forces. It will also require stronger efforts by Pakistan to support Afghanistan's government and to prevent Taliban forces from crossing the border.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: At One Caucus, Sorting Out Rules and Brokering Deals
description: The first to arrive at the Precinct 2 caucus in the Waukee City Hall council chambers were three white-haired women from the housing complex for the elderly in a former cornfield nearby. They lugged a stack of John Kerry posters under their arms.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BERNSTEIN, SOL
description: BERNSTEIN--Sol. To the sweetest father in the world, honoring and missing you on your 104th birthday. Barbara

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KORMAN, GERTRUDE (BROWN)
description: KORMAN -- Gertrude (Brown). Almost 99, at home in New York City, on January 14th. Wife to Samuel for 61 years. Beloved mother of Nancy Korman (London, England) and Linda K. Witt of Austin, TX. Sister-in-law of Jeanne Brown of Lenox, MA. Mother-in-law of Robert Witt, and adoring grandmother, great-grandmother, aunt and great-aunt. The family expresses appreciation of the kind care provided to Gertrude by Mary Osei for over eleven years. Memorials may be sent to any organization dedicated to the defeat of George W. Bush. Any correspondence to 10230 Pinehurst Dr., Austin, TX 78747.

title: Advertising; Concern about U.S. foreign policy has some re-evaluating ad tactics.
description: AN American businessman returns home to the suburbs, where his wife has prepared dinner for the family. He watches as his wife and family eat, drink and break into song. But after starting ''Take Me Out to the Ball Game,'' they switch to a traditional Turkish number.

title: HASTINGS FINISHES UNBEATEN
description: Natasha Hastings of A.P. Randolph High School in Manhattan extended her undefeated indoor season yesterday by winning the girls' invitational 300-meter dash in 38.46 seconds at the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Relays at the Armory Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan.

title: INSIDE
description: Casino Deals Stalled

title: Huge March Backs Cleric Over U.S. Plan
description: As many as 100,000 Iraqis marched peacefully through the center of the city on Monday in a show of support for a revered Shiite cleric opposing the Bush administration's plans for the transfer of sovereignty.

title: A Matter of Taste
description: Q. Does the same food taste the same to everyone?

description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bankruptcies Decline
description: Corporate bankruptcies fell in 2003 for the first time in four years, reflecting an improving economy and help of government subsidies. Last year, 16,624 companies collapsed, 14.6 percent fewer than the previous year, said Teikoku Databank, a research group. The debts left by those companies decreased 14.4 percent, the third consecutive slide. In December, bankruptcies declined 24.6 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SCHEFTEL, STUART
description: SCHEFTEL -- Stuart. Ten years ago today. Your vivid presence and integrity will never be forgotten

title: Max D. Barnes, 67; Wrote Country Hits
description: Max D. Barnes, who wrote many of country music's most evocative hits during the last 30 years, including ''Chiseled in Stone,'' about the death of his son, died here on Jan. 11. He was 67.

title: The Widening of America, or How Size 4 Became a Size 0
description: Last fall, I was thrilled to find a pair of size 0 cotton stretch slacks that fit perfectly. Now, I have never been a 0, not since puberty anyway. I am, at best, a size 4, which is two sizes smaller than what I wore at the same weight in the 1970's. What has happened? Size inflation, that's what.

title: Harry Brecheen, 89, Pitcher With 3 Victories in '46 Series
description: Harry Brecheen, an All-Star pitcher for the St. Louis Cardinals who won three games in their 1946 World Series victory over the Boston Red Sox, died Saturday at a nursing facility in Bethany, Okla. He was 89.

title: Corrections
description: A Sports of The Times column last Wednesday about Pete Rose's efforts to rebuild his reputation misstated the given name of the lawyer who rebuked Senator Joseph R. McCarthy at the Army-McCarthy hearings in 1954. He was Joseph N. Welch, not Robert.

title: SPX SAYS REVENUE ROSE MORE THAN EXPECTED
description: SPX Corporation, a maker of power transformers, broadcast antennas and industrial equipment, said that fourth-quarter revenue rose about 10 percent from the year-earlier period, helped by acquisitions and rising demand. SPX said it previously forecast a 6 percent increase. Full-year profit from continuing operations was at least $3.40 a share, in line with estimates, the company said. In 2002, SPX reported a profit of $3.33 a share, excluding a change in accounting. Excluding acquisitions, sales in the fourth quarter would have risen about 6 percent, the company said. Fourth-quarter sales climbed 18 percent at SPX's service-solutions business and 12 percent at the flow-technology unit, the company said. SPX is based in Charlotte, N.C.

title: KERRY WINS THE IOWA CAUCUSES; DEAN 3RD, FAR BEHIND EDWARDS
description: Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts won the Iowa caucuses here Monday, brushing aside the insurgent anti-war candidacy of Howard Dean by presenting himself as the strongest Democrat his party had to send up against President Bush next year.

title: WELLS FARGO RESTATES EARNINGS FOR 2000 AND 2001
description: Wells Fargo & Company said it had restated earnings for 2000 and 2001 because of accounting changes for car loans, reducing net income by $26 million. The San Francisco-based bank had to restate profit after it reclassified auto leases as loans rather than direct financing, the company said in a statement. Profit from 2000 was lowered to $4.01 billion from $4.03 billion, while earnings in 2001 were cut to $3.41 billion from $3.42 billion. Wells Fargo is scheduled to report fourth-quarter earnings today.

title: Broader Health Coverage May Depend on Less
description: With the number of uninsured Americans rising to new heights, some policy makers and influential health care experts are saying that the best way to give health coverage to more people is to give some people less.

title: Day After Fight at Practice, the Islanders Regroup
description: After Oleg Kvasha weaved his way to a shot that restored the Islanders' two-goal lead over Ottawa on Monday afternoon, he skated down a receiving line of teammates. He tapped knuckles with each, including goalie Garth Snow, who felt those same knuckles in a fight at practice the day before.

title: Looking Back on Battered TV Journalism
description: GARRICK UTLEY's career as a reporter for television spanned the birth and arguably death of network news. He was there at its inception in the fall of 1963 as a young office clerk with the Brussels bureau of NBC News and left the screen a year ago as a commentator for CNN. He watched the half-hour nightly news broadcasts, begun just a few weeks after he started, become the behemoths of news coverage and then tumble in a sad decline with the advent of 24-hour cable news networks, satellite links and videophones.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Lumber Tariffs Endorsed
description: The World Trade Organization's appeals body has endorsed American taxes on imports of softwood lumber from Canada on the grounds that low tree-harvesting fees levied by Canadian provinces amount to an unfair subsidy. In 2002, America imposed taxes totaling 27 percent on Canadian lumber, which is used mainly for housing. Canada challenged the ruling under regulations of the World Trade Organization and the North American Free Trade Agreement. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: A Story of Black Insurrection Too Strong for 1973
description: ''The Negroes are the trouble spot,'' a black aide tells a white senator who is behind in the polls in ''The Spook Who Sat by the Door,'' Ivan Dixon's film about mounting a black insurrection in six American cities. Based on a provocative book by Sam Greenlee, ''Spook'' encountered plenty of trouble itself when it was released in 1973. The story goes that the government pressured the distributor, United Artists, to pull the movie from theaters. Facts are hard to come by, but ''Spook'' quickly disappeared, consigned to cult status and a murky life on bootleg video.

title: Anti-Globalization Forum Adds Variety of Causes to Its Agenda
description: Anti-globalization protesters jostled with opponents of war, and those fighting India's caste system performed street plays alongside groups opposing religious and sex discrimination. At the six-day annual World Social Forum here in India's financial capital, hundreds of groups raised their voices in protest, if not always in unison.

title: Iran Council Backs Off a Bit on Barred Politicians
description: TEHRAN, Jan. 20  The hard-line Islamic religious authority that disqualified 3,600 candidates from parliamentary elections next month has reversed its ruling for 200 candidates, and it announced today that more reinstatements would follow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HERTZBERG, BENJAMIN
description: HERTZBERG -- Benjamin, died suddenly, January 16, 2004. Dr. Diane E. Meier, Director of the Lilian and Benjamin Hertzberg Palliative Care Institute, and Dr. Albert Siu, Chair of the Brookdale Department of Geriatrics and Adult Development of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, and their faculty and staff, mourn the loss of Benjamin Hertzberg. A successful brewer and businessman, ardent photographer, and accomplished cellist, Benjamin Hertzberg was a committed and visionary philanthropist dedicated to improving the care of persons living with serious illness, and their families. With Lilian, his wife of 58 years, he established the Hertzberg Palliative Care Institute at Mount Sinai --a national model for the emerging field of hospital-based palliative care. We will miss him, and extend deepest sympathy to our dear friend and patron, Lilian Hertzberg.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about the novelist Olivia Goldsmith, who died of complications related to anesthesia for elective surgery, misstated the date she entered the hospital. It was Jan. 7, not Jan. 14. The obituary also misidentified the first publisher of her debut novel, ''The First Wives Club.'' It was Poseidon Press, not Arrow.

title: At Ground Zero, Rebuilding With Nature in Mind
description: While most of the anguished debate about ground zero has focused on recreating and remembering what was once there, another effort has been moving forward to create on the site something that never existed, an environmentally sensitive city within a city that is attuned to nature as well as the real estate market.

title: Providian's Profit Rises
description: The Providian Financial Corporation, the San Francisco-based parent of Providian National Bank, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit surged more than fivefold, to $67.1 million, as revenue increased and noninterest expense fell.

title: Casino Deals Are Stalled by State, U.S. and Tribal Hurdles
description: New York State approved the construction of three Indian casinos for the old resort areas here in the Catskills more than two years ago, and people in the area practically began to count the money they expected to get from gamblers and construction projects and new jobs.

title: PILOTS AND MANAGERS TO DISCUSS FINANCES AT US AIRWAYS
description: The US Airways Group and its pilots union said yesterday that they would discuss ways to help the airline meet payment terms on a $1 billion loan that permitted it to leave bankruptcy protection last year. The US Airways Air Line Pilots Association said it would send a group to meet with company executives to extend a discussion begun last Thursday about the airline's finances and options. US Airways said earlier this month that it was considering the sale of some assets like its shuttle in the Northeast to help meet the terms of the loan, $900 million of which is guaranteed by the federal government. The union said it would not drop its demand that David N. Siegel, the chief executive, and Neal S. Cohen, the chief financial officer, step down.

title: Top Iranian Council Reinstates 200 Parliamentary Candidates
description: The Guardian Council, which touched off a political crisis earlier this month by rejecting 3,600 candidates for Parliament, backed off a bit on Tuesday, reinstating 200 candidates and announcing that more reinstatements would follow, a member of the council said in a statement.

title: Bach Made the Rules, Chopin Honored Them
description: What did Chopin admire most of all in the music of Bach (for admire it he did)? I suspect it was the fearless adventure: the courage and knowledge -- the second breeds the first -- to take traditional harmony to the brink of chaos and have it all make sense. One hundred years later, and in a very different way, Chopin did much the same thing. Piotr Anderszewski put the two great men side by side in a piano recital at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday.

title: City Streets Provide a VersionOf Old-Fashioned Ice Capades
description: It was one of those days when it was indeed advisable to walk on the sunny side of the street. After a spate of winter weather, many sidewalks and roadways -- especially those the sun could not reach -- were covered with a thick layer of ice, making them more suitable for curling than for walking or driving.

title: After a Scolding, Seton Hall Burns No. 13 Syracuse
description: Seton Hall had a recent problem with effort, but apparently the Pirates' hearing is just fine.

title: Iraqis Again Seek Elections and a Local Trial for Hussein
description: Thousands of Iraqis demonstrated again on Tuesday in four major cities, demanding that the United States turn over Saddam Hussein to stand trial here and renewing calls for direct elections as the first step toward self-rule.

title: U.S. Says Only Taliban Died in Raid
description: American military officials said Tuesday that a raid over the weekend in southern Afghanistan had killed only 5 Taliban militants, not 11 civilians, as Afghan officials have reported.

title: Putin Eager to Show Russian Gains In Meeting With World Bank Head
description: President Vladimir V. Putin used a visit on Tuesday by the head of the World Bank to underscore his plans for economic improvements at home, as well as Russia's intention to forgive more debts owed by poor nations.

title: Colombia's Landed Gentry: Coca Lords and Other Bullies
description: It was a breathtakingly beautiful spread, 6,000 acres for cattle and crops on one of southern Colombia's most fertile plains, and the family that owned it had no plans to move. But when, late last year, shadowy men arrived and proposed a sale -- and set a bargain-basement price -- the owners felt it was an offer they could not refuse, said one of the family members, asking for anonymity.

title: Pakistan Bars Its Nuclear Scientists From Traveling Abroad
description: Pakistan on Tuesday barred all scientists working on its nuclear weapons program from leaving the country, as the government intensified its inquiry into allegations that nuclear technology had been shared with Iran.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TIGERMAN, JAMES
description: TIGERMAN--James. Age 52 of Chicago. Interior designer, scholar/collector/dealer of Asian and modern art, gallery owner, entrepreneur, devoted son of the late Merle and Happy; survived by family, friends and his devoted dog ''Bouber''. An announcement of a memorial in celebration of Jim's life will be forthcoming. Contributions in Jim's memory may be made to the Art Institute of Chicago or amfAR.

title: Dean's New-Voter Strategy Seemed to Work, for Others
description: Although bringing out first-time voters was central to the strategy of Howard Dean, they largely supported Senators John Kerry of Massachusetts and John Edwards of North Carolina in the Iowa caucuses Monday, according to polls of voters as they entered the caucuses.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Trade Deficit Rises
description: The trade deficit staged an eightfold increase in November compared with the same month a year ago, to $322 million, according to government statistics. Imports were driven up by electronics components, most of which are subsequently used to assemble other electronics products and then exported. While some economists said they suspected exports might have been underreported, others said the new data underscored the weakness of the Philippine economy compared with its Asian neighbors. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Quieting a 'Vampire' From an Author's Grave
description: A dozen years after his death Borislav Pekic is acclaimed as one of the greatest writers in the Serbian language, but he is otherwise little known.

description: Seeking to meet a court mandate to improve the quality of education for New York schoolchildren, one of the most politically explosive and challenging issues facing the state, Gov. George E. Pataki has turned to an old standby: gambling revenue.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''America will never seek a permission slip to defend the security of our people.''

title: Brooklyn Developer Reaches Deal to Buy New Jersey Nets
description: Bruce C. Ratner, the New York real estate developer who wants to move the New Jersey Nets to an arena in downtown Brooklyn, reached a tentative agreement to acquire the team for $300 million, defeating a similar offer by Charles Kushner and Senator Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey, the Nets' ownership group confirmed tonight. ``We're in the final stages of negotiating an agreement with Bruce Ratner,'' said Edwin Stier, president of Community Youth Organization, the Nets' ownership group. ``The contract terms have been finalized and we're putting the paperwork together.''

title: In Gay-Marriage Ruling, Boom for Provincetown
description: After the tourists and the drag queens disappear for the winter, the pace of this Cape Cod village most years slows to a small-town lull. But on a recent afternoon, Dave Schermacher, a caterer here, stared down at a to-do list that spilled over two pages. Mr. Schermacher, who runs PTown Parties, had been busy since 6:30 a.m., already preparing for nine weddings next summer and fall.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Paramilitary Chief Addresses Congress
description: A leader of an 800-member right-wing paramilitary unit that disbanded in November spoke before Congress, urging lawmakers to approve a deal to allow the rest of the 15,000-member militia army to demobilize in exchange for house arrest and the payment of reparations. The appearance in Congress was a first for a leader of the paramilitary force, the United Self-Defense Forces of Colombia, which has committed widespread rights violations in the 40-year conflict. Wearing a suit and tie, the commander, Giovanny Marn, said ''ours is an honest gesture'' aimed at ensuring peace. Critics say a deal would allow warlords to walk free. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAUFMANN, PETER HANS
description: KAUFMANN -- Peter Hans, died on January 20, 2004 at the age of 86. Husband of Ruth, father of Ronald, Jacqueline and Andrew. Fatherin-law of Susan, Howard and Pamela and devoted grandfather of Scott, Adam, Leslie, Tanya and Nicole. He will be greatly missed. Funeral Services on Friday, 2:30 PM at the Stephen Wise Synagogue, 30 West 68 Street, NYC.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: AMOVE TO RECALL THE MAYOR Critics of the mayor of Washington filed paperwork with the city's Board of Elections and Ethics to seek his removal from office. The mayor, Anthony A. Williams, a Democrat, says he will fight the recall drive, which he contends will bring negative publicity to the city. Election law requires the organizers of the recall to collect more than 35,000 signatures in support of the effort. Mr. Williams was first elected in 1998; he said this month that he was considering a run for a third term in 2006.

title: HealthSouth Audit Finds as Much as $4.6 Billion in Fraud
description: Auditors have uncovered hundreds of millions of dollars in previously unreported accounting fraud at HealthSouth, the embattled chain of hospitals and clinics, the company said yesterday.

title: A Not-Full House, by Design
description: As their colleagues watched the president's State of the Union address from the House chamber, four lawmakers and the secretary of commerce, Donald L. Evans, listened on Tuesday night from an undisclosed spot.

title: Piazza Optimistic About Playing First Base
description: The Mets reserved a corner of Grand Central Terminal to unveil their roster and their motto, Catch the Energy, for the coming season yesterday, and Mike Piazza seemed more energized about playing games at first base than he ever did last season.

title: Lawyer Accused of Fixing Home Auction Prices
description: A prominent lawyer in Brooklyn was arraigned yesterday on federal charges that he took $11,000 in bribes to fix prices on buildings for which he was the court-appointed auctioneer.

title: Review/Fashion; A Look That's Lean But Hardly Hungry
description: It takes an exceptionally limber mind to be a true creator, and only a handful of designers are free enough in their imaginations to drive fashion to another level. The rest are just keeping up or running artfully in place. But Karl Lagerfeld has that power to project beyond what you can see, and so do John Galliano and Christian Lacroix, whose shows have addled rational minds at the spring 2004 haute couture collections.

title: Edwards Halts Celebration To Step Up Fund-Raising
description: Flush with his surprise second-place showing in the Iowa caucuses, Senator John Edwards of North Carolina quickly tried to rally undecided voters here to join his ''movement to change America.''

title: The Fish That Came to Breakfast
description: Lovely silvery smelts from cold northern lakes and estuaries glitter on ice in markets now. The slender fish, often no more than six inches long, have sweet, rich flesh, with enough fat to insulate them in wintry weather. When fresh, they have an aroma that suggests cucumbers. Buy them whole and have them gutted. Small ones do not need filleting because their bones are soft and edible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COWLES, RODERICK S.
description: COWLES--Roderick S., 89, of The Dunes, NJ, passed away on January 10 in Manahawkin, NJ. Born in Brooklyn, NY, he graduated from Pratt Institute in 1935 and from Kean College in 1983. He was an Executive VP at E.R. Squibb & Sons, and the company's voice in Wash., DC where he worked closely with the FDA and testified before a number of Senate Committees. He was also instrumental in expanding the company worldwide. He and his family lived in Brooklyn, Seaford, NY, Westfield, NJ and The Dunes, NJ. While in Westfield he was active in the Democratic Party and on the Board of Directors of the Westfield Neighborhood Council. At his bedside were his wife, Joy, his daughter, Marguerite, his 4 sons, Peter, Michael, David and Jonathan, and his granddaughter, Silintira. He also leaves 8 more grandchildren and 3 great-grandchildren. Services were private. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Associated Humane Society, PO Box 43, Forked River, NJ 08731

title: Bank Finds No Signs of a Parmalat Account
description: Bank of America said on Tuesday that it could not find an account linked to Parmalat that an Italian lawyer had said held billions of euros.

description: 'Three Sisters'

title: A Concession Rattles the Rafters (and Some Dean Supporters)
description: DES MOINES, Jan. 20  Senator John Kerry's victory in Iowa may have been a big surprise, but it was Howard Dean's guttural concession-speech battle cry that was the talk of the political world on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WARD, HERBERT EVERARD
description: WARD--Herbert Everard. On Christmas Eve morn 2003 Herbert Everard Ward was born into eternity. Herbert was predeceased by parents Alice Everard Ward, Joseph Marshall Ward, and stepmother Donna Tenny Ward. His brother Frank Ward, sister-in-law Dorothy Ward, niece Alice Ward Raviolo and nephew John Ward survive Herbert. Herbert Everard Ward, born in Indianapolis, IN in 1915, studied art at Oberlin College in Ohio, and was a restaurateur in Manhattan's Greenwich Village, proprietor of Wards. Herbert settled in Bucks County, PA to paint. In 1947 Herbert and Larry Bemis acquired the Black Bass Hotel where they were partners until Larry's death in 1960, also on Christmas Eve. Herbert maintained that he lived in the most beautiful place on earth, Bucks County, PA. He collected art, books, and antiques. His collection of English commemoratives was world-renowned. He was a philanthropist, a Broadway Angel for the original production of The Boys from Syracuse, and he was known to be called Herbert builder, constructing homes and gardens throughout eastern PA. Herbert Everard Ward was a mentor, a friend extraordinaire, and a champion of animals. Boston Terriers Cheers and Mathilda survive him. Along side the aforementioned highlights are countless acts of simple kindness for those of us who were lucky enough to have crossed paths with Herbert Everard Ward. Signing off as Herbert did, ''Don't be good!'' or ''Bye for Now.''

title: Knife in Trash Can Leads to Connecticut Airport Evacuation
description: A concourse at Bradley International Airport was evacuated Tuesday for more than an hour after a utility knife that had been slipped through a security checkpoint was found in a bathroom trash can.

title: Pastas Plain And Not So Simple
description: Nuovo, a line of high-quality fresh pastas made in Stamford, Conn., includes ravioli, tortellini and agnolotti with appealing fillings like porcini; sun-dried tomato and Gorgonzola; and provolone and prosciutto. The company also makes gnocchi, penne and flat noodles, either plain or flavored with garlic, spinach, red pepper or basil.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Levittown: Firefighters Arrested In Attack
description: Three volunteer firefighters kicked and punched a fellow firefighter outside the Classics Sports Bar in Levittown early Monday morning, the Nassau County police said yesterday. The three firefighters, Daniel Lennon, 29, Anthony Parsell, 21, and Joseph Contino, 28, all of Levittown, each charged with second-degree gang assault, were arraigned yesterday in First District Court in Hempstead. The police said that Mr. Lennon attacked Scott Jenkins outside the bar at 1:16 a.m. Monday while the two others kicked him and prevented others from stopping the fight. The police said that the three had been drinking and that there was a longstanding enmity between Mr. Jenkins and Mr. Lennon. Patrick Healy (NYT)

description: Saying New York had turned the corner economically, Gov. George E. Pataki on Tuesday proposed a $99.8 billion budget that would significantly increase state spending and change the way the state pays for education and health care for the poor.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Inquiry At Software Company
description: The software company Finmatica said some executives were under criminal investigation. Finmatica's chairman, Pierluigi Crudele, is being investigated over accusations that he falsified company accounts, according to a person with knowledge of the case. Other directors and at least one internal auditor are also under investigation, the person said. Finmatica said its headquarters offices in Brescia were searched by investigators but it declined to give further details. Eric Sylvers (IHT)

description: In the mid-1990's, Julia Richman High was a big bad Manhattan public school, overcrowded and plagued by violence until a group of innovative educators took over, divided the building into six small schools and turned it into a national model.

description: IT has never been my practice to concentrate on any one ingredient or foodstuff. Somehow, it would seem like giving a class rather than suggesting a real meal.

title: AIR LIQUIDE TO BUY GAS OPERATIONS FOR $1.85 BILLION
description: Air Liquide, one of the world's largest makers of industrial gases, has agreed to buy Messer Griesheim's operations in Germany, the United States and Britain for 1.48 billion euros ($1.85 billion). Air Liquide is buying about two-thirds of Messer Griesheim, one of Germany's leading makers of industrial gases, from the German insurer Allianz, the Goldman Sachs Group and the Messer family. Air Liquide, which is based in Paris, will also assume 1.2 billion euros of Messer debt, the chairman, Benoit Potier, said at a news conference. The French company will take over Messer businesses with 2003 sales of 1.04 billion euros. In the United States, Air Liquide will compete with Air Products and Chemicals of Allentown, Pa.

title: Entrepreneur Confesses to Killing Wife, the Police Say
description: The developer of a new asthma treatment who was ousted a year ago from the research company he founded has admitted killing his wife in the garage of their million-dollar house and then trying to make it look as if she had died in an auto accident, the police said on Tuesday. He pleaded not guilty in Superior Court in Mercer County.

title: Use of Reggae Singer In Rum Ads Is Criticized
description: The dispute over whether advertising for alcoholic beverages is being aimed at teenagers is taking a new twist, as an advocacy organization questions a campaign from Allied Domecq Spirits North America to promote its Malibu rum brand featuring the reggae singer Shaggy.

title: Trip Home From Europe Becomes Kafkaesque Ordeal
description: A German woman married to a Brooklyn schoolteacher had been told that she had all her papers in order when she took a quick trip to show off her infant daughter to her parents in Germany.

title: Argentine Soy Exports Are Up, But Monsanto Is Not Amused
description: Booming soy exports may be a boon to Argentina's convalescent economy, but Monsanto has stopped selling its Roundup Ready soybean seeds because a sharp rise in black-market sales of genetically modified seeds has badly cut into the company's revenue.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Cruise To Nowhere
description: Hundreds of Italian and French cruise passengers were stranded in Barcelona after a Spanish court barred their ship from leaving port because of a contract dispute. The court ruled that the Italian-owned Festival cruise line owed more than $5 million to the company that leased the ship, European Stars. The 750 passengers found out that their 10-day Mediterranean tour would be cut short when the boat left dock but was prevented from leaving port by judicial order. Festival has promised to pay the cost of their trip home. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KATZ, SHELDON C.
description: KATZ--Sheldon C. The Rent Stabilization Association of New York City mourns the loss of Sheldon C. Katz, its longtime Chairman of the Board. Mr. Katz was a giant in the real estate industry who during his 26 years as RSA Chairman was a staunch defender of the rights of small property owners, calling them the backbone of the residential market, and an advocate of privately developed affordable housing. Even during his long and debilitating illness, he found the strength and courage to champion the cause of small property owners. His counsel will be sorely missed, but his voice will be heard forever through the indelible mark he has left on our industry from his years of commitment, dedication and sincerity. On behalf of RSA's 25,000 members, our prayers and condolences are extended to his wife of 41 years, Deana; his son, RSA Board member Lennard A. Katz, and the entire Katz family. Joseph Strasburg, RSA President Arnold Goldstein, RSA Acting Chairman RSA Board Of Directors

title: Economic Talks Draw Elite to Davos, but Have No Salient Issue
description: The black-tie soiree, canceled last year because it might have seemed flippant during a buildup toward war in Iraq, has been reinstated. The executives and politicians have reserved suites in fancy hotels. As for security in these days of terror threats and alarms, the airspace over this snow-struck Alpine village will be closed and hundreds of police officers and up to 6,000 troops will be on patrol.

description: Bruce C. Ratner and Charles Kushner raised their bids modestly yesterday in their competition to buy the Nets, and officials involved in the negotiations said the process was moving rapidly toward a conclusion that could come as early as today.

title: Senate Democrats Delay Approval of Major Spending Bill
description: Congress returned to work on Tuesday after an extended winter recess and picked up where it had left off -- with a partisan fight over spending in the Senate, where Democrats delayed approval of an $820 billion measure covering appropriations for more than a dozen federal departments and independent agencies.

description: Gov. George Pataki asked legislators to make budget reform a priority yesterday. He also presented his own budget for the next fiscal year. Mr. Pataki's plans and the legislative response made the best possible case for the need to fix things, quickly.

description: Oftentimes, leadership and policy are disconnected activities, enacted by individuals who function in silos without the benefit of dialogue or interaction with each other. The focus of the Leadership for Learning Project is to demystify and analyze education leadership and education policy and the respective roles that program participants can play within these areas.

description: Giants Coach Tom Coughlin came closer to rounding out his staff yesterday when he hired five assistant coaches.

Ship off Keith Van Horn while he plays the best basketball of his career? Bring in the noted malcontent Rasheed Wallace just when the Knicks are riding a chemistry high, full of smiles and compliments?

title: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: Jail For Colonel In 1990 Murder
description: In a landmark ruling, the Supreme Court has sentenced a former army colonel, Juan Valencia Osorio, to 30 years in prison for ordering the 1990 murder of Myrna Mack, an anthropologist who was researching military rights abuses committed against the country's Maya Indians. Colonel Valencia, a former head of the presidential security unit, was found guilty in 2002, the first time a military officer had been convicted of a war crime during the country's long civil war, but was released on appeal until Ms. Mack's family won a ruling overturning that decision. Larry Rohter (NYT)

These seven plasma and liquid-crystal sets, priced at $4,500 to $10,000, incorporate a feature called Ambilight, a series of cold-cathode fluorescent lights that project various colors onto the wall just behind the television.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Two Officers Grazed In Shooting
description: Two police officers were injured last night when bullets they fired to stop a charging pit bull hit each of them in the leg, a police spokesman said.The two officers and a lieutenant were answering a burglary call in Washington Heights at 11 p.m., the spokesman said. As they approached an apartment building at 1306 St. Nicholas Avenue, the pit bull charged at them. The officers fired six shots, hitting the dog. But some bullets appeared to have bounced off of the side entrance to the building. Each of the two officers was grazed by a bullet in the right leg, the spokesman said. The officers were taken to Columbia-Presbyterian Center of New York Presbyterian Hospital. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)
