description: Anew $22 million system to allow soldiers and other Americans overseas to vote via the Internet is inherently insecure and should be abandoned, according to members of a panel of computer security experts asked by the government to review the program.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Chemical Executive Resigns
description: The chief executive of the Lonza Group, a biotechnology and chemicals company, resigned as the company posted a decline of 59 percent in 2003 profit. The chief executive, Markus Gemuend, left, who joined Lonza's legal department in 1988, stepped down after less than two years in the job, the company said. Lonza, based in Basel, said that it had expected a recovery in the second half of 2003, but that its net income fell to 91 million Swiss francs ($71.6 million) from 221 million francs. The company said its largest unit, Exclusive Synthesis and Biotechnology, had been hurt by a low rate of drug approvals, inventory reduction by customers, and overcapacity in the industry. Fiona Fleck (NYT)

title: Rover Moves to Investigate Composition of Martian Rock
description: After flexing its mechanical arm and finding some puzzling chemistry in a patch of Martian soil, the robotic rover Spirit began investigating the composition of a rock named Adirondack yesterday with two science instruments and a microscopic camera.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Unisys Posts 25% Profit Increase
description: The Unisys Corporation, which sells server computers and related services to businesses, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit increased 25 percent, lifted by a decline in the value of the dollar, and cost cutting. Net income rose to $111.5 million, or 33 cents a share, from $89.1 million, or 27 cents, a year earlier, Unisys, based in Blue Bell, Pa., said. All of the 5.1 percent increase in sales, to $1.64 billion from $1.55 billion, came from the falling dollar. Revenue increased 5 percent in 2003, the first annual growth for Unisys since 1999, as the chief executive, Lawrence A. Weinbach, added new products and services and won orders from the United States government. Outsourcing orders declined in the quarter, lagging investors' expectations for an increase of as much as 10 percent, said David Garrity, an analyst with American Technology Research Inc. Shares of Unisys dropped 99 cents, or 6.3 percent, to $14.70. Excluding pension costs, Unisys reiterated profit estimates of 83 cents to 87 cents a share this year and 11 cents to 13 cents this quarter. Sales will rise in both periods by a percentage in the ''mid-single digits,'' the company said without elaborating.

title: In Chinatown, a Feast for All Senses
description: IN the chill of winter, Chanoodle, a bright and inviting restaurant on the western edge of Chinatown, offers something special for each of the five senses. First, as you enter, a startling roar whooshes from the open kitchen's forced-air stove, which rams intensified heat up through the burners, allowing chefs to raise cooking temperatures instantly. If you happen to glance toward the kitchen at the sound of the roar, you may see a rising column of flame -- hot oil in flamb mode, Hong Kong style.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: PLANES GROUNDED A SECOND DAY For the second straight day, Japan Air System grounded many of its domestic flights, saying it had discovered cracks in the engines of more planes. About 4,900 passengers were stranded as the airline canceled 95 flights, a spokesman said. On Monday, the airline grounded 120 flights, affecting 7,000 people. As many as 62 flights were expected to be canceled today, the airline said. It began emergency inspections of 25 MD-81 and MD-87 aircraft after two cases of engine trouble. With all but one of the planes inspected, 17 were found to have cracks in their engines. (AP)

title: Putting Psychoanalysis Itself on the Couch
description: Psychoanalysis, Janet Malcolm once wrote, is the wary (ultimately weary) examination by patient and analyst of the patient's behavior toward the analyst. Out of this absurdist collaboration -- the tireless joint scrutiny of the patient's reactions and overreactions to the analyst's limited repertory of activity in the sphere of fees, hours, waiting-room etiquette and above all absences -- come small, stray self-recognitions that no other relationship yields, brought forward under conditions of frustration (and gratification) that no other relationship could survive.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Two Charged In Subway Shooting
description: The police charged two young men yesterday in connection with the fatal shooting of a Bronx man early Monday morning aboard a subway train in Greenwich Village. Ortillio Tapia, 21, of the Bronx, was charged with murder and criminal possession of a weapon, and Pedro Revilla, 17, of Manhattan, was charged with criminal possession of a weapon. The police said that Mr. Revilla boarded a northbound W train at the Eighth Street station with the victim, Silverio Rivera, 25, just before 4 a.m. on Monday. The two of them came across Mr. Tapia; a fight ensued, with Mr. Tapia and Mr. Revilla drawing guns, and Mr. Tapia shot Mr. Rivera twice in the head, the police said. The police said that there were a few other passengers in the subway car at the time, but that none were hurt. Mr. Rivera was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, where he died. Michael Brick (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Yahoo Makes Deal With Rogers Cable
description: Yahoo said yesterday that it would take its high-speed broadband service to Canada in a deal with Rogers Cable, the largest cable television system in the country. Starting sometime this year, customers of Rogers's high-speed Internet service will have the option of using e-mail, content and other services provided by Yahoo. Terms of the arrangement were not disclosed, but Yahoo said the deal resembled a venture with SBC Communications in the United States. SBC pays more than $1 a month per subscriber to Yahoo. The move is a response to Bell Canada's deal last year to offer similar services from Microsoft's MSN to its high-speed data customers, said Brahm Eiley, president of the Convergence Consulting Group, a market research firm in Toronto. Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett Says Canada Halted Contract Payment
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, the computer maker, said yesterday that the Canadian government was refusing to pay some bills on suspicion that it might have been overcharged. The government is conducting cost audits of contracts for services provided to the Canadian defense department, Hewlett said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Canada has asked the company for documents to support its invoices. The audits began after Canada sent a notice to Hewlett on Aug. 1, the filing says. The company said it was cooperating with the inquiry and was conducting its own. The filing neither gives the contract's value nor specifies the nature of the contested billings. Shares of Hewlett-Packard fell 45 cents, to $25.07.

description: A front-page article yesterday about talks at the United Nations between Secretary General Kofi Annan and a delegation of American, British and Iraqi officials included a State Department participant erroneously. Kim Holmes, assistant secretary of state for international organizations, was in Washington.

description: LALLY--Veronica M. (nee McCarthy) entered peacefully into eternal life on January 18, at the age of 83, after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Martin J. Lally, NYPD. Loving mother of Veronica M. Kehoe, the late Martin J. Lally III and Maureen B. Lally. Cherished grandmother of Allise McAuley Dickson, Martin J. IV and Stacy Ann Lally. Friends may visit at the John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Ave (70th St) Tuesday and Wednesday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Rally Planned
description: More than 300 Bronx day care employees represented by Day Care Workers Local 205 plan to rally today in front of City Hall to protest stalled contract negotiations. The workers are among 7,000 members of Local 205 who have been working without a contract for three years, and without a raise for four years, said Michael Green, a spokesman for District Council 1707 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. Mr. Green, whose group includes Local 205 and five other locals, said the day care workers were pressing for pay raises comparable to those extended to other city workers in 2001 contracts. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: MUSIC: COMING ATTRACTIONS
description: A monthlong Brahms festival, the 35th anniversary of the Trisha Brown Dance Company and performances by Yo-Yo Ma, left, Ensemble Intercontemporain and the conductor Jonathan Nott are among the highlights of the 39th season of Lincoln Center's Great Performers series, announced yesterday. The nine-concert Brahms festival, ''The Classical Romantic,'' will feature performances by the Gewandhaus Orchestra of Leipzig, the Dresden Philharmonic and several recitals. The seventh annual New Visions series of experimental works will present Mark Lamos's ''Renaissance Muse'' and the Trisha Brown company, which will perform in the new home of Jazz at Lincoln Center, on Columbus Circle. Mr. Ma, with the Singapore Symphony, is to perform the New York premiere of Chen Yi's Cello Concerto, and Mr. Nott will join the French pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard in a series of Beethoven and Ligeti piano concertos. The 2004-5 season opens on Oct. 13 with a recital by the Russian pianist Mikhail Pletnev, and will continue through June. BEN SISARIO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SELVER, IRMGARD (NEE FRANK)
description: SELVER -- Irmgard (nee Frank), died on January 19, 2004 in New York City surrounded by devoted family and friends. Born August 24, 1906 in Chemnitz, Germany, she married Karl Goeritz with whom she had two children. In 1939 she lost her immediate family when the boat on which they fled war-torn Europe was mined. She came to New York in 1942 where she met and married Henry Selver, also of Chemnitz. They had two daughters, Irene and Veronica, and lived in France where Henry worked for the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee until his death in 1957. Irmi and her daughters returned to New York where Irmi worked as a secretary and massage therapist well into her 80s. Since 1966 Irmi made a second home for herself in her beloved Truro, Cape Cod. Irmi never lost her courage, her optimism, her strength and her love of family and friends. Her indomitable spirit will continue to inspire all who knew her and we will miss her terribly. She is survived by her loving daughters, Irene and Veronica, Veronica's partner Cappy, and her cherished granddaughters Anna and Eve. Donations in Irmi's honor can be made to the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services for the Goeritz Fund, established by Irmi in memory of her first two children (Frank and Irene Goeritz), 120 W. 57 St, NY, NY 10019. A memorial service will be held Thursday, January 22, at 1:30PM at Ansche Chesed, 251 W. 100 St, Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, MURIEL D. (NEE BARRY)
description: BROWN--Muriel D. (nee Barry). A lifelong resident of Greenwich Village in New York City and Budd Lake, N.J. Died suddenly in her New York home on Monday, January 19. She is the mother of Sheila of Budd Lake, N.J. and New York City, Msgr. Patrick E. Brown of Stirling, N.J., Elizabeth Pettinato and Thomas of New York City. She is also survived by her daughter-inlaw Patricia Brown and the late Lawrence George Pettinato. She had six grandchildren Sheila O'Donnell, Katie Brown, Maggie Brown, Thomas Brown, Larry Pettinato and Michael Pettinato and one great-grandchild Kathryn Grace O'Donnell. She is also survived by her brother Edward F. Barry of Staten Island, N.Y. She is the widow of the late Patrick E. Brown who died in 1990. Mrs. Brown lived her life as a devoted mother and grandmother. She was a daily communicant at the Immaculate Conception Church, Manhattan. She was active in the Ladies of Charity in the Archdiocese of New York and was a weekly volunteer at St. Patrick's Cathedral, New York City. The viewing will be at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue, New York City, N.Y. on Wednesday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9PM and Thursday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9PM. The Mass of the Resurrection will be celebrated on Friday at 10AM in St. Veronica's R.C. Church, Christopher Street, Greenwich Village. Interment will follow at The Holy Rood Cemetery, Whippany Road, Morristown, N.J. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the St. Vincent de Paul Endowment Fund.

title: National Briefing | Washington: A Move To Recall The Mayor
description: Critics of the mayor of Washington filed paperwork with the city's Board of Elections and Ethics to seek his removal from office. The mayor, Anthony A. Williams, a Democrat, says he will fight the recall drive, which he contends will bring negative publicity to the city. Election law requires the organizers of the recall to collect more than 35,000 signatures in support of the effort. Mr. Williams was first elected in 1998; he said this month that he was considering a run for a third term in 2006. John Files (NYT)

title: Bird Flu Alert for China; Falcon Found Dead With Virus
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 21  A dead peregrine falcon found near two chicken farms here had the avian influenza virus, agricultural officials said here today. The falcon is the first sign that the disease spreading in chicken flocks in Vietnam, South Korea and Japan may also be present in China.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21  The Supreme Court upheld the authority of the Environmental Protection Agency today, ruling that it was within its authority when it overruled Alaska regulators in a dispute involving a zinc and lead mine.

title: In Gallery, The Faces Highlight The Policies
description: When President Bush acknowledged Adnan Pachachi, the current chairman of the Iraqi Governing Council, in his State of the Union address on Tuesday night, the gesture was not merely a formality. If earlier parts of the speech were meant to underscore a continuing commitment to fighting terrorism, the nod to Mr. Pachachi highlighted the administration's hopes for an easing of the sacrifices that this commitment has thus far entailed.

title: A Celebration With Prickly Undertones
description: A presidential State of the Union address is always a bit like a wedding, a stately, yet celebratory occasion that lays out a grand vision for the future. But when the State of the Union is delivered in an election year, just one day after a blistering contest among Democrats seeking to defeat a Republican president, the celebration can turn a bit prickly.

title: U.P.S. TO BUY PARTNER'S STAKE IN JAPANESE VENTURE
description: United Parcel Service, the world's largest package-delivery company, said yesterday that it would buy the Yamato Transport Company's 49 percent stake in their joint venture to increase services in Japan. The 14-year-old venture, the UPS Yamato Express Company, which has about 600 employees, will become a U.P.S. unit on April 1, the company said. U.P.S., which is based in Atlanta, and Yamato, which is based in Tokyo, did not disclose terms.

title: Bush Promotes Earlier Proposals for Tax-Advantaged Savings Accounts
description: President Bush hinted at big plans on Tuesday about overhauling Social Security and restated demands to make the last rounds of tax cuts permanent, but he made only fleeting references to new initiatives.

title: DRUG DISTRIBUTOR ACQUIRES COMPANY FOR ONLINE SKILLS
description: The McKesson Corporation, a leading drug distributor, has agreed to buy the Moore Medical Corporation for $40 million to gain technology for promoting and selling products on the World Wide Web. McKesson, which is based in San Francisco, will pay $12 a share, a 15 percent premium over Moore's $10.45 closing price on Friday. The acquisition will probably close in the second quarter, Larry Kurtz, a spokesman for McKesson, said. Moore's business uses online marketing that complements McKesson's sales force of 500, Mr. Kurtz said. Moore is based in New Britain, Conn.

title: From Store to Table, Without Going Outside
description: THERE is every reason in the world to believe that if a chef's supply of fresh ingredients is always at hand, his restaurant can serve simple, well-executed food. No need for carved vegetables or a dozen different components on the plate.

title: Sweet as Maple But Spicier: Hickory Syrup
description: Waffles, roasted sweet potatoes, plain yogurt and vanilla ice cream can all gain new personality with a drizzle of hickory syrup, which is earthier and spicier than maple syrup. Hickoryworks in Trafalgar, Ind., makes this old-fashioned concoction, which is a sugar syrup infused with shagbark, from a kind of hickory. The owners, Gordon Jones and his wife, Sherrie Yarling, sell it at www.hickoryworks.com in plastic jugs starting at $16 a pint, including shipping. A fancy eight-ounce bottle with a wax seal, shown here, is $14.50 at the Web site and $15.50 at Dean & DeLuca stores.

title: For Labor, a Day to Ask What Went Wrong
description: The labor unions that backed Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and Howard Dean, the former Vermont governor, were embarrassed yesterday and searching for answers why their candidates -- and the unions themselves -- fared so poorly in the Iowa caucuses.

title: State of the Union; At Home
description: When the president delivers his State of the Union address, we like to listen respectfully and respond politely. It is always easy to find things worth applauding. Last night, for instance, President Bush mentioned job retraining, immigration law reform and programs to help newly released prisoners re-enter society. The impulse is always to split the difference -- to decry the ideas we disagree with and then note the ones we like. This time, such evenhandedness seems impossible. The president's domestic policy comes down to one disastrous fact: his insistence on huge tax cuts for the wealthy has robbed the country of the money it needs to address its problems and has threatened its long-term economic security. Everything else is beside the point.

title: Rich Redefined: 23-Karat Sprinkles
description: Donato Deserio, the chef and owner of Sette in Chelsea, dresses up ice cream, right, and biscotti, left, with gold leaf. He is just one of the chefs adorning confections with gold leaf, a luxurious decoration that home cooks can also use. Steve Martinez, who owns the Gold Leaf Company on Staten Island, charges $28 for 25 sheets of 23-karat gold leaf, each nearly four inches square, with a backing that peels off easily. He also sells gold bits and powder to sprinkle onto cakes or candies or into Champagne.

title: Famous Chefs! Sumptuous Food! Luxuriant Settings!
description: TWO weeks and counting. On Feb. 4, some 100,000 square feet of marble floors will shine behind a facade of 90,000 square feet of glass, and more than 3,000 guests in formal attire will enter the soaring atrium of the Time Warner Center at Columbus Circle to celebrate its opening and the arrival of widely anticipated new restaurants on two floors.

title: The President, a Quarterback And a Toddler in Cornrows
description: Any president delivering a State of the Union address in an election year is a little like a newly minted divorc -- suddenly vulnerable to comparative appraisal.

title: ALL THIS JAZZ
description: The conference of the International Association for Jazz Education, an annual convention of more than 7,000 jazz musicians, scholars, critics, broadcasters, and producers -- really, for anyone working with jazz around the world in any way -- begins today at two midtown Manhattan hotels, the Hilton New York and Towers and the Sheraton New York and Towers. Before it ends on Saturday, it will offer a blizzard of clinics and discussions on topics both minutely practical and philosophically wide. They range from ''How to Embellish Dominant-Seventh Chords and the Use of Tritone Subs'' (clinician: Jamey Aebersold, a pre-eminent publisher of jazz instruction books), to the much more contentious ''The Contributions and Influence of Latino Musicians in Jazz: A Supreme Historical Oversight'' (moderated by the percussionist Bobby Sanabria). In and around the panels and workshops will be dozens of performances, including those by Paquito D'Rivera and the New York Voices, the Dave Holland Quintet, the Maria Schneider Orchestra, Jason Moran's Bandwagon, Bob Brookmeyer and the New Art Orchestra, Nicholas Payton, David Sanchez, Michel Camilo, Jazz at Lincoln Center's Afro-Latin Jazz Orchestra, the English vocal-jazz newcomer Jamie Cullum, and the 14-year-old Italian saxophonist Francesco Cafiso. A National Endowment for the Arts Jazz Master Awards Concert, Friday at 8 p.m. in the Hilton Hotel's Grand Ballroom, will honor this year's winners of that award, with performers including Dave Brubeck, Clark Terry and the Heath Brothers. The jazz association had its first conference in 1968; only during the last decade has the membership enlarged beyond educators, and the annual conventions have become the supreme networking opportunity for the jazz world. Information on registration is available online at www.iaje.org. BEN RATLIFF

title: Magazine Advertising Declined in 2003
description: Magazine advertising in 2003 ended on a downbeat as ad pages sank for a seventh consecutive month in December, according to information released yesterday by the Publishers Information Bureau.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Cheerleader Was Intoxicated
description: An 18-year-old cheerleader from Randolph who fell to her death from a balcony at a resort hotel on the island of Maui on Jan. 12 was intoxicated at the time, Hawaiian authorities said yesterday. The Maui County coroner, Dr. Anthony Manoukian, said tests had determined that the young woman, Lauren Crossan, left, had a blood-alcohol count of 0.17 percent, just over twice the legal limit of 0.08 percent for intoxication in Hawaii. The police have classified the death as an accident, but the investigation remains open. The head of the investigation, Lt. Tivoli Faaumu, said yesterday that detectives had not determined where Ms. Crossan had been drinking. Robert Hanley (NYT)

description: Scott Clemmensen, the Devils' surprise starter in goal Tuesday, lost his stick. He tried to pick it up, but left wing Jeff Friesen stepped on it.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Inmates With H.I.V. Back In The Mix
description: Limestone Correctional Facility in Harvest will stop isolating H.I.V.-positive prisoners from the rest of the prison's population, allowing them to participate in educational and vocational programs with other prisoners. Alabama is the only state still to segregate H.I.V.-positive prisoners, said Margaret Winter, associate director of the A.C.L.U. National Prison Project. Ms. Winter called the new measures a ''huge and historic'' step. Women with H.I.V. are still segregated, she said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: National Briefing: South
description: NORTH CAROLINA: COMMANDMENTS MONUMENT REMOVED A granite monument to the Ten Commandments placed in front of City Hall in Winston-Salem by a City Council member was removed after it was deemed a safety threat, a city spokeswoman said. The monument was lifted with a backhoe and taken to a Department of Transportation warehouse, the spokeswoman, Carrie Collins, said. The monument, four feet tall, consisted of two unfastened pieces that Ms. Collins said could topple. The council member, Vernon Robinson, placed the monument in front of City Hall on Monday while the building was closed for Martin Luther King's Birthday. He said he paid the $2,000 cost of buying and moving the monument himself.    (AP)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Exhibit A: Amazonian Feathers
description: Lawrence M. Small, who heads the Smithsonian Institution, has entered into a plea agreement with a federal prosecutor in connection with charges that his private collection of Amazonian artifacts contained feathers of endangered bird species. Mr. Small will plead guilty to one count, a nonintentional misdemeanor violation of the Migratory Bird Treaty Act. The United States attorney will not recommend a fine or jail time, said a statement by the museum's board of regents. The statement also said that Mr. Small ''voluntarily surrendered his entire featherwork collection to the government.'' The United States Fish and Wildlife Service began an investigation after photographs of Mr. Small's collection were published in the Smithsonian magazine in January 2000. Elizabeth Olsen (NYT)

title: Judge Chooses San Mateo County as Site of Murder Trial
description: Tourism officials in San Mateo County cheered wildly on Tuesday when a judge announced that the murder trial of Scott Peterson would be moved there.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: President's Brother Is New Cuban Envoy
description: President Hugo Chvez has appointed his brother and confidant, Adn, to be ambassador to Cuba, a move sure to irritate the United States, which has raised concerns about Mr. Chvez's close ties to President Fidel Castro. Mr. Chvez's foes charge that his relationship with Mr. Castro is leading Venezuela down a radical political path. Venezuela has made the Castro government a close economic partner and is providing Cuba with oil at bargain-basement prices. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEIN, LILLIAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANE, JODIE S.
description: LANE--Jodie S. The faculty, staff, administration, students and trustees of Teachers College, Columbia University profoundly mourn the tragic passing of Jodie Lane on Friday, January 16. Jodie received her M.S. in 2002 and was a fifth-year doctoral student in our program in Clinical Psychology. She was an excellent student, researcher and clinician. She was working on a book for children who suffered from OCD (obsessive compulsive disorder). She had published articles in professional journals and was an extremely talented therapist who cared deeply about her patients. Jodie was a rare and wonderful woman who will truly be missed by all. Our condolences to her mother Karen, father Roger and stepmother Jill, brother Jacob and boyfriend Alex. A memorial service at Teachers College is scheduled for Thursday, January 22, at 6PM in Milbank Chapel. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Jodie S. Lane Memorial Fund, Wells Fargo Bank, 10400 Research Blvd, Austin, TX. 78759. Arthur Levine, President, Teachers College, Columbia University

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GATEHOUSE, SUZANNE
description: GATEHOUSE -- Suzanne. A lovely flower has wilted: the earthly life of Suzanne Gatehouse that lit so many lives with her unstinting effervescence, exuberant laughter and sheer joy, passed on January 19 at South Nassau Community Hospital in Oceanside, Long Island (NY 11572), close to her home in Lawrence. She was the daughter of the late John P. Gatehouse and Marie Kennedy Gatehouse, and is survived by her first cousin, Charles C. Bingham, many second cousins, and numerous devoted friends. A Mass of Christian burial will be said at 10 A.M. on Friday, January 23, at Saint Joachim's Church at 614 Central Avenue, Cedarhurst, Long Island (NY 11516). Donations in her memory may be made to the hospital or church.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Red Hat Offers Warranty
description: In response to SCO Group's legal action against Linux, Red Hat is offering new legal protection that guarantees the company will replace any code found to infringe copyrights. The warranty, part of what is called the Open Source Assurance Program, is for all existing and future customers of the company's Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system products, the company, based in Raleigh, N.C., said in an announcement on Monday night. The LinuxWorld Conference and Expo is scheduled to begin today in New York. SCO asserts that I.B.M. improperly moved Unix intellectual property into Linux and, independently, that Linux infringes on the company's Unix copyrights. But offers of legal defense are sprouting all over the Linux landscape as advocates try to defuse threats from SCO, which has sued I.B.M. for breach of contract and has promised to sue a Linux user for copyright infringement. Novell, the No.2 Linux seller after Red Hat by virtue of its acquisition of SuSE Linux, began indemnifying its Linux customers last week, following in the footsteps of Hewlett-Packard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRANDENBURGER, ANNE BENNETT
description: BRANDENBURGER -- Anne Bennett, 52, of Greenwich, CT died January 16 in a car accident caused by a ruptured aneurism. Born January 1, 1952 in NYC, she was the daughter of Huntley Bennett of Naples, FL and Alice Rath Bennett of Mill Valley, CA. Anne grew up in Marin County, CA, attending Ross Grammar School and The Branson School in Ross. She graduated from Vassar College in 1974 and attended the NY School of Design and Parsons School. Anne worked in New York City with designers Karl Springer and Mark Hampton before founding the architectural design firm of BennettWallace. She was a member of the ASID and a certified practitioner of Feng Shui. Anne's volunteer beneficiaries included Greenwich Academy and the American Cancer Society. She was a founding co-chair of the Young Friends of the NY Public Library. Anne cherished her family and many friends. She relished quiet mornings, yoga, meditation, the mountains, the sea, indeed, all of nature's beauty. Anne loved the art of Henri Matisse and was an avid tennis player. In addition to her parents, she is survived by her husband, Tom Brandenburger of Greenwich; daughters Alexandra Elise and Madeleine Anne; a stepson, William Brandenburger of Sausalito, CA; and a sister, Nancy (Fern) Bennett Phillips of York, ME. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Anne Bennett Brandenburger Memorial Fund, C/O Greenwich Academy, 200 North Maple Avenue, Greenwich, CT. 06830.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: GUATEMALA: JAIL FOR COLONEL IN 1990 MURDER In a landmark ruling, the Supreme Court has sentenced a former Army colonel, Juan Valencia Osorio, to 30 years in prison for ordering the 1990 murder of Myrna Mack, an anthropologist who was researching military rights abuses committed against the country's Mayan Indians. Colonel Valencia, a former head of the presidential security unit, was found guilty in 2002, the first time a military officer had been convicted of a war crime during the country's long civil war, but was released on appeal until Ms. Mack's family won a ruling overturning that decision. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Malaria on the Rise

One reason for malaria's resurgence is that it has evolved to resist the two standard treatments. In East Africa, chloroquine, the most widely used drug, fails two-thirds of the time, and a newer treatment is useless in nearly half of the cases.

description: A Long Island woman was arraigned yesterday in First District Court in Hempstead on charges of attacking another driver with a baseball bat during a traffic dispute. The woman, Jasmine Thomas, 24, of Farmingdale, was driving in Valley Stream on Tuesday afternoon when she and another motorist stepped outside their vehicles and exchanged heated words, the Nassau County district attorney's office said. Ms. Thomas then hit the victim, who was identified as a 50-year-old Valley Stream man, several times in the head and arms with an aluminum bat, the authorities said. She then drove off, striking the man in his legs, officials said. He was reported in stable condition yesterday at Franklin General Hospital. description: For 30 years, the usually solitary sport of cross-country skiing has been transformed into a mass race of inspiration and perspiration along a 51-kilometer trail through the woods of northwest Wisconsin: it is the American Birkebeiner.

title: Rusty Williams Shows Substance, and Style
description: It was a fashion mismatch. There with her shimmering accessories and halter-top tennis dress designed by Diane Von Furstenberg was Venus Williams. There across the net in her plain white T-shirt and no-nonsense ballcap was Vera Douchevina.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Grocer Closing Office
description: Still struggling to recover from a $1.2 billion accounting scandal, Royal Ahold, the food retailer, said it was closing its United States corporate retail headquarters in Chantilly, Va., relocating or eliminating about 100 positions there. Ahold said most of its corporate retail functions in the United States would be managed starting this summer from a new Boston administrative office that would help manage two of its United States subsidiaries, the supermarket chains Stop & Shop and Giant-Landover. Ahold is in the midst of a major cost-cutting program. Earlier this week, the company announced plans to sell 204 convenience stores in the United States that belong to its Tops Markets chain. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Mortgage Applications Up
description: A gauge of mortgage applications recorded the greatest increase in three years last week as relatively low interest rates continued to encourage home purchases and refinancing.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Fashion page on Jan. 13 about Pitti Immagine Uomo, a men's wear trade show in Florence, Italy, misspelled the given name of a designer there. He is Marc Ecko, not Mark.

title: More Than Just Shelters
description: To the Editor:

title: The State of the Union, Spoken and Unspoken (8 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Sowing Art on the Kansas Prairie; Local Boy Returns to Add Color and Commerce to a Fading Town
description: Not long ago this isolated town nestled in the Flint Hills seemed about to blow off the map. The bank failed, farmers lost or sold their land, stores shut down, and people drifted away.

title: Confronting A Big Loss, A State Just Shrugs
description: As bidders in two states jockeyed over the fate of the New Jersey Nets, the basketball team's fans were mostly cool to indifferent -- a little like they were during the team's entire tenure in the state, where attendance at its games was, even in the best of times, lagging.

title: A Doctor's Office In Disguise
description: ''I wanted to create a maze so kids will walk in, and come in with a smile,'' said Dr. Michel Cohen, a pediatrician who designed and built his own brightly colored twisting office in TriBeCa, above, complete with six fish tanks. Happy children, he said, make the job that much easier.

title: On Columbus Circle, Fighting a Face-Lift
description: THIS much will always be true: The view from the top floor of 2 Columbus Circle is stunning.

title: Bush, on Campaignlike Swing, Promotes Job-Training Initiative
description: The White House insisted on Wednesday that President Bush's State of the Union speech was not the opening shot of his re-election campaign. But that did not stop the president from taking a relatively small job-training initiative that he included in the speech to two of the most hotly contested states in the coming election, Ohio and Arizona.

title: Testimony on Bonuses to Ex-Tyco Executives
description: Investors were not told of millions of dollars of compensation paid to former Tyco International executives, the company's former head of investor relations testified under questioning from prosecutors yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Maxtor Posts Surge In Profit
description: The Maxtor Corporation, the world's second-largest maker of disk drives, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit rose more than tenfold because of higher demand for desktop computers and server machines. Net income increased to $38.8 million, or 15 cents a share, from $3.58 million, or 1 cent a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 13 percent, to $1.17 billion from $1.04 billion, said Maxtor, based in Milpitas, Calif. The shares slipped after the company said sales and profit this quarter might miss analysts' forecasts. Maxtor's first-quarter profit, excluding some costs, will be 12 cents to 15 cents a share, the chief financial officer, Robert L. Edwards, said on a conference call. Sales will rise to $1 billion to $1.06 billion, he said. Shares of Maxtor fell 75 cents, to $10, in extended trading after the report. They fell $1.56, or 13 percent, to $10.75 in regular trading.

title: Sports of The Times; A New Bounce in Brooklyn's Step
description: Contrary to popular belief, Brooklyn did not die when a rich man named Walter O'Malley took away the Dodgers after the 1957 baseball season.

title: Bush Wants Bigger NASA Budget, Official Says
description: The administrator of NASA said Wednesday that the Bush administration would request a 5.6 percent budget increase for his agency for the fiscal year that begins in October, rising to $16.2 billion from $15.4 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GORDON, ZANE
description: GORDON--Zane. On January 21st, 2004. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, friend. We will miss you.

title: For a Fee, Wind Up Atop the Search Heap
description: GOOGLE vanity is getting to be costly.

title: Final Holdout, The Printer, Cuts the Cord
description: FOR those who have savored the freedom of wireless networks, whether at home, at the office or in an Internet cafe, wires and cables may seem like obsolete relics from the earliest days of personal computing. But even networked homes usually maintain one tether to the past: the printer cable.

title: Edwards Acknowledges Negative Memo
description: Senator John Edwards of North Carolina, who has rebuked his rivals for negative campaigning, said Wednesday night that he condemned and took responsibility for a memorandum to his Iowa campaign workers that described Howard Dean as ''an elitist'' and John Kerry as ''part of the failed Washington politics.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Doctor Admits Medicare Fraud
description: A Brooklyn doctor pleaded guilty in Federal District Court to receiving kickbacks for his referrals of Medicare patients, federal authorities in Manhattan said yesterday. The doctor, Andre B. Celestin, who was charged with the scheme in a one-count indictment in May, entered his plea on Tuesday. Federal prosecutors said that for about six years, Dr. Celestin, a general surgeon, received cash payments for referrals. He is to be sentenced in April and faces a maximum of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Home Building Keeps Driving The Economy
description: The housing market may not be done driving the economy.

title: Conservative Groups Differ On Bush Words on Marriage
description: Correction Appended

title: A Light for a Dark or Stormy Night
description: Whether you went through the blackout in the Northeast, live where winter storms frequently knock out the power, or just need to find your way to the baby's room, the Guardian lantern may be helpful. It recharges while hanging from a glowing blue plug that acts as a night light. When the Guardian is removed it turns on automatically and stays on for five hours on a full charge. It also turns on if the power fails. The Guardian is six inches high and gives as much light as a candle; $39 from Vessel, (877) 805-1801 or www.vesselinc.com for store locations. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Terror Indictment
description: A student in Minneapolis who the authorities said attended a terrorist training camp in Afghanistan, was charged in a federal indictment with providing material support to Al Qaeda. The student, Mohammed Abdullah Warsame, 30, a Canadian of Somali descent, is scheduled to be returned to Minnesota from New York to face a charge of terrorism that could result in up to 15 years in prison. Mr. Warsame was arrested last month as a material witness. News reports in Minneapolis indicated that he might have known Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person charged in connection with the Sept. 11 attacks. Law enforcement officials would not comment on any link between the two. Eric Lichtblau (NYT)

title: The Way We Vote: Much Room for Improvement
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HERZBERG, HERBERT
description: HERZBERG--Herbert. Born December 21, 1913, Berlin, Germany, died January 18, 2004, New York, NY. Beloved husband of Rita Guibert Herzberg and the late Luisa Herzberg. Cherished father of Horacio Herzberg, Ernesto Herzberg, and Ana Maria Neuman. Loving Vati to Gabriela and David Herzberg; James, Emanuel, and Walter Herzberg; Andrew and Peter Neuman. Great grandfather to Spencer Neuman. His life and memory are a blessing to all who knew and loved him.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: ORANGE JUICE FALLS. Orange juice fell because of concern that a record orange crop in Florida will overwhelm demand. In New York, orange juice for March delivery fell 4.55 cents, or 6.9 percent, to 61.45 cents a pound.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon To Sell Stake In Indonesian Company
description: Verizon Communications is in talks to sell its 23.1 percent stake in a major Indonesian cellular operator, Excelcomindo Pratama, according to an Excelcomindo executive. Confirming local news reports that talks were under way, the executive said that negotiations with China Telecom and Telekom Malaysia had been delayed last week during Excelcomindo's sale of $350 million in bonds to international investors. The executive said, though, that talks were likely to resume and that Telstra of Australia had also emerged as a potential bidder.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Telecom Venture
description: A South African telecommunications and multimedia company, Allied Technologies, and Econet Wireless, a cellular provider in Johannesburg, said they had created a $140 million joint venture. Under the deal, which is subject to government approval, Allied, known as Altech and controlled by the Allied Electronics Corporation, also of Johannesburg, will contribute $70 million in cash and Econet $70 million in assets, including cellular and satellite interests in Botswana, Britain, Kenya, Lesotho, New Zealand and Nigeria. Econet's company listed in Zimbabwe and its international assets will not initially be part of the deal. The venture will expand Allied's cellular telephone reach and will be based in Johannesburg.

title: The Way We Vote: Much Room for Improvement (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Creative Officer Leaves J. Walter Thompson
description: Michael J. Campbell is leaving his post as executive vice president and chief creative officer at the flagship New York office of J. Walter Thompson, where he led the creative department for three years, ''to pursue other opportunities,'' the agency said yesterday.

title: Potato Chip Mania
description: To the Editor:

title: It Knows All Your Passwords (But Promises Not to Tell)
description: Passwords that are nonintuitive enough to keep private information private can be a bother if you routinely visit secure Web sites (for shopping online, say) or if you use computers that are accessible to others. Passwords should be both irregular and complex, but irregular, complex combinations of letters and numbers are hard to remember.

title: Fiscal Neglect In Nassau Is Outlined
description: Nassau County's economic development agencies often operated in violation of basic rules -- or even without them, witnesses testified on Wednesday at a hearing here.

title: EXPERIMENTAL DRUG FAILS IN STUDY ON LIVER CIRRHOSIS
description: InterMune, a maker of medicines that help the immune system, said yesterday that an experimental drug had failed to reverse advanced liver damage, the goal of a study. The company's interferon gamma-1b drug did not reverse severe liver scarring, known as cirrhosis, after 48 weeks, InterMune said. Researchers studied patients who did not benefit from therapy for hepatitis C, which caused the cirrhosis. InterMune, based in Brisbane, Calif., is seeking new drugs to add to sales of its top-selling product, Actimmune, approved to treat a blood disorder, chronic granulomatous disease, and overly dense bones.

title: Knicks' Fast Break Halted, So Is Their Winning Streak
description: The Houston Rockets took away the Knicks' new toy, the lickety-split fast break led by Stephon Marbury, and reduced the Knicks to a jump-shooting mess Wednesday night.

title: Ex-Executive Is Found Guilty In Nassau Insurance Case
description: A former health insurance executive accused of being the mastermind in an insurance scam that cost Nassau taxpayers millions of dollars was found guilty on Wednesday of evading $1 million in income taxes, prosecutors said.

title: A Chamber Series Hails the Past, or at Least Parts of It
description: Since its earliest days the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has commissioned a handful of new works every year, and in 35 seasons it has amassed an estimable portfolio. The society is celebrating its commissioning program with ''Sound Investment,'' a four-concert series that opened on Tuesday and runs through Feb. 1. Along the way its musicians will sample works by 43 composers who have written for the ensemble.

title: For Flat-Panel Viewers, A Soothing Background Aura
description: A new line of flat-panel televisions coming this spring from Philips produces images that are not only superior to those of conventional sets but also more restful. These seven plasma and liquid-crystal sets, priced at $4,500 to $10,000, incorporate a feature called Ambilight, a series of cold-cathode fluorescent lights that project various colors onto the wall just behind the television.

title: In Stewart Jury Pool, A Sense of Familiarity
description: Several of the nearly three dozen prospective jurors interviewed behind closed doors on Tuesday in the government's case against Martha Stewart have bought her products, watched broadcast interviews in which she proclaimed her innocence, or had dealings with her or her company through relatives or colleagues, a court transcript released yesterday shows.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The euro rose after a European Central Bank council member said the currency's advance was ''not excessive.'' In New York, the euro settled at $1.2633, up from $1.2568 on Tuesday.

title: The State of the Union, Spoken and Unspoken
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GATEHOUSE, SUZANNE
description: GATEHOUSE -- Suzanne. A lovely flower has wilted: the earthly life of Suzanne Gatehouse that lit so many lives with her unstinting effervescence, exuberant laughter and sheer joy, passed on January 19 at South Nassau Community Hospital in Oceanside, Long Island (NY 11572), close to her home in Lawrence. She was the daughter of the late John P. Gatehouse and Marie Kennedy Gatehouse, and is survived by her first cousin, Charles C. Bingham, many second cousins, and numerous devoted friends. A Mass of Christian burial will be said at 10 A.M. on Friday, January 23, at Saint Joachim's Church at 614 Central Avenue, Cedarhurst, Long Island (NY 11516). Donations in her memory may be made to the hospital or church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DURGIN, DON
description: DURGIN--Don. Died December 26, 2003, at Lenox Hill Hospital, at age 79, from an aneurism. Beloved husband of Catherine Meacham Durgin. Father of William Ryerson Durgin II of Manhattan, and Hillary Durgin Harmon of Houston, TX. Grandfather of Murphey, Cornelius Kelley, Samuel and Therese Harmon. Don's first wife, Therese Keresey, died in 1981. Don graduated from the Hotchkiss School 1941, Princeton University, A.B., summa cum laude in 1945, and LLB, NYU 1954. During WW II, First Lieutenant U.S. Army Air Corps, flying combat missions as a B-17 bombardier, 8th Air Force (96th Bomb Group) 1943-45 from England. Don retired in 2001 as Vice Chairman of Newsweek magazine, which he joined in 1989. He spent most of his career at NBC Television Network 1949-'75, leaving briefly in 1951 to join ABC Television Network, becoming at age 32, Vice President ABC Radio Network. Returned to NBC in 1957 as Vice President National Sales NBC Television Network and then President of the NBC Television Network from 1965-'73. Executive Vice President NBC 1973-'75. Don began his career at Foote, Cone & Belding in 1947, becoming Assitant Account Executive. Following his years at NBC, he became President McAffrey & McCall advertising agency, 1975-'76. Director, American Savings Bank. Executive Vice President, Dun & Bradstreet 1977-'82 in charge of broadcast and publishing operations. Vice President marketing 1982-'88. Society of the Cincinnati. Memorial service Saint James' Church, January 23, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Don Durgin Scholarship at Princeton University, P.O. Box 5357, Princeton, NJ 08543; or to The Princeton Triangle Club, c/o McCarter Theatre, Princeton, NJ 08543.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: PalmOne To Cut Work Force By 12%
description: PalmOne, the maker of hand-held computers, said yesterday that it would cut its work force by about 12 percent as part of an effort to refocus its investments on devices that include mobile phones. The company, based in Milpitas, Calif., said it would cut some 100 jobs. The reduction affects positions throughout the company and will leave PalmOne with some 740 employees. PalmOne, created last year by its split from PalmSource and its subsequent acquisition of a rival, Handspring, said it hoped to deliver a profit in the 2005 fiscal year. The company said it planned to maintain its dominant position in the market for hand-held computers, but would invest more in the high-growth area of phones that allow users to keep track of personal information, also known as smart phones. PalmOne shares fell $1.21, or 10 percent, to $10.86.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Cellphone 'Dead Spots'

title: Accounts
description: Pfizer, New York, to the New York office of Arnold Worldwide, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners division of Havas, to handle creative duties for Relpax, a drug that treats migraines, which had been handled by Publicis Worldwide, New York, part of the Publicis Groupe. Spending has not been determined.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Rowland Losing Allies
description: Support for Gov. John G. Rowland continues to erode among Connecticut voters and even among the governor's fellow Republicans in the wake of his admission last month that he lied about receiving free work on his cottage from state workers, according to a poll released yesterday. The poll, by Quinnipiac University, found that 56 percent of voters believe the General Assembly should impeach and remove Mr. Rowland from office, an increase from 42 percent on Jan. 7 Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AMSTEL, SIGMUND
description: AMSTEL -- Sigmund. With great sadness, we announce the passing of Sigmund Amstel, dearly beloved husband of Carrie, devoted father, father - in - law, grandfather, uncle and friend. We shall miss you. Rest in peace. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St & Amsterdam Ave on Friday at 9:30AM.

title: A Possible Challenge To Knicks' Supremacy
description: For the past two seasons, the Nets have been far superior to the Knicks, dunking on them repeatedly in matchups, turning Madison Square Garden into a den of Nets admirers whenever they play there. But, situated across the Hudson River in New Jersey, the Nets have never been able to make a real dent in the Knicks' kingdom.

title: With Big News at Home, Nets Flop on the Road
description: Despite all their assurances to the contrary, the Nets might have been more preoccupied with business than basketball Wednesday night.

title: Guilty Plea Is Expected From Inquiry Into Earnings
description: Lloyd Silverstein, a former senior vice president for Computer Associates, is expected to plead guilty today in United States District Court in Brooklyn to a charge that stems from the federal investigation into the company's accounting practices, people close to the investigation said.

title: Comptroller Rejects Contract To Find Solid Education's Cost
description: State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi on Wednesday rejected a no-bid consulting contract awarded to Standard & Poor's to determine the cost of a sound, basic education for New York's schoolchildren.

title: The Electronic Verification Is in the Mail
description: ENSURING the integrity of a Microsoft Word document can be tricky. Hackers and pranksters have made a hobby of exposing security flaws in the software, often altering what appear to be protected files. But a new service shores up security with an adage that is at once novel and old-fashioned: let the post office handle it.

title: Deutsche Bank Chief Calls Pay Law Unfair
description: The chief executive of Deutsche Bank, Josef Ackermann, facing breach of trust charges for his role in approving 57 million euros in payments to Mannesmann executives four years ago, said yesterday that German laws were unfairly punishing business people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEYER, MANFRED
description: MEYER--Manfred. Age 96. Opera lover, Schlaraffia member. Cousin of Michael, David, Gilbert. Service Friday, 10AM at the ''Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NORWALK, ELLIOTT
description: NORWALK--Elliott. Loving husband of the late Bernice and father of Jeffrey and Arthur. Doting grandfather of Lisa and great-grandfather of Mary. Devoted brother of Carol, Zita, and the late Selma and Lawrence. Service at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapel'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. 12:30pm Thursday.

title: OWNER SAYS TD WATERHOUSE IS NOT FOR SALE
description: The Toronto-Dominion Bank of Canada will not seek another buyer or merger partner for TD Waterhouse, its discount brokerage, its chief executive, W. Edmund Clark, said yesterday. ''I would say the door is closed'' to a merger for Waterhouse, Mr. Clark told investors at a conference sponsored by RBC Capital Markets. Toronto-Dominion, which is based in Toronto, said Sunday that it was unable to come to terms on a proposal to combine TD Waterhouse with E*Trade Financial Corporation. The bank had been seeking a buyer for a stake in TD Waterhouse as part of efforts to cut costs and free up capital.

title: From Paris Castoffs, A Recherch Retreat
description: ''Everything has been rescued in one form or another,'' said Catherine Lvy, referring to the toy trunk she uses as a bench in her apartment here, her mismatched dining room chairs, the white enamel counter in her kitchen. Almost everything in her 860-square-foot apartment, not far from the Bastille, is meant to amuse. Ms. Lvy is one half of Ts & Ts, a design partnership created in 1991 when she and Sigolne Prbois joined forces. Playful interpretations of everyday objects (their row of test tubes known as the April vase; their light garlands of tiny bulbs dressed in colorful bows or paper cubes) have made Ts & Ts a hot name on the French contemporary design scene.

title: The State of the Union, Spoken and Unspoken
description: To the Editor:

title: Conservative Republicans Push For Slowdown in U.S. Spending
description: A day after President Bush vowed to submit an austere budget and halve the deficit in five years, conservatives in his own party said on Wednesday that they were not satisfied and stepped up their campaign to force the White House and Republican leaders on Capitol Hill to do more to hold down the growth of government spending.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Sperm Donors To Lose Anonymity
description: The government said it planned to eliminate anonymity for sperm and egg donors. Under the plan, which still needs approval from Parliament, children born from donors after April 2005 will be able to trace their biological parents once they are 18. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Army Chief Quits
description: The head of the army, Lt. Gen. Gert Gudera, has asked for early retirement, the Defense Ministry said. He will be succeeded by Hans-Otto Budde, head of the army command staff. The ministry did not explain what led to the resignation, but the local press reported that General Gudera had clashed with Defense Minister Peter Struck over military spending cuts disclosed last week. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Fortress Home: Welcome Mat Bites
description: IT is not quite the valley of the shadow of death, but the home front looks menacing these days. Beneath all those Certain-Teed shingle roofs, behind all the Tyvek building wrap, a nation of households imagines itself under siege. And for every domestic fear, it seems, a new product is coming to the rescue.

title: An Unexpected Artifact
description: For more than a century, the Peabody Museum at Harvard University has owned a small paper label that says, in a spindly, old-fashioned script, ''Indian Necklace made of the claws of the Grizzly Bear -- Presented by Capt. Lewis and Clark.'' Whether the museum actually owned the necklace itself was uncertain until last month, when it turned up under the wrong name and among the wrong artifacts. The point of a museum is not only to preserve remarkable objects but also to find them at will. Yet somehow the fact that this necklace was lost for so long makes it seem all the more remarkable -- as if it had come fresh from the hands of Meriwether Lewis and William Clark.

title: No Urgency On Taking Up Terrorism Act
description: Despite President Bush's plea for an extension of the counterterrorism law known as the USA Patriot Act, leading Republicans and Democrats in Congress said Wednesday that were in no rush to take up the politically divisive issue in this election year.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Jan. 13 about plans by Steven T. Florio to step down as chief executive of Cond Nast Publications misstated the timing of his successor's arrival there. The successor, Charles H. Townsend, headed the women's magazine division of The New York Times Company but joined Cond Nast in 1994, before -- not after -- that division was sold to Gruner & Jahr USA Publishing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PEASE, JOAN M.
description: PEASE--Joan M. Died January 21, 2004.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: No Talking While Driving
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey signed into law on Tuesday a bill requiring that drivers talking on cellphones use a hands-free device. The law, which is to go into effect July 1, makes an exception for drivers who are reporting an emergency or who fear for their own safety. The maximum fine is $250, and summonses can be issued only when drivers are stopped for other offenses. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HERTZBERG, BENJAMIN
description: HERTZBERG -- Benjamin. The Citymeals - on - Wheels Board and staff express condolences to our dear friend, Lilian Hertzberg, on the loss of her husband, Benjamin, a man of many talents and a loving heart. We will miss his insights, wit and devotion to our city's frail elderly. Gael Greene, Founder & Chair Joseph M. Cohen, President Marcia Stein, Executive Director

title: FLIGHT ATTENDANTS' UNION REFUSES TO SIGN CONTRACT
description: The flight attendants' union for United Airlines, a unit of the UAL Corporation, has refused to sign a contract approved in April that cut pay by 9 percent because the company has announced plans to reduce retiree health benefits. The Association of Flight Attendants said it would fight the retiree cuts in UAL's bankruptcy proceeding or in other court actions. The Chicago-based airline promised specific benefits to employees who retired by July 1, and more than 2,500 accepted the offer, the union said. The contract is legally viable regardless of whether the union signs it, a United spokeswoman, Jean Medina, said. UAL said last week that it would seek an agreement with 35,000 retirees on the health care payments, and might ask the bankruptcy court to reduce its share of the expenses.

description: In percent

title: Let There Be L.E.D.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: GENERAL MOTORS TO BUY OUT SOUTH AFRICAN AUTOMAKER
description: To gain greater access to a growing market, General Motors has agreed to buy the 51 percent of Delta Motor Corporation, a South African automaker, that it does not already own. Delta sold about 40,000 vehicles last year. The purchase, which would restore G.M.'s control of a former unit, depends on government approval, G.M. said. The transaction price was not disclosed. South African auto sales rose 5.3 percent last year to a seven-year high of 368,454. Delta sells cars and trucks from G.M.'s Opel European unit and from its Japanese affiliate, Isuzu Motors. The company is based in Port Elizabeth.

title: Profits Rose At 3 Big Banks In 4th Quarter
description: J.P. Morgan Chase & Company, the Bank of New York Company and the PNC Financial Services Group all reported higher fourth-quarter earnings yesterday.

title: From Texas, Nets See New Landscape
description: The Nets team that took the court against the Spurs on Wednesday night for a rematch of the N.B.A. finals is much the same as the one that could open a new arena and a new era in Brooklyn.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I hate to follow the crowd, but the Democrats need to get behind somebody who could win.''

title: Music Industry Returns to Court, Altering Tactics On File Sharing
description: The music industry returned to the courthouse yesterday to sue 532 people it accuses of large-scale copyright infringement.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   STEINBERG, RICHARD
description: STEINBERG--Richard. 12/14/18--1/22/01. Still feel so safe and warm when I think of your smile. Miss you so much, Dad. Vick

title: EBay's 4th-Quarter Results Surpass Even Its Own Hopes
description: If there was one company that had a very merry Christmas, it was eBay. The company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter sales and profit were better than expected, largely because of the success of its efforts to position its site, a vast online market known originally for used knickknacks, as a source of holiday gifts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WELLENS, PORTIA NEE POMERANTZ
description: WELLENS -- Portia nee Pomerantz, widow of Philip L. Wellens, Corporate Counsel for the City of NY, died January 15, 2004 in Las Vegas, NV. Burial at Mt. Ararat in Lindenhurst, NY. Survived by daughter Laura Sommer, son-in-law Jack Sommer of NY and Las Vegas, and also the developer of The Aladdin Hotel in Las Vegas. Loving grandmother of Adam, Rachel Sommer Winston and husband Michael, Paul, Sigmund, Ethan, Rebecca and Drew. She will be missed. Her Loving Family, The Sommers

title: Gatti Getting Help in Title Fight From a Man He Beat
description: There are some fighters who can battle through cuts and blood and broken bones to win. And then there is Arturo Gatti.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Firefighters' Lawsuit Expands
description: A federal lawsuit accusing New York City of supplying firefighters with faulty radio equipment on Sept. 11, 2001, has been expanded to blame the manufacturer for the equipment failures. In the expanded suit, filed on Tuesday, lawyers for the families of a dozen New York firefighters who died at the World Trade Center charged that the manufacturer, Motorola, knew about the flaws when it sold the radios to the city in 1999, but deceived officials to win an additional contract. A spokeswoman for Motorola said yesterday that there was no basis for the lawsuit, which was filed in Federal District Court in December. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: To Control Property Taxes, Cut Spending, McGreevey Tells Mayors
description: A day after New Jersey released figures showing that property taxes, already the nation's highest, rose more than 6 percent last year, Gov. James E. McGreevey told the state's mayors on Wednesday that the solution was less spending at the local level, not more aid from the state.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about MovieBeam, a video-on-demand service offered by the Walt Disney Company, misstated the schedule for adding movies to the rotation of those available. Ten movies are replaced each week, not each month.

title: Design for Trade Center PATH Station Is to Be Unveiled
description: Two counterpoised glass wings -- bent as if to offer shelter, soaring as if to offer hope, as long as a city block and capable of movement on their own -- will crown the permanent World Trade Center PATH terminal designed by Santiago Calatrava.

title: Democrats Vow to Battle President on Social Issues
description: GOFFSTOWN, N.H., Jan. 22 - In their final debate before the New Hampshire primary, the Democratic presidential candidates promised Thursday that they could withstand attacks from President Bush on tax cuts and social values, as they sought to quell concerns among Democrats about the party's hopes of winning back the White House this fall.

title: Mars Rover Stops Sending Intelligible Data Back to Earth
description: The Mars Spirit rover has stopped sending intelligible data back to Earth in the past 24 hours, mission officials said today. The project manager, Peter C. Theisinger, described the problem as "a very serious anomaly on the vehicle."

title: 4 Arab Nations Agree to Reduce Debt Owed by Iraq
description: Former Secretary of State James A. Baker III has secured pledges from four Persian Gulf nations to reduce their holdings of Iraq's debt, a senior State Department official said Wednesday.

title: Technology Briefing

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FORD, ANN POSTMA
description: FORD--Ann Postma, 81, died peacefully at home on January 19th, 2004, holding hands with her beloved husband of 55 years, Frank W. Ford, Jr.; and her devoted daughter JoAnn Ford of Westport, CT. Ann dedicated her energy and good judgment to a number of charitable and educational groups. She was President of the Parents Organization at Trinity School and devoted much time and effort to the Civil Division of the Legal Aid Society, chairing the 1971 Legal Aid Auction. Ann's journey through Russia as a U.S. Youth Delegate to Jr U.N. meetings in London and Moscow in 1945-46 ended with severe mastoid infections in both ears. The Russians cured Ann with their limited supply of the new miracle drug Penicillin. This experience rightly convinced Ann that the American and Russian peoples are indeed similar and should indeed live peacefully together. Ann's tireless compassion for others, her steadfast devotion to efforts to achieve peace among all nations, and her loving care of family and friends will be sorely missed. Services Friday, January 23, 1:30 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Reception immediately following at the University Club, 5th Ave and 54 St. Donations in Ann's memory may be made to New Fairfield Animal Welfare Society, PO Box 8232, New Fairfield, CT 06812.

A truck carrying the beer sank as it drove over the Irtysh River in the Omsk region. The driver escaped. Divers from the Ministry of Emergency Situations and workmen armed with saws struggled to free the bottles and kegs in temperatures of minus-16 degrees Fahrenheit. A modified T-72 tank was brought in, and the beer was rescued. The truck was left in the river. Itar-Tass reported that the brewery said the beer could still be sold, since it had been kept cold. Mr. Koulen, who did not have a previous arrest record, was charged with second-degree murder. He told the grand jury yesterday that Mr. Wilson had demanded money and threatened him. title: ROGERS CORP. IS MOVING SOME WORK TO CHINA

title: Bush's Health Proposals
description: President Bush offered a skimpy menu of warmed-over health care proposals in his State of the Union address this week, evidently hoping to convince voters that he is doing something about the millions of Americans who have joined the ranks of the uninsured during his administration. Even if some of his ideas were adopted, they would be unlikely to have much impact on expanding health coverage for the uninsured or on slowing the rise in medical costs. But much of what he said seemed aimed less at passing real reform than at courting swing voters. The president, after all, already has a health care measure to campaign on: the Medicare prescription drug program. And he is calling for his huge tax cuts for the wealthy to be made permanent, a step that would leave little money for costly new health care measures in the years ahead.

title: ALCOA SAYS IT WILL CUT $1.2 BILLION IN COSTS BY 2006
description: Alcoa said yesterday that it planned to cut $1.2 billion in costs by 2006. The plan will bring total savings to $3.3 billion since 1998, and will not involve job cuts, Alcoa said. The company, based in Pittsburgh, plans to improve purchasing practices and manufacturing productivity and reduce administrative costs. The latest plan calls for reductions of about $400 million a year, with most coming through productivity, the chief financial officer, Richard B. Kelson, said. The company also said it would begin more closely linking executive compensation to financial goals and return on capital each year.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Euro Counterfeits On The Rise
description: There was a sharp rise in the number of known counterfeits of euro coins in the European Union last year, the currency's second year in existence, the European Commission said. The number of fake 50 cent, 1 euro and 2 euro coins detected by national central banks rose to 26,191, up from just 2,339 in their first year in circulation. But the total number of counterfeit euro coins found in circulation was still much lower than the number of counterfeit coins of the 12 national currencies that were replaced by the euro in January 2002. Levy of Federal District Court here. The challenge was brought by the New York State Restaurant Association and 44 individual restaurants, which charged that providing public information about inspections, as well as the department's new guidelines for citing and classifying violations, were illegal and unfair. The court said the city had a legitimate public health purpose. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Parks Dept. Criticized
description: An audit by the city comptroller accuses the Parks and Recreation Department of failing to ensure that its concessionaires complete required improvements to their businesses. The audit, presented to the Parks Department in June but released yesterday, found that capital improvements worth $10 million were not completed at 37 of the 58 concessionaires visited by investigators. Megan Sheekey, a spokeswoman for the Parks Department, called the audit wildly inaccurate and said the businesses met or exceeded the improvements required by their contracts. The department supervises 600 concessions, including ice rinks, golf courses, restaurants, stables and marinas, in city parks. Joseph Berger (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa

Mr. Kamuhanda, 51, handed out guns, grenades and machetes, and personally led a Hutu militia attack on ethnic Tutsi who took refuge in a church during a frenzy of violence in 1994, witnesses told the United Nations tribunal. (Reuters)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Conviction In Rape/Murder
description: A State Supreme Court jury found an East Harlem man, William Hernandez, 23, guilty yesterday of raping a 15-year-old girl and throwing her from the roof of a 14-story apartment building. He is scheduled to be sentenced by Justice Bonnie G. Wittner on Feb. 17 and faces a maximum of 25 years to life in prison, a spokeswoman for the district attorney's office said. Mr. Hernandez was convicted of two counts of second-degree murder, and of first- and third-degree rape. Mr. Hernandez was arrested in September 2002, just days after the murder of the teenager, Sheinna Morales, at the George Washington Houses on East 97th Street. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: In a Game of Survival, Safin Outlasts Martin
description: For long stretches of this cool and clear summer afternoon, it seemed quite plausible that James Blake's opponent in the fourth round of the Australian Open was going to be his 33-year-old fellow American, Todd Martin, instead of the younger, quicker and much more volatile Marat Safin.

title: Crowded Skies Are Here Again
description: Here's a bit of welcome bad news: airport congestion is making headlines again. Delays at O'Hare airport in Chicago have become so serious that the Federal Aviation Administration has pressed United and American to reduce by 5 percent the number of flights they schedule at peak hours.

title: Soul-Searching in Prime Time, BBC Responds to Its Detractors
description: On Wednesday night, the BBC's ''Panorama'' program broadcast an investigation into the events leading to the death of David Kelly, a government weapons expert who killed himself last July after he was revealed as the source of a BBC report critical of the government's justification for the Iraq war.

title: COMPETING BID FOR MOORE MEDICAL PUSHES STOCK UP 25%
description: Shares of Moore Medical, a maker of a technology used to distribute medical products over the Internet, surged 25 percent yesterday after a closely held investment firm topped the McKesson Corporation's bid to buy the company. The investment firm, SJ Strategic Investments, offered $15 a share, topping a bid of $12 from McKesson, according to a regulatory filing. SJ Strategic also said it bought 300,000 shares of Moore Medical on Tuesday at an average price of $11.99, making it the company's second-largest holder, with 312,400 shares. Moore Medical's board will review the offer, a spokeswoman said. Shares of Moore Medical rose $2.95, to $14.83.

title: Milestone for a 17-Year-Old MetroStar
description: Glenn Myernick, the coach of the United States Olympic team, yesterday named his 22-man roster for qualifying matches, a list that included MetroStars midfielder Eddie Gaven.

title: Along Public Trail, a Church Recounts Its History
description: ALCOVA, Wyo.  Tens of thousands of people come here each year to a granite-walled nook in the hills just off the old pioneer trail to hear the tale of the lost Martin Handcart Company of 1856 and how a party of poor Mormon converts faced down death in a howling blizzard.

title: U.S. and Saudis Act to Freeze Charity's Assets
description: The Bush administration said Thursday that it had teamed up with Saudi Arabia to freeze the assets of four branches of a major Islamic charitable foundation that they accused of providing financial support to terrorist groups.

But even after his victory in Iowa and his lead in the New Hampshire polls, Mr. Kerry was still not quite the main attraction Thursdaynight, at least not at the start of the Democratic debate.

description: AT the western end of the marshy Big Bend coast of Florida is Apalachicola with 3,000 people, a handful of stores and a reputation for oysters. Far from the crowds of South Florida and set apart from the beach towns farther west, this genteel community of oystermen, shrimpers and 19th-century architecture is a Florida that few visitors see. description: When a satellite rocket exploded in late August on its launching pad at a military-controlled base at Alcntara, on the eastern edge of the Amazon, 21 of Brazil's top scientists and technicians were instantly incinerated.

description: The former chief accounting officer of Enron was indicted yesterday on six felony charges that accuse him of participating in a multiyear effort to disguise the company's collapsing financial performance.

description: IF I hear one more ode to the old Brooklyn Dodgers or to Ebbets Field or to Pee Wee and Jackie, I'll scream. I'm screaming now, but it's hard to hear because of the roar of misplaced celebration.

title: Residential Real Estate; One Old House Is Flash Point for Enclave in Queens
description: It took no more than hearsay to draw more than 60 neighbors and civic leaders to a stately 100-year-old Queen Anne colonial house in Douglaston Hill, Queens, on a bitterly cold afternoon last week to protest its rumored sale and possible demolition.

title: Where Your Food Comes From
description: There are plenty of things wrong with the omnibus appropriations bill passed by the Senate yesterday afternoon. It was stuffed with pork. It had been doctored behind the scenes. It made a mockery of Congressional debate. And, almost as a matter of course, it represented the victory of powerful industry interests with political clout in the Bush administration. Among those interests were food processors and grocery chains, which succeeded in delaying a country-of-origin labeling plan authorized by the 2002 farm bill. That is a significant defeat for farmers and consumers alike.

title: Sharon Is Defiant in Face of Pressure Over Bribery Inquiry
description: Two Israeli cabinet ministers said Thursday that Prime Minister Ariel Sharon would have to resign if a bribery investigation eventually lead to his indictment.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Flu Still Widespread In Five States
description: Though influenza continued to decline around the nation last week, it was still widespread in five states -- New York, Delaware, Minnesota, Pennsylvania and Vermont -- the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said. At the peak widespread influenza was reported by 45 states, the centers said. Lawrence K. Altman (NYT)

title: 2 G.I.'s Killed in Mortar Attack on Base
description: Two American soldiers were killed and one was wounded Wednesday in a mortar attack on a base north of this city, the American military said.

title: Braving The Family Ski Vacation
description: COME the dead of winter, tens of thousands of parents nationwide embark upon the Great Family Ski Vacation. This is monumental considering the gear alone: skis, boots, poles, helmets, gloves, parkas, ski pants, neck gaiters -- never mind diapers and an Xbox. There are also the logistics of transportation (fly or drive? fly and drive?) and the organizational challenges of lift tickets, lodging and lessons. Planning a family ski trip can be as daunting as laying the groundwork for a Himalayan expedition.

title: Bush to Seek More Money To Fight Terrorism at Home
description: President Bush said today that he would ask Congress for another major increase in financing for domestic security, and, in a clear indication of the strategy his aides say he plans to pursue in his re-election campaign, he urged Americans against taking false comfort in the absence of terrorist attacks on American soil for more than two years.
