title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 5 about Interpol's decision to put former President Charles G. Taylor of Liberia on its most-wanted list misidentified the issuing authority of an arrest warrant for Mr. Taylor, who has been indicted for atrocities committed during a 10-year war in neighboring Sierra Leone. As Interpol informed The Times last week, the warrant was issued by the United Nations-sponsored Special Court for Sierra Leone, not Sierra Leone itself. The article also misstated the response from Nigeria, where Mr. Taylor lives in exile. Nigeria has ignored the court's arrest warrant, not rejected an extradition request.

title: A Star of the Underground in Separate Constellations
description: If the art world had something like a No Artist Left Behind Act, Joe Zucker might be as famous as Chuck Close. He is not. At the moment Mr. Close's name adorns a big gold banner on the Metropolitan Museum of Art, heralding an exhibition of prints within. In contrast Mr. Zucker, who has a highly respected but relatively underground reputation, is the subject of twin gallery shows that could give his profile a welcome lift.

description: Several senior executives of Computer Associates conspired to obstruct a continuing federal investigation into the company's accounting practices, a former senior vice president said yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

It was Andrea Blanch, not her traveling companion, Gabby Tana, who said: ''I will always like four-star luxe living. It was challenging for me to rough it and not speak for periods of time, but the results made up for it. I left with such an amazing feeling that, although I complained about little things, like hearing other people go to the bathroom in the middle of the night, I returned refreshed. It was freeing. So what if it meant having to make my own bed?''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Profit Surges At Siemens
description: The electronics group Siemens said it earned 726 million euros ($923 million) in the first quarter, a rise of 39 percent from the period a year ago. Sales were down 3 percent, to 18.3 billion euros ($23.3 billion), but orders rose 2 percent, to 20.5 billion euros ($26 billion), Siemens said. The company, based in Munich, said sales of mobile phones helped operating profit at its mobile unit more than double. Petra Kappl (NYT)

He is survived by his wife, Marianne, daughter, Ally, son, Erik, brother, Richard Wahlberg, and sisters Janet Ferguson and Susan Wahlberg. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Airline Posts A Profit
description: The airline KLM Royal Dutch said that its cost-cutting program helped it post a profit of 8 million euros ($10 million) in its most recent quarter, reversing a loss of 66 million euros in the quarter a year earlier. Revenue in the period, which ended Dec. 31 and was the third quarter of KLM's fiscal year, fell 7 percent, to 1.46 billion euros. The carrier expects to break even in the current fiscal year. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

description: Most major league teams crave additional pitching and, sure enough, scouts from 19 teams -- including the Mets and the Yankees -- showed up Thursday to watch as the former Yankee Orlando Hernndez worked out at the University of Miami in an effort to show he could still compete.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Panel To Look Into Conflict-Of-Interest Claims
description: The National Institutes of Health director said he was forming a task force to review possible conflicts of interest among institute scientists who do consulting work in the private sector. The director, Dr. Elias A. Zerhouni, said the panel would report on appropriate types of collaborations and make recommendations for possible rules changes. Three members of Congress last week urged the General Accounting Office to look into the matter. John Files (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Chemical And Atomic Waste Cleanup
description: The Department of Energy pledged spending of $2.4 million this year to clean up chemical and atomic waste at 126 sites at Sandia National Laboratories in Albuquerque. Some of the contamination, which dates to 1945, has entered the underground aquifer that serves Albuquerque, although the state said the city's water was being drawn from untainted wells and was safe. Steve Barnes (NYT)

description: Already looking past New Hampshire, Senator John Kerry picked up an endorsement on Thursday from Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, one of seven states with primaries on Feb. 3.

title: Corrections

It was the New York office of Brown & Wood, not its Chicago office. (Brown & Wood later merged with another firm, Sidley & Austin; the combined firm is named as a defendant in the suit.)

title: Democracy at Risk
description: The disputed election of 2000 left a lasting scar on the nation's psyche. A recent Zogby poll found that even in red states, which voted for George W. Bush, 32 percent of the public believes that the election was stolen. In blue states, the fraction is 44 percent.

title: 2 MIDSIZE BANKS IN TALKS ON $6 BILLION DEAL
description: In the latest sign of consolidation in the banking industry, the Regions Financial Corporation of Birmingham, Ala., is in talks to buy the Union Planters Corporation of Memphis for about $6 billion in stock, people close to the discussions said last night. The deal, which could be announced as early as today, would create a bank with about $81 billion in assets and branches concentrated mostly in the Southeast and Midwest. While much smaller in scope, it would follow two other recent bank transactions: the combination of J.P. Morgan Chase and Bank One for $58 billion and the merger of Bank of America and FleetBoston Financial for about $48 billion.

title: The Sturm und Drang Over Chris Bangle
description: RICK SPARKS has taken to writing song lyrics to express how he feels about the newly redesigned BMW 6 Series, whose curvaceous but controversial look was overseen by the company's much maligned head of design, Chris Bangle. Set to the tune of the Beatles' ''Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band,'' Dr. Sparks riffs, ''We're the Sixers Lovely Coupes Club Band; we wish C. Bangle would just go.''

title: What's Doing in Udrogoth, Land of Sorcerers and Dave
description: On ''Dave the Barbarian,'' which starts tonight on the Disney Channel, cartoon lugs in cartoon Uggs thrash around against backgrounds that appear to be sponge-painted, like a suburban bathroom. It's ugly. To be sure, the show's writing is sharp, the vaudeville voices are decent and the themes timely (steroids, carbs, food allergies, quack psychologists). But its look is generic and uncontrolled; you almost wish it were a radio show.

World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Steady Rate Supports Currency
description: Brazil's currency strengthened from a two-week low against the dollar after the central bank unexpectedly kept its benchmark rate unchanged at 16.5 percent. The bank kept its benchmark lending rate at 16.5 percent, ending seven months of cuts, after inflation accelerated. The currency, the real, was up 0.2 percent to 2.8355 per dollar. In another boost to the currency, Brazil on Thursday posted its first annual trade surplus in 11 years. The central bank said the country had a $349 million surplus last month, bringing the total for the year to $4 billion.

title: Transcript of the Democratic Candidates Debate in New Hampshire
description: The following is the transcript of the Democratic candidates debate in New Hampshire sponsored by WMUR-TV, FOX, The Union Leader and ABC News, as recorded by ABC News.

title: IRAQIS PRESS U.S. FOR COMPROMISE TO GAIN SELF-RULE
description: The Bush administration is under growing pressure from Iraqi leaders to shift course and transfer power to an expanded version of its handpicked Iraqi Governing Council, which would then prepare for a direct election later this year, administration and Iraqi officials said Thursday.

title: Microsoft's Revenue for Quarter Gains as Profit Declines
description: Buoyed by the unexpected double-digit growth in PC sales and an increase in business-customer revenue, the Microsoft Corporation reported on Thursday that its fiscal second-quarter results substantially surpassed financial analysts' expectations as revenue exceeded $10 billion for the first time.

title: The Perils of Online Voting
description: Internet voting has been viewed as a possible cure for some of the ills that afflict the mechanics of American democracy. Recently, the technology has seemed to move ahead of any serious consideration of whether it is actually a good idea to allow home computer owners to choose a president in the same way they order bath towels online or send e-mail to their relatives. But now there are grave questions about whether even the technology makes sense.

title: PENNEY TO CLOSE TELEMARKETING CENTER AND CUT 475 JOBS
description: J.C. Penney plans to close a telemarketing center in Austin, Tex., cutting 475 jobs, and take over management of six warehouses to reduce costs. The moves will reduce fourth-quarter profit by about 4 cents a share, Penney said. The company, based in Plano, Tex., still expects net income to rise to 80 cents a share, including the costs, a spokesman said. Penney will have nine call centers after closing the Austin location in the second quarter. It operates seven warehouses itself in addition to the six that were managed by outside contractors. The changes, which may include additional job cuts resulting from centralized purchasing and distribution, are expected to save Penney about $100 million a year.

title: Namath Wants to Stop Drinking
description: Joe Namath, whose bizarre behavior during a sideline report in December raised eyebrows, admitted in an interview with ESPN to be broadcast Sunday that he is seeking professional help for an alcohol problem.

title: The Sweet And Lowdown On Sugar
description: To lose weight, people must eat less, be more active, or both. The first part of that prescription, of course, raises the question, ''Eat less of what?'' For the World Health Organization and most nutritionists, one obvious answer is sugars. But the United States and American food companies seem to have a different idea.

title: Banana Republic Picks Goodby, Silverstein
description: Banana Republic, the retail chain owned by Gap Inc. , has named Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco to handle strategic brand duties and creative duties for print and outdoor advertising, which had been handled internally since 1997. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

description: MOSKOWITZ--Jerry, January 21, 2004, of Kew Gardens, NY. Husband of Claire (nee Kriegsman) Moskowitz. Father of Richard (Linda) Moskowitz, Eileen Beth Moskowitz and Nancy (Lester) Eisenberg. Brother of Mollie Gropper. Grandfather of Michelle, Eric, Jessica, Larissa, Michael and Eric. Services Friday, 10:30am, Platt Memorial Chapels, Incorporated, 2001 Berlin Road, Cherry Hill, New Jersey. Interment Beth Israel Memorial Park.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Nuclear Inquiry To Be Quick
description: Pakistan said it intended to quickly conclude its inquiry into charges that its nuclear technology was shared with Iran and has vowed legal action against anyone involved. The information minister said the questioning of nine people -- including an assistant to Abdul Qadeer Khan, the scientist who led Pakistan's nuclear bomb program, two retired generals and three scientists -- will be completed within a week. Salman Masood (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Anatomist Unsure He Accepted Executed
description: The anatomist Gunther von Hagens, whose human corpse exhibition ''Body Worlds'' has evoked fascination and disgust, said he could not rule out having used bodies of executed Chinese prisoners for his displays. ''My orders have always been clear: no one who was sentenced to death, but I wouldn't put my hand in the fire for it and say we weren't perhaps given one or the other execution victim,'' Dr. von Hagens said in Frankfurt. He was responding to a report in the magazine Der Spiegel that said his company in China had procured corpses from prisons, including one for political prisoners. Among the bodies in the inventory, the magazine said, were at least two with bullet holes in the heads. Dr. von Hagens's exhibitions display bodies posed in activities like running, sitting or sleeping. The corpses are opened to show internal organs, muscles and bones. Since 1996, the show has attracted more than 13 million visitors around the world. Kirsten Grieshaber (NYT)

title: 36 Hours | Apalachicola, Fla.
description: WHILE millions flood Florida's theme parks and southern beaches in winter, a shrewd few head instead to the central Panhandle. Sure, the sun isn't quite as warming, but tupelo honey runs pure in national forests, rivers flow along moss-threaded cypress stands, and Apalachicola Bay -- one of the planet's richest -- lavishes diners with choice seafood. The ideal base camp is the town of Apalachicola, 75 miles southwest of Tallahassee. It has long been famous for its oysters and lately for its demeanor: a historic fisherman's haven with stylish inns and galleries but solid Old South roots. Known locally as Apalach, it was founded by 19th-century sponge divers and cotton and lumber barons. Their restored Georgian and Victorian manses and cottages idle along the bay, and their descendants work hard hauling shrimp, fish, crabs and oysters. Meanwhile, newcomers trickle in (the population is barely 3,000), opening fashionable boutiques, cafes and antiques stores in former cotton warehouses. Minutes from Apalach, the white sands of the barrier-island beaches are so smooth and quiet, locals guarantee that ''you can hear the fiddler crabs shuffle by.'' CATHERINE O'NEAL

description: A military tribunal convicted Theodore Dago Sery, a 28-year-old police officer, of the murder of a French journalist in Abidjan in October, and sentenced him to 17 years in prison. The verdict came a year after a peace accord, mediated by France and intended to end the country's civil war, unleashed violent protests against French citizens and businesses in Abidjan, the largest city. The journalist, Jean Hlne, 50, a longtime reporter for Radio France Internationale, was shot outside a police station. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBAUM, ALLEN S.
description: ROSENBAUM--Allen S. The employees of BMW of Manhattan wish to acknowledge the untimely passing of their friend and co-worker, Allen. We wish to offer our sincere condolences to his family and loved ones. We thank Allen for his professionalism, kindness, and inspiration. He will be truly missed. Please know that we will continue to press on in his memory. He will always be in our thoughts, hearts, and prayers. The Employees of BMW of Manhattan, Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DARRELL, MARY HAND
description: DARRELL--Mary Hand, 98, died on Tuesday, January 20, 2004. She was a daughter of the late Judge Learned Hand and Frances Hand, and the wife of the late Norris Darrell, a partner of Sullivan & Cromwell, and President of the American Law Institute. She was graduated from the Brearley School and Bryn Mawr College. A patron of the Metropolitan Opera since 1968, she served for many years on its National Council, Eastern Region. As Chairman from 1948 until 1961 of the Off-the-Record Luncheon Series, under the aegis of the Foreign Policy Association, she presided over much of its substantial growth in membership and financial solvency. She is survived by a sister, Constance Morris of Sharon, CT, a son, Jonathan Hand Churchill of New York City and two stepsons, Norris Darrell, Jr. of Cold Spring Harbor, NY, and Richard W. Darrell of Naples, FL.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: 3 Sentenced In Robbery/Rape
description: Three of the five homeless men who have admitted robbing, beating and raping a woman near Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in 2002 were sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court in Queens. Luis Carmona, 21, and Armando Juvenal, 21, were sentenced to 22 years in jail, and Carlos Rodriguez, 23, to 23 years. The three men pleaded guilty in December to sexually assaulting a 42-year-old woman in a homeless encampment near the park on Dec. 19, 2002. A fourth man, Victor Cruz, 23, was sentenced last week to 21 years in prison. The fifth defendant will be sentenced next month. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: Azerbaijan Represses Dissent, Rights Group Says
description: In its first three months in office, the new government of Azerbaijan has conducted a campaign of repression marked by arbitrary arrests, beatings, torture and the dismissal of dissenters from government jobs, according to a report released on Friday by the international rights group Human Rights Watch.

title: Cheney's Davos trip is just 2nd appearance overseas
description: WASHINGTON:  When Vice President Dick Cheney leaves Friday for the Davos economic conference in Switzerland, he will be undertaking only his second trip abroad since taking office.

title: Corrections

Taylor of Liberia on its most-wanted list misidentified the issuing authority of an arrest warrant for Mr. Taylor, who has been indicted for atrocities committed during a 10-year war in neighboring Sierra Leone. As Interpol informed The Times last week, the warrant was issued by the United Nations-sponsored Special Court for Sierra Leone, not Sierra Leone itself. The article also misstated the response from Nigeria, where Mr. Taylor lives in exile. Nigeria has ignored the court's arrest warrant, not rejected an extradition request.

title: FURNITURE BRANDS TO CLOSE 2 PLANTS AND CUT 395 JOBS
description: Furniture Brands International plans to close two furniture plants in North Carolina and cut as many as 395 jobs. The closings are scheduled for April, Furniture Brands said. One of the plants, in Marion, N.C., employs about 350 people and the other, in Morgantown, N.C., has about 45 workers. Some employees may be offered jobs at other plants. The plants have been operating at less than capacity even with business improving, the company said. Work at the plants, which will be sold, will be transferred to other sites.

The idea is that Col. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Yukos Executive Arrested
description: The Russian government arrested the chairman of a Yukos refinery, putting more pressure on the oil company. A regional court ordered that the executive, Rafail Zainullin, be detained for two months on charges that the plant evaded taxes in 1999, when he served as general director of the Kuibyshev plant in the Volga Samara region. Mr. Zainullin retired as general director of the refinery in 2002, but remained chairman. The arrest expands Russian prosecutors' investigations into the former Yukos chief executive Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, who remains in jail awaiting trial, and other leading Yukos shareholders. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

The plan will be used to manage a northwest part of the government's 23.5 million-acre National Petroleum Reserve in Alaska, which geologists believe may contain 6 billion to 13 billion barrels of oil. Environmentalists said the plan threatened the health of Arctic tundra, ponds and lakes that are home to wildlife and migratory birds.   (AP)

The baseball team went west after it was denied a new field at the corner of Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues. If he gets his way, that's exactly where the developer Bruce Ratner will move the Nets, into a gleaming new arena designed by Frank Gehry. Brooklyn should be allowed a moment of exuberance. And then it will need to come back to earth.

title: LEATHER RETAILER TO CLOSE 100 STORES AND CUT 1,000 JOBS
description: Wilsons the Leather Experts, a retailer of leather clothing and accessories, plans to close as many as 100 stores and eliminate about 1,000 jobs to reduce expenses as it renegotiates agreements with lenders. The cuts include about 950 jobs at stores and 70 others at the company's headquarters and distribution centers, Wilsons said. The closings are in addition to 28 stores that are to be closed this month and the termination of as many as 50 leases already planned for the chain. Wilsons, based in Brooklyn Park, Minn., will have pretax costs of as much as $50 million to liquidate inventory and end leases.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: CAMBODIA: LABOR LEADER KILLED Chea Vichea, a prominent labor leader affiliated with the country's main opposition party, was shot to death on a street in Phnom Penh. Three other members of the Sam Rainsy Party have been killed in recent weeks. Mr. Vichea, 39, helped organize unions at garment factories and was closely associated with the Rainsy Party. The party is locked in a struggle with the government of Prime Minister Hun Sen, whose Cambodian People's Party won last year's election but failed to get the two-thirds majority required to govern alone. The runner-up Rainsy Party has refused to join a coalition government and has called for the prime minister step down. (AP)

title: MONDAVI SAYS IT IS SELLING ITS INTEREST IN A WINE BRAND
description: The Robert Mondavi Corporation, the maker of Woodbridge and Opus One wines, is selling its interest in the Caliterra brand produced in Chile to a partner, Via Errazuriz, as part of a plan to focus on more profitable lines. A loss on the sale is being recorded in the second quarter, ended Dec. 31, reducing profit by $3.9 million, or 23 cents a share, Mondavi said. Net income in the quarter fell to 52 cents to 57 cents a share, from 60 cents a year earlier. Final results will be reported next Thursday. The company will maintain 50 percent stakes in the higher-price Sea and Arboleda lines, part of a venture with Via Errazuriz. Shares of Mondavi fell $1.39, or 3.6 percent, to $36.88.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: EURO COUNTERFEITS ON THE RISE There was a sharp rise in the number of known counterfeits of euro coins in the European Union last year, the currency's second year in existence, the European Commission said. The number of fake 50 cent, 1 euro and 2 euro coins detected by national central banks rose to 26,191, up from just 2,339 in their first year in circulation. But the total number of counterfeit euro coins found in circulation was still much lower than the number of counterfeit coins of the 12 national currencies that were replaced by the euro in January 2002. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Cow Tracking Expands
description: The investigation tracking cattle from the Canadian herd of the first cow in the United States with mad cow disease has expanded outside Washington State. Agriculture officials said that a cow from the herd had been found at a dairy in Boardman, near the Washington border. The officials said the cow had not been imported with the infected cow but had been part of a later shipment. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

description: India's long-term foreign-currency rating was raised one level by Moody's Investors Service to investment grade for the first time in almost six years, a move that may reduce overseas borrowing costs for Indian companies. Moody's said it raised the rating to Baa3 from Ba1 with a stable outlook because of increasing foreign exchange reserves, accelerating economic growth and higher overseas investment. The rating upgrade may also help attract more overseas investment, especially from pension funds and other professional investors.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Porsche's Profit Rises
description: The sports car maker Porsche said it earned 118 million euros ($148 million) in the first quarter, an increase of 16 percent from the year earlier. Strong sales of its Cayenne sport utility vehicle fueled a 28 percent gain in sales. But the increase fell short of market expectations as sales of Porsche's 911 and Boxster sports cars declined. Porsche said it sold 16,890 Cayennes in its first full year of the product. Sales of the 911 fell 26 percent, to 10,250, while those of the Boxster fell by 44 percent, to 5,250 cars. Porsche, which is based in Stuttgart, Germany, said revenue in the period, which ended Jan. 31, rose to 2.82 billion euros ($3.5 billion). Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: CABLE AND WIRELESS WINS APPROVAL TO SELL U.S. UNIT
description: Cable and Wireless won a bankruptcy judge's permission to sell its United States division for $155 million in cash to the Savvis Communications Corporation. The bid by Savvis in a bankruptcy auction topped offers by six other companies, including the private equity firm Gores Technology Group of Los Angeles and XO Communications, a telecommunications company controlled by Carl C. Icahn. Judge Charles Case of United States Bankruptcy Court in Phoenix approved the sale yesterday. Savvis, a St. Louis-based provider of networking services, will also assume $12.4 million in debt.

description: In May, a New York cabdriver from Afghanistan was arrested after asking an undercover agent questions about buying enough explosives to blow up a mountain. Prosecutors labeled him dangerous and suggested he might be a terrorist.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON GETS SUBPOENA ON SCHIZOPHRENIA DRUG
description: Johnson & Johnson said that it had received a federal subpoena for documents related to Risperdal, the most-prescribed schizophrenia medication in the nation. The subpoena, which was sent to the company's Janssen Pharmaceutica division, came from investigators for the Office of Personnel Management, Johnson & Johnson said. Risperdal has been at the center of lawsuits filed by Johnson & Johnson, which is trying to block other companies from making generic copies of the medicine. A patent on the drug is set to expire in 2007. A spokesman for Janssen, Doug Arbesfeld, said that the company was cooperating with the inquiry. Rusty Asher, a spokesman for the Office of Personnel Management, which oversees health benefits for federal employees, said the agency did not comment on active investigations. Johnson & Johnson is based in New Brunswick, N.J.

description: VIENNA  Before moving abroad, Alecia Myers and her husband Ken drove to Chicago to attend a daylong cross-cultural training seminar designed to teach them how to understand and relate to people from foreign cultures. There they learned about high context and low context cultures, sub-cultures, and co-cultures, the seven dimensions of culture, and increasing intercultural business competency. One year later, happily settled in Austria, Alecia looks back favorably on her cross-cultural training and tries to remember what she learned.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SULCER, FREDERICK ''SANDY.''
description: SULCER--Frederick ''Sandy.'' DDB Worldwide and its staff deeply mourn the death of advertising great Sandy Sulcer. The former copywriter, who penned ''Put a Tiger in Your Tank,'' achieved tremendous success during his tenure in the advertising industry, rising through the ranks to become Chairman of Needham Harper & Steers International and later Vice Chairman of DDB Needham Worldwide before retiring in 1994. His enthusiasm for the industry never waned though, and he continued to teach and write about the subject until his death. We are grateful to have been touched by his extraordinary generosity and commitment, and express our deepest sympathy to the Sulcer family. To remember and celebrate Sandy's life, a memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home on Madison Avenue at 81st Street in New York on Friday, January 30, at 3:30 p.m.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Economic Growth
description: The British economy grew at an annual rate of 2.3 percent in the fourth quarter, gaining on the 2.1 percent growth in the previous quarter, and raising concern that the Bank of England will have to raise interest rates. The figure, provided by the National Statistics Office, showed growth at the fastest rate in nearly four years. ''It obviously increases the chances of a February rate rise to a virtual certainty,'' said Dan McLaughlin, a Bank of Ireland economist.

description: President Bush told the nation's mayors on Friday that he would send them more money to protect their cities from potential terrorist attacks. But his remarks were greeted with skepticism from some officials who said that Mr. Bush had not followed through on earlier pledges.

description: The Bottom Line, the Greenwich Village music club that was a launching pad for the likes of Bruce Springsteen and other rock stars, finally shut its doors on Thursday after almost three decades as a music industry landmark, its lawyer said yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: 4,500 Call Hospital Over H.I.V. Doctor
description: A children's hospital in Montreal was flooded with 4,500 phone calls from parents in response to a warning that a physician there had performed thousands of surgeries while infected with the AIDS virus. Officials at Ste.-Justine Hospital said the risk of contracting the virus from the doctor was low but asked 2,614 former patients who were operated on from 1990 to 2003 to take an H.I.V. test. The patients were being contacted by registered letters, and the hospital set up a hot line to handle the calls. The doctor, Maria Di Lorenzo, who died in August at age 48, was cleared in 1991 by an expert committee of other doctors at the hospital to continue to perform surgery. The hospital administration learned of her condition just two weeks ago from another staff member. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: A French Mood For a Festival In Washington
description: Diplomacy may work best when nobody says anything. The Americans and the French, at any rate, are getting along admirably in the midst of a three-week, seven-program Festival of France here at the Kennedy Center. The National Symphony under Leonard Slatkin is doing the playing; the French are providing the music. Aside from Ravel's ''L'Enfant et les Sortilges'' last week and Rene Fleming singing his ''Shhrazade'' next weekend, words are few.

title: Painting Ordered Back to Greece

title: National Briefing: Northwest
description: WASHINGTON: PROTECTION FOR SALMON A federal judge has instituted buffer zones around salmon-bearing streams where 38 pesticides cannot be used. The ruling by Judge John Coughenour of Federal District Court in Seattle is meant as an interim measure until the Environmental Protection Agency institutes permanent guidelines for pesticide use near salmon streams. Judge Coughenour also required that warning labels be displayed near some pesticides sold at home or garden stores in urban areas in Washington, Oregon and California, where runoff can damage water quality. The ruling was part of a suit filed by fishing and environmental groups. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

The endorsement, which praised Mr. Lieberman as a fiscal conservative willing to cross party lines for the national interest, came on a day that the campaign released a commercial in New Hampshire emphasizing his support for removing Saddam Hussein from power, a position that distinguishes him from his rivals. Speaking to reporters in Portsmouth, N.H., Mr. Lieberman unveiled a new line, saying Saddam Hussein himself ''was a weapon of mass destruction.'' Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Missile Test
description: India successfully tested a medium-range ballistic missile capable of carrying a nuclear warhead, defense officials said. Officials said the test of the Prithvi missile was part of a series of tests and did not reflect a change in the diplomatic situation in South Asia. Pakistan and India agreed this month to re-start peace talks. P. J. Anthony (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Tycoon Takes A New Name
description: First Britain granted Boris A. Berezovsky, the self-exiled Russian tycoon, political asylum. Now it has granted him a new identity. Britain's home secretary announced in a statement that Mr. Berezovksy received travel documents under the assumed name Platon Yelenin, the BBC and other news agencies reported. Mr. Berezovsky, who is still wanted on fraud charges in Russia, traveled to neighboring Georgia last month under that name, prompting a storm of protests from Russian law enforcement officials. How the name was chosen was not immediately known. Platon is also the first name of a Berezovsky-like character in the 2002 movie ''Oligarch,'' loosely based on Mr. Berezovsky. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a federal appeals court's upholding of a New York State law that bans masks at public demonstrations misidentified the organization that handled the Ku Klux Klan's challenge. It was the New York Civil Liberties Union, not the American Civil Liberties Union. The article also misstated a word in a quotation from Judge Jose A. Cabranes. He wrote, ''The mask that the American Knights seek to wear in public demonstrations does not convey a message independently of the robe and hood'' -- not ''masks.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KEESHAN, ROBERT J.
description: KEESHAN--Robert J. It is with deep regret and sorrow that the Board of Trustees, Administration, Medical Board, Medical Staff, Volunteers and Employees of Good Samaritan Hospital Medical Center mark the passing of Robert J. Keeshan, Trustee Emeritus. Mr. Keeshan, a Babylon resident, was an esteemed and honored member of the Board of Trustees from 1969 to 1978. He aided the hospital immeasurably as an active member of the Executive, Community Relations and Development Committees. Known to television audiences everywhere as ''Captain Kangaroo'', Keeshan as president of the Board, brought his expertise and talent to assist his community hospital in its growth and development. With his exceptional speaking skills, he was the highlight of the first annual Samaritan dinner in 1961, and was chair of the Good Samaritan Ball in 1968 and 1969. His unique appeal and enthusiasm made these events highly successful endeavors. The winner of numerous awards for his continuing excellence from the television industry, he lent his time, talent and expertise to Good Samaritan Hospital Medical Center. He will be remembered for his dignified, caring and friendly manner. To his family, Good Samaritan Hospital sends its heartfelt condolences.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: CYPRUS: TURKEY PUSHES NEW TALKS Turkey's top civilian and military leaders called for new negotiations to reunite the divided island of Cyprus loosely based on a plan proposed by the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan. Talks on the plan collapsed early last year. Cyprus is to join the European Union in May, and European leaders have said that failure to reunify the island before then could jeopardize Turkey's own chances of European Union membership. The Turkish prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, is to meet with Mr. Annan in Davos, Switzerland, today. (AP)

description: Scientists have found more evidence for a possible link between non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and long-term use of dark hair dye. A study of more than 1,300 women in Connecticut shows that those who began coloring their hair before 1980 increased their chance of developing the disease by 40 percent.

title: National Briefing: South
description: GEORGIA: SECT LEADER CONVICTED The leader of a quasi-religious sect was convicted of molesting boys and girls at the group's compound. The sect's leader, Malachi York, 58, could face up to 80 years in prison. During the trial, 14 children from the sect, the United Nuwaubian Nation of Moors, said Mr. York molested them from 1998 until 2002, when federal agents raided the group's compound in Eatonton, 65 miles southeast of Atlanta. Mr. York, whose moved his group to Georgia from Brooklyn in 1993, did not take the stand. His lawyer, Adrian Patrick, argued that the youngsters had concocted their stories in a conspiracy by Mr. York's son, Jacob, who was angry that his father would not finance his music career. (AP)

title: UNION PLANTERS AND REGIONS FINANCIAL TO MERGE
description: The Regions Financial Corporation, one of the biggest banks in Alabama, agreed to combine with the Union Planters Corporation in a $5.9 billion transaction that would create a bank with 1,400 branches in the South and Midwest. Each share of Union Planters would be exchanged for one share in the new company, and each share of Regions would be converted into 1.2346 shares, the banks said. Shares of both companies rose after the announcement. Profit growth at each of the banks lagged the industry average last year. Regions, based in Birmingham, and Union Planters, based in Memphis, will have an equal number of board seats.

title: ARIBA WILL BUY FREEMARKETS FOR $493 MILLION
description: Ariba agreed to buy FreeMarkets for $493 million in cash and stock, uniting two makers of software for Internet commerce. Ariba, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., sells spending-management programs and has had annual losses since 1997. FreeMarkets makes Web auction software, and this month bought the auto-parts auction business of Covisint, a venture among General Motors, Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler. Investors in FreeMarkets, which is based in Pittsburgh, will receive 2.25 shares of Ariba and $2 a share in cash, giving them 28 percent of the combined business, the companies said. The total offer of $10.33 a share is a 23 percent premium for FreeMarkets holders, based on Thursday's closing stock prices.

title: ST. PAUL ADDS TO RESERVES TO PAY MALPRACTICE CLAIMS
description: The St. Paul Companies, the commercial insurer merging with the Travelers Property Casualty Corporation, said yesterday that it added to reserves to pay medical malpractice claims, erasing as much as 84 percent of fourth-quarter profit. The additional reserves cost $228 million, or 98 cents a share, reducing fourth-quarter net income to 19 cents to 21 cents a share, the company said. St. Paul, which stopped selling new medical malpractice policies in 2001, told investors in the last year that it might need to increase reserves to pay claims on old policies as lawsuits against doctors and medical costs increased. Before taxes, the reserve increase cost $350 million. The company is based in St. Paul.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: WEDDING FIRE KILLS 45 A fire at a makeshift palm-frond wedding hall in the southern town of Srirangam killed 45 people, including the groom, and injured dozens more as the couple were about to take their vows, the police said. The bride and 52 guests were injured, four in a critical condition, the police said. An electrical short circuit probably caused the fire, they said, which broke out in the makeshift enclosure set up on the terrace of a single-story house. (Reuters)

He was 76.

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY'S BID FOR OAKWOOD IS APPROVED
description: Berkshire Hathaway, controlled by Warren E. Buffett, won the approval of a bankruptcy judge for its $373 million offer to purchase the mobile home builder Oakwood Homes and combine it with Clayton Homes. Judge Peter Walsh of United States Bankruptcy Court approved Mr. Buffett's bid at a hearing yesterday in Wilmington, Del., after no other offers were made for Oakwood, the company's lawyers said. Mr. Buffett plans to create the biggest maker of mobile homes by merging Oakwood, which is based in Greensboro, N.C., with Clayton Homes.

title: Mars Rover Communicates Again, but From Sickbed
description: The Mars rover Spirit called home on Friday morning, re-establishing contact after two days of garbled transmissions. But mission controllers said that they were still confused by its brief messages and inconsistent behavior and that it would be some time before the problem could be diagnosed and repaired, if ever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DURANDO, PATRICIA A.

Caring sister of William Sullivan, sister-in-law and aunt to many. Nurturing and adoring friend and caretaker of all, including her cherished pets. Her vibrant nature and warm smile will always be remembered and terribly missed. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, Inc., Ascan Ave, corner Metropolitan Ave, Forest Hills, NY, Saturday, January 24, 7-9 PM, & Sunday, January 25, 2-5 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Mercy Church, Kessel St. & 70th Ave., Forest Hills, Monday, January 26, 2004, at 10:30 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to Asthma & Allergy Foundation of America, 1233 20th St, NW, Suite 402, Washington, DC 20036, would be appreciated.

description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation, the hospital chain being investigated for overcharging the Medicare program, said two doctors had received subpoenas about their financial arrangements with three of the company's Texas hospitals. The Department of Health and Human Services, which oversees Medicare, is seeking information on the ties between the physicians and Tenet hospitals in El Paso, the company said. Tenet, based in Santa Barbara, Calif., is trying to resolve government investigations after disclosing in November 2002 that it raised prices to generate higher payments from Medicare, the health-insurance program for the elderly and disabled. Harry Anderson, a spokesman for Tenet, said the company would cooperate with the inquiry.

Over the past year or so, in image after image, we have seen ourselves shown gazing at the wonders that will someday be built in Lower Manhattan. On Thursday, we got yet another glimpse of the future, when Santiago Calatrava's design for the new transportation hub at ground zero was revealed. If anything, the New Yorkers pictured in the computer renderings of this design appear too complacent. They should be pictured with looks of surprise and gratitude on their faces.

It's a film by Morgan Spurlock about his decision to eat nothing but McDonald's food for one month to see what effect it would have on his body.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Economic Slowdown
description: Japan's all-industry index fell a larger-than-expected 1.3 percent in November from October, as warmer weather hurt sales of winter goods and construction and public spending declined. The index, a proxy for gross domestic product, last fell in July. However, economists expect the index to surge to a seven-year high in the quarter ended in December, a sign that recovery in Japan remains intact. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THATCHER, MARGUERITE FUNSTON
description: THATCHER -- Marguerite Funston, of Greenwich, CT died on January 2, 2004, in an automobile accident. Peggy is survived by her beloved husband, John M.P. Thatcher III, four children, Peggy, Katherine, John M.P. IV, and Christina, a sister Gail Wasson of Lebanon, NH, a brother G. Keith Funston Jr, of Sudbury, MA, four nieces and nephews and her aunt Mrs. Gordon Reed of Greenwich. Peggy, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. G. Keith Funston of Greenwich, was born in Alexandria, VA on March 26, 1942. Childhood was at Trinity College where her father was president. Her father became president of the New York Stock Exchange and she graduated from Greenwich Country Day School, Westover School and Smith College in 1964. After a career in the securities industry and at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, she became a docent in the Sarah Bush Program, a past member of the board of the Greenwich Historical Society, a member of the Greenwich Garden Club and a substitute teacher at Greenwich Country Day School. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church at 254 East Putnam Avenue in Greenwich on Friday, January 23, at 2:00pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Historical Society of Greenwich, The Association of Retarded Citizens, Greewich or Trinity College, Hartford, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEIDELL, ROBERT CHARLES
description: HEIDELL--Robert Charles. 79, of Vero Beach, FL, died January 20, 2004, at the VNA Hospice House of Vero Beach, after a prolonged illness. He was born on October 19, 1924, in Brooklyn, NY, and had retired to Vero Beach in 1998, after residing in Bronxville, NY. He graduated from Union College and Albany Law School. Prior to retirement he was the senior partner in the law firm of Heidell, Pittoni, Murphy and Bach, NYC, specializing in the defense of physicians and health care facilities. He was a Fellow of the American College of Trail Lawyers, admitted in 1975. He served on the Board of Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, NY, and was counsel to the Eastchester Volunteer Ambulance Corps, Eastchester, NY. He was a veteran of WWII, serving as a naval aviator trained in aircraft carrier landings, 1943 to 1946. He was a former member of the Bronxville Field Club and served as secretary of Siwanoy Country Club, Bronxville, NY. He also served on the Board of Governors of the Campfire Club of America, Chappaqua, NY. He was a member of the Community Church and Bent Pine Golf Club, Vero Beach, FL. Surviving are his wife of 33 years Valerie Meyer Summerlin, three step-children, John Summerlin of Westport, CT, Tina Summerlin of Brooklyn, NY, and Scott Summerlin of Newtown, CT, and six step-grandchildren. Memorial contributions may be made to VNA Hospice House of Indian River County, 1111 36th St, Vero Beach, FL 32960. A memorial service will be held at the Community Church on Thursday, February 5, 2004, at 2 pm. For information contact Indian River Cremation, Vero Beach.

title: The Tyranny of Copyright?
description: Last fall, a group of civic-minded students at Swarthmore College received a sobering lesson in the future of political protest. They had come into possession of some 15,000 e-mail messages and memos -- presumably leaked or stolen -- from Diebold Election Systems, the largest maker of electronic voting machines in the country. The memos featured Diebold employees' candid discussion of flaws in the company's software and warnings that the computer network was poorly protected from hackers. In light of the chaotic 2000 presidential election, the Swarthmore students decided that this information shouldn't be kept from the public. Like aspiring Daniel Ellsbergs with their would-be Pentagon Papers, they posted the files on the Internet, declaring the act a form of electronic whistle-blowing.

title: Aspiring Divers
description: To the Editor: The last two words -- ''freak out '' -- of ''Homework for Aspiring Divers'' (Practical Traveler, Jan. 11) could have been the focus of the article. The freak-out factor is what makes the difference between a disturbing experience and a deadly one. Things often go wrong. It's what happens when things go wrong that changes the course of events. Certain skills, like scuba diving, in order to be learned properly, must be learned slowly. Divers who have taken full certification courses (as opposed to quickie courses) and who have put in a reasonable amount of time practicing certain critical skills (like how to handle air emergencies) are less likely to freak out and more likely to survive.

title: The Reassuring Shock of the Early Buuel
description: ''ONCE upon a time'' (or so the first title card declares), a man stood at the sink, stropping his straight razor, as clouds sliced across the full moon. And because this movie, in spite of being pulled nonsensically backward and forward by those arbitrary title cards, exists only in the present tense, what followed remains one of the most notoriously shocking images in the history of cinema. Nobody who has seen it has forgotten it, and many who have never seen it are nonetheless aware of it. The man, with studied casualness, applies his razor to the eyeball of a woman seated in front of a window. By means of a sleight of hand accomplished by one kind of cutting -- the snipping and splicing of pieces of film to create the illusion of continuity -- we see, in close-up, the results of another, more brutal kind. The eyeball (which belongs to a calf smuggled into the frame while we were looking at the moon) is neatly dissected, its inner matter squeezed out in a gelatinous glob.

Sarah Pribek, a tall, athletic and seemingly nerveless detective with the Hennepin County Sheriff's Department, has been married for just two months to a Minneapolis police officer named Mike Shiloh when he vanishes while on his way to Quantico for F.B.I. training. Ignoring the probability that her sexy, enigmatic spouse has simply walked out on her, Sarah investigates his disappearance as she would any other missing-person case, following a trail that takes her back to his family roots in Utah and reveals a person she never knew.

title: America Unbound
description: George W. Bush had reason to be pleased as he peered down at Baghdad from the window of Air Force One in early June 2003. He had just completed a successful visit to Europe and the Middle East. The trip began in Warsaw, where he had the opportunity to personally thank Poland for being one of just two European countries to contribute troops to the Iraq War effort. He then traveled to Russia to celebrate the three hundredth birthday of St. Petersburg and to sign the papers formally ratifying a treaty committing Moscow and Washington to slash their nuclear arsenals. He flew on to Evian, a city in the French Alps, to attend a summit meeting of the heads of the world's major economies. He next stopped in Sharm el-Sheik, Egypt, for a meeting with moderate Arab leaders, before heading to Aqaba, Jordan, on the shore of the Red Sea to discuss the road map for peace with the Israeli and Palestinian prime ministers. He made his final stop in Doha, Qatar, where troops at U.S. Central Command greeted him with thunderous applause. Now Bush looked down on the city that American troops had seized only weeks before. As he pointed out landmarks below to his advisers, the pilot dipped Air Force One's wings in a gesture of triumph.

title: The Swinging Detective

This was news to me, though not to many other people, as I discovered after asking around. Sherlock Holmes and his companion, Dr. Watson, long ago joined various male duos (among them the Lone Ranger and Tonto, Batman and Robin and even Frodo and Sam) as the subject of smirks, winks and occasionally more earnest efforts at extracting the hidden meanings of pop icons. But Robb -- who offers his speculations on the sexual orientation of Holmes and other literary sleuths in a coda to a book that's mostly about historical figures -- doesn't want his observations taken for mere crude outing. He is not, he insists, engaged in ''a sly attempt to ensnare the great detective in the elastic web of gay revisionism.''

title: The Grandmothers
description: On either side of a little promontory loaded with cafes and restaurants was a frisky but decorous sea, nothing like the real ocean that roared and rumbled outside the gape of the enclosing bay and barrier rocks known by everyone - and it was even on the charts - as Baxter's Teeth. Who was Baxter? A good question, often asked, and answered by a framed sheet of skilfully antiqued paper on the wall of the restaurant at the end of the promontory, the one in the best, highest and most prestigious position. Baxter's, it was called, claiming that the inner room of thin brick and reed had been Bill Baxter's shack, built by his own hands. He had been a restless voyager, a seaman who had chanced on this paradise of a bay with its little tongue of rocky land. Earlier versions of the tale hinted at pacific and welcoming natives. Where did the Teeth come into it? Baxter remained an inveterate explorer of nearby shores and islands, and then, having entrusted himself to a little leaf of a boat built out of driftwood and expertise, he was wrecked one moony night on those seven black rocks, well within the sight of his little house where a storm lantern, as reliable as a lighthouse, welcomed in ships small enough to get into the bay, having negotiated the reef.

title: Professor Nagl's War
description: Maass's report has further darkened whatever dim hopes I once had for an expeditious end to the occupation of Iraq. Perhaps in some future monograph, Major Nagl will point out the difference between liberation and invasion. Liberators are greeted with ''flowers and sweets'' because they free a country from foreign occupation. Foreign armies that arrive to replace indigenous governments, no matter how repressive those governments may be, will always be perceived as invaders. title: Too Noisy Despite New Windows
description: Q. My partner and I live in a New Jersey co-op. In the spring of 1998 -- about a year after we moved in -- the building installed replacement windows. Several months later, we started to hear howling and whistling noises coming from the windows. The noise would always occur when the winds were northwesterly and greater than 10 miles per hour, which means we experience the problem throughout the fall and winter. The building had the window manufacturer's engineers attempt to fix the problem twice, but to no avail. The building then replaced the windows a third time, but we still have a problem. The co-op board has just presented us with a letter stating they won't do anything else to try to fix the problem. What recourse do we have? . . . Larry Kahm, Fort Lee, N.J.

title: Dead to Me
description: My mother was a ghost. She haunted me for 16 years, off and on. Hers was not a traditional haunting. She did not rattle chains or appear beside my reflection in the mirror, though I would have much preferred it that way. She just became invisible. It happened when I was 18. On a brilliant September afternoon, I ran away from home to escape my stepfather. She came home from work to find me stuffing my belongings into my beat-up Chevy Nova. Instead of stopping me, she watched for a moment and then warned that she wouldn't have me in her life if I didn't have him in mine. I was stunned.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AUGUST, JESSE
description: AUGUST--Jesse. 75, of Hobe Sound, FL, passed away Friday, January 23, 2004, at his residence. Born in China, Jesse has resided in Hobe Sound for the past six years, moving here from New York. Jesse was a self employed pearl importer and exporter all over the world prior to retiring. He was a U.S. Army Veteran and he was a member of Temple Emanuel, New York City. Jesse was an active member of Hobe Sound Golf Club, Hobe Sound, FL, he was an avid golfer, bridge player and loved photography. Jesse was well loved by everyone who met him or knew him. Jesse loved his pets. He was the son of the late Edward and Rebecca Slutsky and was predeceased by his son Stefan Slutsky. Surviving are his wife Buzzy August of Hobe Sound, FL, two daughters Shari Lanzarone of Wakefield, MA, and Susan Taplansky of upstate New York, and his two stepdaughters Diane Dann of Chappaqua, NY, and Margie Satell of Simsbury, CT. Jesse is also survived by nine grandchildren. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to a charity of one's choice in his memory. Burial will be in Baron Hirsch Cemetery, Staten Island, NY. For further information please call Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 212769-4400.

With a life here that includes a husband, two children and the freedom to go to the movies anytime she likes, Ms. Scott Thomas isn't about to challenge Nicole Kidman as Hollywood's leading clotheshorse. title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: PATRICIA FRANCHINI, Jean Seberg's character in the New Wave classic BREATHLESS (1959), has a lot on her mind. ''I'm not sure if I'm unhappy because I'm not free or if I'm not free because I'm unhappy,'' Patricia, an American in Paris, tells a male journalist who is giving her a chance at being a reporter. Meanwhile she's hawking newspapers on the streets and telling her semi-boyfriend (Jean-Paul Belmondo) that she's pregnant. And, oh yeah, he just killed a policeman. Jean-Luc Godard directed, Godard and Franois Truffaut wrote the screenplay, and Paris looks improbably beautiful in black-and-white -- Saturday at 8 p.m. on Channel 25.

title: Patches for the Drug Program

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OSBORNE, ELIZABETH JANE GIBBY
description: OSBORNE--Elizabeth Jane Gibby. Born November 29, 1930, in Elizabeth, NJ, to Edgar Budd Gibby and Beatrice Hadley Gibby; died January 20, 2004, at home. She had the great good fortune to benefit from six years of expert, caring and effective outpatient care by staff of the Cancer Institute of New Jersey and, at the end, Hospice of Princeton. She was a member of the Vail Deane School class of '48 and Goucher College '52, a 50 year member of Delta Gamma Fraternity, and proud to be Princeton University h'36. Lib/Liz/EJ soon found her way into the teaching profession, notably her 30 year career as a master teacher at Chapin School (the New Jersey one). Her marriage to Alexander P. Robinson produced two fine sons, Alexander M. Robinson, who predeceased her, and Bruce M. Robinson, living happily in South Carolina. She later honored William H. Osborne III, with 20 affectionate years of ''retread'' marriage, and his descendants with her warm love: Lynn Osborne, Wendy O. Pierce, and William H. Osborne IV, and their spouses and children. Lib never forgot a friend (or anything about him or her), hundreds of whom enjoyed her individually crafted birthday cards, year after year. She had many connections with Princeton University, counting among alumni her father, uncles, brothers, two fathersin-law, former brothers-inlaw, a cousin and a husband. In late years, she has served that University effectively as Chair of the University's Class Associates Committee, recently as In Memoriam Chair, and as a representative member of the Alumni Council's Committees on Reunions and on Class Affairs. In 2000 she was honored with an Alumni Council Award for Service to Princeton. No services are planned, but contributions will be welcomed, in Memory of Elizabeth Gibby Osborne, to Cancer Institute of New Jersey, mailed to Development Office, 195 Little Albany Street, New Brunswick, NJ 08901.

title: Drugs, Bodies, Weapons And Terrorists
description: THERE's no stopping ''Traffic.'' In 1989 the British ''Traffik,'' a Channel Four production, traced heroin trade along ancient smuggling routes from the poppy fields of Pakistan to the end-user: teenage drug addicts in England. Then in 2000, Steven Soderbergh's equally downbeat epic, with an innovative multistrand story line, shifted locales to Mexico and the United States and earned four Oscars, including one for best director, and a nomination for best picture. This week, USA presents its own six-hour ''Traffic'' mini-series, with a new, terrifyingly human twist.

Images of pianos are everywhere: printed on the fabric draperies at the entrance, in woven tapestries on the walls and as a keyboard logo on the menu and business cards. title: As Unpretty as a Picture

In it, a young boy watches a lascivious woman lying naked in bed as he slips his hand into her purse on a table behind him. Mr. Fischl caught a moment in a way that photography catches moments -- as evidence, with observation, in stark existential relief.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOWERS, PHILIP JAMES III
description: BOWERS--Philip James III. 65, of Bernardsville, NJ, died Friday, January 23, 2004, of lung cancer complications. Jim was born a triplet in Newark, NJ, to the late Philip James Bowers II and Ruth Geiger Bowers, residing in Tryon, NC, who survives him. He graduated from the Delbarton School and Georgetown University in Washington, DC. He served as an Officer in the Air Force ROTC. Jim was the Founder and President of J. Bowers & Co., Inc., a residential building firm in Bedminster, NJ, and served on the Boards of The Ethel Walker School, The Far Hills Country Day School, The Seeing Eye in Morristown, NJ, The Somerset Hills Country Club and was a Board member and the President for the past 28 years of the Essex Hunt Club in Peapack, NJ. Jim is survived by his beloved fiancee Leigh E. Fenwick of Bernardsville, NJ, his four children Ruthann Bowers of New York, Gretchen Bowers Fallon of Amagansett, NY, Philip James Bowers IV, of New York, Hilary Geiger Bowers of New York, four grandsons and Leigh's three children Sibyl, Lili and Bayard Fenwick of Bernardsville, NJ. Also surviving are his two sisters Jeanne Bowers Bennett Hall and Joanne Bowers Little, and former wife Ann Lind Bowers. A Mass celebrating Jim's life will be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Seeing Eye, P.O. Box 375, Washington Valley Road, Morristown, NJ 07960, or The Community Cancer Research Fund #

title: The Treo 600
description: As the editor of Gizmodo, a Web log that traffics in the latest news about gadgets from cellphones to laptops, Peter Rojas is bombarded with e-mail from people who want to hear (or spread) the latest gossip about this or that device or innovation. But the anticipation around one particular gizmo stood out over the past year: a so-called smart phone known as the Treo 600, made by PalmOne. The buzz started in June, months before the phone became available in the United States, when a certain photograph was posted on online message boards. Lying down on the floor of the studio in his house here, he placed his feet on the wall and squirmed like a trapped bug. Slowly he writhed into a standing position and bent his right leg and extended it in front of him. He finished the sequence by spinning across the room in a series of slow pirouettes. Little of what he did seemed even remotely like flamenco.

Others are simply in denial, like President Bush, who insisted that heterosexual marriage was ''one of the most fundamental, enduring institutions of our civilization'' in his State of the Union address last week. Yet this statement came shortly after his own administration floated a proposal for a $1.5 billion miracle cure: an initiative to promote ''healthy'' marriage, particularly among low-income couples. And what of all the millionaires in failing marriages or fleeing commitment? Where are the initiatives devoted to rehabilitating this afflicted group? Sorry, they're on their own in the romance department. In this administration, the economic benefits filter upward, the marital meddling filters down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KEESHAN, ROBERT J.
description: KEESHAN--Robert J. It is with deep regret and sorrow that the Board of Trustees, Administration, Medical Board, Medical Staff, Volunteers and Employees of Good Samaritan Hospital Medical Center mark the passing of Robert J. Keeshan, Trustee Emeritus. Mr. Keeshan, a Babylon resident, was an esteemed and honored member of the Board of Trustees from 1969 to 1978. He aided the hospital immeasurably as an active member of the Executive, Community Relations and Development Committees. Known to television audiences everywhere as ''Captain Kangaroo'', Keeshan as president of the Board, brought his expertise and talent to assist his community hospital in its growth and development. With his exceptional speaking skills, he was the highlight of the first annual Samaritan dinner in 1961, and was chair of the Good Samaritan Ball in 1968 and 1969. His unique appeal and enthusiasm made these events highly successful endeavors. The winner of numerous awards for his continuing excellence from the television industry, he lent his time, talent and expertise to Good Samaritan Hospital Medical Center. He will be remembered for his dignified, caring and friendly manner. To his family, Good Samaritan Hospital sends its heartfelt condolences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NESS, ANNE FARRAR SEMPLE
description: NESS--Anne Farrar Semple, 96, died at a nursing home in Mashpee, MA on January 11, 2004. Philip Wahmann Ness, her husband of 72 years, died recently. Mrs. Ness graduated from the Mary Institute (St. Louis, MO) in 1925 and the Knox School (Cooperstown, NY) in 1927. She was an avid sportswoman and versatile musician. Mrs. Ness is a descendant of the original settling families of Virginia and early American families who came to St. Louis after the Louisiana Purchase. A distant grandfather, Nicholas Farrar, was a leading member of the Virginia company that backed the first settlement. She is a descendant of William Clark, co-leader of the Great Expedition to the Pacific in 1804 to 1806; General Bernard Farrar, who helped organize the Missouri Volunteer Infantry, commanded a Union army brigade at the siege of Vicksburg and was later military governor of Natchez, MS district; and Oliver A. Hart, a leading St. Louis architect and industrialist in the mid 1800's who helped rebuild St. Louis after the Great Fire in 1849. A memorial service is planned in Osterville, MA. early this summer.

title: Dollars and Cineastes
description: The Sundance Film Festival, which wraps up tonight, offers a yearly opportunity to survey the state of independent film in America -- and also to punditize on the death of independent film in America, which may amount to the same thing. The subtitle of ''Down and Dirty Pictures,'' a new book by the film historian Peter Biskind that was probably more avidly discussed on the streets of Park City this year than any of the movies in competition, is ''Miramax, Sundance and the Rise of Independent Film.'' The story Biskind tells is a paradoxical one, in which every chapter in the rise of the elusive ''independent spirit'' is also an episode in its decline -- its corruption by money, celebrity worship and all the other elements of Hollywood business as usual. Such moments stretch back a decade or more, to Miramax's absorption by Disney, to the first time a distribution deal was made at Sundance, to the coronation of Quentin Tarantino as King of the Indies.

title: 'Collected Poems'
description: Despite all the red flags it raises -- a famous novelist publishing a book of poems, the most recent of which are nearly 25 years old -- this is not the work of a dabbler. Before making his name as a writer of postmodern mysteries, Paul Auster was a poet almost exclusively. He spent his 20's apprenticed to the French Surrealists, the American Objectivists and a handful of hard-to-classify poets like William Bronk, perhaps the most conspicuous influence here. ''Collected Poems'' is dominated by sequences of short, dense lyric meditations on the nature of reality and our inability to apprehend or describe it: ''everything / has changed in us, if we speak / of the world / it is only to leave the world / unsaid.'' But Auster rarely achieves Bronk's clarity or control. Translations of several French poets -- Rene Char, Andre Breton -- feel right at home, not because Auster makes English seem like their natural idiom but because his own poems so often read like French Surrealism in translation: ''Along with your ashes, the barely / written ones, obliterating / the ode, the incited roots, the alien / eye -- with imbecilic hands, they dragged you / into the city.'' Here Auster seems reluctant to make any phrase syntactically subordinate to another. Does ''ones'' refer back to ''your ashes'' or forward to ''they''? What's doing the ''obliterating''? Hard-core admirers of Auster, or of his poetic models, might also admire this sort of terminal indeterminacy. Others will prefer the more involving mysteries of his prose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARTSOOK, JANE POLLARD
description: HARTSOOK--Jane Pollard. Of Richmond, VA, died Sunday, January 18, 2004. Born May 12, 1916, in Ashland, VA, she received a BFA degree from New York State College of Ceramics in Alfred, NY, in 1939. After further studies in art education at the University of Virginia, University of Richmond, and Columbia University, she obtained a master's in fine arts at Alfred in 1946. From 1946 to 1982, Ms. Hartsook was the Director of Greenwich House Pottery in NYC. Under her direction Greenwich House grew from a locally acclaimed pottery school to become an internationally renowned institution with a gallery, a permanent collection, book and slide libraries, and a staff of well known artists working, exhibiting and instructing. Awarded honorary membership in the National Council on Education for the Ceramic Arts in 1982, she became a member of the New York Settlement Hall of Fame in 1986. In 1992, recognizing her status as an artist and administrator, Greenwich House presented a retrospective of 50 years of her work, and the gallery, founded by her in 1970, was named the Jane Hartsook Gallery. She received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the National Museum of Women in the Arts in 2000. The widow of L. Parke Hartsook, she is survived by numerous neices, nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews. Contributions may be made to the Scholarship Fund, Greenwich House Pottery, 16 Jones St, NYC 10014; or the Chapel of Our Lady, c/ o Ms. Betty Green, 8 Northern Ave, Cold Spring, NY 10516.

title: War Of Ideas, Part 6
description: For the past few weeks I've tried to lay out the tactics we in the West can adopt to strengthen the moderates in the Arab-Muslim world to fight the war of ideas against the forces of intolerance within their civilization -- which is where the real war on terrorism will either be won or lost. But if there is one thing I've learned in examining this issue it's this: ideas don't just spread on their own. Ideas spread in a context. So often, since 9/11, people have remarked to me: ''Wow, Islam, that's a really angry religion.'' I disagree. I do agree, though, that there are a lot of young Muslims who are angry, because they live in some of the most repressive societies, with the fewest opportunities for women and youth, and with some of the highest unemployment. Bad contexts create an environment where humiliation -- and the anger, bad ideas and violence that flow from it -- are rife. In short, it is impossible for us to talk about winning the war of ideas in the Arab-Muslim world without talking about the most basic thing that gives people dignity and hope: A job.

title: Dreaming in the New Russia
description: The people in THE RED PASSPORT (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22), Katherine Shonk's collection of stories about life in post-Soviet society, can be roughly divided between real Russians and those who wish they were; natives trying to get out; well-meaning Americans trying to fit in; and some older types still trying to wake from the nightmare of the New World Order. ''Their desire to be in each other's countries hung between them,'' Shonk writes of a pair of couples, ''embarrassing and sad, as if the four of them were misfits who, full of false hope, expected to fit in elsewhere.'' Fresh from the Chechen conflict, Sasha in ''Our American'' plans to save his younger brother from conscription by marrying Amy, the cute girl from Ohio who works on a collective farm; the three of them, he thinks, will simply move to America. Temporarily stuck in Prague, an American named Rachel in ''Honey Month'' is faced with a painful decision: returning to her selfish boyfriend in Moscow or helping an expectant Russian couple desperate to get to America. Leslie, the American descendant of czarist-era nobility in ''Kitchen Friends,'' is so convinced she's a real Russian that she proclaims imaginary guilt over her ancestors' treatment of serfs -- a stance that cuts no ice with the locals. (''Russian-American, eh?'' sneers one. ''Like a dictionary?'') In ''The Conversion,'' a rootless American named Tom finds himself returning to Russia following a nasty breakup because he ''harbored a secret conviction that if he remained in America, he would always regard his time in Russia as the best of his life.'' In her first collection, Shonk sees these and other varied perestroikans with an eye both rueful and ruthless, sympathetic to their dreams even as she sees through them. She writes with the comfortable sense of one who has not only been there but taken a good look around. Rodney Welch

title: For the Survival of Democracy
description: March 4, 1933. The thirty-second president of the United States, the latest in an unbroken line stretching from George Washington, took the oath of office amidst pomp and circumstance and crowds that braved a bleak, cold day to cheer him. Just four years earlier, his predecessor Herbert Hoover had told a far more optimistic and celebratory gathering: "We are steadily building a new race, a new civilization great in its own attainments." Hoover had taken office in a time of unmatched prosperity and mass affluence, which seemed likely to continue into the indefinite future. He had delivered only hard times and mass unemployment. He had not been primarily to blame for a worldwide economic catastrophe, but he undeniably had failed to cope with it. As he left office a dour, bitter man, the nation seemed in a state of collapse. In many other countries, contenders for power might have been fighting in the streets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POND, CHARLES ''CHUCK'' JR.
description: POND--Charles ''Chuck'' Jr. An electrical contractor in Fairfield County for 30 years, who was easily recognizable by the gold leaf CWP logo that adorned the company's fleet of trucks, died on Friday, January 23, 2004, at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital in New York. He was 68, and lived in Norwalk, CT. The cause was lung cancer, said his wife Patricia Pinto Pond. C.W., as he was known, completed hundreds of projects in and around Fairfield County Connecticut. These projects involved electrical design, new construction and corporate renovation. Chuck built a clientele that has been loyal to him and the C.W. Pond family for more than 30 years. Chuck was very proud of his relationships with his professional staff and the family atmosphere he fostered at his organization. His peers, associates and customers recognized and respected him as a leader in the industry with a vision that allowed him to excel in the trade. He was a highly respected pioneer in design and build and value engineer concepts, and has passed his knowledge on to his son Jeff and other key members of the C.W. Pond team. Chuck was a proud veteran of the armed forces, having served in the U.S. Army in the First Howitzer Battalion, Second Artillery, in Baumholder, Germany. After his service, Pond relocated to Stamford, CT. Pond had a long and prosperous career as a contractor in Fairfield County, having formed various C.W. Pond companies, starting in 1974. He was an avid yachtsman and a member of the Stamford Yacht Club and New York Yacht Club. He began boating in 1979, and sailed for many years on sailboats that bore the name ''Perpetual Motion.'' His most recent boat was a custom green hulled motor yacht named after his uncle, Raymond ''Ducky'' Pond, the legendary Yale football coach. ''Ducky'' could be seen in the summers from Nantucket to Newport, all over Long Island Sound and in the winters in Palm Beach, FL. Mr. Pond was born in Torrington, CT, in 1935, and was the son of the late Charles and Mildred Pond, and brother of the late Linda Pond Richardson. He leaves behind his beloved and adoring wife and partner, Patricia Pinto Pond, and is survived by his three children and their spouses, daughter Susan Saracena and her husband Tom, son Jeff Pond and his wife Donna and son Kyle Pond and his wife Susan, plus seven grandchildren. Calling hours will take place on Wednesday, January 28, at the Leo P. Gallagher and Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer Street in Stamford, CT, from 3-5 pm, and 7-9 pm. A memorial service to celebrate Chuck's life will take place on Thursday, January 29, at 10 am, at St. Mary's Church, at 566 Elm Street in Stamford, CT. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Cancer Foundation, c/o Norwalk Hospital, Maple Street, Norwalk, CT 06856.

Also surviving are his two sisters Jeanne Bowers Bennett Hall and Joanne Bowers Little, and former wife Ann Lind Bowers. title: Editorial Observer; New Hampshire Is Everyone's Personal Shopper

This is, after all, the state that four years ago gave us Gary Bauer falling off the stage during a pancake flipping contest and Alan Keyes throwing himself into a mosh pit. The current campaign has delivered nothing more than a few strained stabs at regular-guyness. Wesley Clark has bagged groceries, gone bowling and served coffee at Dunkin' Donuts. (''Each represents a different part of the mosaic of the American workplace,'' said Mr. Clark's consultant, Chris Lehane.) John Kerry played in a hockey game, but his deportment was extremely staid. The other players -- students, firefighters and several ex-Boston Bruins who all seemed to be named Ken Hodge -- wore a motley combination of well-worn uniforms and T-shirts, while the immaculate senator appeared to have been run through a mangle on the way out to the ice.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Court Extends Term Limits To Prosecutors
description: District attorneys are subject to the state's term-limit law, just like other elected officials, the State Supreme Court decided. The ruling cements Colorado's status as the sole state to include prosecutors in such laws, legal experts said. Coloradans approved a constitutional amendment in 1994 that extended the term-limit law to ''nonjudicial'' elected officials. That followed disputes over whether the office of district attorney, a career position in many regions, was included. In 2002, voters rejected a statewide referendum to exempt prosecutors. The new ruling means that district attorneys can serve no more than two four-year terms in a row. Kirk Johnson (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Mass-Mailing Virus Infects PC's
description: Antivirus concerns warned yesterday of a new mass-mailing computer virus that has gained a foothold in a large number of PC's by masquerading as an e-mail error. The virus, dubbed MyDoom, arrives in an in-box with one of several random subject lines like ''Mail Delivery System,'' ''Test'' or ''Mail Transaction Failed.'' The body of the e-mail contains an executable file and a statement such as: ''The message contains Unicode characters and has been sent as a binary attachment.'' Vincent Gullotto, vice president for the antivirus emergency response team at Network Associates, said in one hour, Network Associates received 19,500 e-mail messages with the virus from 3,400 Internet addresses. One telecommunications company shut down its e-mail gateway to stop the virus. Antivirus companies were scrambling to learn more about the virus, which started spreading in early afternoon. Mail systems that remove executable files from e-mail can stop the program from spreading.
