title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Grows
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus grew 41 percent in December, to 1.1 trillion yen ($10.6 billion), as strong exports to China and elsewhere offset the effect of the yen's appreciation. The sixth consecutive monthly expansion in the surplus came partly as a result of an 8.5 percent jump in exports, including a 32 percent rise in shipments to China. At the same time, Japan's surplus with the United States fell for the 12th consecutive month as Japanese automakers and other producers build more of their goods in North America. Exports from Japan to the United States fell 7.8 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: White House Shows Less Certainty Now About Iraq's Arms
description: The White House began to back away on Monday from its assertions that Iraq had illegal weapons, saying it now wanted to compare prewar intelligence assessments with what may be actually found there.

title: Demanding Respect, and Looking Up to Moses
description: IF you look hard at Peter C. Harvey, the first African-American to serve as attorney general of New Jersey, you can see his preacher father. Not the one who presided over long Baptist church meetings and services, not the one who made weekly visits to sick parishioners, not the one who thundered from the pulpit, but the one who believed that life was about struggle, about making the world a place where those who were different were not just tolerated, but respected.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Inquiry At Oil Concern
description: The Venezuelan state oil company, Petrleos de Venezuela, said it was opening an investigation into what it said were irregularities in sales of crude oil and oil products. Petrleos de Venezuela gave no indication in a statement what sales were under investigation. The company fired most of its finance department during a two-month strike last year, and that has led to delays in producing its financial results and accusations by former managers of irregularities.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Parmalat Unit Hires Specialist
description: The Brazilian unit of Parmalat hired a corporate turnaround specialist to help overhaul its money-losing operations, the company said. Afonso Champi, a Parmalat spokesman here, said Claudio Galeazzi, a consultant who has previously helped to rework the finances of Lojas Americanas and Vila Romana, two well-known Brazilian retail chains, and Mococa, another dairy company, started work as part of an agreement between Parmalat and its local creditors. Mr. Galeazzi should lend credibility to Parmalat's management, which is trying to keep its day-to-day operations running without any backing from banks, Mr. Champi said. Like its Italian parent, Parmalat's Brazilian unit operated under two sets of rules, one for its listed operational unit, which owes local banks $160 million, and another more byzantine set of practices used by its two holding companies under direct control of the Tanzi family in Parma. Bankers say the total owed by the two Brazilian holding companies, which were involved in financing acquisitions in the 1990's and Parmalat's expensive sports marketing and soccer interests, could exceed $1.6 billion. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: American Express Profit Rose 12% for 4th Quarter and 2003
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that its earnings rose 12 percent in the fourth quarter and the year, driven by greater spending and borrowing on its payment cards as well as more investment activity.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Yonkers: Sex Offender Fatally Shot
description: A convicted sex offender was fatally shot early yesterday outside a building on Riverdale Avenue in Yonkers, the police said. The man, Richard Tunley, 50, died from multiple gunshot wounds, said Detective William Maher of the Yonkers Police Department. Mr. Tunley had been released from a prison in New York State in 2001, after serving time for third-degree rape, according to public records. The shooting took place at 4:30 a.m., Detective Maher said. Although no arrests had been made late last night, detectives on the case ''know who they are looking for,'' and ''are actively pursuing the suspect'' Detective Maher said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

description: A power struggle between members of a fundamentalist Mormon sect has exposed deep fissures in the largest polygamous community in North America, a town in which most men have several wives and sometimes dozens of children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STERN, STANLEY R.
description: STERN--Stanley R. On January 24, 2004, our beloved friend and companion for 50 years passed away. Simply stated, Stanley Stern was a man whose loyalty, generosity, kindness and intellect transcended normal human bounds. He found intellectual pursuit the most nourishing of forces, and he saw it as a glorious school for the heart...his wisdom and intellect were free of disillusionment. We profoundly mourn the untimely death of our dear friend. His loving exuberance remains strong in our hearts and minds. We are confident but pray that he encounter a kind and gentle providence, and extend our most sincere love and sympathy to his beloved dear wife Lorrie, all of the children and grandchildren, all of whom he held so dear. Lee & Ralph Kern & family

So you might think ''Weights,'' his touching one-man show, which runs through Feb. 1 at Urban Stages, is a literal reference to gym equipment. But it's about a kind of emotional weight training that has made it possible for him to live well and happy as a blind man.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Constitution Is Law
description: President Hamid Karzai signed Afghanistan's new Constitution at a ceremony in Kabul, in the presence of the former king, Mohammad Zahir Shah -- now formally the Father of the Nation -- cabinet ministers and foreign diplomats. The Constitution became law immediately. It was approved by a loya jirga, or grand council, on Jan. 4. Mr. Karzai also offered prayers that the Constitution would guide the way to national unity and democracy. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: CENTRAL GARDEN TO BUY POTTERY MAKER FOR $69 MILLION
description: The Central Garden and Pet Company, a distributor of lawn, garden and pet products, said it had agreed to buy the closely held New England Pottery Inc. for about $69 million to add products that are less seasonal. New England Pottery, a unit of Heritage Partners Inc., has annual sales of about $75 million, Central Garden said. The purchase will allow Central Garden, which is based in Lafayette, Calif., to sell pottery and lighting products during the winter months when consumers buy fewer lawn and garden items, it said. New England Pottery is based in Foxboro, Mass..

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WANG, FLORENCE WU
description: WANG--Florence Wu, beloved wife of Cheng Ching and devoted mother of Vera and Kenneth died peacefully early Saturday morning, the 17th of January surrounded by her immediate family. She was born in 1918 in China, the youngest daughter of General Wu Jing Biao, military governor of Jiangxi province and Wu Yue Shin. Born at a time before the Communist Revolution when women were not necessarily encouraged to pursue higher learning, she completed all of her studies including earning her B.A. degree from Xi Nan University. After her marriage in 1939 she fled mainland China via India due to the Communist takeover to join her husband in the U.S., where she served as a translator for the United Nations. Long recognized for her extraordinary innate style and aesthetic flair, with a passion for the arts and education, she embraced her new life in her adopted country and instilled similar values in her children. She served as an early inspiration for her daughter's activities as a fashion designer and remained an active supporter until her passing. Her husband Cheng Ching, daughter Vera Wang Becker, son Kenneth, five grandchildren and sister Diana survive her. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the New York Presbyterian Hospital in the name of Florence Wu Wang. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, on Wednesday, January 28th, from 6pm to 9pm. Funeral private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARFINKLE, SANDOR
description: GARFINKLE--Sandor, founder of Gemini Industries, dies at 67. Sandor Garfinkle, the founder and long-time CEO of Gemini Industries of Clifton, NJ and an active philanthropist, died yesterday in his home in Boca Raton, Florida. He was 67. Mr. Garfinkle founded Gemini Industries in 1964 and oversaw its growth into a multi-million dollar corporation and one of the leading manufacturers of consumer electronics accessories. Under Mr. Garfinkle's management, the corporation was sold to Wesray in 1985, and to Merrill Lynch Capital Partners in 1989. He was an active but quiet philanthropist, who supported a wide variety of causes. Mr. Garfinkle was an especially ardent friend and champion of the Jewish Community, both at home and abroad. His love of nature and the arts was combined in his support for the tradition of wildfowl carving, a uniquely American art form. Most of his prominent collection of works from contemporary American artists will be given to the Ward Museum of Wildfowl Art in Salisbury, Maryland. Mr. Garfinkle is survived by his wife of 46 years, Rani, of Boca Raton and Manhattan. In addition, he is survived by his children, Suzy Garfinkle Chevrier, of Boca Raton; Benjamin Garfinkle of Fort Lee, NJ, Steven and Victoria Garfinkle of Bellingham, WA; grandchildren Matthew, Ari, Sophi, Jakob and Rebecca Garfinkle and Claire, Joelle and Natalie Chevrier, and his dear nieces and nephews. Service Monday Boca Raton.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Jail Guards Accused Of Smuggling
description: Two corrections officers have been indicted and accused of smuggling goods to inmates housed in the county jail where they work, the State Division of Criminal Justice said yesterday. The accused were identified as Vincenzo A. Perricone, 25, of Burlington, and James H. Dowd, 27, of Lumberton, who are stationed at the Burlington County Jail. A grand jury indictment, handed up on Friday, accused Mr. Dowd of smuggling in marijuana, prepaid cellphones and alcohol. Mr. Perricone was accused of bringing in cigarettes in exchange for at least $200 in cash bribes, the criminal division said. Both men have been suspended. The indictment charged Mr. Dowd with bribery, official misconduct, and engaging in a pattern of official misconduct. There is no record of a lawyer for Mr. Dowd, and Mr. Perricone's lawyer did not return a call for comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page news analysis article on Wednesday about the impact of electoral politics on President Bush's State of the Union address referred incorrectly to a statement in last year's address, about Iraqi efforts to acquire uranium. He did not specifically mention the African country of Niger, though it was identified several weeks earlier -- along with Somalia and Congo -- in the National Intelligence Estimate provided to members of Congress on Iraqi purchase attempts.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: Convicted Colonel A Fugitive
description: An army colonel convicted of ordering the assassination in 1990 of Myrna Mack, an anthropologist and human rights activist, remains a fugitive despite alerts to international law enforcement groups. Col. Juan Valencia Osorio, who belonged to a presidential intelligence unit linked to numerous rights abuses, was sentenced to 30 years in prison in a landmark Supreme Court ruling last week. But rights monitors had worried that he would flee, since the police had been unable to enter his residence for two days after the ruling. At one point, a group of soldiers confronted police officers outside his home. When the police finally entered, the colonel had vanished. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: Frequent Flier; Beware of Knife Throwers Bearing Cultural Blindfolds
description: When I was in Shanghai on business, about the only thing to do on a free night, after having made the required stroll down the Bund by the river, was to visit the Shanghai Circus in a vast Communist-style People's Auditorium. Being a Westerner, I was able to buy the most expensive $5 seat: right on the aisle, down front. Suddenly, I was ''chosen'' by the circus master and escorted onto the stage. A large board was wheeled out and an acrobat stood in front of it. His partner across the stage suddenly threw a knife at him, and in a lightning moment it thrust into the board just below his elbow. The audience burst into thunderous applause. I stopped smiling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARX, GERTIE F., M.D.
description: MARX--Gertie F., M.D. On January 25, 2004. Loving wife of the late Eric Reiss. Trusted advisor and cousin of Ronald Simon, M.D. Treasured mentor and ''medical mother'' of Jill M. Rabin, M.D. She was Professor Emerita of Anesthesiology at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY. There she founded the field of obstetric anesthesiology. She popularized the epidural block by identifying factors which increased its safety and efficacy. The Gertie Marx Needle is a mainstay for the epidural block in use today. She founded the Society for Obstetric Anesthesia and Perinatology in 1971 and was founding editor of Obstetric Anesthesia Digest. She authored over 30 book chapters, over 150 scientific papers and one textbook, The Physiology of Obstetric Anesthesia that was published in 1969. Multiple career awards, including the Distinguished Service Award of the American Society of Anesthesiologists. In 1993, received the College Medal of the Royal College of Anesthetists, which was presented to her by Queen Elizabeth. When asked what her most important contribution was, she stated ''Improving the well-being of both mother and baby.'' No one has ever given more meaning to the title of physician, and she has truly graced all of our lives. Services Wednesday, 10 am, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th and Amsterdam Ave. Donations may be made to the Gertie F. Marx Labor and Delivery Fund at Jacoby Medical Center, C/O Dr. Ronald Simon, Dept of Surgery, or to Obstetric Anesthesia and Perinatology Endowment Fund, 2 Summit Park Drive, #

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Court Case On Missing Organs
description: A civil trial involving 2,140 families began with the High Court hearing details about how organs were removed from dead relatives, mostly children, over more than a decade without the consent of family members. They are seeking compensation from 130 hospitals around the country. An attorney for the families, Richard Lissak, told the court that the ''practice was objectionable on three levels -- morally, ethically and legally.'' In the cases presented yesterday, the bodies of two infants who died days after being born were returned to their parents after major organs, including their brains, had been removed. A lawyer for the National Health Service defended the medical professionals, saying, ''These are the self-same people who cared for these children'' and earned the gratitude of parents. ''Why should their devoted professionalism suddenly cease?'' Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Bank's Profit Rises
description: The largest bank in Spain, Santander Central Hispano, said that it earned 2.6 billion euros ($3.24 billion) last year, an increase of 16.2 percent, despite a decline of nearly 15 percent in net interest income. The results surpassed analysts' expectations, even though the weak United States dollar and currency depreciation in Latin America hurt its interest income. The increase reflected growth in European retail banking; increased lending in Brazil, Chile and Mexico; and lower costs, the company said. The chairman, Emilio Botn, said that the bank had ''much room to grow'' in Europe and Latin America, but he ruled out large cross-border mergers. ''These operations do not create value for shareholders,'' he said. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: The Politics of Security
description: President Bush is making an oddly timed push for renewal of the Patriot Act. Since important provisions of the law do not expire until the end of 2005, his real reason for raising the issue last week in his State of the Union address seemed to be political: to create the appearance of being tough on terrorism, which is central to his re-election campaign, while undercutting the chorus of critics, spanning the political spectrum, who are calling the act a threat to civil liberties. Mr. Bush had it exactly backward. Rather than rushing to renew the law, Congress should curtail its many serious excesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MUNNELL, DR. EQUINN WILLIAM
description: MUNNELL--Dr. Equinn William, noted obstetrician and gynecological surgeon, pioneer in ovarian cancer, skilled teacher, and beloved father and husband to his family, died on January 21, 2004. Born 1913, he was Emeritus Professor of Clinical Obstetrics and Gynecology at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. A graduate of Amherst College and Cornell University Medical School, he was a past President of the New York Obstetrical Society, Sloane Alumni Society and New York Medical Society. Equinn Munnell was a long time resident of Gramercy Park and Southport, CT, and a former member of the Pequot Yacht Club. The cherished husband for 65 years of Frances Clark Munnell, deceased, he is survived by his children, Thomas Clark Munnell of Boston and Marion, MA, Catherine Munnell Smith of Washington DC, and Elizabeth Hamilton Munnell of Cambridge, MA. Memorial service will be held on Saturday, February 7 at 2 PM in Calvary Episcopal Church at 21st St and Park Avenue South, NYC. title: CHIQUITA IN TALKS TO SELL COLOMBIAN BANANA OPERATIONS
description: Chiquita Brands International Inc. said yesterday that it was in talks to sell its Colombian banana operations as it tries to reduce costs and develop higher-profit products. Chiquita is negotiating with C.I. Banacol, a unit of Invesmar, to sell its Colombian operations, including a port, the company said. Chiquita, which is based in Cincinnati, might save money by buying fruit from C.I. Banacol, a banana producer and exporter based in Medellin, analysts said. The talks are ''serious and in an advanced stage,'' C.I. Banacol said. Chiquita, which emerged from bankruptcy in 2002, is selling businesses to cut costs by $110 million by the end of 2005.

UFJ, which denied a report in Nihon Keizai Shimbun saying regulators would begin an investigation, nonetheless postponed the sale of bonds worth $677 million. Regulators at the Financial Services Agency declined to comment on the report and the bank did not set a new date for the sale. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Islip: Judge In Grubman Case Is Reprimanded
description: A justice of the State Supreme Court in Suffolk County, John C. Bivona, was reprimanded by the state for inappropriately issuing an order in a civil suit against the publicist Elizabeth S. Grubman as a favor to a friend, the State Commission on Judicial Conduct said yesterday. In December 2001, on a Saturday, the commission said, Christopher Modelewski, the lawyer for a bouncer who had sued Ms. Grubman for backing her S.U.V. into him at a Hamptons nightclub, went to Justice Bivona's home and asked for an order postponing some depositions that Ms. Grubman's lawyers had scheduled. The justice, who in addition to being Mr. Modelewski's friend was a client of his in a separate case, complied. He was not the judge handling the Grubman case, but was on call to handle after-hours motions. The commission said that because of his relationship with Mr. Modelewski, he should not have become involved. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOMAN, NICHOLAS R.
description: DOMAN--Nicholas R., 90, slipped peacefully away Sunday morning, January 25. Husband of Judith Nicely Doman, father of Daniel, Alexander, stepfather of Lisa, grandfather of Amanda and Joshua, stepgrandfather of four. Born in Budapest, educated in Hungary and at the University of Colorado. Served in the U.S. Army and the O.S.S. Assistant prosecutor Nuremberg trials 1945-1946. A brilliant lawyer, he worked tirelessly on the restitution of properties seized during the Nazi and Communist periods. He spoke five languages, had the map of every major city in his head, loved tennis, bridge, travel and his house in Shelter Island. But above all, he loved his family who will keep him in their hearts forever. Memorial service St Mary's Church, Shelter Island 3 PM February 6.

title: When Protein-Folding Goes Awry
description: Prions are proteins. Proteins are made by genes that determine how the molecules that make up proteins, called amino acids, are arranged. A newly synthesized protein is a floppy string of amino acids. Based on how it is strung, with positive and negative forces bumping into each other, each protein folds itself into a three-dimensional shape. A protein's shape determines its function, in the way that keys fit into locks.

Smith of Federal District Court in Providence, ruled last month that the tax amounted to a tax on consumers, not the tribe. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Mets and Royals Trade Pitchers

The Mets are still seeking a fifth starter, and Sedlacek will attend spring training as a nonroster invitee, although he is a long shot to make the team in any capacity. Sedlacek, 27, went 4-11 with a 6.45 earned run average for Class AA Omaha last season and was 3-5 with a 6.72 E.R.A. for the Royals in 2002. Cerda was deemed expendable in a Mets bullpen already secured with the left-handers John Franco and Mike Stanton, and he would have been competing for a long reliever role. He was 1-1 with no saves and a 5.85 E.R.A. in 27 games over 32 1/3 innings last season. Rafael Hermoso

title: NATIONAL EQUIPMENT WINS APPROVAL FOR RECOVERY PLAN

National Equipment, which reported $621.3 million in fiscal 2002 sales and a $193.5 million net loss, filed Chapter 11 papers in Chicago last June after missing interest payments to bondholders. ''The company now starts off on solid financial ground, with a new $500 million'' in financing from a group led by the Wachovia Bank, said F. Duffield Meyercord, the company's chief restructuring officer. Under the plan, debt will be converted into equity, and unsecured creditors and bondholders will get 97.5 percent of the new common stock.

description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans, upheld a settlement in 29-year-old litigation to desegregate Mississippi's public universities, five of them historically white and three historically black. The settlement calls for the state to allocate $503 million over 17 years toward improvements to balance the universities' quality and further integrate them. It was approved by most of the parties, including the federal government, which had joined the plaintiffs in suing the state. Some plaintiffs, contending that the settlement's financing was insufficient, sought to have it voided and asked permission to continue litigating. The court denied the requests. Ariel Hart (NYT)

Indeed, all the best barbecue literature takes the form of a quest. You can practically hear the lyres a-strumming as the seekers triumph over challenges and obstacles in pursuit of the tender objects of their desire.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Wave Of Killings
description: A rash of drug-related killings and deaths has swept Mexico in the past week, and federal and state authorities have no solid explanation for the violence. Eleven bodies have been unearthed at a suspected drug trafficker's house in Ciudad Jurez, and three men were killed in Nuevo Laredo, both cities on the Texas border. Two federal drug agents and an army captain were killed in Mexico City. A former deputy state attorney general was shot to death in Tijuana along with three other people. Five more deaths took place in the drug-growing state of Sinaloa. Theories voiced regarding the spate of killings include turf wars and score-settlings among drug gangs and corrupt government officials working with them. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WANG, FLORENCE WU
description: WANG--Florence Wu, beloved wife of Cheng Ching and devoted mother of Vera and Kenneth died peacefully early Saturday morning, the 17th of January surrounded by her immediate family. She was born in 1918 in China, the youngest daughter of General Wu Jing Biao, military governor of Jiangxi province and Wu Yue Shin. Born at a time before the Communist Revolution when women were not necessarily encouraged to pursue higher learning, she completed all of her studies including earning her B.A. degree from Xi Nan University. After her marriage in 1939 she fled mainland China via India due to the Communist takeover to join her husband in the U.S., where she served as a translator for the United Nations. Long recognized for her extraordinary innate style and aesthetic flair, with a passion for the arts and education, she embraced her new life in her adopted country and instilled similar values in her children. She served as an early inspiration for her daughter's activities as a fashion designer and remained an active supporter until her passing. Her husband Cheng Ching, daughter Vera Wang Becker, son Kenneth, five grandchildren and sister Diana survive her. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the New York Presbyterian Hospital in the name of Florence Wu Wang. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, on Wednesday, January 28th, from 6pm to 9pm. Funeral private.

Among the choices are a tartly spicy Thai barbecue marinade, an earthily hot Moroccan spice blend and a suave butter chicken sauce. Each is labeled according to its spiciness, starting with mild. Toasty Sri Lanka curry paste is accurately marked hot, but is still not hair-raising. There are easy recipes on the jars, which usually call for half the contents for a dish to serve 6. title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: More Remains In Serial Case

Not to be missed are green apple, grapefruit and Meyer lemon sorbets and coffee, hazelnut and chocolate chip ice cream, shown at left, in addition to eggnog and bracing peppermint. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GIBSON, CHRISTIAN DILLARD
description: GIBSON--Christian Dillard. A leading designer of material handling equipment and holder of numerous patents on related mechanical devices, died on January 22, 2004, in League City, TX. He was 89 years old. Chris was born in Rocky Ford, CO on August 29, 1914, and graduated in 1937 with a degree in civil engineering from the University of Colorado. On June 25, 1937, he married Virginia Lay. In 1943 Chris began working at what is now the Raymond Corporation in Greene, NY. During his 60 years of affiliation there he invented the narrow-aisle forklift truck, which revolutionized the material handling industry, and earned 43 patents. He held several senior administrative positions at the company and was a member of its Board of Directors. He was also a member and officeholder of several professional organizations and contributed greatly to the common good through community work in Greene. Chris's first wife died in 1968. They are survived by five children: Diane Gibson Faissler of Ipswich, MA; Donald Gibson of St. Petersburg, FL; Sue Gibson of Minneapolis, MN; Jeanne Gibson and husband Michael Giuliano of Cambridge, MA; and Tom Gibson and wife Jamie Hendry of Lewisburg, PA. There are also two grandchildren, Noel Raymond and partner Amy Finch (and great-grandchildren Max and Phebe FinchRaymond) of Minneapolis, and Todd Raymond of Squaw Valley, CA. In 1974 Chris married Ethel Babor Hoag, who survives him. Other survivors include his stepson, Eric Hoag, daughter-in-law Pat Hoag, and granddaughter Suzanne Hoag, all of League City, TX; as well as brothers Ellery Gibson and Raymond Gibson of Arizona and Blaine Gibson of California. A fourth brother, Homer Gibson, preceded Chris in death. A memorial service will be held in Greene, NY, at a later date to be announced. Burial will be in Sylvan Lawn Cemetery in Greene, and memorial contributions may be made to the Moore Memorial Library, Genesee Street, Greene, NY 13778, or to the charity of one's choice.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: EarthLink Posts Profit And Lowers Forecast
description: EarthLink, the Internet-access service, earned $10.7 million in the fourth quarter as it added subscribers and cut costs by eliminating jobs. The company forecast lower sales in 2004 than analysts had projected. Net income was 7 cents a share, compared with a year-earlier net loss of $32.9 million, or 24 cents, before the payment of dividends, EarthLink, which is based in Atlanta, said. Sales rose to $348.6 million, from $347.9 million. EarthLink said it expected 2004 sales to rise to as much as $1.44 billion, from $1.40 billion in 2003. The company had been expected to report $1.45 billion in revenue, according to the average estimate of eight analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. EarthLink shares fell $1.10, or 10 percent, to $10.

title: Six G.I.'s And 7 Iraqis Die in Spike Of Violence
description: Six American soldiers were killed and four were wounded, at least one critically, when homemade bombs exploded in two separate roadside attacks on Tuesday in central Iraq, military officials said. An Iraqi civilian was killed and several others were hurt in one of the bombings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HERMANN, ROBERT LEWIS
description: HERMANN--Robert Lewis, who celebrated his 69th birthday on December 11th, lost his battle with depression on Sunday, January 25th, 2004. Bob is survived by his wife Karen Kennedy Hermann, and their daughter Priscilla from Stanfordville, New York. From his previous marriage to Barbara Hermann of San Diego, CA., he is survived by his son Dr. Richard Hermann of Cambridge, MA., his daughter Lee Hermann Holterrman of Pennington, New Jersey, and his granddaughter, Callie Holterrman. Bob began his long and successful career at Sears, Roebuck & Company where he worked fourteen years. He eventually accepted a position as sales manager of The McCall Pattern Company in 1973. McCall's became Bob's passion, and by 1987 he was President/ CEO. Under his guidance, McCall's flourished and the devoted employees became his extended family. Bob will be missed by every life he touched. Rest in Peace Bob. Services will be held on Thursday January 29th, 2004 at 1:00PM at All Souls Church, Lexington and 80th. Reception to follow. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to: ''Midnight Run Fund'' Millbrook Prep School, School Road, Millbrook, NY 12545

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Power Plant Denied
description: The State Board of Electric Generation Siting and the Environment yesterday rejected a power company's application to build a 520-megawatt plant off 22nd Street because it had not been completely filed before Jan. 1, 2003, when a program for accelerated decisions on proposed sites expired. The decision was a blow for the Sunset Energy Fleet company, which wanted to build a floating power plant at the end of a pier. ''It's a major victory,'' said Elizabeth C. Yeampierre, executive director of the United Puerto Rican Organization of Sunset Park, a community group. John W. Dax, a lawyer representing the company, declined to comment on the decision. title: MERCK EARNINGS FALL AS COMPANY LIMITS SHIPMENTS
description: Merck said yesterday that earnings declined 26 percent in the fourth quarter as it began limiting drug shipments to wholesalers to keep them from stocking up before price increases. Net income showed the biggest quarterly drop in a decade, falling to $1.4 billion, or 62 cents a share, from $1.89 billion, or 83 cents, a year earlier. Revenue declined 7 percent, to $5.63 billion, from $6.06 billion. That beat an average estimate of $5.53 billion in a Thomson First Call survey of analysts. Steps to restrict wholesaler stocks will help Merck control prices and give more accurate earnings forecasts, its chief executive, Raymond V. Gilmartin, said.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: Thousands March; Aristide Set For Talks
description: More than 15,000 people marched on the capital, Port-au-Prince, in the latest in a series of large-scale demonstrations demanding the ouster of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide. For a second straight day the protesters marched through the city largely without incident but still closely watched by the national police force, which in recent weeks has clashed with demonstrators. The protest came as President Aristide prepared to meet this week with leaders of other Caribbean nations who have called on him to take immediate steps to resolve the political crisis. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Bond Plan Dropped
description: The Philippines scrapped plans to sell $750 million of bonds this month after its junk debt rating was cut one level by Moody's Investors Service, which cited political risks stemming from the May 10 presidential election. The country's long-term foreign-currency debt rating was cut to Ba2, two levels below investment grade, from Ba1, Moody's said in a statement in Singapore. The outlook on the rating, now the same as Fiji, Bulgaria and Guatemala, is negative, suggesting it may be lowered further.

LaBranche said that an outside evaluation found a permanent reduction in value of assets including stocks held by firms it bought, and its seats on the N.Y.S.E. and the American Stock Exchange.

title: RUSSIAN OIL COMPANY TO BUY 795 U.S. GAS STATIONS
description: Lukoil, the Russian oil producer, said it had agreed to buy 795 gas stations in New Jersey and Pennsylvania from ConocoPhillips for $266 million, which will more than double its share of the Northeast fuel market. The service stations supply about 1.2 billion gallons a year, the company said. Lukoil, which is based in Moscow, will pay $50 million and Lehman Brothers Holdings will finance the rest over six years. Lukoil, which bought Getty Petroleum Marketing in 2000, is expanding in the United States as some major oil companies shrink their domestic networks of gas stations. ConocoPhillips, which is based in Houston, is selling most of its stations in the United States to pare debt and plans to complete $4.5 billion of asset sales by the end of the year. Sunoco, the largest refiner in the Northeast, said it would pay $187.4 million for 385 gas stations from ConocoPhillips in Delaware, Maryland, Virginia and Washington, D.C.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STERN, STANLEY R.
description: STERN--Stanley R. On January 24, 2004, our beloved friend and companion for 50 years passed away. Simply stated, Stanley Stern was a man whose loyalty, generosity, kindness and intellect transcended normal human bounds. He found intellectual pursuit the most nourishing of forces, and he saw it as a glorious school for the heart...his wisdom and intellect were free of disillusionment. We profoundly mourn the untimely death of our dear friend. His loving exuberance remains strong in our hearts and minds. We are confident but pray that he encounter a kind and gentle providence, and extend our most sincere love and sympathy to his beloved dear wife Lorrie, all of the children and grandchildren, all of whom he held so dear. Lee & Ralph Kern & family

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Confidence Rises
description: German business confidence climbed for the ninth consecutive month, according to a survey of 7,000 companies in western German, which was released by the Ifo Institute in Munich. The overall index rose to 97.4 from 96.9 in December, the highest reading for three years. Sentiment was strongest in the manufacturing and construction sectors, while retail and wholesale companies, became more pessimistic during the month, the institute said. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARX, GERTIE F., M.D.
description: MARX--Gertie F., M.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of our renowned and distinguished professor emerita of anesthesiology. A member of our founding faculty, in 1954, Dr. Marx's outstanding contributions to the field of anesthesia in labor and delivery profoundly influenced the well-being of countless mothers and babies. A firm believer that pain during childbirth could be harmful to mother and child, she literally created the field of obstetric anesthesiology and the Gertie Marx Needle is a mainstay for the epidural block still in use today. We remember Dr. Marx as a uniquely caring physician, an influential educator and an innovative researcher in pain relief during labor. She will be greatly missed by all those who knew her. We extend our deepest condolences to her family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine

title: CITIGROUP ANNOUNCES MORE LAYOFFS AT A FORMER SEARS UNIT
description: Citigroup plans to eliminate 847 jobs at a New Orleans credit card center purchased from Sears, Roebuck & Company and close the facility by October, a spokeswoman, Maria Mendler, said. The cuts are part of a plan to cut 3,400 jobs, or about 40 percent of 8,300 employees in the unit, Ms. Mendler said. Citigroup bought the Sears business in November for $3.4 billion. The company said last week that 930 workers at a Sears card center in Trevose, Pa., would be laid off.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Gun Collector Charged
description: A gun collector who the authorities said kept a cache of unlicensed weapons in his home has been charged with weapons possession, the Queens district attorney announced yesterday. Last week, the police executed a warrant at the home of the collector, Bruce Steinfelder, 55, of 58th Road in Flushing, and found 69 weapons, including 51 pistols, 8 assault weapons, 4 shotguns and 6 rifles, the authorities said, adding that 25 of the weapons were unlicensed. Upon running a check, the authorities discovered that Mr. Steinfelder had failed to renew a pistol permit from 1976, the official said. His lawyer did not return a call for comment yesterday. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hospital Fined
description: Federal environmental officials have fined Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center $214,420 for improperly disposing of chemotherapy waste and other hazardous materials. The Environmental Protection Agency discovered the violations during a random inspection of the hospital last March. Chemicals used for chemotherapy, along with dental fillings, which contain mercury, were kept in standard red biohazard containers, but regulations require more specific identification of the content, Elizabeth Zimmerman, an agency spokeswoman, said yesterday. Christine Hickey, a hospital spokeswoman, said the chemotherapy chemicals were originally handled and labeled as regulated medical waste and not as hazardous chemical waste, as regulations require. Since the violations were noted, the hospital has been using the more specific terms, she said. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: Do the Math
description: Faced with attacks on his economic plan in 2000 by Al Gore, George W. Bush accused his Democratic rival of "fuzzy math." As president, Mr. Bush has been criticized by Democrats for budget numbers that do not add up, a line of attack certain to be sustained throughout this year's campaign. Today, Mr. Bush had an arithmetic problem that transcended partisan politics.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Monticello: Mother Sentenced For Killing Children
description: A woman who was convicted of killing three of her newborn children, whose corpses she transported around the country for at least a decade until abandoning them in an Arizona shed, was sentenced in Sullivan County Court yesterday to 25 years to life in prison. Evidence at the trial showed that the woman, Dianne Odell, 50, did not want the children because she was not married at the time, District Attorney Stephen F. Lungen said. The infants, born in 1982, 1983 and 1985, died shortly after their births in Kauneonga Lake, where Ms. Odell was living. Ms. Odell, who continues to maintain her innocence, was convicted of three counts of second-degree murder in December. Judge Frank LaBuda sentenced her to 15 years to life for the first child, 20 to life for the second and 25 to life for the third, with the sentences to run concurrently. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: MOVEMENT ON RAIL PLAN California and federal officials said they would move ahead with plans for a 700-mile, high-speed rail system that might cost up to $37 billion, a project opposed by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, who has said the price is too steep. Joe Petrillo, chairman of the California High-Speed Rail Authority, said a 2,000-page environmental impact report on the proposed transit system would now be available for public comment for a 90-day period, a required regulatory step. The system has drawn opposition from Mr. Schwarzenegger, who has proposed that lawmakers remove from the November ballot a nearly $10 billion bond measure that would finance the initial phases of the system's construction. The governor, who supports limited financing for further planning on the train system, is opposed to an expensive borrowing plan to break ground on the system while state's finances and economy remain wobbly, a spokesman said.    (Reuters)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Home Health Aides Unionize

Union officials said that during a two-week mail-in vote that ended last week, 1,227 health aides had voted to join the union and 233 had voted against. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: The American Canon's Unabashed Patriot
description: Leonard Bernstein once described Charles Ives as ''our musical Mark Twain, Emerson and Lincoln all rolled into one.'' That nicely captures this composer's blend of mercurial wit, maverick individualism and inspired vision of what American music could be. To this illustrious list Bernstein might have added Lewis and Clark, as Ives was also a relentless sonic explorer whose pioneering innovations cut a path deep into the terra incognita of music's future.

title: Defrosting the Primaries

But it would be ridiculous for the party to settle on a candidate because he managed to win the biggest slice of the vote in one small state that happens to be next-door to his home base. When larger, more diverse states start holding their primaries next week, the voters deserve to have a real choice.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: IDT Buys Stake In Archie Comics
description: The IDT Corporation, a telephone company that has been expanding into entertainment, bought a 5 percent stake in Archie Comics Entertainment, including the right to produce animated programs based on the comic-book characters. The company did not disclose the purchase price yesterday. IDT has acquired five other properties in the last year to expand IDT Entertainment's production and distribution, according to a company spokesman. IDT said it would immediately begin developing DVD features based on Archie Comics characters, including Archie, Jug-head, Sabrina the Teenage Witch, and Josie and the Pussycats. IDT shares rose 11 cents, to $21.71.

title: AFFILIATED MANAGERS AGREES TO BUY GENESIS HOLDINGS
description: The Affiliated Managers Group, owner of stakes in fund managers across the United States, agreed to buy Genesis Holdings International of London to add $7 billion invested in emerging markets. Affiliated also said it expected to earn at least 7 percent more this year than previously forecast. Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed. Affiliated, based in Beverly, Mass., said fourth-quarter earnings increased 30 percent as rising stock markets increased fund fees. The company's stock rose as much as 7.4 percent. Affiliated earns fees from revenue-sharing agreements with its 18 affiliates. Genesis, which was founded in 1989 and has offices in London, Guernsey, Kenya, Chile and Brazil, will enhance Affiliated's access to funds invested in some of the world's most lucrative markets.

Now Cameron Slocum, a painter and a vintage furniture dealer in Los Angeles, is reproducing as many as 40 pieces by the man he refers to as ''the most underrated designer in L.A. Modernism.'' Mr. McCabe's 1956 Triangle table, below, is made of glass and polished tubular chrome and was designed for Koenig's Case Study House 21. The reproduction will cost about $2,200. title: The Dead Center
description: The dismal fifth-place showing by Senator Joseph Lieberman in the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday serves as both reminder and motivator to the other Democratic presidential candidates on what it will take to win in November. For so long now, everyone has assumed that recapturing the presidency depends on who triumphs in the battle between liberals and moderates within the party. Such thinking, though, is inherently flawed. The real fight is between those who want only to win back the White House and those who also want to build a new political movement -- one that rivals the conservative movement that has given Republicans their dominant position in American politics.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Cabinet Backs Rule Against Scarves
description: The cabinet approved a draft law banning the wearing of religious symbols in public schools, paving the way for its consideration by the National Assembly on Tuesday. President Jacques Chirac and his center-right government have said the law, which would ban Muslim head scarves, Jewish skullcaps, large Christian crosses and perhaps other symbols from school premises, is needed to preserve the secular nature of the French state. But it is widely seen as a move to stanch the rise of militant Islam among the country's large Muslim population. ''The government bill clearly reaffirms the neutrality of public schools,'' Mr. Chirac told the cabinet, according to a spokesman. ''It does not aim to ban religious symbols in everyday life.'' Elaine Sciolino (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ERLICH, STEVEN
description: ERLICH--Steven. The Congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its member and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Amy Lemle, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi

title: Testing Two Leaders; Tony Blair, Vindicated
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain has given an impressive demonstration of how good governance can also be smart politics. Yesterday, an independent judicial inquiry fully exonerated his administration, refuting charges that it knowingly manipulated intelligence about Iraqi weapons and that it compounded the pressures that led a government scientist, Dr. David Kelly, to kill himself.

title: Party Leaders Express Relief at the Emergence of Kerry
description: Democratic leaders expressed relief Wednesday at the emergence of John Kerry as the leader of the party's presidential field, after his twin victories over Howard Dean. But they voiced concern about the potential electoral liabilities of Mr. Kerry, a candidate who remains unknown in much of the country.

title: Bush Visits New Hampshire After Primary to Praise Tax Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  President Bush traveled to New Hampshire today, perhaps to take some attention from the Democratic presidential candidates and definitely to remind the state's people of his tax-cutting agenda.

title: Fed Keeps 1% Rate, but Hints at a Rise Sometime This Year
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  The Federal Reserve left short-term interest rates at just 1 percent on Wednesday, the lowest level since 1958, but it jolted markets by retreating from its open-ended pledge to keep rates low for "a considerable period."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHERMAN, ROBERT (BOB)
description: SHERMAN -- Robert (Bob). Age 74, died peacefully of a stroke on Sunday, January 25th. Survived by beloved wife Mimi, devoted children Ricky (Alisa), Carol (Deivy) and Bruce (Lori). Grandfather to Ryen, Brett, Ilana, Alex, Brandon and Jamie. Bob was an avid tennis player and always viewed his children and grandchildren as his greatest life accomplishment. Services at 10AM, on Friday, January 30th, at ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: Never Mind the Guy Shoveling. In the Suburbs, Even Children Grow Tired of Snow.
description: Wearing a black wool cap and a 10 o'clock shadow, Claudio Edber had just finished scooping, blowing and scraping almost a foot of snow from his front steps, his driveway and car. He looked really tired. Not just of snow removal, but of winter, particularly this winter.

title: Kerry, the 'Underdog'
description: Senator John Kerry promised to campaign ''with the same underdog mentality'' that had carried him to victory so far. Page A21.

title: Outdoor Artwork, Presided Over by a Queen
description: The French-American artist Niki de Saint Phalle (bottom left) began building a sculpture garden in Escondido, Calif., in 1999 as a gift to the children of the city. Ms. de Saint Phalle died in 2002, at the age of 71; the garden, called Queen Califia's Magical Circle, opened last month. It honors Queen Califia, the fictional black queen of the Amazon whose name the Spaniards borrowed for the land they called California. The garden contains a 400-foot-long ''snake wall'' (bottom right) surrounding a maze, totems (top left) and the throne of the Eagle with Queen Califia perched on top (top right). Susan Pollack, the public art consultant for Escondido, said Ms. de Saint Phalle wanted to celebrate the cultural diversity of California.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Randalls Island Arena
description: The financier Carl Icahn, through two of his charitable foundations, will donate $10 million toward a new track and field stadium at Randalls Island Park. The gift is the largest ever from a donor to a New York City park other than Central Park. The $40 million project is also financed by $20 million in public funds and $10 million in other private donations. It is expected to be complete in the fall of this year. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

description: HARDWARE

title: Driver's Brother Offers Defense in Fatal Queens Hit-and-Run
description: A Long Island man charged in the death of a young woman who was struck by three separate hit-and-run drivers in Queens told his brother that he did not know he had hit the woman, the brother said Wednesday.

title: Price Competition Leads to Profit Warning From Ryanair
description: Ryanair, the low-fare Irish carrier, warned on Wednesday that profit in its financial year ending in March could be down as much as 10 percent as its revenue per passenger plummets.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PHILIPPINES: EXECUTIONS STAYED The Supreme Court voted 7 to 6 to suspend for a month the executions of two kidnappers set for tomorrow. It was to be the first use of capital punishment in four years. The justices said they needed to consider new evidence. After a wave of kidnappings, President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo ordered the moratorium on capital punishment, in effect since 2000, lifted in December, just months before the country holds a presidential election. Critics have accused her of swapping the lives of the two kidnappers for votes, particularly those of the small but influential ethnic Chinese community that suffers most of the abductions. (Reuters)

title: Fed Keeps 1% Rate, But Hints at a Rise Sometime This Year
description: The Federal Reserve left short-term interest rates at just 1 percent on Wednesday, the lowest level since 1958, but it jolted markets by retreating from its open-ended pledge to keep rates low for ''a considerable period.''

description: As federal investigators pore through records they have subpoenaed about Gov. John G. Rowland's personal finances, one name will no doubt be familiar: Shared Technologies Cellular.

description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report yesterday in the Arts Briefing column reversed the racial identifications of two members of the Dave Matthews Band, which is to receive a special N.A.A.C.P. award in March. The bassist, Stefan Lessard, is white; the violinist, Boyd Tinsley, is black.

description: Correction Appended

title: IN SHAKE-UP, DEAN NAMES GORE ALLY TO RUN CAMPAIGN
description: After spending nearly $40 million only to face devastating defeats in Iowa and New Hampshire, Howard Dean named a longtime friend of former Vice President Al Gore as his campaign chief on Wednesday, prompting the abrupt resignation of his campaign manager, Joe Trippi.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Government Sues Coal Plant
description: The Justice Department filed a civil lawsuit, contending that the East Kentucky Power Cooperative did not comply with a clean-air rule that typically requires coal-burning power plants to make pollution-control upgrades after major modernization projects. In December an appeals court suspended a new Environmental Protection Agency directive narrowing the government's ability to file such suits. The E.P.A. has said it will continue to bring lawsuits under the older, more stringent regulations until the legal battle is finished.

title: Volatility in Closing Prices Worries S.&P.
description: Correction Appended

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Brewery Stake Is Acquired
description: The Dutch brewer Heineken said it was investing 28.5 million euros ($35.6 million) through an Asian-affiliated company to acquire a stake in Guangdong Brewery Holdings in southern China. The affiliate, Heineken Asia Pacific Breweries China, is acquiring 21 percent of Guangdong Brewery, whose subsidiaries make Kingway beer. A co-owner of the affiliate, Asia Pacific, is also investing 28.5 million euros. Guangdong Brewery will brew Heineken beer in addition to its own local product. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Man Sought in Shooting Death of Sex Offender
description: A Yonkers man is being sought in the shooting death of a convicted sex offender who the man thought had molested his 2-year old daughter, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBERG, MARI
description: GOLDBERG--Mari on January 27, 2004 of Roslyn Heights, NY. Beloved wife of Jerry. Dear mother of Carla Brady. Loving daughter of Carmen & Paula Minardi and sister of Salvatore & Carmine Minardi & Paula Pacicco. In repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset on Thursday 79PM and Friday 2-4 & 7-9PM. Funeral mass Friday 10AM St Mary's RC Church, Roslyn Harbor. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: HAITI: ONE DEAD IN CLASH NEAR U.S. CONSULATE One person was killed and several others injured in a clash between the police, supporters of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide and antigovernment marchers near the American Consulate in Port-au-Prince. Demonstrators had gathered outside the consulate, where they burned a coffin and called for the ouster of Mr. Aristide. As the demonstrators were leaving, rock-throwing Aristide supporters confronted them. The police fired warning shots and tear gas to disperse the crowd. Hospital officials said the man who was killed died when he was struck in the chest by a tear-gas canister. A spokeswoman for the consulate said the office closed because of the unrest but that officials hoped to re-open it today. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Virtual Cemetery Visits

title: Editorial Observer; Finally, a Primary With a More Varied Complexion
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton is showing South Carolina voters a new kind of presidential campaign -- candidate as circuit preacher. He has been racing around the Carolina Midlands for months, delivering Sunday sermons from dozens of pulpits, working this state's politically crucial assemblage of faithful Christians who also happen to be fervid Democrats and proud African-Americans.

title: Safest Prediction for the Outcome in North Dakota's Primary Is 'Cold'
description: The first campaign staff members for Senator John Kerry did not set up shop in North Dakota until last Friday, putting him months behind Howard Dean and Gen. Wesley K. Clark, whose campaigns have been working the state since the fall.

description: It was not exactly the message City Hall was trying to put out yesterday.

title: Citing Improvement, Moody's Upgrades City's Bond Outlook
description: A major credit rating agency announced yesterday that New York City is on pace to resolve ''one of the most serious fiscal challenges it has faced in decades.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cuts At British Airways
description: British Airways said it would cut 300 million ($546.7 million) from its budget for its employees in the next two years, by encouraging unpaid leave, part-time work, early retirement and voluntary severance. Since the terrorist attacks of September 2001, British Airways has announced 13,000 job cuts. ''The last two years have been about survival; now we want to be in a position to prosper,'' the chief executive, Rod Eddington, said in a statement explaining the cuts.

title: On the N, Not the Seine
description: AMONG the last things you might expect to find in Astoria, Queens, a few blocks from the Greek grocery shops, Italian salumeria and Mexican-Iranian supermarkets, are two young French women in what looks like an outtake from an Eric Rohmer movie, up to their elbows in expensive French textile paints, painting fabrics that will end up on runways for Carolina Herrera and Catherine Malandrino during Fashion Week in New York.

description: To the Editor:

title: Car Bomber Kills British Peacekeeper in Kabul
description: A suicide car bomber slammed his taxi into a British peacekeepers' vehicle in Kabul on Wednesday, blowing himself up and killing one soldier and wounding four others, the commander of the peacekeeping force said. One Afghan civilian -- a 14-year-old boy -- was killed and three others were wounded in the blast, local police and hospital officials said.

title: Putin Challengers Drop to 6 in Russia President Race
description: What passes for Russia's presidential contest is progressing smartly.

title: U.S. Flies Home Large Group Of Illegal Brazilian Detainees
description: A group of 277 deportees about a quarter of the illegal Brazilian immigrants held in detention in the United States -- arrived home Wednesday on a plane chartered by the United States government.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Quest To Buy Aelita For $115 Million
description: Quest Software, which makes software for speeding database programs, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Aelita Software Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, for about $115 million. Aelita makes software and other tools that help businesses administer and audit Microsoft Active Directory and Microsoft Exchange, a Quest spokeswoman, Erin Jones, said. Quest is based in Irvine, Calif., and has 18,000 customers. The active directory is a feature within Windows servers that enables companies to manage the programs and systems their employees use. Microsoft Exchange is an e-mail program. Quest shares rose 39 cents, to $16.79.

title: For the Jogger Craving Data, A G.P.S. Tracker
description: Tracking the distance you jog can be a dubious and bothersome task. Most pedometers require a user to estimate the length of his or her stride, something that is difficult to do with precision. But with the Forerunner 201, a gadget from Garmin that straps onto your wrist, you can shelve the pedometer and bring home better workout records.

title: BBC's Chairman Quits After Hutton Report, as a Watchdog Becomes the Watched
description: As if to illustrate the strangeness of the position it found itself in, reporting on the news even as it became the news itself, it was the BBC that broke the story of the resignation of its chairman, Gavyn Davies, late Wednesday afternoon.

title: Danish Principals Revel in Their Bournonville
description: It became easy to understand why the Royal Danish Ballet is such a beloved company when a troupe called Principals and Soloists of the ballet performed on Sunday afternoon at Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College. These dancers filled the stage with choreographic sunshine.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Inquiry In Deportation Case
description: The government announced a public inquiry into what role Canadian officials played in the detention and deportation of Maher Arar, a Syrian-born Canadian citizen detained in New York in 2002 and deported to Syria, where he has said he was tortured. Since Mr. Arar's return to Canada in October, the government had firmly resisted calls for a public inquiry. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: Kerry Support Found Across Wide Range of Democrats
description: For two weeks in a row, Senator John Kerry has demonstrated broad support among Democratic voters across economic, ideological and demographic lines.

title: Revival of U.S. Shipbuilding Is Set Back by German Storm
description: An ambitious plan by Congress to revive the American commercial shipbuilding industry is under water -- quite literally.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Attack On Upper East Side
description: A young woman was robbed and sexually assaulted on the Upper East Side early yesterday, the police said. The 18-year-old woman, whom the police did not identify, was entering her apartment building at 4:30 a.m., when a man approached her with his hand in his pocket and told her that he had a gun. The man forced the woman to a nearby grocery store, where she withdrew $100 from an automatic teller machine. He took the money and then forced her back to her building, where he attacked her, the police said. The police said the attacker was between 25 and 30 years old. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Big Parmalat Unit Files for Bankruptcy In Brazilian Court
description: Parmalat's Brazilian dairy unit filed for bankruptcy protection on Wednesday, buckling under the effects of the accounting scandal at its Italian parent and legal actions in Brazilian courts.

title: Two Newcomers From Nikon Boast a Sharp Eye for Detail
description: Two new cameras announced by Nikon this week share a price ($1,000) and a target market (affluent amateur photographers). But the similarities end there.

title: Safin Eliminates Agassi in Australian Open
description: MELBOURNE, Jan. 29  It certainly looked like a farewell gesture. Andre Agassi does not typically blow kisses and bow to the crowd unless he wins a match. He lost this one in five sets, and considering how well Marat Safin served and returned and hustled in this Australian Open semifinal, there was no shame in losing; no glaring reason for Agassi to question whether he still belongs at the highest level.

Interment Calvary Cemetery. Visiting Friday 2-5, 7-9 PM.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GENN, MINNA MARDER
description: GENN--Minna Marder. 86, on January 27, from cancer. Formerly of Tenafly, NJ. Wife of the late Dr. George Genn. She held an Ed. M. from Harvard. She completed courses for her Ph.D. and analytic training. She participated in designing the Wechsler Intelligence tests. She was a supervising psychologist at Columbia Presbyterian while practicing privately. She taught her recently immigrated Yiddish-speaking parents English and surmounted a variety of obstacles to create her own vibrant path. She will be remembered for her strength, her commitment to her family, patients and large circle of friends and her wonderful dinner parties. She is survived by daughter, Sarah, and son, Leo. Memorials in her name to National Abortion Rights Action League or Meals on Wheels. Services 1 PM, Friday, January 30, Plaza Chapel, Amsterdam Ave.

title: Verizon Wireless Outpaces Rivals in New Subscribers
description: Verizon Wireless confirmed yesterday that it had added 1.5 million new subscribers in the fourth quarter, outpacing its rivals as new rules allowed consumers to keep their phone numbers when switching mobile carriers. But the impact of so-called number portability appears to have been less significant than was projected by some companies and many industry analysts.

title: Henin-Hardenne and Clijsters Follow Form Into the Final
description: The Melburnians who snapped up tickets months ago for the Australian Open women's semifinals must have liked their chances of seeing the Belgians Justine Henin-Hardenne and Kim Clijsters in action. The surprise came with the Belgians' opposition Thursday. There was not a Willliams sister or Jennifer Capriati or Amlie Mauresmo in sight, not even a rising Russian with a wicked forehand or a modeling contract.

title: Throwing a Winner on a Loser, And How It Can Make Sense
description: The first lesson for a beginner explains how to discard a loser on a winner. At the intermediate level, how to discard a loser on a loser is effectively explained. But how about discarding a winner on a loser? How does that happen?

title: As Its Role Shifts, Hezbollah Gains in Prisoner Trade
description: The tense and hilly border here is where, if all goes to plan, Israeli trucks will on Friday return the bodies of 59 men killed during Israel's long occupation of southern Lebanon. The streets will be packed in celebration, predicted a grocer, Mahmoud Tahir, who lived under that occupation for 22 of his 63 years.

title: Heatley Returns to Ice Months After a Fatal Crash
description: A hockey team starting to fade from the N.H.L. playoff race drew a near-sellout crowd of 16,271 Wednesday night at Philips Arena. There was an opening-night buzz around the team, which had won only twice in its last 14 games. Seats farthest from the ice filled up an hour before the puck dropped.

title: Hooked Rug Renaissance
description: HAND-HOOKED rugs, a staple of the folk art tradition, are going mainstream, thanks in part to inexpensive imported reproductions of favorite old patterns. Antiques, while available, tend to be small and worn as well as pricey. New designs, especially geometric ones, are well suited to modern interiors, and American workshops make them in custom sizes, large enough to go wall-to-wall or as one-of-a-kind pieces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TANEN, NATHAN
description: TANEN -- Nathan. Distin guished New York Attorney over 50 years until January 24, 2004; was a JAG in WWII; and always a friend. Norma & Marshall Kaminer & Frances Kaminer-Pyle

description: FISHER--Jodi. Our hearts are broken for our dear friends Barry, Rhoda, Dick, Robert, Jeffrey, Grandma Rose, and Jodi's dear children Jordan, Samantha and Charlie, and the entire Fisher and Spiegel families. Dearest Jodi, your shining light will glow forever in our hearts. Charlotte and Roger

title: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 10 on Jerusalem Bus
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 29 — A Palestinian police officer detonated a bomb packed with shrapnel aboard a bus here this morning, killing himself and 10 others. Despite the attack, Israel proceeded with a planned prisoner exchange with the Lebanese guerrilla group Hezbollah.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 10 on Jerusalem Bus
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 29  A Palestinian suicide bomber detonated a shrapnel-packed bomb aboard a city bus less than two blocks from the prime minister's residence here this morning, killing at least 10 other people.

description: MEINHOFER -- Georgiana. On January 27, 2004 at age 81. Loving wife of the late Raymond, adored mother of Carol, William, Paul and his wife Betty. Kamelhar, G. Haralambou, and H. Weintraub, 1 Park Ave., 9th floor, NYC 10016

title: Qaeda Trainee Is Reported Seized in Yemen
description: Jaber A. Elbaneh, the last member of a group of Yemeni-American men from Lackawanna, N.Y., who attended a Qaeda training camp in the spring and summer of 2001, has been taken into custody in Yemen, officials there and in the United States say.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Railway's Profit Rises
description: Reporting stronger than expected earnings, Canadian National Railway announced a three-for-two stock split and a 17 percent increase in its quarterly dividend. Fourth-quarter profit climbed to 224 million Canadian dollars ($169 million) from 22 million Canadian dollars in 2002. The earlier figure included sizable provisions for staff reductions and personal injury claims. Canadian National is based in Montreal. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: New Man at Top Is Something of an Old Hand
description: In choosing Roy Neel to oversee his presidential campaign, Howard Dean has selected a Washington insider known for organizational skills and close ties to Al Gore.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Venezuela Leader Met With Guerrillas
description: The government's former peace negotiator, Camilo Gmez, told a radio station that the former president, Andrs Pastrana, twice asked President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela to meet with guerrilla envoys. His disclosures came a day after Mr. Chvez, left, told reporters in Venezuela that he had met with leftist guerrillas at the request of Colombia's government. Mr. Chvez's comments touched off a flurry of criticism from foes who have long claimed that the Venezuelan leader supports the Marxist rebels. Mr. Chvez said the meetings were intended to help Colombia's troubled peace talks and to obtain the release of hostages. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: China Killing Birds to Curb Spread of Flu
description: China began killing tens of thousands of birds in three provinces Wednesday to curtail the spread of the deadly avian influenza, while Asian government officials holding an emergency meeting in Bangkok pledged better cooperation and openness, partly in response to criticism that the initial outbreak was mishandled.

title: State Accused of Reneging on Child Welfare
description: Two children's rights organizations said that they planned to file court papers today accusing the State of Connecticut of reneging on its agreement to let a federal monitor manage its troubled child-welfare system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEUBERGER, HENRY L.
description: NEUBERGER--Henry L., 82, Venice, FL, formerly of White Plains, NY, died January 23, 2004. Survivors include his wife, Lillian ''Mickey'', son, Henry III, daughters Joan and Lois, sister, Gloria Marienthal, and six grandchildren. Memorials may be made to the Plantation Community Foundation, 500 Rockley Boulevard, Venice, FL. 34293, or Hospice Foundation of SW Florida, 5955 Rand Boulevard, Sarasota, FL. 34238.

title: Does Anybody Really Know What Time It Is? Or Really Care?
description: One of childhood's milestones was learning how to tell time by deciphering the relationship between the clock's big hand and its little hand.

title: With Shelves So Handsome, Why Clutter Them With Books?
description: William Emmerson, who was born in Britain, was on his way 14 years ago to Panang, Malaysia, when he stopped off in Los Angeles. Now 37, he's still here. These days he has his own furniture store, Emmerson Troop. Above, eight-foot-wide shelves made of European seven-layer plywood with aluminum I-beam structural supports, after a similar piece by Jean Prouv; $4,200.

title: Crazylegs Hirsch, 80, Rams' Big-Play Receiver, Is Dead
description: Crazylegs Hirsch, the Hall of Fame receiver for the Los Angeles Rams' high-powered offenses of the early 1950's, died yesterday at an assisted-living facility in Madison, Wis. He was 80.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: School Janitors Win Legal Fight
description: A judge has voided two contracts between the City Department of Education and private building maintenance companies that serve more than 200 public schools, dealing a setback to the city's effort to expand school privatization. In a lawsuit filed by the school custodians' union, Local 891 of the International Union of Operating Engineers, the city was accused of violating competitive bidding practices in awarding contracts worth $60 million to two companies, Johnson Controls and Temco Service Industries, for cleaning and maintenance work in 228 schools. In a ruling this week, Justice Faviola Soto of State Supreme Court in Manhattan declared the contracts void and said the city had violated both state and city competitive-bidding laws. City education officials said they planned to appeal. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: From Mies' Pencil to Your Living Room
description: A collection of furniture based on drawings by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe is now in Knoll showrooms. The pieces, a lounge chair, settee, sofa, ottoman, benches and a square side table, were designed for the Lange and Esters houses in Krefeld, Germany, built in the late 1920's. The furniture has never before been in production. It was developed by KnollStudio in collaboration with the Museum of Modern Art from its Mies archives. The Krefeld chair, right, is $1,179 in fabric and $2,830 in leather, the architect's choice. The ottoman is from $900 and $1,697. Tables are $890 and $1,905. At all Knoll Showrooms; locations: www.knoll.com. In Santa Monica, 214 Wilshire Boulevard, (310) 289-5800. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: No Cameras In Bombing Trial
description: No photography will be permitted in the trial of Terry L. Nichols, a state judge ruled. The state is seeking the death penalty against Mr. Nichols, who is charged with 161 counts of murder in the bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City in 1995. Mr. Nichols, 48, whose trial begins March 1, is serving a life sentence for his conviction on federal charges. A second defendant, Timothy J. McVeigh, was executed in 2001.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Civil Rights Charges In Prostitution Case
description: Three brothers were indicted by a federal grand jury on civil rights charges of taking women to the Atlanta area from Mexico and forcing them into prostitution. Prosecutors say several women, the youngest 16 years old, were forced through violence and psychological coercion to have sex with numerous men each night. The brothers, Juan Reyes Rojas, 24, Jose Reyes Rojas, 26, and Raul Reyes Rojas, whose age was unknown, face more than 30 years in prison if they are convicted, the United States attorney's office said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Prewar arms stance was wrong, expert says
description: WASHINGTON:  David Kay, the former chief U.S. weapons inspector for Iraq, told a keenly attentive Senate hearing Wednesday that "we were almost all wrong" in believing before the war that Saddam Hussein possessed banned weapons.

title: U.S. Arrests 10 as Members of Big Cigarette Smuggling Ring
description: The cartons of cigarettes carried familiar brand names like Marlboro and Marlboro Lights, and would fetch as much as $70 each in New York City.

title: Dr. Gertie F. Marx, 91, A Pioneer in Her Specialty
description: Dr. Gertie F. Marx, a New York anesthesiologist who helped advance the use of modern epidural injections that ease women's pain during childbirth, died on Sunday at the Schervier Nursing Care Center in the Bronx, according to Dr. Jill M. Rabin, a friend and colleague. Dr. Marx was 91.

title: In Houston, Football Mania and a Shuttle Tribute
description: Did Commissioner Paul Tagliabue of the National Football League really say that? This week? In Houston? ''There are better things to do than playing football''?

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article and a picture caption on Tuesday about the Army's proposal to dispose of the nerve agent VX misidentified the substance that the DuPont Company would treat in southern New Jersey under an Army contract. It is hydrolysate, a nonlethal byproduct that will result when VX is neutralized at a depot in Indiana -- not the nerve agent itself.
