description: THE END OF BLACKNESS

title: Candidates' Schedules
description: WESLEY K. CLARK -- Oklahoma City; Rock Hill and Greenville, S.C.

title: Mortgage Index Declines
description: An index of mortgage applications fell for the first time in four weeks as interest rates edged higher and purchases dropped from a record, an industry group report showed yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 12 about the Stephen Foster Folk Culture Center State Park in White Springs, Fla., included an erroneous figure supplied by the center for its staff size. It has 15 members, not 17. The article also misstated the timing of budget cuts cited by a state parks specialist, Martha Nelson. They occurred before the administration of Gov. Jeb Bush, as well as during his tenure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OSNOS, BERNA
description: OSNOS--Berna, 73, youngest child of Charles and Jane Mayer of New York City. Always an extremely generous person to individuals and charity, her light of love will live on in her children, Simon and Noah, daughters-in-law Marsha and Annette, grandchildren Victor and Leah, devoted friends, and family. Her courage in battling and finally accepting her fate serves as a model for us all. A celebration of her life will be held on her birthday, February 7, for friends and family at the home of Simon Osnos in Cabin John, MD.

title: When Furnishings Say Family
description: IN 1997, when my marriage was ending, I thought a lot about a story by Andre Dubus (pre) that chronicled a man's adjustment to his divorce. Although he has acquired a new lover, his children are all he really cares about. But his apartment is small and dreary, so when they get together he mostly takes them out. Which is why, on a chilly winter's night he prolongs the too-brief visit with a long talk in his car. The next morning, the inside of the windshield is iced. And as he scrapes it clean, he realizes that ''the gray ice curling and falling from the glass was the frozen breath of his children.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Arrest In Two Killings
description: A Bronx man has been arrested in connection with two unrelated killings in the last two years, including that of a young woman who was found burned to death in a Brooklyn parking lot in May, police officials said yesterday. The man, Rafael Cajigas, 33, was charged with two counts of second-degree murder on Tuesday in the deaths of Taisha Camacho, 19, who the police said was his girlfriend, and Omar Pena, 21, an acquaintance who the police said Mr. Cajigas intentionally ran over with an S.U.V. on a Bronx street in February 2002. In both cases, the police said, Mr. Cajigas had a prior dispute with the victims. The police said they believed that Mr. Cajigas strangled Ms. Camacho in the Brooklyn apartment they shared at the time, then set her body on fire in a parking lot in Sunset Park. In the hit-and-run case, Mr. Pena and another man, Luis Turnbull, 28, were struck while walking on Westchester Avenue. Mr. Turnbull survived. Andrea Elliott (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Inside Art column of Weekend on Friday about a coming exhibition of Ralph Lauren's vintage cars at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston misstated the model of his 1938 Bugatti. It is a Type 57SC Atlantic Coupe, not Atlanta Coupe.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Forstmann Little & Co., New York, the leveraged buyout firm, plans to sell about one-fifth of its stake in Citadel Broadcasting Corp., Las Vegas, for about $400 million.

title: Kerry Plans to Continue Projecting Underdog Image
description: Taking his campaign nationwide, Senator John Kerry forecast on Wednesday a grueling contest for the presidency and promised to campaign ''with the same underdog mentality'' that carried him to overwhelming come-from-behind victories in Iowa and New Hampshire.

description: Correction Appended

title: U.S. Proposes Rules to End Tax-Avoidance Transactions
description: The Treasury moved yesterday to make it more difficult for large corporations to hide abusive tax-avoidance transactions. For the first time in decades, it proposed new rules governing the differences between the profits that companies report to shareholders and the (usually smaller) figures they report on their tax returns.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Trade Restrictions Eased
description: India announced a series of measures that would relax import duties and restrictions for several sectors of the economy in an attempt to increase exports. The government said it would eliminate duties on professional equipment for the services industry and on fuel for the manufacturing industry. Restrictions on gold and silver imports by jewelers and by bullion traders were also eased. The government hopes the measures help it meet a goal of a 12 percent increase in exports this year. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: On-Screen Box or Bar Unavoidably Tells All
description: Watch any football game, and you see some variation of it, as a box that dances between corners of the television screen or as a strip across the top. They are the urgent town criers of televised sports -- agile, multihued graphics that display scores, down and distance, the quarter, time remaining and flags thrown, a field goal's length, a touchdown scored or a coach's challenge.

title: Sugarbush Resort Is Reclaiming Some of Its Past Glory
description: At the Sugarbush Resort in central Vermont, which opened 45 years ago this winter, a celebrated history yields pride and a predicament.

description: To the Editor:

description: ROSENGARTEN -- Ida, on January 28, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Sol. Loving mother of Doris. Devoted grandmother of Kenn, Greg, & Doug. Great-grandmother of Matthew, Aaron, Nathaniel and Addi and brother Irving. We will miss you. Service on Friday, 12 noon, ''Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels'' 76th Road and Queens Blvd in Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EISEN, MILTON E., M.D.
description: EISEN--Milton E., M.D. The Mount Sinai Alumni express profound sorrow at the loss of our esteemed colleague and longtime friend. He will be missed. Our deepest condolences are extended to his entire family. William G. Stein, M.D., President Barry D. Stimmel, M.D. Vice President Elliot J. Rayfield, M.D. Secretary Betty J. Mintz, M.D., Treasurer

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Ratings Raised
description: Standard & Poor's raised the short-term rating on Shinsei Bank to A-2 from A-3, citing the bank's strong asset quality and funding. S.&P. left Shinsei's long-term rating unchanged at BBB. Shinsei, the first foreign-owned lender in Japan, will hold a public share offering on Feb. 19. In preparation for the offering, the bank reduced its nonperforming loans by 43 percent in the last nine months of 2003 and expected to earn 65 billion yen ($613 million) in the fiscal year ending this March. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MIHLRAD, JACK
description: MIHLRAD--Jack. 5/17/14-1/29/95. Nine years and your sweet presence is with us daily. Lovingly remembered, Diane and Mom

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PODOLSKY, SEYMOUR
description: PODOLSKY--Seymour. Milly, Charles, Alex and Tim offer our heartfelt sympathy to your wonderful family on this loss. You will always be remembered.

title: Advice From Someone Who Defeated a President Bush
description: Former President Bill Clinton, venturing on to Capitol Hill today to advise Democrats on election-year strategy, managed to combine praise for Senator John Kerry with a swipe at the Bush administration for ``taxing less and spending more.''

title: Forgoing Software For a Firewall You Can See
description: With worms and viruses -- not to mention malicious humans -- loose on the Internet, sitting down at your computer to do a little Web browsing can feel a bit like exposing yourself to the Sword of Damocles, that legendary blade suspended by a thread and a bit of luck. But a good shield can deflect many a sword, and hence comes AlphaShield, a hardware firewall said by its eponymous manufacturer to be ''100 percent unhackable'' and backed by a 100 percent money-back guarantee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEELE, WILLIAM H.
description: STEELE--William H., aged 76 years, on Sunday, January 25, 2004. He was the son of the late Sally and Paul Vining of West Springfield, MA and the brother of the late Pauline Van Wert of Spruce Head, ME. He attended the Choate School in CT and Yale University. He is survived by and lovingly remembered by his four nieces and nephews: George Van Wert of Richmond, KY, Susan Gonzalez of Fairfield, CT, Sally Glassbrook of Chapel Hill, NC, and Alan S. Van Wert of Portsmouth, ME. He is also survived by many grand-nieces and grand-nephews. Visitation Friday, January 30 from 3-7 PM at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue (70th Street), NYC. Interment services are private. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory preferred to the Actors' Fund of America, 729 7th Avenue, 10th Floor, New York, New York 10019.

title: A Morphing Map Gives Fire Chiefs the Big Picture
description: ''THIS is our replacement command board,'' Deputy Chief Vincent Mandala said, opening an 18-by-24-inch welded aluminum case standing on folding legs in the 11th Division station in downtown Brooklyn. ''The old one was destroyed on 9/11.''

title: No Luck at Third
description: Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman has made dozens of telephone calls to teams since learning about 10 days ago that third baseman Aaron Boone seriously injured his left knee playing pickup basketball. But soon after Cashman finishes dialing, he has repeatedly been greeted with frustrating news.

description: To the Editor:

title: High School Scientists of Tomorrow Compete for a Major Prize
description: If you get him going, Matan Harel, a 17-year-old senior at Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan, will talk your ear off about little blobs with tails. His obsession with the topic may explain why he was among the 40 students from 14 states and the District of Columbia announced yesterday as finalists for the prestigious Intel Science Talent Search, which presents an award often called the junior Nobel Prize.

title: A Japanese Avant-Gardist Who Also Loved Impressionism
description: The Japanese composer Toru Takemitsu had a peculiarly bifurcated career. From the late 1950's through the 1960's he was an avant-gardist who used clouds of dense, atonal harmonies - tempered by a hint of French-influenced Impressionism - to create tactile, spiky sound structures. By the mid-1970's, though, the Impressionist side had taken over. His late works could almost have been written by another composer, one given to supple, melodic writing that evokes the gentler forces of nature.

title: $4.5 Billion Award Set For Spill of Exxon Valdez
description: Fifteen years after the Exxon Valdez spilled 11 million gallons of crude oil into the Prince William Sound in Alaska, a federal judge yesterday imposed punitive damages of $4.5 billion on the Exxon Mobil Corporation. With interest, the total punitive award amounts to about $6.75 billion, according to lawyers for the 32,000 fishermen and residents who brought the suit in 1989.

title: A Countrified Hotel With an Exterior to Match
description: The Farmer's Daughter, a newly refurbished hotel opposite the popular Farmers' Market, started life as the Farmer's Daughter motel in 1961. In the 70's it spent some time as a Best Western, and now it has been reincarnated under new ownership and management.

title: Grand Proportions for Great Books
description: The Westchester-Loyola Village Branch Library, near the Los Angeles International Airport, is one of 32 new Los Angeles libraries. Its architect is Aleks Istanbullu of Santa Monica, Calif. The library, above, has a painted stucco exterior and is set in a newly created park. Inside, Mr. Istanbullu designed a 120-foot-long by 24-foot-high wood-paneled public area inspired, he said, by the Ste.-Genevive library in Paris. There are silk-screened images of local people by Jill D'Angenica on the walls and ceiling.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: European Commission Scolds France
description: The European Commission scolded France for not making enough effort to reduce its budget deficit. The commission said that the French government's budgetary plans lacked ambition, and it warned that France is set to break the deficit ceiling, intended to protect the euro, for the next three years. In reports on individual countries, the commission said Britain, Greece, Italy and the Netherlands also risk breaching the deficit ceiling, which is 3 percent of the gross domestic product. Paul Meller (NYT)

description: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Fed's monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to leave interest rates unchanged:

description: The awful part is that George W. Bush and Saddam Hussein were both staring into the same cracked spook- house mirror.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANDAU, RABBI SOL
description: LANDAU--Rabbi Sol. The Rabbinical Assembly mourns with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague, rabbi emeritus of Beth David Congregation in Miami and professor of psychology at Auburn University. We extend our deepest condolences to his family and to all who were touched through his rabbinate.

title: Eye for the Family With 2 Mommies or 2 Daddies
description: A double take is understandable. It's not every day a lesbian of such eclectic attributes -- Kelli Carpenter O'Donnell meshes Sharon Stone-esque platinum punk chic with peachy keen Southern belle manners -- sinks into a leather chair beneath a theater poster featuring a male with unmistakable cleavage, and a titillating title, ''Taboo, '' then calmly dissects her life and partnership with the beleaguered celebrity she calls ''Ro.'' As in Rosie O'Donnell, of talk show, comedy, courtroom, theater, film and, starting with a July cruise to the Bahamas, travel service repute. In a shared business venture, Rosie and Kelli O'Donnell are promoting R Family Vacations, which caters to a gay and lesbian clientele -- and their offspring.

title: Looking for Intel on the Intel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  Since the fall of Saddam Hussein, a burning question here is how the C.I.A. could have gotten the intelligence about Iraq so wrong.

title: National Briefing: Mid-Atlantic
description: PENNSYLVANIA: CAFETERIA TABLE SETTLEMENT The mother of a Philadelphia kindergartner who died after a folded cafeteria table fell on him has settled a lawsuit against the table's manufacturer, Midwest Folding Products of Chicago, for $10 million. Midwest, a unit of Sagus International, has discontinued the table, but thousands are still in use in schools around the nation, said a lawyer for the 5-year-old boy's mother, Angeline M. Uberti. (AP)

title: The Neediest Cases; Recounting the Blessings of Life as Well as Its Battles
description: For Joy Persaud, 49, of East New York, Brooklyn, the trouble starts when she hears a noise in her head. In those moments, no matter where she is, she sits on the floor, arms crossed, and waits for a seizure. Ms. Persaud has epilepsy, and three to five times a week the seizures come. Though this has been her life for five years, she remains fearless and upbeat. In the summertime, she has cookouts every week for her neighbors.

title: Over There; Catching the Big Game by Satellite Feed in Iraq
description: SATELLITES have long brought live broadcasts of the Super Bowl to American troops stationed overseas. But because the military has a limited number of satellite decoders, live broadcasts of the game could only be watched by off-duty troops at a few locations, like mess halls and operations centers.

title: New Conductor Guides Data Along the Fiber Optic Route
description: A CONVENTIONAL fiber optic cable that transmits telephone signals over long distances is a lot like a garden hose. Instead of water, though, light pours through it, contained by its walls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUTENPLAN, DANIEL, ESQ.
description: GUTENPLAN--Daniel, Esq. On January 28th, 2004. Beloved husband of Roz for 53 years, devoted father of Susan and Jayne and father-inlaw of Allan and Ed. Poppa D to Eric, Ethan, Gregg and Melanie. Services on Friday, at 11 A.M. at Gutterman's, Boca Raton. Sunday graveside at New Montefiore.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Sect Sues Minister
description: Four members of the spiritual movement Falun Gong filed a complaint in a Paris court against the Chinese culture minister, Sun Jiazheng, who is visiting France with the Chinese president, Hu Jintao. The members charge that Mr. Sun is responsible for torture they say they suffered at the hands of the Chinese police. China has banned the movement and has used harsh measures to suppress its spread on the mainland. But it is unlikely that the complaint will result in any action. Mr. Sun is scheduled to leave France today. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Pakistani Scientist Is Focus Of Atomic Sale Investigation
description: Pakistani officials said Wednesday that their investigation into the sale of the nation's nuclear technology to Iran had now focused on Abdul Qadeer Khan, the father of Pakistan's atomic bomb, and that a ''security ring'' had been set up around his house five days ago to keep him from leaving the country.

title: Mad Cow Disease Raises Safety Issues Beyond the Kitchen
description: Cows are everywhere, and they are not just for dinner anymore.

title: Corrections
description: Two reports in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day yesterday, about quarterly results for Xerox and SBC Communications, carried incorrect credits. They were by Reuters, not Bloomberg News.

title: Sports of The Times; Pioli Prefers the Back Seat In the Patriots' Front Office
description: SHOULD the New England Patriots win their second Super Bowl in three years Sunday, do not expect their front-office guru to make the late-night talk rounds or become the subject of best-selling nonfiction. Operating as the stealth administrator between coach and cast, the rock and a hard cap, Scott Pioli asserted yesterday that there was no place in football for a front-office celebrity, for the equivalent of Billy Beane.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Fairfield: New University President
description: The dean of Fordham College at Rose Hill, the original undergraduate division of Fordham University in the Bronx, has been named president of Fairfield University. The dean, the Rev. Jeffrey P. von Arx, 56, an associate professor of history, will succeed the Rev. Aloysius P. Kelley on July 1. Father von Arx, left, a graduate of Princeton and Yale Universities and a scholar of 19th-century British history, has worked at Fordham since 1998. Father Kelley, 74, who was university president for 25 years, announced in October that he would retire at the end of this academic year. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Home-Court Advantage Fades With St. John's
description: Maybe one game St. John's guards Elijah Ingram and Daryll Hill will combine the way they were expected to in the preseason. And maybe Grady Reynolds will dominate inside in that same game, and Kyle Cuffe and Abe Keita will play up to their potential.

description: THERE is a quiet waiting quality to the winter garden, especially these last few frozen weeks, when boots squeak on the snow and birdbaths are solid ice.

title: Bush Visits New Hampshire After Primary to Praise Tax Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  President Bush traveled to New Hampshire today, perhaps to take some attention from the Democratic presidential candidates and definitely to remind the state's people of his tax-cutting agenda.

description: Prosecutors in Queens suggested yesterday that a city correction officer killed her father in 2001 so she could seize the family's million-dollar fortune.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Parmalat Rescue Endorsed
description: The European competition commissioner, Mario Monti, said after an initial examination, that Italy's proposed new insolvency law for large companies facing bankruptcy, like the dairy group Parmalat, did not pose any problems under unionwide government aid laws. The new law, known as the Marzano Decree, allows for quicker procedures for adopting a restructuring plan of any Italian company with more than 1,000 employees and debt of more than 1 billion euros. He said he would re-examine the law once it had been passed by the Italian Parliament.

title: Invitation By Governor Unnerves Lawmakers
description: Gov. John G. Rowland has invited all 71 Republicans in the legislature to his residence on the eve of his annual State of the State Address next week, but several members said on Wednesday that the invitation was inappropriate and that they would not attend, citing the current legislative inquiry that could lead to the governor's impeachment.

title: California Lottery Selects 5 Finalists
description: The California Lottery Commission has named five finalists in the latest review for its account, with a four-year contract and total billings estimated at $100 million. The review is the third in less than two years, after the results of previous reviews were nullified when some participants protested.

title: Kerry and Edwards Face A Critical Test in the South
description: Senator John Kerry expected the endorsement of a prominent African-American congressman in the fight for South Carolina and has vowed to local political leaders that he will not abandon the South in the fall should he become the Democratic presidential nominee.

title: J.P. MORGAN CHASE AND BANK ONE EXCHANGE OPTIONS
description: J.P. Morgan Chase & Company and the Bank One Corporation granted each other options to buy up to 19.9 percent of their outstanding common stock in connection with their pending merger, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The options granted by Bank One have an exercise price of $44.61 a share, while the options granted by J.P. Morgan have an exercise price of $38.90 a share. The holder of the option may exercise it, in whole or part, if the deal is terminated for a variety of reasons, the filing said. The companies also revealed in the filing that the value of the termination fee for the deal is $2.3 billion, which is equal to the previously reported fee of 4 percent.

title: A Suicide Bomber Kills 3 in Baghdad
description: A suicide bomber driving an ambulance blew himself up Wednesday morning in downtown Baghdad, shearing the facade off a hotel, killing at least 3 people and wounding more than 15.

title: FIDELITY NATIONAL TO BUY SANCHEZ COMPUTER
description: Fidelity National Inc., the title insurer, agreed to buy Sanchez Computer Associates Inc. for about $184 million in cash and stock, the latest acquisition that the company has made to add financial services operations. Fidelity said it would pay $3.25 in cash and $3.25 in stock for each Sanchez share. The offer represents a 16 percent premium to Sanchez's closing price of $5.60 on Tuesday. Sanchez, which is based in Malvern, Pa., provides computer services to about 400 companies worldwide. It will become a subsidiary of Fidelity National's information services unit. Fidelity, based in Jacksonville, Fla., began offering software and other services to mortgage companies in April after buying a software unit of the Alltel Corporation for $1.05 billion in cash and stock.

description: To the Editor:

title: Phones, Too, Get TV Time
description: WHEN gadget lovers are young, it doesn't take much to give them dilated pupils and sweaty palms. You just whisper into their ears, ''Batteries included.'' But as they grow older, it takes more and more to give them the same thrill. For a while, the term ''remote-controlled'' satisfies them, before they move on to such potent concepts as ''flat panel,'' ''six-megapixel'' and ''64-bit multiprocessor.'' But once they've tasted the honey of ''wireless broadband,'' how will they top it?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUCA, MARY K. (NEE TAVELLI)
description: LUCA--Mary K. (nee Tavelli). Died late on Tuesday January 27, 2004 at her home in Yonkers after a prolonged illness. Mary leaves four loving children: two daughters, Barbara Dodd and Joan Leibowitz, two sons, Robert and Paul Luca, and four adoring grandchildren, Tom Dodd, Jeremiah and Tim Leibowitz and Kimberly Luca. Mary was born and lived in Williamstown, Massachusetts, until she moved to New York, where she attended college, taught and married. After raising her family, Mary spent 18 years as the Administrator of the Medical Office at Barnard College in New York City, and served as a volunteer at the Veteran's Hospital in the Bronx. After her retirement, she continued to work part time, traveled, and became a Master Bridge player. Visitation will be Friday at Flynn Memorial Home in Yonkers from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM. A funeral mass will be celebrated at St. Eugene's Roman Catholic Church in Yonkers at 10AM on Saturday. Mary will then be laid to rest on Monday after a service at the Eastlawn Cemetery Chapel in Williamstown, Massachusetts.

title: Senate Passes A Bill to Cover Pension Plans
description: The Senate overwhelmingly passed legislation yesterday that would save companies an estimated $80 billion on their pension contributions over the next two years, but it was unclear whether the Bush administration would support the measure.

description: Twenty years after the Super Bowl first became as big a day for advertising as it is for professional football, Madison Avenue is gearing up for what looks to be a cheerier, somewhat sillier and certainly more expensive version of the annual midwinter festival of commercialism.

title: Raiders Hire Jets Assistant
description: Jimmy Raye, who joined the Jets' offensive staff in 2002, was hired by the Oakland Raiders yesterday as their offensive coordinator and assistant head coach.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Berlusconi Acknowledges Eye Tuck
description: Silvio Berlusconi, Italy's seemingly rejuvenated prime minister, said all the observers who spied a taut difference around his eyes were indeed noticing a strategic nip. But Mr. Berlusconi, in remarks at a party in Rome for Italian fashion designers, insisted that his recent adventures in elective surgery did not include any other parts of his face or body, according to The Associated Press. An Italian newsweekly has reported that Mr. Belusconi, 67, received a more extreme makeover. His aides have declined to comment, but they deny speculation that his recent absence from public view was because of illness.

title: For Her, U.S. Borders Are Profit Centers
description: All Lurita Doan had to do was sign on the bottom line. It was early 2000, and Ms. Doan, who had founded New Technology Management 10 years earlier, had just been offered what some entrepreneurs in her field might consider the opportunity of a lifetime: a $22 million contract to supply hardware to the government.

title: After Victories, Kerry Focuses on Jobs in South Carolina
description: Senator John Kerry campaigned in South Carolina today on top of victories in Iowa and New Hampshire and an endorsement from the state's most prominent black Democrat, Representative James E. Clyburn.

description: GERSHWIN--Sam. Remembering you on your birthday, January 29. Your daughter Vicki Amster misses you.

title: Elephants Can't Fly
description: A year ago, at the Davos World Economic Forum, I saw elephants fly. Yes, sir, right here in the Swiss Alps I saw big ideas defying gravity. At this year's Davos forum, though, all the elephants came crashing down. Turns out elephants can't fly after all -- and the world is a better place for it.

description: MANY American computer programmers complain that they're losing their jobs to lower-paid workers in India. The trend toward foreign ''outsourcing'' has become a political flashpoint.

description: As a youngster of varied talents, Tedy Bruschi had to choose between a life as a football player and a life as a jazz musician. Not a bad choice for a boy.

description: PRODUCTS that can transmit video, audio and other digital media throughout the house were everywhere at the annual Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas this month. But most of them are either not yet on the market or rather expensive.

title: Health Agency Must Reform or Die, Nassau Says
description: Nassau County's financially ailing health care agency needs to lay off more workers, drop its specialized services and strip down its hospital to stave off financial collapse, county officials said on Wednesday.

title: Security Poor in Electronic Voting Machines, Study Warns
description: Electronic voting machines made by Diebold Inc. that are widely used in several states have such poor computer security and physical security that an election could be disrupted or even stolen by corrupt insiders or determined outsiders, according to a new report presented today to Maryland state legislators.

title: Testing Two Leaders; George Bush, in Denial
description: While Tony Blair was cooperating with a British investigation into his handling of the lead-up to the Iraqi invasion, the Bush White House continued to follow its strategy of spin and evade. Because Mr. Blair was compelled to take the risk that objective investigators would find that he had acted honorably and honestly, Britain is now able to move on to the next logical step -- finding out why its intelligence was so completely wrong. Americans, however, are still stuck in stage one. President Bush needs to move things forward by starting -- or allowing Congress to start -- an independent investigation that goes beyond the British inquiry and looks into all aspects of the apparent intelligence failures on Iraq.

Norges Bank, whose mandate is to maintain stable price increases, trimmed its benchmark deposit rate a quarter percentage point to an all-time low of 2 percent, putting it in line with the main rate of the European Central Bank for the first time.

Weiner's announcement that he was forming an exploratory campaign committee for the 2005 mayoral election in New York misstated the location of the 48th City Council District, which he once represented. It was in Brooklyn, not Queens.

title: Bloomberg, Looking to Convention, Restrains Cheer for Bush
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has entertained President Bush at his home, and once made the optimistic claim that Mr. Bush could carry New York City in the next election. But that does not mean that Mr. Bloomberg plans to spend his time at the Republican National Convention this summer screaming his support for the president.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: RWANDA: TRIBUNAL'S DEFENSE LAWYERS STRIKE Lawyers defending suspects facing charges in the 1994 genocide in Rwanda began a three-day strike. The lawyers said they backed a list of defendant demands, including rights to bail, to subpoena defense witnesses, and to know the identity of prosecution witnesses sometimes protected by the international court, based in Tanzania. (Reuters)

title: HALLIBURTON GETS $575 MILLION ASBESTOS SETTLEMENT
description: Halliburton, the oil field services company, will receive $575 million from Equitas to settle insurance claims against underwriters at Lloyd's of London that are reinsured by Equitas, the companies said last night. The settlement will resolve asbestos-related claims made against Lloyd's underwriters by Halliburton, the companies said. Equitas was created to pay some of Lloyd's nonlife liabilities. The agreement depends on final confirmation of the bankruptcy plan for the reorganization of several Halliburton affiliates.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Warning On Microsoft Antitrust Case
description: Time is running out for a settlement between the European Commission and Microsoft in the long-running antitrust case, said Mario Monti, left, the European commissioner for competition. ''We are not against a settlement, if that is clearly in consumers' interests, but the time is running out,'' he said yesterday. A draft ruling that brands Microsoft an abusive monopolist is being circulated internally within the commission, before it is shown to national competition regulators for comments next month. A final decision is expected in March or April. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TANDY, MILDRED FICKEN
description: TANDY--Mildred Ficken died in her sleep January 23. Born February 19, 1920 in Manhattan where her family had lived since the 1840s, she grew up on Riverside Drive while attending the Barnard School for Girls and Manhattanville College. She married Russell H. Tandy Jr. in 1942 and together they raised three boys in Westfield, N.J. Blessed with a sharp mind and vivacious personality, she was an active member of St. Paul's Church in Westfield, Christ Memorial Chapel in Hobe Sound, Planned Parenthood, and the Jupiter Island Garden Club. She is survived by her sons Russell III, Spencer, and David and grandchildren Napper, Catherine, Corinne, and Peter. There will be a memorial service this spring on Jupiter Island.

She was a member of Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, NY. She is survived by one son, David and his wife Brandy of Eustis, ME, two daughters, Judy and husband Michael Brack of Seattle, WA and Susan Teicher of Victoria, B.C. Public graveside services will be held Friday 11AM at the New Montefiore Cemetery with Rabbi Widom officiating.

It has been known to lunch on rinkhals, a cousin of the cobra. It has attacked lions and even elephants when provoked. Kermit would disown it.

His thoughts drifted to the day he visited this very museum with his mother when he was 8. A watercolor seascape painted by John Marin had struck him in particular, he said.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: One Dead In Clash Near U.S. Consulate
description: One person was killed and several others injured in a clash between the police, supporters of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide and antigovernment marchers near the American Consulate in Port-au-Prince. Demonstrators had gathered outside the consulate, where they burned a coffin and called for the ouster of Mr. Aristide. As the demonstrators were leaving, rock-throwing Aristide supporters confronted them. The police fired warning shots and tear gas to disperse the crowd. Hospital officials said the man who was killed died when he was struck in the chest by a tear-gas canister. A spokeswoman for the consulate said the office closed because of the unrest but that officials hoped to re-open it today. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: POP: DOBIE GRAY ON TOP
description: After a remarkably diverse show-business career, the 63-year-old singer and songwriter Dobie Gray, left, at last has his first No. 1 single with a remake of his classic, bittersweet 1973 pop hit ''Drift Away.'' The new version, which returned to the No. 1 spot on the Billboard adult contemporary chart in the Jan. 31 issue and has lingered on the chart for an astonishing 46 weeks, is a duet teaming Mr. Gray with Uncle Kracker, the longtime Kid Rock sideman. It has been 39 years since Mr. Gray, born Lawrence Darrow Brown in Texas and nicknamed after the 1960's television character Dobie Gillis, first reached the pop Top 20 with the soulful '' 'In' Crowd.'' Since then he has had many record deals with mixed success; moved to Los Angeles to be a movie star (acting instead in the theatrical production of ''Hair''); relocated to Nashville in 1978 to become a country singer and songwriter, and wrote with George Reneau a No. 1 country hit for John Conlee (''Got My Heart Set On You,'' 1986). But like most black artists (except Charley Pride and briefly Ray Charles), Mr. Gray ran into a brick wall with Nashville executives and country radio programmers. In a music world becoming ever more diverse, Mr. Gray sees country's de facto whites-only approach as severely outdated. ''It kills the industry,'' he said in an interview. ''I think that's why the country market is kind of in limbo. It needs a new infusion. I'm not saying it needs to be a black artist, but it needs something new.'' PHIL SWEETLAND

title: BRAZILIAN FARMERS TO PAY MONSANTO FOR SOYBEAN SEEDS
description: Brazilian farmers have agreed to pay royalties to the Monsanto Company for use of its genetically engineered soybean seeds. Monsanto said it had reached a preliminary agreement with farm associations in the southern state of Rio Grande do Sul, the only state where genetically modified soy is widely grown. The farmers' associations said they were still working out final details, but in principle agreed to pay royalties. The deal foresees royalties of 20 reais ($7) per metric ton for the 2004 and 2005 harvests. For crops just harvested, the charge would be as low as 10 reais ($3.50) a metric ton, Monsanto said. For years, the company complained that farmers in the state were using seeds developed with its Roundup Ready technology without paying royalties. The seeds were initially smuggled from Argentina. Tony Smith (NYT)

Many reporters are finding that the more equipment they can merge the better, and the less to lose. This makes a device like the Handspring Treo 600, a combination telephone, keyboard, organizer, digital camera, MP3 player and more, very appealing. Newer and faster do not always mean lighter or more streamlined.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: New Version Of Virus Appears
description: A new version of the MyDoom virus has appeared, and it tries just as hard as the first one to live up to its name. MyDoom is the fastest-spreading computer virus to date, with some 300,000 infected computers and 160,000 virus-bearing e-mail messages zinging across the Internet every hour, said Craig Schmugar, a virus researcher for Network Associates. He and other virus experts said it will program infected computers to start an online attack on Sunday against SCO Group, which sells the Unix operating system. The new version will begin a similar attack against Microsoft, and blocks access to antivirus online sites that could help users protect against the malicious software, as well as some online advertising sites. The goal of the programmer behind the worms, said Mr. Schmugar, appears to be creating a large population of machines that can be controlled remotely for such purposes as sending spam and diverting online advertising traffic. The new version contains a comment within its lines of code, ''andy: I'm just doing my job, nothing personal, sorry.'' John Schwartz (NYT)

title: Bush Scaling Back Dollars for Third World
description: President Bush plans to scale back requests for money to fight AIDS and poverty in the third world, putting off for several years the fulfillment of his pledges to eventually spend more than $20 billion on these programs.

title: A West Wind Kisses Marrakesh
description: TEN minutes outside the red clay walls of this 950-year-old city, an asphalt avenue abruptly gives way to rutted dirt. Dusty goats saunter by, and a date palm grows inconveniently in the middle of the narrow road like a giant feather duster. Houses hunker down amid hills of cactus. Don't be fooled by the apparent desolation. Here in the Palmeraie, a date-palm forest of nearly 30,000 acres that has become a blue-chip suburb, is the latest evidence that a new generation of designers is teaching old Marrakesh new tricks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARX, GERTIE F., MD.
description: MARX--Gertie F., MD. The Administration, Community Advisory Boards, Auxiliaries, and Medical Staff of Jacobi Medical Center mourn the death of Dr. Gertie F. Marx, Professor Emerita of Anesthesiology at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY, and longtime Anesthesia attending at Jacobi Center of the North Bronx Healthcare Network. An exceptional clinician, researcher, and teacher, Dr. Marx devoted her professional career to the provision of safe and effective methods of pain relief during labor and delivery. She is considered the ''mother of obstetric anesthesia,'' and the Gertie Marx Spinal Needle continues as the standard used today for administration of the epidural block used during labor. Her efforts to improve the care of mothers and their babies during childbirth have earned her worldwide recognition, respect, and admiration. Her passing is a sad loss to the medical community, and our hearts go out to her family and to all those who loved her. The Administration of the North Bronx Healthcare Network (NBHN); The Community Advisory Boards of the NBHN; The Auxiliaries of the NBHN; The NBHN Department of Anesthesia

title: Dirty and Broken Bathrooms Make for a Long School Day

At the High School for Health Professions and Human Services in Manhattan, leaky bathroom ceilings prompt students to head for McDonald's, or hold out for hours.

title: WATERS, A LAB EQUIPMENT MAKER, TO ACQUIRE NUGENESIS
description: The Waters Corporation, which makes laboratory equipment, agreed to acquire the closely held NuGenesis Technologies Corporation for $43 million. NuGenesis sells software to help scientists organize data. The acquisition, which is expected to close in the first quarter, will not affect Waters's earnings, the company said. Waters is based in Milford, Mass., and NuGenesis is based in Westborough, Mass.

title: SHARES PLUNGE FOR VISX, A MAKER OF VISION LASERS
description: Visx Inc., a maker of vision-correcting lasers, said first-quarter earnings probably would be less than analysts had expected, setting off a 23 percent decline in its share price. First-quarter earnings will be 18 cents to 20 cents a share, Visx said after markets closed Tuesday. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected the company to earn 21 cents a share. Visx, which earned 11 cents a share in the first quarter 2003, is experiencing more competition for its customized laser eye surgery device. Stock in Visx, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., fell $6.09, to $20.01 a share.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: PeopleSoft Profit Falls As Costs Rise
description: PeopleSoft, a business software maker that is fighting a takeover bid by Oracle, said yesterday that profit fell as costs rose 52 percent, dwarfing a 34 percent sales increase. Net income fell to $17.4 million, or 5 cents a share, from $57.4 million, or 18 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales rose to $685.2 million, from $512.3 million. PeopleSoft said that excluding some costs, profit would have been 20 cents a share, matching the average estimate of 34 analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Sales beat the analysts' forecast for $654 million. Shares of PeopleSoft fell as much as $1.37, or 6 percent, to $21.62 in after-hours trading. They dropped 4 cents, to $22.99, in regular trading.

title: A Surging Kerry Is Not Up to Speed on the 'Electric Slide'
description: John Kerry may have leapt into the lead in the Democratic presidential race, but he apparently needs to work on his "Electric Slide" group dance.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Nintendo Cuts Profit Forecast
description: The Nintendo Company cut its profit forecast for the year that ends in March, citing weak sales of its video games in Japan. The company expects to earn 54 billion yen ($509 million) this fiscal year, 10 percent less than expected earlier. Nintendo also trimmed its sales goal by 7 percent, to 510 billion yen ($4.8 billion). Ken Belson (NYT)

description: Electronic voting machines from Diebold Inc. have computer security and physical security problems that might allow corrupt insiders or determined outsiders to disrupt or even steal an election, according to a report presented yesterday to Maryland state legislators.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, IRVING J.
description: COHEN--Irving J., 95, died January 27, 2004 in Lauderhill, FL. Loving father of Beth A. Cohen, devoted husband of the late Mildred B. Cohen, cherished uncle to the Glogower, Rosen, Blank and Friedland families. Dear friend of the late Bess Kirschner and Jessie Schifrin. Remembered with love and admiration by family and friends. Graveside service Sunday, February 1, 1:00 PM, New Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

title: A Frenchman on the Lam, Out to Settle Old Scores
description: Lucas Belvaux's ''Trilogy,'' whose first part opens today in New York, tells three overlapping stories in succession, going back over some of the same events and showing them from different points of view. This fragmented, looping approach to storytelling might once have seemed radical, but after ''Pulp Fiction'' (and ''Run Lola Run'' and ''Go'' and ''Amores Perros'' and so on and so on) it has become a convention, a hallmark of what film historians of the future will most likely identify as a curious turn-of-the-century style.

description: Correction Appended

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Sex Offender Sweep
description: Federal agents arrested 29 illegal immigrants with sex crime convictions throughout Westchester County yesterday as part of a federal crackdown on sex offenders. The arrests came after months of planning between the United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency and the Westchester County Department of Probation. Sex offenders who are illegal immigrants or legal permanent residents can be deported if convicted of a felony. Those arrested included a Mexican citizen who had abused his 4- and 7-year-old nieces and a Peruvian citizen who had raped a 14-year-old girl, officials said. Lisa W. Foderaro (NYT)

title: USA Today Orders Outside Inquiry on Ex-Correspondent's Work
description: USA Today said yesterday that it had appointed a panel of three outside journalists to review every article written since 1982 by Jack Kelley, the longtime foreign correspondent who resigned this month after the newspaper found he had misled editors conducting an internal investigation of his work.

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC AGREES TO SELL PULP BUSINESSES TO KOCH
description: Georgia-Pacific, the paper and lumber maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its pulp businesses in Georgia and Mississippi to Koch Industries for about $537 million. Koch, a closely held company based in Wichita, Kan., will also assume $73 million in debt, Georgia-Pacific said. Included in the sale is a mill in New Augusta, Miss.; a mill in Brunswick, Ga.; and the assets of two international sales offices. Georgia-Pacific said it would apply a charge of $106 million to its 2003 fourth-quarter results to write down the value of the assets being sold.

title: Wait Till You Hear What Makes Those Doughnuts So Good
description: Chris Rock has become one of the best and most beloved comedians in the country by mastering one specific thing. He's not much of a storyteller, and he moves so little that he can get through an entire show without unbuttoning his jacket. But he is a brilliant curmudgeon, railing against the petty (and not-so-petty) fraudulence of everyday life. At the Theater at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, he delivered a series of mostly pitch-perfect rants, glazing his irritability with a fine layer of glee.

title: Democratic Contenders Attack Bush on Iraq, Terrorism, Trade and Economy
description: The Democratic presidential contenders attacked President Bush on Thursday for his handling of Iraq and terrorism and for his stance on trade and the economy and insisted that their party would be able to compete against him in the South.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Plane Bombs Chad Side Of Border
description: In a battle against rebel insurgency in the western Darfur area, a Sudanese plane bombed a border town in neighboring Chad, killing 2 civilians and 15 others, a United Nations official said. The official said it was the first time since war broke out a year ago between the Sudanese government and guerillas in Darfur that Chadian territory had been bombed. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ACCENTURE, Hamilton, Bermuda, the management and technology consultant, said it had agreed to manage purchasing for Deutsche Bank, Frankfurt. Terms were estimated at $250 million over seven years.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Archdiocese Reaches A Settlement
description: The Archdiocese of Boston has reached a settlement with the children of a woman who clergy personnel files show was left alone by a priest as she overdosed on barbiturates in 1973 and died the next day. According to the files, released in December 2002, the woman, Rita Perry, had been involved in a 13-year relationship with the priest, the Rev. James D. Foley. Tests show that Father Foley, who was removed in 2002, fathered two of Ms. Perry's four children. Details of the settlement were not released, but Archbishop Sean O'Malley apologized to Ms. Perry's children. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Pleads Guilty In Shooting
description: A man accused of fatally shooting his girlfriend in a Times Square hotel room during a dispute over money pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court to first-degree manslaughter, the district attorney's office said. Prosecutors said the man, Richard Jenkins, 49, of Portland, Ore., shot his girlfriend, Elizabeth Forman, 45, of Media, Pa., on Jan. 13, 2003, inside a room at the DoubleTree Guest Suites. The couple had met at a New York convention for the cult television show ''Dark Shadows.'' Mr. Jenkins had given Ms. Forman about $95,000 because she said she needed it, the authorities said, but he later concluded that she had been defrauding him. Justice Bonnie Wittner said she would sentence Mr. Jenkins to 25 years in prison on Feb. 26. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The beveled glass windows and door with fanciful wood strips are so unusual that the casual passer-by wants to know what is behind them. The banner flying above the door, emblazoned with ''Terra 47,'' gives no hint.

title: BLACK & DECKER TO CLOSE 2 PLANTS AND CUT 900 JOBS
description: Black & Decker, the power tool maker, said yesterday that it would close plants in Oklahoma and Arizona and cut 900 jobs, or 4 percent of its work force, as part of a cost-saving program. The company recorded in the fourth quarter $10 million in costs related to the closing of a Kwikset lock plant in Bristow, Okla., and the cutting of 750 jobs. Black & Decker will begin moving production in the second quarter and close the factory by the end of 2005, a spokeswoman said. It will also close a Weiser Lock office and distribution plant in Tucson, Ariz., cutting about 150 jobs.

title: Whoever Is Chosen, Democrats Spoil for a Fight
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  The struggle for the Democratic presidential nomination is not just about personalities and programs, but also about the direction  maybe even the soul  of the party. While still very much a work in progress, the Democratic Party emerging from Iowa and New Hampshire is different from the careful centrism of the Clinton era.

description: The Bush administration said on Thursday that the new Medicare law offering prescription drug benefits and private health plans to the elderly would cost at least $530 billion over 10 years, or one-third more than the price tag used when Congress passed the legislation two months ago.

description: PARIS, Jan. 30  In a stunning blow to President Jacques Chirac and the future of his ruling party, the former prime minister Alain Juppe was found guilty today of illegal party financing of a fake jobs scheme, a move that could bar him from running for president in 2007.

title: Agassi's Australian Exit Has Feel of a Final Bow
description: It certainly looked like a farewell gesture Thursday night. Andre Agassi does not typically blow kisses and bow to the crowd unless he wins a match. He lost this one in five sets, and considering how well Marat Safin had served and returned and hustled in their Australian Open semifinal, there was no shame in losing, no glaring reason for Agassi to question whether he still belongs at the highest level.

description: Who knew? All those philosophers and scientists and theoreticians and composers who believed in the ancient notion of a Music of the Spheres were onto something. There is such a music, and it's the note of B flat.

title: The Spread of Avian Influenza
description: The number of countries reporting avian influenza in their bird flocks has grown at an alarming rate in recent weeks, increasing the risk that sooner or later a mutant strain of bird flu may set off a human pandemic. So far 11 people in Vietnam and Thailand have caught bird flu from exposure to chickens, and 8 of those have died. The good news is that no case spread from one human to another has yet been documented. But if the virus spreads widely among poultry, exposing more people to infection from contact with the birds, the odds will go up that it may mutate to become more transmissible among humans. An immediate infusion of Western expertise and money is needed to head off that potential calamity.

title: Albany Pact Would Refinance Co-op City
description: Co-op City, the sprawling apartment complex in the Bronx, has reached a $475 million agreement with the state to refinance its crushing debt and to receive new loans to fix its crumbling facades, broken windows and collapsing parking garages.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Young Killer Pleads Guilty
description: Lionel Tate, the teenager whose life sentence for killing a girl when he was 12 was overturned last month, pleaded guilty to second-degree murder in a deal that allowed his immediate release. Lionel , who turns 17 on Friday, was tried and convicted as an adult in 2001 for killing Tiffany Eunick, 6. Under the plea bargain, Lionel, who has spent three years in a juvenile prison, faces a year of house arrest and 10 years of probation. During the plea hearing, Deweese Eunick-Paul, Tiffany's mother, said, ''My wish is that Lionel will grow up and not hurt any other human being.'' Abby Goodnough (NYT)

description: Taiwan said it was suspending high-level government exchanges with France to protest President Jacques Chirac's criticism of the island's planned referendum on missile defense. Mr. Chirac made the comments while serving as host to the Chinese president, Hu Jintao.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Testimony In Abuse Case Limited
description: No testimony will be allowed at hearings about an accusation that a former deputy county executive sexually assaulted his assistant, the Nassau County Legislature's presiding officer, Judith A. Jacobs, said last night. Ms. Jacobs, a Democrat, said that the legislature's Republican minority wanted to call witnesses who dealt with the complaint when hearings resume here on Monday into irregularities in the agencies run by the accused former deputy, Peter Sylver. But the county district attorney's office is investigating the assault accusation and asked that legislators refrain from taking testimony, she said. Mr. Sylver's lawyer has denied the accusation. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

description: In an effort to reach young people who dropped out of high school or were pushed out because they had fallen behind, the New York City Department of Education published ads yesterday in 27 newspapers inviting them to re-enroll.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEYN, ETHEL KENYON
description: HEYN--Ethel Kenyon. Loving wife of the late Ernest Heyn, adored mother of Dalma and the late Suzy Lochridge. Beloved mother-in-law of Richard Marek and Willard Lochridge and grandmother of Diana, Christie and Julie. Died at home in New York on January 22, 2004 at age 99. Star of movies in the 1930s, Effie's unique beauty and wit endured throughout her life and continue as an indelible memory to her family and friends. Without her radiance, the world is a little darker.

title: Corrections

title: A Throwback Leads Surging Pitt
description: Earlier this week, after a practice, Carl Krauser wore a black shirt with the word Throwbacks above color pictures of retired basketball stars like Michael Jordan, Larry Bird and Julius Erving. But the one Krauser pointed to was in the lower left corner: Isiah Thomas.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: 9/11 PRISONER SEEKS RETRIAL Lawyers for Mounir el-Moutassadeq, the only person convicted of involvement in the Sept. 11 terror attacks, asked Germany's highest court to overturn the verdict, and the court said it would decide by March 4 whether to order a retrial. Mr. Motassadeq, a Moroccan, was sentenced to 15 years last February for helping the Qaeda cell in Hamburg that produced three of the Sept. 11 pilots. The trial of a second Moroccan charged as an accessory to the attacks, Abdelghani Mzoudi, is to hear testimony today from a man described as an Iranian defector who has told German investigators he has information incriminating Mr. Mzoudi. Desmond Butler (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUSSO, SERAFINA
description: RUSSO--Serafina, 92, died peacefully at home, January 28, 2004. Known as Sally and Sadie to friends and family. Beloved wife of the late Nicholas L. Russo, M.D., mother of Maria T. Russo and D. Nicholas Russo; sister of Philomena DiIorio. Retired kindergarten teacher of PS 32, Queens. Her unwavering positivity for humankind and its creative works and her deep respect for the gifts of nature were hallmarks of her persona. Contributions in her memory may be made to any charity reflecting these values. A memorial gathering will be held in the spring.

title: Mirrors and Minimalism, Scented With Lilies
description: The Brazilian-born New York sculptor Valeska Soares produces the kind of installation that the eight finalists for the World Trade Center made famous: more or less Minimalist design with sound, light, water and plant life added, and with didactic references clearly conveyed by words or symbols. It is viewer-friendly: reasonable, accessible, theatrically entertaining and nonalienating.

title: The Neediest Cases; Budding Designer Rises From Broken Home
description: Brenda Mendez said it was the consensus among teachers at Fashion Industries High School that her daughter, Norma Delila Mendez, was the most beautiful girl at her senior prom last spring. And it was more than looks, it was talent: she had designed the backless bone-colored dress with a rust chantilly lace overlay that she wore to the dance, complete with tiara.

title: Michael Wolff to Leave New York Magazine for Vanity Fair
description: Michael Wolff, media columnist for New York magazine and part of a failed bid for the publication, will be going to Vanity Fair magazine as a columnist and contributing editor beginning March 1, according to Vanity Fair's editor, Graydon Carter.

title: Discounter From Out West Is Gnawing at Air Canada
description: As a captain with WestJet Airlines, Allen Byl estimates that his salary is about one-third less than that of his counterparts at Air Canada. The only place outside Canada he occasionally spends a night is Cancn, and chances are slim that he will ever command a plane bigger than a Boeing 737. Yet Mr. Byl has no desire to fly for a different airline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CONWAY, JOHN PHILLIPS
description: CONWAY--John Phillips, 19, of Greenwich, CT. Died on January 29, 2004 in Nashville, TN where he was a sophomore at the Vanderbilt University School of Engineering. He died from a sudden fatal heart arrhythmia while visiting a professor. Beloved son of John B. and Patricia Ranlet Conway. Adored brother of Benjamin B. and Patricia Laura Conway. Devoted grandson of Robert B. and Patricia P. Silleck. John was a graduate of Brunswick School in Greenwich., CT and Deerfield Academy in Deerfield, MA. A memorial service was held for his many friends and classmates at the Benton Chapel at Vanderbilt University on January 29, 2004. Another memorial service will be held at Deerfield Academy on Saturday, February 21, 2004 at 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Deerfield Academy.

title: Residential Real Estate; New Housing Spurt Sweeping Boroughs Outside Manhattan
description: Though the construction of luxury apartment buildings in Manhattan has commanded far more attention, new census data show that New York City is in the midst of a more surprising housing boom that extends across much of Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx, including neighborhoods where developers once feared to tread without large government subsidies.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel Reports 4th-Quarter Income
description: The Nortel Networks Corporation reported fourth-quarter net income yesterday of $499 million on higher sales, leading to the company's first annual profit since 1997. Net income was 11 cents a share, compared with a restated net loss of $168 million, or 4 cents a share, in the period a year earlier, said the company, based in Brampton, Ontario. Sales rose 12 percent, to $2.83 billion, the first quarterly increase in three years. The company had its biggest quarterly profit ever after the chief executive, Frank A. Dunn, trimmed 60,000 jobs and sold or closed most of its manufacturing operations amid a three-year decline in orders for phone gear. Nortel's wireless unit led the recovery in sales, with a 33 percent increase in the quarter. The shares rose $1.26, or 19.1 percent, to $7.84 in after-hours trading. They rose 12 cents to $6.58 in regular trading.

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Fourth Tribe Is Recognized In Connecticut; Casino Feared
description: The federal Bureau of Indian Affairs yesterday formally recognized the existence of an Indian tribe based in northwestern Connecticut, to the dismay of political leaders and residents who fear that the designation will lead to the creation of a third casino in the state.

title: Under Arizona Sky, Stars Shine Brightest On the Tennis Courts
description: A COUPLE of years ago, I was checking into the Fairmont Scottsdale Princess hotel in Arizona for a tennis-immersion vacation -- I'd play a few sets each morning, then watch the pros play in the Franklin Templeton Classic tournament being held in the 5,000-seat stadium on the hotel grounds. All the big names were scheduled to be there -- Pete Sampras, Andre Agassi, Lleyton Hewitt -- and I figured it was a good chance to see them up close rather than from my usual vantage, the upper-reaches of the balcony at the United States Open.

description: The two key Senate authors of the bill that created an independent commission to investigate the Sept. 11 attacks said Thursday that they would introduce legislation next week to extend the panel's deadline by eight months, to next January.

description: THIS 1958 Lincoln Continental Mark III convertible is more than a well-waxed relic of the days when such gas-guzzling dinosaurs roamed the highways. Bill Bonnell, who keeps one of the 19-foot-long monsters in his Greenwich, Conn. garage, says it is ''a work of art on wheels.'' Page 9.

title: U.S. Commander Surveys Challenges in Iraq Region

title: Exhausting Federal Compassion
description: The pernicious joblessness bedeviling the nation is spawning a new category of Americans dubbed ''exhaustees'': the hundreds of thousands of hard-core unemployed who have run through state and federal unemployment aid. According to the latest estimates, close to two million Americans, futilely hunting for work while scrambling for economic sustenance, will join the ranks of exhaustees in the next six months. They represent a record flood of unemployed individuals with expired benefits -- the highest in 30 years -- who are plainly desperate for help.

title: Haiti's Neighbors Are Pressing Aristide for Reforms
description: At 24, David Jonathas is barely old enough to remember the political revolution that eventually placed a Catholic priest named Jean-Bertrand Aristide in the presidential palace. And yet, Mr. Jonathas hopes to be part of another movement, equal in determination to that earlier campaign waged in the late 1980's but with opposite results.

title: Federer Breezes Into Australian Final
description: MELBOURNE, Jan. 30  Let's get right to it. Roger Federer certainly did tonight on his way to the Australian Open final and the No. 1 ranking: He rolled through a tired, injured Juan Carlos Ferrero by the score of 6-4, 6-1, 6-4 to earn himself a potentially much more suspenseful matchup with Marat Safin on Sunday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Jail Officer Faces Sex Charge
description: A city correction officer has been arrested and charged with engaging in a sex act with an inmate, the city's Department of Investigation said yesterday. The officer, Anthony Phillips, 45, who has 18 years in the Department of Correction, was also charged with sexual abuse and assault for punching the inmate and shoving his head under a running faucet in a jail area of the Criminal Courts Building at 100 Centre Street early Wednesday morning after the inmate tore his clothing, according to court documents. He was arraigned and released on $5,000 bail Wednesday, a department spokeswoman said. Officer Phillips, who was suspended without pay, could not be reached for comment yesterday. Paul von Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Nassau Delivers Proposal to Bail Out Its Health Agency
description: Nassau County's plan to rescue the agency that runs a deficit-ridden hospital, nursing home and health clinics by revamping them is drawing a generally favorable response. But some experts said getting major changes enacted would not be simple, and union leaders objected to further staff reductions.

title: Bronx Boy, 1, Drowns in Bucket in Leaky Kitchen
description: A 1-year-old Bronx boy drowned yesterday when his head became trapped in a bucket that his family had put out to catch incessant leaks from their kitchen ceiling, the police said.

title: A Dollar, a Dream, a Brooklyn Bote
description: It will be impossible for you to walk past a shuttered restaurant and not feel a chill after seeing the documentary ''Eat This New York,'' which opens today in Manhattan. The directors Andrew Rossi and Kate Novack may not be great filmmakers -- it's hard to tell, based on this bare-bones picture -- but they know a great story, and more important, how to tell it. The movie will grip those fascinated by the restaurant business, like myself, and those who merely drift by the Food Network on the way to MoreMax or Speedvision on the cable dial.

title: Study from an F.D.A. critic argues that the agency is slow to police misleading pharmaceutical ads.
description: THE Food and Drug Administration is increasingly failing to enforce its own rules on prescription drug advertising, according to a report released yesterday by the ranking Democrat on the House Committee on Government Reform.

title: For Some Weekenders, Ski-In, Ski-Out Religion
description: THERE'S a synagogue directly across the street from Pierre Schoenheimer's apartment building on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. Come to think of it, there's a synagogue directly behind it as well. But for the last 20 years or so, Mr. Schoenheimer, an investment banker, has confined his worship to the Jewish Center of the Hamptons, near his weekend home in East Hampton. ''I like sitting in the sanctuary and looking out on nature,'' he said. ''It seems more spiritual, closer to nature and closer to God.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUILLOTON, ALAIN
description: GUILLOTON--Alain, passed away on January 25 at the age of 76. He enjoyed close ties to the Village Light Opera Group for over 30 years. He is survived by his children Suzanne, Jacques and Andre; his grandchildren Matthew, Deirdre and Christopher; family members and friends here, in Canada and France.

title: INSIDE ART
description: A Bernini Bound For Fort Worth

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Profit At Refiner
description: The petrochemicals maker and oil refiner, Reliance Industries, reported a 27 percent increase in quarterly profit. Reliance said that its net profit rose to 13.74 billion rupees ($304 million) in the quarter ended Dec. 31, from 10.83 billion rupees ($240 million) a year earlier. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Dean Aims for Delegates And Tries to Calm Donors
description: Returning to the road with an emboldened attack on Washington politicians, including his opponents in the Democratic presidential contest, Howard Dean on Thursday rebuffed the notion that he must win in one of the states voting on Tuesday, saying he is concentrating instead on collecting delegates, perhaps with an eye toward a convention challenge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FIELD, ROSE
description: FIELD--Rose. Died peacefully at 95. Beloved wife of the late Arthur N. Field. Loving mother of David and Robert. Adored grandmother of Mitchel, Laurence, Michael, Jamie and Leigh. Great grandmother of Nicholas, Anna and Charles. Her family celebrates her long and wonderful life.

title: Republican Concerns About Deficits Grow
description: A senior House Republican warned on Thursday that President Bush was on a collision course with Congress over his plans to reduce the deficit by almost freezing the growth of discretionary programs aside from military and domestic security items.

title: Shopping List | Poker Night
description: THIS winter, while the snow is falling and the temperatures are plummeting, hunker down with friends for a Saturday night of poker. With the right accouterments, like a Montecristo in one hand and a glass of whiskey in the other, you can pretend you're among the new breed of young card sharks racking up big wins in Las Vegas. WENDY KNIGHT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WERFEL, PHYLLIS
description: WERFEL--Phyllis, 86, beloved mother of Steven, mother-in-law of Jeannette, grandmother of Jeffrey, passed away January 29, 2004. She will be dearly missed by all her family and friends

description: Jack Shainman Gallery

description: BASSETT--Genia Esther (nee Paltrowitz), 97. Beloved wife of the late Dr. David Bassett and the loving and adored mother of Irwin and Rita, Lawrence and Charlotte; and Ann and Fred Schwartz. She also leaves 10 grandchildren and 17 great grandchildren. A woman of high ideals and wisdom. Graveside services at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, Long Island, Sunday, February 1, at 11 A.M.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Steelmaker In Bankruptcy
description: Stelco, Canada's biggest steel producer and a supplier to the North American automotive industry, sought court protection from its creditors. Stelco, based in Hamilton, Ontario, reported losses of 168 million Canadian dollars in the first nine months of 2003 on sales of 2 billion Canadian dollars. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Vodka Stream Meets Walden Pond
description: MOST trial watchers focused their attention yesterday on Centre Street in Manhattan. You could hardly blame them.

title: Senate Democrats Summon Clinton as Political Adviser
description: With Howard Dean regrouping and other Democratic presidential candidates rejiggering, Senate Democrats decided maybe they should get a little election-year advice, too.

description: The Project

title: Israel and Hezbollah Trade Prisoners and War Dead in Flights to and From Germany
description: Israel and the Lebanese guerrilla group Hezbollah carried through with their deal to exchange prisoners and war dead on Thursday, in a trade greeted in Israel by a spare ceremony for three fallen soldiers and in Lebanon by a day of national celebration.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Ally For Reichman Bid
description: The founder of the Canary Wharf Group, Paul Reichmann, said that he did not have enough financial backing to bid for the East London office property. Instead, Mr. Reichmann said that he would align with Brascan, a Toronto group vying with a consortium led by Morgan Stanley. The allies have until Feb. 11 to bid. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: 9/11 Prisoner Seeks Retrial
description: Lawyers for Mounir el-Moutassadeq, the only person convicted of involvement in the Sept. 11 terror attacks, asked Germany's highest court to overturn the verdict, and the court said it would decide by March 4 whether to order a retrial. Mr. Motassadeq, a Moroccan, was sentenced to 15 years last February for helping the Qaeda cell in Hamburg that produced three of the Sept. 11 pilots. The trial of a second Moroccan charged as an accessory to the attacks, Abdelghani Mzoudi, is to hear testimony today from a man described as an Iranian defector who has told German investigators he has information incriminating Mr. Mzoudi. Desmond Butler (NYT)

title: Wildlife in a Verdant Jungle of the Mind
description: Jacqulyn Buglisi and Donlin Foreman, who have danced with Martha Graham, are seen by some as taking the Graham canon into the 21st century. But one of the most enjoyable aspects of a program presented by Buglisi/Foreman Dance on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater was the way it reached back into the past.

title: Mexico Links Drug Traffic With Police
description: Correction Appended

title: Abundant Skills, Abbreviated Years
description: In his ''Lives,'' Vasari tells the story that during the sack of Rome in 1527, Girolamo Francesco Maria Mazzola, the painter known as Parmigianino, being preoccupied as usual with his work, didn't notice the turmoil until the Germans were already in his house. Finding him painting, they were then so stunned by his genius that instead of pillaging and murdering, they requested a few drawings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DIANTONIO, VINCENT
description: DIANTONIO -- Vincent. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Vincent Diantonio, associated with The Times from July 2003.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hackensack: Contractors Admit Fraud
description: The owners of a painting contracting firm pleaded guilty yesterday in State Superior Court to defrauding three New Jersey school districts of $1.5 million by paying their workers less than what they had been promised and pocketing the difference. The owners of the company, the Paint Smart Corporation, of Nutley -- Jose LoGreco, 53, the president, and Charles Paraboschi, 65, the vice president -- face a minimum of five years in prison each at their sentencing, set for May 7. The company was barred from receiving any future local, county or state contracts. Maria Newman (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cray Shares Plunge On Forecast
description: Shares of Cray Inc. fell yesterday after it said sales this year would miss analysts' forecasts. Sales will rise to about $300 million this year from $237 million last year, said Cray, based in Seattle. Analysts expected $312.1 million, the average from Thomson First Call. The company is having a tough time predicting orders from the federal government, the chief executive, James E. Rottsolk, said. Cray said fourth-quarter sales increased 71 percent, and revenue had risen for seven consecutive quarters because of higher federal government orders. Cray supercomputers help simulate nuclear explosions, car crashes and climate change. Shares declined $3.10, to $7.75.

title: G.M. Returns 10 Years After End Of Apartheid
description: Correction Appended

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Profit At Canon
description: The world's largest office equipment maker, Canon Inc., said that it earned 276 billion yen ($2.6 billion) last year, an increase of 45 percent over the previous year, helped by strong demand for its copiers and digital cameras. Canon said sales rose 4.1 percent to 3.2 trillion yen ($30 billion). In 2004, Canon said it expected its profit to increase another 3.7 percent.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Oil Auction
description: Russia's government will hold an auction of oil-rich blocks on the remote eastern island of Sakhalin, despite a request from ExxonMobil for an exclusive deal, according to the Interfax news agency, which quoted the deputy prime minister, Viktor Khristenko. ExxonMobil had sought a ''production-sharing agreement'' for the oil fields, which guarantees stable taxes. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: SUDAN: PLANE BOMBS CHAD SIDE OF BORDER In a battle against rebel insurgency in the western Darfur area, a Sudanese plane bombed a border town in neighboring Chad, killing 2 civilians and 15 others, a United Nations official said. The official said it was the first time since war broke out a year ago between the Sudanese government and guerillas in Darfur that Chadian territory had been bombed. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: Making a Splash At Cabo San Lucas
description: THE plush white mat was thick enough to fall asleep on and the surrounding 1970's architecture seemed to enhance the effect of my Pucci bikini. And the only objects obscuring my panoramic view of the rocky hillside to the east and the deep blue waters of the Sea of Cortez as it joined the Pacific Ocean were a few knee-high rocks, desert flower bushes and cactuses planted into the stone terrace surrounding the pool.

title: Glory of the Pharaohs, Liberated From the Gloom With Fanfare
description: The undying appeal of ancient Egyptian art for modern audiences may be a mystery to some of us. But there's no mystery at all as to why the Metropolitan Museum has engineered a minor hullabaloo around the opening of a revamped section of its Egyptian collection.

title: Slots Ride Into Saratoga Raceway
description: It was almost post time for the first race on the first night of a new era at Saratoga Gaming and Raceway, where, nine hours earlier, the slot machine parlor had opened its doors for the first time. The horseplayers, a couple here, a couple there, milled about, hoping to find a winner among the field of seven about to meet in a $2,200 trot. It wasn't much different from any other cold winter Wednesday night at this track: the place was uncomfortably quiet.

title: A Tchaikovsky of Contrasts and Momentum
description: George Balanchine's ''Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto No. 2'' is a dazzling and demanding creation. It appeared rather pallid when the New York City Ballet offered it earlier this season at the New York State Theater. But on Tuesday night it was performed with far more glitter, even though the finale never achieved the proper splendor.
