title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: U.S. Passenger To Be Deported
description: An American who was detained and had his visa revoked for throwing a cup of water over a crying Brazilian baby on a flight from Miami to So Paulo was to be deported, the police said. It was the second incident at the airport this month involving an American. Two weeks ago, an American Airlines pilot was ordered to pay a $13,000 fine after using a vulgar gesture to protest the fingerprinting of visiting Americans. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: BBC Director Resigns as Fallout Over Iraq Report Builds
description: The director general of the British Broadcasting Corporation resigned Thursday in the wake of a devastating report attacking the BBC's journalistic practices, saying he hoped his departure would help save it from further damage.

title: 36 Hours | Boulder, Colo.
description: BOULDER, a half-hour drive from Denver, could arm wrestle any town for the title of fittest in the nation and walk away champion. In the last few years, the hyperoutdoorsy city pressed against the Rockies has been crowned everything from the nation's best running city (Runner's World magazine), to the No. 1 sports town in America (Outside). What other city can boast 42,000 acres of protected open space and a bank with a drive-through lane for cyclists? Surging shards of tilting sandstone, called the Flatirons, lean like old-fashioned irons over town, a constant reminder that rock-climbing (outdoors and in), mountain biking and trail-running await. Meanwhile, the sun shines more than 300 days a year, and it's not unusual to be able to eat at an outdoor cafe in mid-January. Such charms have also lured to this traditionally left-wing city of 100,000 people (counting the 25,000 students at the University of Colorado) plenty of well-heeled bourgeois bohemians, who like to push their bodies by day but still kick back with a local microbrew at night. CHRISTOPHER SOLOMON

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Industrial Output Falls
description: Industrial production fell 1.0 percent in December from November, more than expected, but output for the fourth quarter still rose at its fastest rate in nearly three decades, helped by a surge in exports of cars, electronics and steel. Production for the October-December period grew 15.3 percent from the previous quarter, the fastest growth since 1976. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: East Meadow: Underwear Theft
description: An employee of the Nassau County Correctional Center was arrested yesterday and accused of stealing underwear he was supposed to have handed out to poor inmates, law enforcement officials said. The worker, John Cofield, Jr., 39, of Uniondale, was accused of stealing more than $13,000 in packaged men's and women's underwear since 2002. Mr. Cofield, a jailhouse laborer for eight years, was in charge of dispensing the undergarments to needy inmates, the Nassau County district attorney's office said. He said he was giving them to family and friends, said Rick Hinshaw, a spokesman for the prosecutor's office. Stacy Albin (NYT)

description: Despite three decades of progress, existing air-quality laws are inadequate to prevent pollution from threatening the environment and human health, the nation's top scientific advisory group concluded yesterday.

description: To the Editor:

title: Beijing Journal; At the Swimming Hole in Winter, a Workout for the Soul
description: Cold? Zhang Shixiang pulls off his wool cap, peels off his thick sweater and stands smiling in a peach-colored bathing suit. The afternoon sun is leaking out of the sky, and skaters cut across the frozen lid of the finger lake named Houhai. The temperature is a degree or two above freezing.

title: Investigators Find Abuses In Annuities
description: Opening a new chapter in the investigations of improper fund trading, federal and state regulators have found evidence of trading abuses that hurt investors in variable annuities, a popular product sold by the life insurance industry, several officials working on the investigations said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PECCHIOLI, ANNA ELIZABETH BLUHM
description: PECCHIOLI--Anna Elizabeth Bluhm, 86, also known as ''Betty,'' passed away on January 24, 2004. Born in New York City, she earned a B.A. degree from Hunter College and an M.A. degree from Columbia University. She taught art at Washington Irving High School until her retirement in 1971. Then she lived for many years in Florence, Italy with her husband, the late Roberto Pecchioli. Betty was an artist who worked in oils and watercolors. Her paintings were exhibited extensively in Italy where they won acclaim and numerous awards. Following the death of her husband, she lived several years in Indian Harbour Beach, FL. Betty, a dearly beloved aunt, is survived by her niece, Cathy Dobson of Satellite Beach, FL, her nephew, Robert T. Bluhm, Jr. of Waterville, ME, her sister-in-law, Virginia Bluhm of Indian Harbour Beach, FL and four grandnieces and grandnephews. Services and interment will be in Florence, Italy. For information, contact Beach Funeral Home, Indian Harbour Beach, FL.

title: California Measure Would Align Building Rules With Feng Shui
description: With a budget deficit of about $14 billion, California could use a major infusion of positive energy.

title: Edwards Didn't Always Revel in His South Carolina Roots
description: Senator John Edwards is reveling in his South Carolina roots these days as the state's important Democratic presidential primary looms next Tuesday, embarking on what his campaign described as his "Bringing It Home" swing. But he was not always so exuberant about claiming his heritage.

title: In the Finger Lakes, the Sweet Taste of Winter
description: IT'S 12 degrees outside, there's at least a foot of snow on the ground, and Bob Madill, a winegrower in the Finger Lakes region of New York, is picking grapes. For makers of ice wine, a dessert-style wine that gets its nuanced sweet flavor from grapes that have been allowed to freeze on the vine, the recent spate of Arctic weather has been ideal for harvesting. ''Fun and crazy is sort of what this is,'' said Mr. Madill, one of the owners of Sheldrake Point Vineyard on Cayuga Lake in Ovid, N.Y.

title: Third Bomb Attack Directed at France's First Muslim Prefect
description: A bomb exploded in the mailbox of a school here on Thursday, the third attack in what is apparently a campaign to intimidate a man appointed as the first prefect in France who is both foreign born and Muslim.

title: Houston Decides to Take Time Off to Rehabilitate
description: After a season of quick-fix rests, Allan Houston finally realized he could not continue to play while healing his arthroscopically repaired right knee.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: Beef Products Are Recalled
description: The Vincent Giordano Corporation is recalling 52,000 pounds of beef products that may be tainted with a bacterium. The meats, which are sold nationwide, were packaged on Dec. 16, 2003. Each of the products is marked with the code ''EST. 5397'' inside the inspection seal. Officials say the bacterium, Listeria monocytogenes, can cause flulike symptoms and can be fatal to the elderly, infants and those with weakened immune systems. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOROSS, JEANNE
description: MOROSS -- Jeanne, died peacefully at 93. Beloved wife of the late Irving (Jay) Moross. Loving mother of Barry (Noreen) and Jeffrey (Jane). title: Veto Threatened on Bill to Restrict Powers Under Terrorism Law
description: The Bush administration, stepping up the debate over its antiterrorism policies, threatened on Thursday to veto a pending bill that would scale back the government's powers under the USA Patriot Act.

title: Safe-Driving Campaign Awarded to Bartle Bogle
description: The Florida attorney general's office awarded an assignment yesterday to create a national safe-driving campaign, aimed at owners of sport utility vehicles, to the New York office of Bartle Bogle Hegarty. Spending on the campaign, a one-time assignment, will be $27 million.

title: N.Y.S.E. Chief Said to Seek Electronic Shift
description: The new chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange is preparing a plan that would encourage far more trading on its electronic system and perhaps blunt criticism from institutions of the trading now done on its floor, according to executives who have been briefed on the measure.

description: For many second-home owners, weekends generally center on earthly pursuits like golf, tennis or skiing. But for some, the weekend is time for playing and praying, whether it means finding a shul by the beach or hitting early Mass before hitting the slopes. Page 2.

Loving sister of Robert, Edward, Dorothy, Joseph and the late Lawrence, Stuart and Harriette. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Family will receive friends Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Williams Funeral Home, corner of West 232nd St., Broadway, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial, Our Lady of Angels Church, on Monday 9:45AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla NY.

title: Hitting the Beach to Enjoy A Little Laid-Back Larceny
description: Coming at the end of a dismal and frigid January, ''The Big Bounce,'' directed by George Armitage from a script by Sebastian Gutierrez, is like a paid Hawaiian vacation -- somebody else's. Everyone involved with this picture, the second screen adaptation of Elmore Leonard's first foray into crime fiction, seems to have had a good time making it, which was nice for them, but it may not do you much good. There are a few vicarious pleasures to be gleaned --a pungent, off-kilter one-liner here, a sly sight gag there, enough smooth, uncovered flesh to titillate all tastes and persuasions -- but the movie itself seems to have been misplaced amid all the sun and surf, the pineapples and bikinis.

title: Lloyd Bucher, 76, Skipper of Seized Navy Spy Ship, Dies
description: Former Cmdr. Lloyd M. Bucher, who commanded the Navy spy ship Pueblo when North Korea seized it in 1968, beginning 11 months of captivity and torture for the crew, died on Wednesday at a hospice in San Diego. He was 76.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The reason we're doing this is to make God a part of the relationship. We are making our union with God in public. We do see it as a sacrament.''

title: Arias From Familiar Sources and a Bit of Peru
description: The bitter winds on Sunday afternoon didn't deter a dozen or so music-lovers from milling outside Alice Tully Hall to try to get last-minute tickets for the sold-out recital by the Peruvian tenor Juan Diego Flrez. He has become a genuine operatic superstar, the new prince of the Bel Canto repertory, a dashing, though small-framed, stage presence and a wonderfully appealing artist.

title: Bushs Risky Options
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  The intensifying debate over prewar American intelligence about Iraq presents President Bush with difficult and risky alternatives as he balances election year politics with calls to overhaul the intelligence apparatus and to restore the nation's credibility around the world.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Marijuana Laws Relaxed
description: The government changed the classification for marijuana, downgrading it to a category of drugs that includes prescription antibiotics. The police are being discouraged from arresting people smoking the drug. The maximum sentence for possession was cut to two years, from five. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Israeli Envoy Criticizes U.N. Secretary Generals Comments
description: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 30  Israel's ambassador to the United Nations made a rare criticism of Secretary General Kofi Annan today, saying he had shown bias in his response to Thursday's suicide bombing in Jerusalem.

title: Dean Supporters Voice Frustration but Soldier On
description: Just as the news was coming out of Vermont that the architect of Howard Dean's campaign had been replaced by a Washington lobbyist and that the campaign was nearly out of money, Dr. Dean's New Hampshire state director assembled her staff on Wednesday night and tried to stem the damage.

title: Bush Seeks Rise In Arts Funds
description: The White House on Thursday called for an increase of $18 million in the budget for the National Endowment for the Arts this coming fiscal year.

title: White House Cites Iraq's History of Seeking Arms as a Reason for War
description: The Bush administration, justifying its decision to go to war against Iraq despite its failure since then to find any banned weapons there, said Thursday that even if Saddam Hussein had not amassed stockpiles of nuclear, biological or chemical weapons, the United States could not have afforded to leave him in power because he had a history of trying to acquire them.

title: NEIMAN MARCUS SAYS BERGDORF CHIEF HAS GONE TO SAKS
description: Neiman Marcus, the owner of luxury department stores, said yesterday that Ronald Frasch, chairman and chief executive of its Bergdorf Goodman chain, had taken a job with a rival, Saks Inc. Neiman's president and chief executive, Burton M. Tansky, will lead Bergdorf until a successor is named, the company said. Mr. Frasch, 55, will work on ''international opportunities'' and private-brand development and report to the chief executive, R. Brad Martin, Saks said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NISCE, LOURDES Z., M.D., F.A.C.R.
description: NISCE--Lourdes Z., M.D., F.A.C.R. On January 29, 2004. Attending physician and professor of radiation oncology at New York Presbyterian Hospital, Weill Cornell Medical College, and Memorial Sloan-Kettering. Pioneering woman in medicine, graceful, witty and generous; a life of love and dedication to family and friends and her grateful patients and colleagues. Beloved aunt of Helen, Steven, Pamela and Samantha Spindel and Antonia and Ivan Ekebrink. Also survived by many devoted nieces, nephews and friends. description: For the past week, senior government and intelligence officials, speaking anonymously, have steadily disclosed details of a deepening inquiry into what seems to have been the transfer of Pakistan's nuclear technology to Iran and other countries in the late 1980's and early 1990's.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the termination of a Justice Department program that monitored criminals' use of drugs referred imprecisely to its procedures. The program  known as the Arrestee Drug Abuse Monitoring Program, or ADAM  tested new jail inmates in 35 cities for narcotics, not for narcotics violations. (Participation was anonymous, and the program was not used to prosecute drug crimes.)

title: Patriots' Offense Finds Its Balance
description: New England quarterback Tom Brady offered a potential candidate Thursday for the most valuable player in Super Bowl XXXVIII. The player he picked is running back Antowain Smith.

title: Whoever Is Chosen, Democrats Spoil for a Fight
description: The struggle for the Democratic presidential nomination is not just about personalities and programs, but also about the direction -- maybe even the soul -- of the party. While still very much a work in progress, the Democratic Party emerging from Iowa and New Hampshire is different from the careful centrism of the Clinton era.

description: George Bush promised to bring honor and integrity back to the White House. Instead, he got rid of accountability.

title: Whatever It Is, Its a Wild World
description: The first act of Antonio Rodriguez's ``Madama Fortuna!'' is a knockout. Mouse (Fred Gunsch), slouching around the basement of a defunct library, has decided to take acid and commit suicide. Until then, he amuses himself reciting lines from the film ``Pulp Fiction.'' His roommates, Simon (Drew Cortese) and Jude (Aundre Chin), bring home a huge bag containing a little girl in a fancy red dress. They're upset because Magda (Jenny Penny Curry) has turned on the lights.

title: Deal to Let MBNA Issue American Express Cards
description: American Express said yesterday that it had reached a deal to have its cards issued by MBNA, the country's second-largest credit card issuer, making its first foray into the Visa and MasterCard networks in the United States.

title: Somalis Reach Peace Deal After Dozen Years of Fighting
description: An array of Somali warlords and clan leaders struck a deal here on Thursday that could lay the groundwork for the country's first national government since 1991.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: TEXAS: THREE SENTENCED FOR SMUGGLING IMMIGRANTS Three men who admitted smuggling illegal immigrants and then extorting money from them have been sentenced to prison terms of up to nine years. Prosecutors said each immigrant had paid the three men, Felipe Ceron-Espinoza, 20, Erik Angeles-Mendoza, 21, and Daniel Angeles-Mendoza, 23, at least $1,500 for passage to the United States, only to be held at gunpoint at a house in Austin until relatives paid the smugglers more money. Steve Barnes (NYT)

description: SPECTOR -- Eleanor nee Friedman, 91, on January 29, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Reuben Spector, Q.C. of Montreal. Devoted mother of Linda Spector of New York City and Barbara Berlin of Montreal. Grandmother of Mark Pariser of Los Angeles. Donations in her memory may be made to Cabrini Hospice, 227 E. 19 St, 10th Floor, NY, NY, 10003. Graveside services will be held 11:30am at Union Fields Cemetery, Ridgewood, Queens, NY, Friday, January 30, 2004.

title: Givers and Takers
description: Each of the Democratic candidates vying to replace George W. Bush has a serious electability problem. The problem has nothing to do with their biographies or temperaments -- and everything to do with a significant, but unnoticed, structural divide in American presidential politics.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: DVD Group To Expand
description: Hewlett-Packard and Dell, the computer makers, will join the Blu-ray Disc Founders, a group of companies promoting one of the competing standards for next-generation DVD's. The group, which includes Sony, Matsushita Electric and Hitachi, is developing DVD disks and players that can store high-definition movies, television programs and other video. A rival group led by Toshiba and NEC is promoting another standard, and a consortium of Chinese companies is promoting a third. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: The Day's Agenda: Nothing at All
description: THE sun is two fists (a k a 20 degrees) above the horizon, which means there is about an hour and 20 minutes until sunset -- almost time for me to head to the Mucky Duck. I am at a beach near a small cemetery on Captiva Island, the more northern of two barrier islands off the mainland at Fort Myers, Fla., the other being Sanibel, and only a mollusk's throw from the Duck, the beachfront bar where I will join the congregation for the sacred island rite of watching the sun set over the Gulf of Mexico.

title: New SARS Study Stresses Need to Act Fast Against Epidemics
description: Chinese scientists analyzing the genome of the SARS virus have documented the immense rapidity with which it evolved from an animal pathogen into one capable of infecting human cells.

title: A Hip-Hop Dance Team Duels Some Menacing White Boys
description: ''May the dopest crew win!'' proclaims the hip-hop star Lil' Kim somewhere near the welcome end of ''You Got Served,'' which opens today nationwide. She is not referring to sailors on steroids, but to dueling hip-hop dance teams, one led by African-American teenagers from an unspecified Los Angeles neighborhood and the other by sinister-looking white boys from Orange County, who face off in an MTV dance contest at the climax of this modest programmer directed by Christopher B. Stokes.

title: Fed Opted Last Month To Keep Phrase on Rates
description: Federal Reserve policy makers debated on Dec. 9 whether to stop saying that they would hold interest rates low for a ''considerable period'' before deciding to keep the phrase, minutes of the meeting released yesterday show.

title: Sports of The Times; 'Hey, God, I Know You Are With Me'
description: IF the Carolina Panthers' jerseys get sweaty enough during Super Bowl XXXVIII, you may be able to see the black numbers, 51 and 58, on the white T-shirts the players wear underneath their shoulder pads as a tribute to two of their own: 51 for the linebackers coach Sam Mills, who has intestinal cancer, 58 for linebacker Mark Fields, who has Hodgkin's disease.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AHERN, ANN
description: AHERN--Ann. On January 27, 2004, of Forest Hills, N.Y. Daughter of the late Maurice and Edna Ahern. Sister of the late Charles. Also survived by her niece Michelle, sister-inlaw Jeanne and cousins William, John and Joseph O'Conor. Funeral Mass at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Forest Hills, 9:30AM Saturday. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: Pace of Economic Growth Slowed to 4 Percent at End of 2003
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  The nation's economy expanded at an annual rate of 4 percent in the final quarter of last year, much slower than the torrid pace of last summer but still strong by historical measures, the federal government estimated today.

title: With Lindros's Future Unclear, the Rangers Have to Wait
description: The Rangers practiced yesterday, but Eric Lindros was not there. Instead, after the eighth documented concussion of his career, he flew to Montreal and was examined by Karen Johnston, a concussion specialist who has previously treated him.

title: The Beat Is From Mars and From Venus
description: SHERRIE L. MARICLE was in the fourth grade living with her divorced mother and two younger sisters when she decided, like many girls her age, to play an instrument. She told the school music teacher she would like a trumpet.

title: Mars Rover Appears to Find Mineral Linked to Water
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 30 — The Mars rover Opportunity may have detected the iron oxide — a possible sign of water from Mars' ancient past — that was the original motivation for sending it to a broad plain near the planet's equator, some scientists involved in the project said.

title: Grand Jury Said to Look At Fund Case
description: The New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, has convened a grand jury to consider evidence against Richard S. Strong, founder of Strong Capital Management, according to people briefed on the proceedings.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: War Crimes Inquiry
description: Luis Moreno-Ocampo, chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court, said the court was considering an inquiry into rights abuses by the Lord's Resistance Army, the rebel group that has terrorized northern communities since 1987. President Yoweri Museveni asked for the war crimes investigation. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: To Brown or Cornell, On the Wings of a Heist
description: ''The Perfect Score,'' which opens nationwide today, is a thin, pleasant teenage heist comedy with a chewy nugget of social criticism buried inside it. Actually, it isn't buried very deep at all. The movie, directed by Brian Robbins from a script by Mark Schwahn, Marc Hyman and Jon Zack, begins with an indictment of the Scholastic Aptitude Test, and pauses several times in the course of its desultory action to complain about the regime of standardized testing that turns America's young people from vibrant, complicated individuals into calculable quantities, pigeonholing them before they have figured out who they are.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: New Campaign For Republican
description: Bobby Jindal, a Republican who lost a runoff election for governor in November, has announced that he will seek the Congressional seat being vacated by Representative David Vitter, a fellow Republican who is running for the Senate. Mr. Jindal, 32, was ahead in the polls for much of the race for governor but lost to Kathleen Blanco, a Democrat, 48 percent to 52 percent. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Questions Swirl in Roof Shooting Inquiry
description: That Police Officer Richard S. Neri Jr. shot and killed an unarmed teenager last week is not in dispute. But there are a swirl of questions to be considered by a grand jury, which could meet as early as today to hear evidence in a case that some have called an accident and others have called murder.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Won't Make Changes For Patent
description: Microsoft said yesterday that it would not, ''for now,'' make changes in its software as a result of a court ruling in which a jury told it to pay $521 million for infringing patents related to Internet Explorer. Microsoft had said in October that it was considering modest changes that would let Web developers who use Internet Explorer technology avoid any concern of infringing a University of California patent licensed to Eolas Technologies. A federal jury in Chicago said Microsoft impermissibly used technology for methods for navigating the Internet. Microsoft is appealing the verdict and the Patent and Trademark Office is reviewing whether the patent should have been issued. Microsoft's Internet Explorer has 96 percent of the worldwide market for Web browser software. ''The steps were modest that we were proposing, and the feedback that we were getting from the industry was, rather than change something, just hold off'' until the appeal and patent office review are resolved, a Microsoft spokesman, Jim Desler, said. An Eolas lawyer, Martin Lueck, said the announcement illustrated how important the technology was to the browser.

title: Yukos to Pursue Merger Though Target Objects
description: Yukos, Russia's biggest oil company, dug in its heels on Thursday in its long, bitter dispute with a smaller rival, Sibneft. The Yukos board said Thursday that it would recommend that the company's management resume merger talks. The board also said that it had hired Squire, Sanders & Dempsey as a legal adviser and J.P. Morgan, the investment banking unit of J.P. Morgan Chase, as bankers and financial consultants.

title: Scarves and Symbols
description: With France on the verge of passing a law that would prevent Muslim girls from wearing their head scarves in class, Americans are asking why the French are so attached to secularism. I always want to respond to this question by asking another, a version of one asked by Montesquieu nearly three centuries ago: how can one be French? Our uneasiness about head scarves and other religious symbols in schools is a result of our long, often painful, history. If we bow to demands to allow the practice of religion in state institutions, we will put France's identity in peril.

title: Creating Confusion by Rerouting the Receivers
description: The Oakland and Kansas City defenses of the 1970's perfected it and called it the jam. The fierce Philadelphia defenses of the early 1990's called it No Free Access. Both Super Bowl XXXVIII defenses on Sunday will showcase it and call it rerouting.

title: Bush's Risky Options
description: The intensifying debate over prewar American intelligence about Iraq presents President Bush with difficult and risky alternatives as he balances election year politics with calls to overhaul the intelligence apparatus and to restore the nation's credibility around the world.

title: City Sues to Have State Expand Housing for Retarded Children
description: The city filed a lawsuit yesterday against New York State demanding that it pay for and build more places to house severely mentally retarded and developmentally disabled children in foster care, or at least pay private agencies to care for such children.

title: Best Sellers, On a Scale Of Good Read To Good Grief
description: A cover, a title, binding and paper: these are things to take for granted about any book. But the words themselves are a different story, sometimes so irrelevant to the book's fate that they seem downright optional. The world of best sellerdom is full of books that might be wildly popular even if their pages were blank.

title: Suicide Bomber on Jerusalem Bus Kills 10 and Himself
description: A Palestinian policeman detonated a bomb packed with shrapnel aboard a bus here on Thursday morning, killing himself and 10 others. Despite the attack, Israel proceeded with a planned prisoner exchange with the Lebanese guerrilla group Hezbollah.

title: Player Inspired by Child's Wish
description: An hour or so before the biggest game of his life, Kevin Donnalley will take a moment in the Carolina Panthers' locker room on Sunday to write a name on his wrist tape: Hope Stout.

title: No Wine in Antarctica; Try the Finger Lakes
description: SNOW? Freezing rain? Arctic windchills? It's a great time to visit the not-too-crowded tasting rooms of the Finger Lakes wine region. Among the offerings is proof that winter's cruel weather has a bright side: ice wine, a sweet amber nectar made from grapes that have frozen on the vine. There are also February wine festivals, and some vineyards have Valentine's Day events. Page 8.

title: Janet Frame, 79, Writer Who Explored Madness
description: Correction Appended

title: GENZYME WINS APPROVAL TO SELL A DRUG IN JAPAN
description: The Genzyme Corporation said yesterday that it had won Japanese approval for its drug Fabrazyme, which treats a rare enzyme deficiency called Fabry disease. Genzyme said it would sell the drug as soon as the Japanese government set a price. The company said several hundred patients in Japan had the disease. Small increases in the number of patients taking Fabrazyme are important because the treatment costs about $165,000 a year for the average patient. The medicine is already approved in the United States and Europe, and sales of Fabrazyme reached $81 million last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FISHER, JODI
description: FISHER--Jodi. Our hearts are broken for our dear friends Barry, Rhoda, Dick, Robert, Jeffrey, Grandma Rose, and Jodi's dear children Jordan, Samantha and Charlie, and the entire Fisher and Spiegel families. Dearest Jodi, your shining light will glow forever in our hearts. Charlotte and Roger

title: Going Beyond The Familiar Shostakovich
description: Dmitri Shostakovich lived through the darkest hours of the tragic Soviet experiment, and his music spoke from its void with unparalleled impact. But for all the celebration and controversy that has surrounded him, how well do we actually know his work beyond the war horses?

title: In the South Bronx, The Arts Beckon
description: Correction Appended

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Landfill-Closing Money
description: Ten communities in New York State, including Smithtown on Long Island, will receive a total of $9.7 million to help safely cap and close old landfills so they meet rigid environmental standards, Gov. George E. Pataki's office announced yesterday. The money, from the state's Environmental Protection Fund, will cover up to 90 percent of the cost of closing the inactive landfills and preventing hazardous substances from leaking into the ground and contaminating water supplies. Smithtown, in Suffolk County, will receive $2 million to clean up a 23.5-acre landfill on Old Northport Road. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: Snow Day Poses a Complication For Seniors Needing Regents Test
description: The snowstorm that forced the closing of schools in New York City on Wednesday also forced students to miss Regents exams, some of which are required for graduation. Now the state must decide what to do next.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Kirshenbaum Bond Loses Its Independence
description: One of the few remaining large independent agency companies, the Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network in New York, is independent no longer. Its owners have sold a 60 percent stake to MDC Partners in Toronto.

title: ARCHIBALD CANDY FILES FOR CHAPTER 11 PROTECTION
description: Archibald Candy said yesterday that it had filed for bankruptcy protection, just weeks after announcing the sale of its Fannie May and Fanny Farmer brands and the closing of its manufacturing plant and its 238 retail stores. The company, which is privately held, filed for Chapter 11 reorganization on Wednesday in United States Bankruptcy Court in Chicago, where the company is based. Archibald listed assets of $50 million to $100 million and debt of more than $100 million. Archibald said the filing would not affect its Canadian subsidiary, which sells the Laura Secord brand. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CIRILLO, NICHOLAS W.
description: CIRILLO--Nicholas W., 71, of Bedford Village, New York died in Boca Raton, Florida on Thursday, January 29, 2004. He will be deeply missed by his loving wife, Joan. He is also survived by his children: Donna (Ken) Wright, Gregory (Lisa) Cirillo, Nicholas (Marianne) Cirillo, Jr., Paul (Laura) Cirillo and nine beloved grandchildren. Also survived by his brother William Cirillo and sister Monica Rippa. A memorial service in celebration of his life will be held on Saturday, January 31, 2004, from 3-4 P.M. at Babione Funeral Home (561-395-8787) in Boca Raton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUDEFIN, MICHEL J.
description: GUDEFIN--Michel J., 80, on January 26, 2004, after a prolonged illness. Beloved husband of Claire, adored father of Christine and Michael, father-in-law of Manuel Villas-Boas and Gretchen, cherished grandfather of Antonio and Alexandre and caring brother and uncle. His strength and love will stay with us forever. Donations in his memory may be made to Columbia University Medical Center, Division of Medical Oncology, 177 Fort Washington Avenue, Room MHB 6435, New York, N.Y. 10021. Funeral service on Tuesday, February 3, at 11AM, at St. Michael the Archangel Church, 469 North Street, Greenwich, CT.

title: France facing big bill in Taiwan frigate deal
description: PARIS:  Illegal payments linked to a French defense deal with Taiwan signed in 1991 have placed the French government at risk of being ordered to repay up to $600 million in murky commissions, according to a report published on Wednesday.

title: Republican Meeting Turns Focus to Kerry
description: Senator John Kerry's emergence as the leading Democratic presidential contender won him a new round of criticism on Thursday, but not from other Democrats seeking the nomination.

title: Time for Exxon to Pay
description: It has been 15 years since the Exxon Valdez fetched up on a reef in Prince William Sound in Alaska, spilling 11 million gallons of crude oil and dealing biological and economic shocks to the sound and its adjacent communities, none of which have fully recovered. In 1991, the ship's owner -- now Exxon Mobil -- reached a $900 million civil settlement with the federal government and Alaska. Its obligations to the thousands of fishermen and others who suffered from the spill remain unresolved. It is past time for the company to pay up and put the entire sorry episode behind it.

title: Four Buildings Are Destroyed In New Jersey Warehouse Fire
description: A six-alarm fire at a warehouse complex here started on Wednesday and burned through the night, destroying four buildings and delaying the morning rush Thursday as heavy smoke, visible from Manhattan, drifted onto the Pulaski Skyway.

title: Afghan Blast That Killed 7 G.I.s Is Seen as Accidental
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 30  The explosion of a weapons cache that killed at least seven American soldiers south of Kabul on Thursday was probably an accident, the senior United States military spokesman in Kabul, Lt. Col. Matthew P. Beevers, said today.

title: Costs and Savings in Medicare Change on Wheelchairs
description: For a few months after severe arthritis in her knees forced Sister Scholastica Rzepka into a manual wheelchair, her arms still had the strength to propel her around the Sisters of the Holy Spirit convent near Pittsburgh, her home for the last 77 years. By last fall, with arthritis crippling her shoulders, her doctor prescribed a power wheelchair.

title: Revelations and Repercussions For a Missionary and a Party Boy
description: The gay romantic melodrama ''Latter Days'' draws on an unconscionable number of conventions, but works in the end because of its commitment to its characters and a handful of fine performances.

title: Clark Challenges Kerry on 92 Affirmative Action Remarks
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 30  Gen. Wesley K. Clark attacked Senator John Kerry today for statements that the Massachusetts senator made in 1992 about affirmative action, and the retired general also said that Mr. Kerry failed take responsibility for those statements during a debate among the Democratic candidates in South Carolina on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HYMAN, BRUCE
description: HYMAN--Bruce, 63, of Highland Beach, FL, formerly of New York City. Father, golfer, poker player, husband, passed away January 26, 2004 (561-272-1167).

description: Events

title: Exploring Ways to Make Guitar Strings Sing
description: The guitar was a concept and work in progress, not a standardized instrument, during the Guitar Marathon at the 92nd Street Y on Sunday, the main event of the New York Guitar Festival. In eight hours of music by 16 pickers -- acoustic and electric, solo and with groups -- the marathon presented an instrument that composers, musicians and builders can't resist tinkering with as they seek ways to make plucked strings sing.

title: Bruins Give the Islanders Yet Another Cold Slap
description: The Islanders' Jason Blake was controlling the puck in the middle of overtime against the Boston Bruins on Thursday night. Ahead of him his teammates were surging out of the defensive zone, and he circled back to give himself room.

title: Top Conductors, Top Orchestras, Brahms in Common
description: These are the sorts of weblike, almost incestuous relationships you find in the symphonic world: on Tuesday evening Sir Simon Rattle, the music director of the Berlin Philharmonic, led the Philadelphia Orchestra in a concert at Carnegie Hall. Sir Simon and the Philadelphians have had a long and productive relationship, and when the Philadelphians were seeking a new music director in the late 1990's, they were said to have been actively courting him but were unable to persuade him to move his conducting base from Europe.

title: As City Cites Snowy Walks, It's Told to Clear Its Own
description: One day after a storm left 10 inches of snow in the city, the Sanitation Department yesterday dispatched legions of workers to issue summonses to property owners who had not shoveled their sidewalks.

title: Pension Agency to Cut Its Stock Holdings
description: Ten years after it adopted an ''all equities'' strategy, the agency that insures pensions has decided it has taken on too much risk and will reduce stocks to as little as 15 percent of its total investments.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption in Business Day yesterday about plans by the Standard & Poor's Corporation to use American Stock Exchange closing prices for some Nasdaq stocks when it compiles its 500-stock index misstated the title of David M. Blitzer, an S.& P. executive. He is chairman of the company's index committee, not its chief investment strategist.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the termination of a Justice Department program that monitored criminals' use of drugs referred imprecisely to its procedures. The program -- known as the Arrestee Drug Abuse Monitoring Program, or ADAM -- tested new jail inmates in 35 cities for narcotics, not for narcotics violations. (Participation was anonymous, and the program was not used to prosecute drug crimes.)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Grand Jury Is Investigating Founder of Strong Funds

title: Gay Couples Seek Unions In God's Eyes
description: Correction Appended

title: Con Ed Blames Faulty Work In Electrocution
description: Consolidated Edison said yesterday that improperly insulated wire beneath a metal plate had contributed to the death of an East Village woman who was electrocuted while walking her dogs this month.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: A Bid Too Low
description: The chief executive of Aventis, Igor Landau, said that a $60 billion takeover bid made by its rival, Sanofi-Synthlabo, was too low. Mr. Landau told a French radio station, Europe One, that his company was being undervalued by at least 30 percent and that no offer would be ''interesting'' unless it was increased by 40 percent to 50 percent. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Couple Out Over 'Puppy Farming'
description: The Kennel Club, the body that oversees the Crufts dog show, the world's largest, has accepted the resignation of Peter Mann, the Crufts chairman, after anonymous critics searched the dog-breeding records of his wife, Joan, in the early 1970's and accused her of ''puppy farming.'' The term refers to mass production of litters, a practice now considered unethical and in some circumstances illegal. Mrs. Mann resigned as this year's best-in-show judge, citing the ''stress and anguish'' of ''scurrilous anonymous accusations.'' The Kennel Club did not dispute the allegations, which were sent to dog magazines. The records showed that Mrs. Mann, a breeder of Yorkshire terriers, registered 23 litters of 126 puppies in 1971. Some were sold to traders. Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

title: In Puerto Rico, Discovering a Surf Mecca
description: ON a warm afternoon in mid-January, the sunset happy hour was revving up at the Calypso, a wooden open-air bar perched on the side of a hill overlooking Maria's, the main surf break in Rincn, P.R. Throngs of buff surfers in sandy flip-flops, board shorts and T-shirts were sipping $2 Coronas and exaggerating their day's surf triumphs when, suddenly, all heads turned to watch the action about to unfold in the water.

title: Setback for Prosecutors in Martha Stewart Trial
description: A federal judge delayed the testimony of the main witness in the trial of Martha Stewart on Thursday in an embarrassing setback for prosecutors. The order came after lawyers for her co-defendant accused them of unfairly withholding an important document that could exonerate their client.

title: Griffin Incident a Misunderstanding
description: An incident Sunday in which the police were called to Eddie Griffin's hotel in New Jersey after a complaint about him was a misunderstanding, the Nets and the police said Thursday.

title: National Briefing | Washington: New President For NAACP Fund
description: The NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc. has named Theodore M. Shaw as its new president and director-counsel. Mr. Shaw, 49, has been with the organization for 19 years, most recently as associate director-counsel. He will take office May 1, when Elaine R. Jones steps down after 11 years in office. Brian Wingfield (NYT)

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Joyful Actions And Reactions

title: Sales Rise for Electronics Makers in Japan
description: Sales at Japan's largest industrial electronics companies rebounded in the October through December quarter on strong demand for optical disk drives, cellphones and the semiconductors used in digital cameras and other hot-selling gadgets.

title: Jack Sheinkman, 77, Lawyer; Led Clothing Workers' Union
description: Jack Sheinkman, the former president of the nation's largest union of clothing workers and a major strategist in one of labor's biggest victories, organizing the textile maker J. P. Stevens, died yesterday at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 77.

title: Shuttle Investigator Will Review Hubble Decision
description: The head of the board that investigated the Columbia space shuttle disaster has agreed to examine NASA's decision to cancel any missions to extend the life of the Hubble Space Telescope, agency officials said on Thursday.

title: Forthcoming Coaches Can Help N.F.L. Telecast
description: One of the tasks for football announcers like Phil Simms and Greg Gumbel, who will call the Super Bowl between New England and Carolina for CBS on Sunday, is to talk to the teams' coaches a day or two before a game. Some coaches cooperate, providing insight into their game plans, and some would rather surrender their children.

title: On Baseball; An Independent Owner Is Needed for the Expos
description: MAJOR League Baseball has held the Montreal Expos hostage long enough. It's well past time to liberate them and let an independent owner determine their future.

title: Tyco Auditor Discusses Bonuses
description: The former lead auditor of Tyco International testified yesterday that he had informed a board committee about bonuses paid to the former chief executive, L. Dennis Kozlowski, which prosecutors say were stolen from the company.

title: White House Cites Iraqs History of Seeking Arms as a Reason for War
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 — The Bush administration, justifying its decision to go to war against Iraq despite its failure since then to find any banned weapons there, said Thursday that even if Saddam Hussein had not amassed stockpiles of nuclear, biological or chemical weapons, the United States could not have afforded to leave him in power because he had a history of trying to acquire them.

title: In a Visit to New Hampshire, Bush Sounds Campaign Themes
description: President Bush blew into New Hampshire on Thursday, less than 48 hours after the Democrat competitors left, to try to dig out from the piles of invective that those candidates had heaped on him in a presidential primary that White House officials said Mr. Bush was too busy to notice.

title: Pranksters, Pundits, Political Animals All
description: Correction Appended

title: Freddie Mac Ordered to Raise Capital Reserves
description: Freddie Mac, which last year restated earnings by $5 billion because of accounting errors, must keep 30 percent more capital on reserve than previously required at least until it releases financial statements for 2003, the company's regulator said yesterday.

title: Judge Delays a Decision on Artworks
description: APennsylvania judge said yesterday that he needed more evidence before deciding whether the Barnes Foundation and its famed multibillion-dollar collection of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art could move from its home in a small Philadelphia suburb to an urban setting near the Philadelphia Museum of Art and the Rodin Museum.

title: Hollinger vs. Hollinger: A Paper War Everyone but Lawyers Could Lose
description: THERE are two morality tales to be seen in the war for control of the media empire built by Conrad M. Black, the Canadian publisher turned British lord. Which one you find more compelling may depend as much on your place in the social structure as on the facts.

title: The Heart Meets the Mind in an Improvisational Set
description: The bassist Charlie Haden has been playing a lot of duets, for reasons of art, since the late 1970's. But after tinnitus -- a ringing or buzzing in the ears -- became a problem for him in the last decade duets also became a necessity in clubs where a full group's noise might otherwise overpower him. About once a year, he pulls into the Blue Note for a week's engagement with a few more duet partners. Among other things, it's a way to make an attractive booking that will draw fans, without spending lots of time preparing new music.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Not Just for Sleeping, But for Showing Status

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Greenwich: Calls For Fire Chief To Step Down
description: Firefighters in Greenwich called yesterday for the town's fire chief, Daniel Warzoha, to step down over what they said was poor judgment he exercised at a fire in December, charging that he had been intoxicated. A representative for the Greenwich Fire Fighters Association, the union for firefighters in Greenwich, whose department includes volunteers and paid firefighters, said an investigation ordered by the fire commissioner into Chief Warzoha's conduct concluded this week that he had been impaired during a fire on Dec. 5. Three firefighters suffered serious injuries during that fire when they jumped out a third-floor window to avoid being burned, the union representative said. Fire Commissioner James Lash, who is also the town's first selectman, declined to comment on the investigation, citing personnel privacy rules. Chief Warzoha could not be reached for comment. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: One Rover Returning to Work As Another Prepares to Begin
description: In another step to return to full health, the Mars rover Spirit performed limited scientific work on Thursday, photographing nearby rocks, and it could resume full operations as early as Sunday, mission controllers said.

title: Playing to a Home Crowd, Edwards Sticks to a Basic Pitch
description: He calls it the ''Bringing It Home'' tour, and makes sure his audiences know what he means from the start, the Carolina drawl just a bit more pronounced.

title: GLAXOSMITHKLINE LOSES BID TO BLOCK A GENERIC DRUG
description: GlaxoSmithKline, the drug maker, lost a legal bid yesterday to block Impax Laboratories from selling a generic version of its antidepressant Wellbutrin SR. The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington upheld a lower court ruling that Impax does not infringe Glaxo patents for the twice-a-day form of the drug. Impax has an agreement with the Andrx Corporation, the first company to file for regulatory approval of a generic version of Wellbutrin, that allows it to go to market with the drug.

title: The Luxuriant Works of Parmigianino
description: The show of works at the Frick Collection gives you a hint of the Italian artist's glossy, luxuriant Mannerist finesse.

title: Poker Night
description:
By WENDY KNIGHT
This winter, while the snow is falling and the temperatures are plummeting, hunker down with friends for a Saturday night of poker.

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: NEW IRAQ AGENCY TO HUNT REBELS
description: The Iraqi authorities, with the help of American intelligence agencies, are creating an intelligence service here that will focus on rooting out guerrilla fighters, especially those from outside the country, Iraqi and American officials said Friday. The service will employ some former agents of Saddam Hussein's security apparatus and will probably receive financing from the American government, the officials said.

description: Cannibal Case: 8 1/2 Years

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAPLAN, JACK
description: KAPLAN--Jack. On January 28, 2004 in Delray Beach, FL, after a four-year battle with cancer. Survived by his wife Lee Kaplan; daughters Marcy Kaplan of Downers Grove, IL; Debby Kaplan (Francis Keenan) of NY; Cindy Kaplan Rooney (Stephen P. Rooney) of Montclair, NJ; grandson Stephen Charles Kaplan Rooney; granddaughters Ava Pat Kaplan Rooney and Nellie Bowe Kaplan Keenan; sister Felice Stein and brother Howard Kaplan, both of New York. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, February 1 at 11 AM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65th St. Contributions may be made to the Mighty Eighth Air Force Museum in Savannah, GA or the Samuel Waxman Cancer Research Foundation in New York.

title: Serendipitous History Of the Gift of a Word
description: It came to pass that three princes from Ceylon were journeying in a strange land, and they came upon a man seeking a lost camel. The princes had never seen the animal. But they asked the owner: was this camel blind in one eye? Was it missing a tooth? Was it lame? Astoundingly, yes, all this was true. The princes also surmised that the missing camel was laden with butter on one side and honey on the other, that it was being ridden by a woman and that, moreover, the woman was pregnant.

title: Tagliabue Says Fines For Taunts May Go Up
description: Near the end of one of the most competitive and highly watched seasons in recent N.F.L. history, Commissioner Paul Tagliabue called on the league's 1,696 players to embrace their status as role models and warned them that they could face increased penalties during the 2004 season for taunting and similar acts.

title: Reporter at Center of Dispute Over Iraq Resigns From BBC
description: Andrew Gilligan, the reporter at the center of the bitter dispute between the British Broadcasting Corporation and the British government over whether the government had exaggerated the case for war against Iraq, resigned from the BBC on Friday.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Court Backs Spanking
description: The Supreme Court ruled that parents have the right to spank their children, but said that the children must not be under 2 or over 12 years of age and that the force used be limited. Children's rights advocates had sought to abolish such punishment, but the court said that children were protected from abuse and that opening parents to criminal charges for using limited force would do more harm to children than good. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: Gateway Makes Deal To Acquire EMachines
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHEINKMAN, JACK
description: SHEINKMAN--Jack. The administration and board of Amalgamated Bank mourns the death of Jack Sheinkman, former Chairman of the Bank and President of the Amalgamated Closing and Textile Workers Union (now known as UNITE!). An exceptional fighter for labor in the boardroom and on the ground, Mr. Sheinkman pioneered the area of corporate governance when, in 1992, he founded a set of institutional investment funds, the LongView Funds, to enhance shareholder value through active and involved ownership. He also led the labor union in two historic struggles: the campaign to bring social and economic justice to 4,000 workers at the Farah Manufacturing plants in Texas in 1972, which took 22 months before its successful conclusion; and the struggle to unionize J.P. Stevens textile plants, which took over four years and ended in a contractual agreement in 1980. His passing is a sad loss to banking and labor communities, and our hearts go out to his family and all who loved him. The Administration & Board of Amalgamated Bank and UNITE! Labor Union

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POWER, TARGE
description: POWER--Targe. Of Gulf Stream, Florida on January 28, 2004 at the age of 98. Wife of the late John F. Power. Mother of Mary, John Jr., Patricia, Margaret, Catherine, James and Elizabeth. Grandmother of 28 and great grandmother of 31. Contributions in her honor may be made to St. Rita's Church, 13645 Paddock Drive, Wellington, FL 33414. Services 10 AM February 9, 2004 at St. Rita's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FUREY, BERTRAM J.
description: FUREY--Bertram J. Age 84, of Jupiter, Florida, died on Wednesday, January 28, 2004. Bert attended St. Lawrence University before joining the Royal Canadian Air Force and then the U.S. Air Corps as a bomber pilot. He was shot down while on a night mission and spent 22 months as a prisoner of war in Germany. He retired as an executive of Conde Nast publications. Bert was predeceased by his daughter Constance and by two brothers and one sister. He is survived by his loving wife of 58 years, Marcelle, and by daughters Laurette (Drew) Giles, Georgette Furey (Roel) van der Vossen, Marcelle Furey and son Bertram, Jr. (Melina). He is also survived by seven grandchildren and one sister and one brother. To express condolences please make donations to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, Florida 33407.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Prosecutor For Unexplained Killings
description: The attorney general named a special prosecutor to investigate 300 unsolved murders of women over the past decade in Ciudad Jurez, on the Texas border. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: FEDEX SHAREHOLDERS TO VOTE ON BOARD TERMS
description: The FedEx Corporation, the overnight shipping company, will hold a shareholder vote on electing all of its 13 directors annually, after investor pressure to increase accountability. FedEx, which previously opposed the change, now has three classes of directors who serve staggered three-year terms. In 2002 and 2003, owners of its stock passed a nonbinding Teamsters union resolution for annual terms. FedEx's binding proposal will be voted on at the September annual meeting and requires approval by 80 percent of shareholders.

title: Judge Says DaimlerChrysler Trial Will Resume
description: The judge overseeing the billionaire Kirk Kerkorian's fraud lawsuit against DaimlerChrysler told lawyers in a conference call on Friday that the trial he suspended last month would resume either Feb. 9 or March 11. He gave the two sides until Monday to agree on the date.

title: One Dead, One Hurt in Queens Knife Fight
description: A fight in Queens yesterday left one young man stabbed to death and another in critical condition, the police said.

title: Resting Place for Columbia's Debris: A Springboard for Memories
description: The first piece of wreckage lifted from the first trailer to arrive here from the fields of Texas and Louisiana was a window frame. Just 10 days before, on the morning of Feb. 1, 2003, astronauts had still been looking through that frame at the glorious promise and the forbidding dangers of space, nearly 100 miles over the dark Pacific.

title: Second Jury Deadlocks on Officer's Use of Force
description: A jury declared on Friday that it was deadlocked in the trial of a former police officer who was videotaped slamming a teenager wearing handcuffs onto the trunk of a patrol car and punching him in the face. A previous trial last summer had the same result.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WITKIN, DR. NED
description: WITKIN--Dr. Ned, 47, of Atlanta, GA, died January 29. Dr. Witkin was a renowned doctor of optometry and low vision specialist who helped the visually impaired regain their independence. He was a researcher and inventor, but most of all, a compassionate clinician. Survived by wife Beverly, and daughter Sehra. Donations to Ned Witkin's Scholarship Fund, 245 Shadowbrook Drive, Roswell, GA 30075. 770-451-4999.

title: Fire Captain In S.I. Case Is Leaving Department
description: A Staten Island fire captain who worked in the firehouse where a firefighter was critically injured in a brawl on New Year's Eve said yesterday that he was leaving the department.

title: Nets' Griffin Will Enter the Betty Ford Center
description: Nets forward Eddie Griffin is preparing to enter the Betty Ford Center in Rancho Mirage, Calif., where he plans to spend the next six weeks being treated for alcohol abuse, said his lawyer, Rusty Hardin.

title: New Dean Campaign Strategy Leap-Frogs Over 13 States
description: Aides to Howard Dean's Democratic presidential campaign unveiled a new strategy on Friday that looks beyond the seven states choosing delegates on Tuesday to the Wisconsin primary on Feb. 17.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Unemployment Falls
description: Japan's unemployment rate fell three-tenths of a percentage point, to 4.9 percent, in December, the first time it has been below 5 percent since June 2001. The improvement comes thanks to a decline in bankruptcies and an upturn in production. The decline in unemployment should translate into an improvement in consumer spending later this year, economists said. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Profundities of the Bible Get Murkier and Murkier
description: The set for the Classic Stage Company production of ''The Mysteries'' is intriguing. Six tables are arranged in a rectangle, each with books lying open on them displaying celestial maps. Two glasses stand side by side on each, one completely empty and the other half full (or half empty, depending on one's state of mind). Sawdust covers the floor. An old-fashioned chamber pot and pitcher are placed under one table; at the end is a washtub filled with bright red apples. A flat-bottomed boat hangs suspended from the flies. Curiouser and curiouser. It presents a promising puzzle for arriving theatergoers. Then the show itself begins, and it all goes downhill from there.

description: If six no-trump is doubled, there are three likely explanations. One is that the double is a Lightner move, attempting to guide the opening lead.

title: Rangers Feel Absence Of Lindros in a Loss
description: Anyone wondering whether the loss of Eric Lindros's production for the Rangers would be offset by the addition of Jaromir Jagr's found out last night: Not yet, maybe not at all.

description: Allan Houston was at home in front of his television Friday night, watching the team he guaranteed would make the playoffs first sputter, then spark and finally explode without him for a 92-74 victory over the Boston Celtics.

title: New Yorkers Can't Beat Death, But Data Says They're Gaining
description: For the first time since the 19th century, when New York was a far different, far smaller place, fewer than 60,000 people died in the five boroughs in 2002, continuing a steady decline that began in the early 1990's and setting a record low for the city's death rate.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SERBIA: CLOSE, BUT NO SPEAKER VOTE Four pro-democracy parties agreed late Thursday to form a coalition government, but haggling over cabinet posts prompted one party to withhold approval. The deal would have enabled a vote in the Assembly to elect a speaker and appoint a prime minister-designate, but the Parliament session  which started earlier this week and was adjourned after lawmakers failed to elect a speaker  was postponed again. A date to resume the session is still to be decided. (AP)

title: A Classic With Contemporary Lines and a Danish Twist
description: Peter Martins's streamlined staging of ''Swan Lake'' for New York City Ballet is a feast for the eye. It has stunning abstract dcor by the Danish painter Per Kirkeby, vivid dancing and vibrant colors in the costumes.

title: Israeli Criticizes U.N. Chief on Reaction to Bus Attack
description: Israel's ambassador to the United Nations issued rare criticism of Secretary General Kofi Annan on Friday, saying he had shown bias in his response to a suicide bombing in Jerusalem on Thursday.

title: Advocacy Group Upset at Rejection of Anti-Bush Ad
description: Frustrated in efforts to run an advertisement critical of the Bush administration during the Super Bowl, the Internet-based grass-roots advocacy group MoveOn.org said it would instead run it on CNN on Sunday and in closely divided states in February.

title: An Italian One-Hit Crooner Is Back at Center Stage
description: THREE words have defined Tony Renis's life.

description: This postcard-perfect New England town seems an odd place for a showdown over casinos, Indian sovereignty and other issues swirling around the long-disputed status of the tiny Schaghticoke Tribal Nation.

title: That Old New Orleans Sound, Preserved but Enlivened
description: When Preservation Hall opened in New Orleans in 1961, it was a simple and radical idea: create a place where the original practitioners of jazz could play and pass on their music. The first batch of Preservation Hall regulars are gone now, but the idea has stayed so unshakably appealing that the hall has become a tourist destination.

title: Stopping The Traffickers
description: When I was in Cambodia recently, writing about two teenage prostitutes whose freedom I had purchased, Srey Neth and Srey Mom, readers started sending me frantic e-mail along the lines of: I'll wire you some money if you'll free one for me, too.

title: Charles Brown, 57, Known For Versatility of Stage Roles
description: Charles Brown, an actor celebrated for his comic exuberance and dramatic power in plays on Broadway by Samm-Art Williams and August Wilson, died on Jan. 8 at his home in Cleveland. He was 57.

James Stockdale, whose performance as a vice-presidential candidate was a discussion topic. The admiral ran as an independent in 1992 with Ross Perot, not as a Republican in 1996 with John McCain, who was not a nominee.

description: An emeritus professor rolling naked in the snow at minus-20 degrees Fahrenheit and yelling like a banshee is either exhibiting an amazing remission from seasonal affected disorder or he is performing a slight (O.K., a not-so-slight) act of braggadocio. In any case, I jumped right back into the sauna after 20 seconds, having briefly experienced an altered state of mind.

description: In a test on the rights of patent holders, the Tokyo District Court on Friday ruled that the Nichia Corporation must pay 20 billion yen ($189 million) to the inventor of a widely used semiconductor device.

title: Relieved by Test Results, Pitino Is Ready to Coach
description: After what he referred to as a scare regarding a urological ailment, Rick Pitino, the University of Louisville basketball coach, returned from two days of tests at the Cleveland Clinic and said Friday that he was relieved by the results.

title: Much of Europe Is Derisive About Report on Iraqi Arms
description: Much of Europe has given a collective snort to the testimony by David Kay, the former chief United States weapons inspector, that there probably were no illicit weapons in Iraq before the United States-led war there.

title: Sanofi Makes a Plea to Aventis Investors
description: Jean-Franois Dehecq, the chief executive and chairman of the French drug maker Sanofi-Synthlabo, arrived in the United States this week for a series of meetings with some of the largest shareholders of Aventis.

title: Economy Remained Strong In 4th Quarter, U.S. Reports
description: The nation's economy grew at an annual rate of 4 percent in the final quarter of last year, much slower than the torrid pace of last summer though still rapid by historical standards, the government estimated on Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KORNBLEE, JILL
description: KORNBLEE--Jill, 84, died on January 29, 2004. Beloved wife of Leonard V., loving mother of John C. and Elisabeth Kornblee, and Mary K. Gabriel, mother-in-law of Carolyn T., and grandmother of Joanna and Rachael Gabriel, and Elizabeth Kornblee.

title: Inquiry Won't Hurt Earnings, Adecco Says
description: Adecco, the world's largest employment services group, said on Friday that an investigation begun two and a half weeks ago into accounting weaknesses at its North American unit had so far not uncovered any problems large enough to dent earnings significantly for 2003.

title: East Side Sex Attacks
description: A man who the police said robbed and raped a woman on the Upper East Side early Tuesday morning is believed to have similarly attacked a man in the same neighborhood two days later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, IRVING J.
description: COHEN--Irving J., 95, died January 27, 2004 in Lauderhill, FL. Loving father of Beth A. Cohen, devoted husband of the late Mildred B. Cohen, cherished uncle to the Glogower, Rosen, Blank and Friedland families. Dear friend of the late Bess Kirschner and Jessie Schifrin. Remembered with love and admiration by family and friends. Graveside service Sunday, February 1, 1:00 PM, New Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

title: Pakistan Adopting A Tough Old Tactic To Flush Out Qaeda
description: At the start of the month, Pakistan massed several thousand troops in and around the town of Wana, near the country's mountainous border with Afghanistan. Using a harsh century-old British method, officials handed local tribal elders a list and issued an ultimatum.

title: Bush to Seek '09 Deadline for Liberty Bonds
description: President Bush plans to ask Congress to extend until 2009 the Liberty Bond program, which provides tax-free financing to help New York City rebuild after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: New Concern Is Expressed About Flights From Abroad
description: American officials said on Friday that they had received new information in recent days pointing to the possibility of an international hijacking and were considering the grounding of several flights from England and France over the weekend as a result.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Trade Surplus Falls
description: South Africa posted a higher-than-expected 5.7 billion rand ($814 million) trade surplus for December and an annual trade surplus of 16.6 billion rand for 2003, the government said. The 2003 surplus was down 22.6 billion rand from 2002. Analysts said the smaller annual surplus was largely a result of the strong rand, which has hurt exports. The surplus sent the rand higher, but pushed down the Johannesburg Stock Exchange. Nicole Itano (NYT)

title: ATA REACHES AGREEMENT WITH CREDITORS
description: Creditors of the ATA Holdings Corporation agreed yesterday to let the company delay debt payments for the next two years to avoid a bankruptcy filing. ATA, the parent of the discount airline ATA Airlines, exchanged $260.3 million in notes due in 2004 and 2005 for cash and new notes due in 2009 and 2010, the company said. The carrier, based in Indianapolis, also delayed aircraft lease payments, the company said. Without the lease and debt changes, ATA might have been forced to restructure its debts in bankruptcy, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR DROPS. The dollar fell after a government report showed that the economy expanded less than forecast in the fourth quarter. In New York, the euro settled at $1.2472, up from $1.2405 on Thursday.

title: For the Football Anti-Fan: Aliens, Lovers, Lingerie
description: If the prospect of Super Bowl XXXVIII's celebration of football and commercialism leaves you cold, do not despair. Television executives have not completely abandoned you.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the On Stage and Off column of Weekend on Jan. 23 about a coming revival of Neil Simon's 1963 comedy ''Barefoot in the Park'' misstated its place in the sequence of his Broadway plays. It was the second; the first was ''Come Blow Your Horn,'' in 1961.

title: Pakistan's Nuclear Responsibility
description: Gen. Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's military ruler, has a history of strong declarations, followed by weak and contradictory actions. Washington cannot settle for a repetition of this pattern in the Pakistani investigation into whether its nuclear scientists passed bomb technology to North Korea, Iran and Libya. All the links in this reckless supply chain -- commercial, military or political -- must be uncovered and severed.

title: Faith Can Enrich More Than the Soul
description: Forget investment and savings rates, worker productivity and wage scales to determine which countries will become richer or poorer. What really stimulates economic growth is whether you believe in an afterlife -- especially hell.

title: Rep. Tauzin Leans Toward Retirement
description: Representative Billy Tauzin, the Louisiana Republican who has been courted in recent weeks for lobbying positions with the motion picture and pharmaceutical industries, expects to leave public life this year, his spokesman said Friday.

title: Jets Hire Former Rutgers Coach Graber
description: The Jets completed the overhaul of their defensive staff yesterday, hiring Doug Graber, who was once the head coach of Rutgers, as their defensive backs coach.

title: Greenhouse Gases
description: To the Editor:

title: Debt-Heavy Economy May Be Too Jittery About Rates
description: For many Americans, the last couple of years have been a prolonged borrowing spree. Families piled on debt to buy homes. They put new computers on credit cards. They bought cars on dealer credit and refurbished their houses with home equity loans.

title: German Court Convicts Internet Cannibal of Manslaughter
description: A German computer technician who killed and ate a willing victim he found through the Internet was convicted of manslaughter on Friday, in a ruling that reflected the legal ambiguities of a case that has, by turns, fascinated and repulsed people here.

title: Snapple Checks Leave Some Schools Short
description: More than four months after the first Snapple vending machines were placed in public schools in New York City as part of a citywide agreement, the schools have received their first commission checks, ranging from $12,085.90 for Tottenville High School on Staten Island to $10.68 for Middle School 224 in the Bronx.

title: Rover Appears to Find 2nd Hint of Past Water
description: The Mars rover Opportunity appears to have located the iron oxide -- the second hint of water in the ancient past at the site -- that was the motivation for sending it to a broad plain near the planet's equator, some scientists involved in the project said Friday.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article in Weekend yesterday about religious films that have stirred contention included an erroneous reference to the Immaculate Conception in connection with Jean-Luc Godard's 1985 film ''Hail Mary.'' Christian doctrine teaches that Mary was conceived by her mother, Anne, without the stain of original sin; the term does not refer to the conception of Jesus by Mary.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Economy Stalls
description: Canada's economy stalled in November, Statistics Canada reported, with gross domestic product adjusted for inflation unchanged from the previous month. Strong performances in the housing and energy sectors were offset by lower mining output and motor vehicle sales. Many economists predict that the Bank of Canada will cut interest rates for the second time this year at its next review of monetary policy, on March 2. The Canadian economy grew 1.8 percent in the first 11 months of 2003, compared with the period a year earlier. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: A Child's Wish: To Touch Antiquity, Once
description: To the Editor:

title: Insurer Says Its Annuities Face Inquiry By Regulators
description: In the first action against an insurance company in a sweeping investigation of variable annuities trading, federal and state regulators have prepared a case against Conseco, asserting that the insurer provided advantages to big investors that could increase profits but hurt small investors, the company acknowledged yesterday.

title: The Fight for the Democrats' Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: The Folly of Stuff and Glitter
description: Throughout much of Kevin Doyle's ''Styrofoam'' -- a play in the Stampede Theater Festival at the Trilogy Theater -- the sting of the playwright's unyielding satire is softened by his gift for comic absurdity. But the last few minutes will leave no one untouched by a shudder of revulsion.

title: It's Cold and Snowy and the Train Is Late. Why? It's Cold and Snowy.
description: Robert Sullivan, a recent law school graduate who has been commuting to New York City for job interviews, bounded off the 3:22 p.m. Metro-North train and into the frigid dusk.

title: Tucked Behind the Home Page, a Call to Worship
description: When Doug Reese put up his Web site, he felt he was answering a call. A college wrestling coach with a long involvement in Christian youth ministries, he wanted to spread a Christian message to people who were not getting it.

title: U.S. Women Top Sweden in China
description: Playing its first game of the year, the United States women's team defeated Sweden, 3-0, yesterday in its opening match of the Four Nations tournament in Shenzhen, China. The United States got two goals from 20-year-old Lindsay Tarpley and one from Shannon Boxx. In the day's other match, China defeated Canada, 2-1. The United States was playing without Mia Hamm and Brandi Chastain, who are expected to join the team for regional Olympic qualifying matches next month in Costa Rica. The United States will play China tomorrow and complete play in the round-robin event against Canada on Tuesday. Jack Bell

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CONWAY, JOHN PHILLIPS
description: CONWAY--John Phillips, 19, of Greenwich, CT. Died on January 29, 2004 in Nashville, TN where he was a sophomore at the Vanderbilt University School of Engineering. He died from a sudden fatal heart arrhythmia while visiting a professor. Beloved son of John B. and Patricia Ranlet Conway. Adored brother of Benjamin B. and Patricia Laura Conway. Devoted grandson of Robert B. and Patricia P. Silleck. John was a graduate of Brunswick School in Greenwich., CT and Deerfield Academy in Deerfield, MA. A memorial service was held for his many friends and classmates at the Benton Chapel at Vanderbilt University on January 29, 2004. Another memorial service will be held at Deerfield Academy on Saturday, February 21, 2004 at 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Deerfield Academy.

title: EPIQ TO ACQUIRE POORMAN-DOUGLAS FOR $115 MILLION
description: Epiq Systems Inc., which makes and sells software used by bankruptcy trustees, agreed to buy the closely held Poorman-Douglas Corporation for $115 million in cash to add services for law firms. The acquisition will be financed with cash and a $100 million credit facility, Epiq said yesterday. The purchase will give Epiq, which is based in Kansas City, Kan., more legal services, including class-action, mass tort and bankruptcy case products used by lawyers and trustees, the company said. Poorman-Douglas, based in Portland, Ore., had $63.6 million in sales in its fiscal year ended Sept. 30, Poorman-Douglas said.

title: Moving Bills Subpoenaed In Rowland Investigation
description: Gov. John G. Rowland twice had the state pay to move furniture between his official residence in Hartford and his lakeside cottage in Litchfield, according to documents that were subpoenaed by federal investigators. The two bills, one for $890 and one for $861, stem from moves that took place in Nov. 20, 2001 and May 1, 2002. Both invoices are conspicuous in their lack of detail beyond noting that a ''large piece of furniture'' was being transported in each case.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the documentary film maker Charlotte Zwerin on Tuesday misstated the location of the fatal stabbing of a fan at a 1969 Rolling Stones concert shown in ''Gimme Shelter,'' a film she edited. It occurred in front of the stage, not onstage.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Honda's Profit Rises
description: Honda Motor said it earned 151 billion yen ($1.4 billion) in its third quarter, a 31 percent increase over the year-earlier quarter. Sales in the period, which ended Dec. 31, were steady at 2 trillion yen. Honda raised its outlook for full-year income by 0.6 percent, to 473 billion yen. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: An Olympian Works on His Version of Paradise
description: The scene is a typical Keys seascape. Backcountry mangroves dot the warm water of Florida Bay. Herons dive for fish. Wealthy boaters step onto the decks of vessels with names like ''Endless Summer'' and ''Toadily Wasted'' to clink glasses in appreciation of another setting sun.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Support For Arms To China
description: The Foreign Ministry said it supported French calls to lift a European Union ban on weapons sales to China imposed after the 1989 killing of pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in Beijing. France hopes the ban will be lifted by April 1. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: French Ex-Premier Is Convicted of Graft
