title: Republicans Designate Hotels For Convention Delegations
description: The Texas state Republican delegation will not have a luxury cruise ship to sleep on when it comes to New York this summer -- the House majority leader, Tom DeLay, abandoned that idea -- but it will have the Hilton New York.

She is Kimberly Camp, not Beverly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KURZWEIL, PAULINE
description: KURZWEIL--Pauline. 95, of Margate, FL., on January 29, 2004. Wife of the late Leon; courageous mother of Martin (Edith), loving grandmother of Larry (Rhonda), David (Debbie), Steven (Stacey) and proud great grandmother of Jordan, Marc, Matthew, Emily, Madison, Caroline. Lifelong companion of Gerry Ginson. Services at Gutterman's, Woodbury, at 1 PM on Sunday, February 1st. We'll miss her.

description: Senator John Kerry stood squarely at the center of the Democratic presidential race on Friday, trying to keep his focus on President Bush, but facing assaults from two rivals on affirmative action and health care.

description: After an evening practice late last season, Providence Coach Tim Welsh expected his players to be watching their customary television fare in the locker room -- music videos on Black Entertainment Television. Instead, they were tuned to ESPN's Big Monday, sizing up a future Big East opponent.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS

Terms were not disclosed.

title: Hundreds Attend Funeral Of Rooftop Shooting Victim
description: Bleary, refracted sunbeams shone through the patterned windows of the Friendship Baptist Church in Bedford-Stuyvesant yesterday, casting dim light around cantilevered balconies weighted with mourners in Sunday finery and mourners in hooded sweatshirts. The ringing overtones of clipped, two-note chords from a pipe organ announced the entrance of a coffin bearing the body of a young man shot dead by a police officer.

title: Israelis Mourn Their Dead and Destroy Bomber's House
description: Even by the ever declining standards of this conflict, the Palestinian suicide bombing that claimed 10 Israeli lives on Thursday seemed senseless -- or sensible only if calculated to deepen the misery of both peoples.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TSAKONAS, MARY

title: EYETECH SHARES SURGE 54% ON FIRST TRADING DAY
description: Shares of Eyetech Pharmaceuticals, which raised $136.5 million in an initial public offering on Thursday, rose 54 percent on their first day of trading. Eyetech, a New York-based biotechnology company developing eye treatments, sold 6.5 million shares at $21. The stock rose $11.40, to $32.40 a share, yesterday. The company is working with Pfizer on a treatment for age-related macular degeneration, the most common cause of blindness in people over age 50. Eyetech plans to file for approval of the drug, called Macugen, this year, according to a regulatory filing.

title: Paying Homage to Basie, Especially to His Extremes
description: Count Basie was a wily pragmatist. At all costs, he kept his band going, playing for dancers and honoring simple but effective musical devices. But how driven he must have been to keep it that way. Hundreds of musicians passed through his bands, which are basically grouped into Basie Version I (1935-1950) and Version II (1952 to his death in 1984, and still going, now under the direction of Bill Hughes). As with a few of jazz's other long-running big bands, it created something like a subculture unto itself. And at the basis of the subculture, underneath all the running jokes and play-acted rivalries, were grooves and tight ensemble playing.

title: Nights May Be Cold but Gopher Tickets Are Hot

Outside the arena, where it was 17 degrees, two heavily bundled scalpers worked the sidewalk. Inside, the second-largest crowd of the season -- 13,638 -- left scant seating room in an arena affectionately known as the Barn.

title: WELLA TO CUT 600 JOBS AT COSMETICS OPERATION
description: Wella, the German maker of hair-care products that is controlled by the Procter & Gamble Company, plans to cut about 600 jobs at its cosmetics unit as part of an agreement that gives its parent company the right to license Wella products. About two-thirds of workers at the division, which has 2,000 employees worldwide, will be offered transfers to Procter & Gamble and its distributors, a spokeswoman, Birgit Klesper, said. The agreement lets Procter & Gamble sell and market Wella cosmetic products like Londa and Ultra Sheen, the company said on Thursday. Wella is based in Darmstadt, Germany, and Procter & Gamble is based in Cincinnati.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bad Loans Decline
description: Japan's banks reduced their nonperforming loans by 10.5 percent in the six months that ended on Sept. 30, as the economic expansion made it easier for borrowers to repay their loans. Japanese banks held 31.6 trillion yen ($298 billion) in nonperforming loans, according to the Financial Services Agency. The ratio of nonperforming loans to total lending fell to 6.8 percent at the end of September, versus 7.4 percent six months earlier. Ken Belson (NYT)

The lawsuit was filed on behalf of plaintiffs claiming to have been molested in the Diocese of Covington since 1956. By today, potential plaintiffs must withdraw from the class-action suit if they want to sue the church on their own. (AP)

title: UNION PACIFIC NAMES CHIEF FOR RAILROAD UNIT
description: The Union Pacific Corporation promoted its chief financial officer, James Young, to lead its railroad unit, the biggest in the United States, and named Robert Knight to succeed him in the finance post. Mr. Young, 51, will succeed Ivor Evans, 61, who becomes vice chairman of the company, Union Pacific said. Mr. Young and Mr. Evans were also named to a new office of the chairman along with the chief executive, Richard Davidson, who turned 62 this month. Mr. Knight, 46, was the senior vice president for finance and has been at the company for 23 years. Mr. Young is a 25-year employee of Union Pacific and had been chief financial officer of the company since November 1999. Union Pacific is based in Omaha.

All but $3 million of the increase will go to create a new program called ''American Masterpieces: Three Centuries of Artistic Genius,'' which will include a mix of touring performances, local presentations and arts education in partnership with public and private organizations across the country.

title: How to Hack an Election
description: Concerned citizens have been warning that new electronic voting technology being rolled out nationwide can be used to steal elections. Now there is proof. When the State of Maryland hired a computer security firm to test its new machines, these paid hackers had little trouble casting multiple votes and taking over the machines' vote-recording mechanisms. The Maryland study shows convincingly that more security is needed for electronic voting, starting with voter-verified paper trails.

title: Egon Mayer, 59, Sociologist Who Dealt With Jewish Issues

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: U.S. Fails On Agreement For Weapons Raids
description: The senior American arms control negotiator, John R. Bolton, ended two days of talks without securing a pledge by Russia to cooperate with an international effort to intercept shipments of components of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons, as well as missiles. President Bush announced the effort last year, but officials said Russia remains concerned about the legal basis for intercepting aircraft and ships believed to be carrying illicit shipments. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Plains: Kansas: Harsh Penalties For Gay Sex Are Upheld
description: Older teenagers who engage in homosexual sex with younger ones may be subject to far harsher penalties than their heterosexual counterparts, a state appeals court ruled. Last year, the Supreme Court stuck down a Texas law criminalizing gay sex between adults at home and ordered the Kansas court to reconsider an earlier ruling holding the sentencing disparity constitutional. The state appeals court ruled that in the current case the differing penalties remain justified by ''traditional sexual mores'' and the need to prevent sexually transmitted disease. A dissenting judge called the justifications a pretext for discrimination. Adam Liptak (NYT)

Preceded in death by her husband, Bonnie will be buried at his side. The funeral will be Sunday, Feb. 1, 11AM, at Brueggemann FH, 522 Larkfield Rd., East Northport. Contributions can be made to the Revlon Run/Walk for Women, PO Box 4059, Santa Monica, California 90411. Courageous, passionate, intelligent, adorable, we will miss every freckle on her face.

title: FORD PLANS LAYOFFS AT FACTORY NEAR ST. LOUIS
description: The Ford Motor Company plans to lay off about 1,000 workers at an assembly plant near St. Louis on April 26 as part of job cuts agreed to with its biggest union. The automaker is reducing production at the Hazelwood, Mo., plant to one shift from two, a spokesman, Ed Lewis, said. The factory has about 2,700 workers and produces the Ford Explorer and Mercury Mountaineer sport utility vehicles. Ford agreed in last year's national contract talks with the United Auto Workers to cut a shift at the Missouri factory rather than follow through on a 2002 plan to close the plant.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Profit Up At Yukos
description: Yukos Oil reported higher third-quarter earnings, and its results appeared to show that its bottom line has so far not been affected by the investigation of its former chief executive and largest shareholders. Yukos said it earned $1.32 billion in the quarter, up from $850 million a year earlier. Sales in the period, which ended Sept. 30, rose to $4.48 billion from $3.38 billion. Executives forecast a 10 percent increase in crude output for 2004. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Puma Doubles Profit
description: The sportswear and athletic equipment maker Puma said that its net profit more than doubled for the third consecutive year, beating expectations. The company, based in Herzogenaurach, Germany, posted a profit of 179 million euros ($222 million) in 2003. Pretax profit also more than doubled, reaching 264 million euros. Sales rose 40 percent, to 1.7 billion euros. The results came a day after its bigger competitor, Adidas-Salomon, posted a 14 percent increase in profit, to 260 million euros. Hurt by the weakness of the United States dollar, however, Adidas's sales fell 4 percent, to 6.3 billion euros. Victor Homola (NYT)
